赞扬Factor Man

Praise for Factor Man

“ 《人性本恶》为我们展现了一位时代英雄：一位拥有常识并致力于社会责任的科技天才。这是一部原创、巧妙的惊悚小说，它拓展了你的想象力，让你一直沉浸其中直到故事结束。”

“Factor Man gives us a hero for our times: a tech genius with common sense and a commitment to social responsibility. An original, smart thriller that stretches your imagination and keeps you engaged to the end.”

—艾米·罗杰斯 (AMY ROGERS)， 《石油瘟疫》作者

—AMY ROGERS, author of Petroplague

“本·斯蒂勒应该在电影里扮演我！”

“Ben Stiller should play me in the movie!”

—Robert Hasday，Duane Morris 律师事务所合伙人

—ROBERT HASDAY, Partner, Duane Morris LLP

“这本书非常精彩，它带我们踏上了一段旅程，书中的人物引人入胜，情节激动人心，英雄和反派都深思熟虑，这种类型的人物在同类书中非常罕见。我非常喜欢这本书。”

“A fantastic job of taking us on a ride featuring engaging characters, exciting action and deep-thinking heroes and villains of a type all too rare in the genre. I greatly enjoyed this book.”

—BART MASSEY，波特兰州立大学计算机科学副教授

—BART MASSEY, Associate Professor of Computer Science, Portland State University

“这本书真的很吸引人，因为书中的人物、情节曲折和幽默感。尽管我比书中的主人公更善良，但我仍然喜欢它。”

“A real page-turner, thanks to the characters, plot twists and humor. Even though I’m nicer than the guy in the book, I still loved it.”

—瑞士信贷前总裁布莱恩·芬恩

—BRIAN FINN, ex-president of Credit Suisse

“这是一部优雅而巧妙的惊悚小说，最好在关掉手机、保持大脑清醒的时候阅读。”

“A classy and clever thriller best read with your phone off and your brain on.”

——马克·布莱克比， 《你再也不会回到这里》作者

—MARK BLACKABY, author of You’ll Never Be Here Again

因子人

Factor Man

马特·金斯伯格

Matt Ginsberg

本小说纯属虚构。本小说中的人物、姓名、事件、对话和情节，以及本小说中出现的真实人物和公司名称，以及这些真实人物和公司的属性和行为，均为作者的想象或虚构。

This novel is a work of fiction. The characters, names, incidents, dialogue, and plot of this novel, and where the names of real persons and companies are used, the attributes and actions of such real persons and companies described in this novel, are the products of the author’s imagination or are used fictitiously.

FACTOR MAN。版权所有 ©2017 Matthew Ginsberg LLC。保留所有权利。

FACTOR MAN. Copyright ©2017 by Matthew Ginsberg LLC. All rights reserved.

第一版，2018 年

致我的妻子，计算机科学家

To my wife, the computer scientist

我的孩子们总是喜欢这样的故事

And to my kids, who always liked stories like this one

序幕

Prologue

伯克特

Burkett

2021 年 7 月 9 日

July 9, 2021

我自从在互联网上露面以来的四年里，这位被称为 Factor Man 的人只联系了五个人。尽管联系很少，但他（或她）现在已成为地球上最知名、最富有和最有权势的男人（或女人）之一。

In the four years since appearing on the Internet, the individual known as Factor Man has reached out to exactly five human beings. In spite of this minimal contact, he (or she) is now one of the best known, richest and most powerful men (or women) on the planet.

在这五个幸运儿中，除了一人以外，其他人现在都已经非常出名了。一人是纽约律师罗伯特·哈斯戴 (Robert Hasday)。Factor Man 的礼宾服务由社交组织者杰西·麦克默里 (Jess MacMurray) 提供，她以 Pepper Potts 的名字为世人所知。没有人知道与 Factor Man 合作过的黑客组织 Anonymous 成员的名字，但每个人都知道那位黑客做了什么。还有记者威廉·伯克特 (William Burkett)，他对这一切的感受非常复杂。

Of those lucky five, all but one are now ridiculously famous. There is the New York lawyer, Robert Hasday. Concierge services for Factor Man are provided by the social organizer Jess MacMurray, known to the world as Pepper Potts. No one knows the name of the member of the hacking group Anonymous who has worked with Factor Man, but everyone knows what that hacker did. And there is the reporter William Burkett, who has very mixed feelings about all of it.

第五个人就没那么出名了。他是一位名叫布莱恩·芬恩的银行家。五十多岁的瑞士信贷前总裁，现已退休。秃顶。尽管他竭尽全力保持苗条，但体重还是超标了。据我所知，他是个非常好的人。

The fifth person is not so famous. He’s a banker named Brian Finn. The fifty-something retired ex-president of Credit Suisse. Balding. Overweight in spite of his best efforts not to be. An extremely good guy, as far as I can tell.

大约六个月前，我和 Finn 一起喝咖啡认识。我不知道我是否被跟踪了。有时我被跟踪，有时没有。我现在真的不在乎了。

Finn and I met over coffee about six months ago. I have no idea if I was followed or not. Sometimes I’m followed, sometimes I’m not followed. I don’t really care either way any more.

Finn 给了我一个信封，然后我们谈到了 Finn 在 20 世纪 80 年代 RJR Nabisco 杠杆收购案中所扮演的角色。我写了一篇文章，将 20 世纪 80 年代的收购狂潮与今天的互联网泡沫进行了比较，但似乎没有人意识到我和 Finn 的会面与 20 世纪 80 年代完全无关。

Finn gave me an envelope, and then we talked about Finn’s role in the leveraged buyout of RJR Nabisco in the 1980’s. I wrote a story comparing the buyout frenzy of the 1980’s to the Internet bubble of today, and no one seemed to realize that my meeting with Finn wasn’t about the 1980’s at all.

一切都与信封有关。信封里记载着 Finn 与 Factor Man 的互动。Brian 告诉我，可以写下来，但前提是直到 FCOP 前一天，没有人知道他参与其中。这是 Factor Man 的指示，他说。我同意在 FCOP 前一周之前不看它。

It was all about the envelope. Inside was the story of Finn’s interaction with Factor Man. Brian told me it was okay to write about it, provided that no one learned of his involvement until the day before FCOP. Factor Man’s instructions, he said. I agreed to not even look at it until a week before FCOP.

Finn 不是 Factor Man。他没有背景。我认为 Finn 甚至不知道 Factor Man 是谁。不过，他可能知道。

Finn isn’t Factor Man. He doesn’t have the background. I don’t think Finn even knows who Factor Man is. He might, though.

但这并不重要。明天，我们都会知道。FCOP。发音为 Eff-COP。The Factor Man 出柜派对。而 Brian Finn 将成为一个有钱的混蛋。

But it doesn’t matter. Tomorrow, we’ll all know. FCOP. Pronounced Eff-COP. The Factor Man Coming Out Party. And Brian Finn is going to be one rich son of a bitch.

我叫威廉·伯克特，是一名记者。自称是我朋友的人都叫我威尔伯。我想，叫我奥维尔可能更糟糕。

My name is William Burkett, and I’m the reporter. People claiming to be my friends call me Wilbur. Orville would be worse, I suppose.

这是过去四年的故事。如果我们不是一起经历过，没有人会相信其中任何一个字。

This is the story of the last four years. And if we hadn’t all lived through it together, no one would believe a word of it.

1

1

因子人

Factor Man

2017 年 5 月 12 日

May 12, 2017

西埃纳·海森堡是一位物理学家，出生于十九世纪初二十世纪初。他对物理学做出了重大贡献，并因开创量子力学领域而获得 1932 年诺贝尔奖。他有一个以自己的名字命名的不确定性原理。他弄清楚了恒星是如何运转的。

Werner Heisenberg was a physicist born just as the nineteenth century ushered in the twentieth. He made such significant contributions to physics that he won the 1932 Nobel Prize for creating the field of quantum mechanics. He had an uncertainty principle named after him. He figured out how stars worked.

最后这一点一直让我感同身受。据说，在海森堡发现这一点后不久，一天晚上，一位朋友对他说，星星真漂亮。“它们很美，”据说海森堡回答道。“我是世界上唯一知道它们为什么看起来那么美的人。”

This last contribution has always struck a personal chord with me. Rumor has it that some time shortly after Heisenberg figured this out, a friend commented to him one evening how beautiful the stars were. “They are,” Heisenberg is said to have replied. “And I’m the only person in the world who knows why they look that way.”

我盯着电脑屏幕。我想，这就是我的海森堡​​时刻。

I stared at my computer screen. This was my Heisenberg moment, I figured.

我的电脑打开了两个窗口。其中一个窗口里的数字在慢慢流过。另一个窗口里有一封电子邮件等待发送。这 21 个单词可能会改变世界。我只需点击“发送”即可。

My computer had two windows open. In one, numbers streamed by slowly. In the other, an email waited to be sent. Twenty-one words that might change the world. All I had to do was click on send.

但这二十一个字一旦发出去，就再也回不来了。所以在点击发送之前，我考虑了一下。

But once those twenty-one words were out there, I could never get them back. So before clicking send, I thought about it.

我思考了一下科学。

I thought about the science.

我想起了丹妮丝，她在谷仓里和马匹一起工作。即使结婚多年，马匹也永远是她的初恋。如果这封电子邮件改变了我的生活，那么它也会改变她的生活。

I thought about Denise, down at the barn working with the horses. Even after many years of marriage, they would always be her first love. If the email changed my life, it would change hers with it.

我想到我们的孩子不再住在家里，开始在世界上为自己开辟道路。如果我发出这个信息，他们就会在一个与他们昨天探索的世界不同的世界里开辟自己的道路。

I thought about our kids, no longer living at home and beginning to make their own way in the world. If I sent the message, they would be making their ways in a different world than they had explored yesterday.

我思考着我的计划。我想知道我和我的家人是否安全。我想知道我是否真的能够至少避免我的技术可能带来的最严重的破坏。

I thought about my plan. I wondered if my family and I would be safe. I wondered if I would indeed manage to deflect at least the worst of the disruption to which my technology might lead.

我想到了海森堡。关于只有你知道的事情，你知道它会以你无法预测的方式改变世界。量子力学花了一代人的时间才发明了核武器，而科学花了更长时间才发明了一种新的、清洁的——尽管危险的——能源。我猜想，我的发现会产生同样巨大和不可预测的影响，但速度要快得多。

And I thought about Heisenberg. About knowing something that only you know, and that you know will change the world in ways you cannot predict. It took a generation for quantum mechanics to beget nuclear weapons, and longer still for the science to lead to a new and clean – albeit dangerous – energy source. My discovery, I suspected, would have as great and as unpredictable an impact, but far more quickly.

我想到了科学，以及科学的伦理。我们科学家只是做我们该做的事，并且以某种方式相信我们所发现的东西将更多地用于有益的事情。这种乐观主义是否合理一直不清楚，也没有人赋予我们道德权威，让我们将个人进步带给世界其他地方。但我们是科学家。我们做我们该做的事。

I thought about science, and the ethics of science. We scientists just do what we do, and somehow trust that the things we discover will be used more for good than otherwise. It’s never been clear that such optimism is justified, and no one ever gave us the moral authority to unleash our personal progress on the rest of the world. But we’re scientists. We do what we do.

我想到丹尼斯、孩子们以及未知的后果。

I thought about Denise, and the kids, and the unknown consequences.

我思考了一下这个计划。

I thought about the plan.

我想到海森堡。

I thought about Heisenberg.

我想到的是科学。

I thought about science.

我点击了发送。

I hit send.

伯克特

Burkett

2017 年 5 月 12 日

May 12, 2017

我当时正在放松，抽着烟，感觉很好。是的，是的，我知道。吸烟对身体不好。希望我能在它杀死我之前戒掉它。

I was relaxing, smoking a cigarette, and feeling pretty good about myself. Yeah, yeah, I know. Smoking is bad for you. Hopefully, I’ll manage to quit before it kills me.

不过，在这个特别的夜晚，我并不担心这件事。几个月前，我写了一篇对唐纳德·特朗普推文进行统计分析的文章，引起了极大的关注。那天下午，我听说这篇文章被选为年度突发新闻最佳数据使用奖的决赛入围者。

On this particular night, though, I wasn’t worrying about it. An article I had written a few months previously with a statistical analysis of Donald Trump’s tweets had gotten a ridiculous amount of traction. I’d heard that afternoon that it had been selected as a finalist for an annual prize regarding Best Use of Data in a Breaking News Story.

这就是我所做的事情。从 2016 年底到现在，我一直是《纽约时报》的记者。我的这份工作要归功于内特·西尔弗，他经营着一个名为 fivethirtyeight.com 的网站。538 根据统计数据提供新闻（有时也提供预测）。内特最初是一名从事体育统计的量化分析师，他运用同样的技术来预测谁会在各种政治竞选中获胜。例如，他正确地预测了巴拉克·奥巴马在 2008 年和 2012 年总统大选中获胜的每个州。从那时起，他基本上也预测对了所有事情，除了唐纳德·特朗普的事情。没人预料到这一点，尽管内特比大多数人更接近事实。

This is the kind of thing I do. From late 2016 until now, I’ve been a reporter for the New York Times. I owe my job to Nate Silver, who runs a website called fivethirtyeight.com. 538 presents news (and sometimes predictions) based on statistics. Nate started his life as a quantitative analyst doing sports statistics, and applied the same techniques to predict who would prevail in various political contests. For example, he called every state correctly in Barack Obama’s presidential victories in 2008 and 2012. He’s basically gotten everything right since then, too, except for the Donald Trump thing. No one saw that coming, although Nate was closer than most.

不管怎样，内特成名了，该网站在 2012 年大选期间归纽约时报所有，占据了 nytimes.com 流量的六分之一左右。当内特在 2016 年大选前转投 ESPN 时，纽约时报决定用自己的统计团队取代他。他们聘请了一群年轻的能人，我就是其中之一。

Anyway, Nate got famous and the website, which was owned by the New York Times during the 2012 election cycle, was responsible for something like a sixth of all the nytimes.com traffic. When Nate switched to ESPN before the 2016 election, the Times decided they needed to replace him with a statistics group of their own. They hired a bunch of young hotshots, and I was one of them.

2017 年 5 月的那个晚上，我 28 岁，刚刚获得德克萨斯大学奥斯汀分校统计经济学博士学位。我热爱我的工作，我的工作就是利用统计数据来计算一些很酷的东西。预测谁将赢得世界象棋锦标赛。（是的，人类仍然会下象棋。）分析唐纳德·特朗普推文中的文字，并表明它们更像另类右翼的言论，而不是任何形式的理性话语。《纽约时报》在写作方面给了我很大的自由度，允许我复制 Nate 在 538.com 使用的非正式风格。对于一家主要新闻媒体来说，这很不寻常，但我完全没问题。

On that night in May of 2017, I was twenty-eight years old, with a new Ph.D. in statistical economics from the University of Texas at Austin. I loved my job, which was to use statistics to figure out cool stuff. Predict who was going to win the world chess championship. (Yes, humans still played chess.) Analyze the words in Donald Trump’s tweets and show that they bore more resemblance to the rhetoric of the alt-right than to any form of rational discourse. The Times gave me a great deal of slack on the writing side, allowing me to duplicate the informal style that Nate used at 538.com. Unusual for a major news outlet, but totally fine with me.

我住在布鲁克林，住在一套两居室的公寓里，那是三楼的无电梯公寓。我不必告诉你这些；我现在还住在那里，你在电视和互联网上也看到过那套公寓。记者也许是世界上最好的工作，但薪水却不高。也许我会在 FCOP（Factor Man Coming Party）结束后，试着为自己争取一份更好的待遇。不过，在那之前，我有足够多的事情要担心。

I lived in Brooklyn, in a two-bedroom apartment that’s a third floor walkup. I don’t have to tell you this; I still live there and you’ve seen the apartment on TV and the Internet. Reporting may be the best job in the world, but the pay is only modest. Maybe I’ll try to negotiate a better deal for myself after FCOP – the Factor Man Coming Out Party – is over. Until then, though, I’ve got enough to worry about.

如今，我很怀念自己的隐私。四年前五月的一个周五晚上，我抽着烟，放松着，那时我甚至还没有维基百科页面。我刚刚开始在《纽约时报》工作。只有一群小圈子里的人知道我是谁，仅此而已。

Nowadays, I miss my privacy. Smoking that cigarette and relaxing on a Friday night in May four years ago, I didn’t even have a Wikipedia page. I was just getting started at the Times. A bunch of folks in ridiculously small circles knew who I was, and that was about it.

对我来说，这一切都很好。小时候，我的英雄是蝙蝠侠和罗宾，他们很酷，可以出现在漫画书中，而且很有个性。到了 2017 年，我开始崇拜揭露水门事件的记者卡尔·伯恩斯坦和鲍勃·伍德沃德。报道可以是一项相当崇高的事业，我对真相的兴趣远远超过了我对名利的兴趣。我甚至不清楚我对名利有什么真正的兴趣。

That was all just fine with me. As a kid, my heroes had been Batman and Robin, folks cool enough to appear in comic books and with attitude to boot. By 2017, I looked up to Carl Bernstein and Bob Woodward, the reporters who broke the Watergate story. Reporting can be quite a noble enterprise, and my interest in the truth dwarfed my interest in fame or fortune. It wasn’t even clear to me that I had any real interest in fame or fortune.

我记得当时正在下雨。纽约市初夏的一场雷雨，大约在午夜时分。我掐灭了香烟，去查看电子邮件。六条消息。

I remember it was raining. An early summer thunderstorm in New York City, around midnight. I stubbed out my cigarette and went to check my email. Six messages.

发件人：tdalton@nytimes.com

From: tdalton@nytimes.com

你没有赢，但干得好

you didn't win but great job

来自：KBURKETTJR@aol.com

From: KBURKETTJR@aol.com

妈妈玩得很开心

Mom had a great time

来自：factorman0@gmail.com

From: factorman0@gmail.com

回报恩惠

returned favor

来自：trindell@wisconsin.edu

From: trindell@wisconsin.edu

重新计算这些数字

rerunning those numbers

来自：kate@bedandbreakfast.com

From: kate@bedandbreakfast.com

年度最佳优惠

best deals of the year

发件人：emmabhardaway@gmail.com

From: emmabhardaway@gmail.com

无法参加-抱歉！

can't make it - sorry!

当然，你马上就看出来。但我只看到那是星期五晚上，而艾玛刚刚在星期六放了我假。好吧，有时生活就是这样。

You see it right away, of course. But all I saw was that it was Friday night, and Emma had just blown me off for Saturday. Well, sometimes life is like that.

于是我就去睡觉了。

So I went to bed.

* * *

* * *

周六早上，我会打篮球。我打得很糟糕，但其他人也一样。我们八点见面，因为那时我们可以去健身房，打到十点左右，然后喝咖啡。

Saturday mornings, I play basketball. I pretty much suck, but so do all the other guys. We meet at eight because that’s when we can get the gym, play until around ten, and then have coffee.

八点钟很早，但咖啡可以喝上几个小时。我告诉你这一切只是为了让你明白为什么当我回到电子邮件时已经是星期六下午一点多了。

Eight o’clock is pretty early, but coffee can go on for hours. I tell you all of this only so that you understand why it was a little after one on Saturday afternoon when I got back to my email.

因子人最终接触了我们五个人，其中四个人后来被公众所知。芬恩是幸运的。他们称我们其余的人为“四大天王”，尽管我不清楚生活在这种荒谬的显微镜下有多好。不管怎样，我是第一个被偏爱的人。

Factor Man would eventually reach out to five of us, of whom four would become known to the public. Finn was the lucky one. The Favored Four, they call the rest of us, although it’s not clear to me how favorable it is to live under this ridiculous microscope. For better or worse, I was the favored first.

来自：factorman0@gmail.com

From: factorman0@gmail.com

收件人：wburkett@nytimes.com

To: wburkett@nytimes.com

主题：回报恩惠

Subject: returned favor

伯克特先生：

Mr. Burkett:

你曾经对我好过，所以我要回报你。

You did me a kindness once, and I'm returning it.

factorman0.blogspot.com

factorman0.blogspot.com

四十八小时内，这个故事只属于你。

The story is yours, and yours alone, for forty-eight hours.

调频

FM

我看了看信息发送的时间，已经过去了十四个小时。

I checked the time at which the message had been sent. Fourteen of those hours were already gone.

接下来，我做了你会做的事情。事实上，我做的几乎每个人都已经做过了。我访问了 Factor Man 网站。

Next, I did what you would have done. In fact, I did what pretty much everyone has already done. I visited the Factor Man web site.

我有一种快速分解大数的方法。但这是个问题，因为它会破坏公钥加密。如果我能破解它，其他人最终也会知道。简单地保密并不可行。

I have a fast method for factoring large numbers. This is a problem, because it breaks public key encryption. And if I figured it out, so will someone else eventually. It’s not really viable to simply keep it secret.

更糟糕的是，或者说更好的是，该方法通过将数值分解问题转换为布尔可满足性，然后调用看似多项式时间 SAT 求解器来发挥作用。

To make matters worse, or perhaps better, the method works by converting number factoring problems to Boolean satisfiability and then invoking what appears to be a polytime SAT solver on them.

从某种程度上来说，这是件好事。从长远来看，多项式时间 SAT 求解器是唯一的希望。我们将治愈更多疾病，变得更健康。我们将更加高效，能够更好地为最需要的人提供资源。我们将更有能力应对一系列问题，其中最重要的就是全球变暖。

At some level, this is good. A polytime SAT solver is, in the long term, only promise. We will cure more diseases, and be healthier. We will be more efficient, and better able to get resources to those of us who need them the most. We will be more able to cope with a huge range of problems, not the least of which is global warming.

然而，从短期来看，多项式时间 SAT 解算器只会带来危险。将不再有牢不可破的密码。而在一个越来越依赖密码的世界里，这意味着将不再有秘密。

In the short term, however, a polytime SAT solver is only peril. There will be no more unbreakable codes. And in a world that has become increasingly dependent on them, that means there will be no more secrets.

我希望通过这篇博文来解决这个问题，帮助我们共同实现承诺，同时避免至少一些危险。为此，我将着手实施一个涉及两个不同阶段的计划。

My hope in this blog is to deal with this issue, to help us collectively achieve the promise while avoiding at least some of the peril. To that end, I will be embarking on a program that involves two separate phases.

第一是示范。我需要向世界证明我确实能做到我所说的。

The first is demonstration. I need to show the world that I can indeed do what I say I can do.

第二是分发。我需要让每个人都能使用这项技术。

The second is distribution. I need to make the technology available to everyone.

在第一阶段，我将公开对大数进行因式分解。具体方法如下。如果您想要对某个数字进行因式分解，请将该数字通过电子邮件发送至 factorman0@gmail.com。我将每天选择五个数字，并在此博客 (factorman0.blogspot.com) 中回复因式分解结果。

For the first phase, I will simply factor large numbers in public. The way this works is as follows. If you want a number factored, send that number in an email to factorman0@gmail.com. I will select five numbers each day and respond in this blog (factorman0.blogspot.com) with the factorizations.

但也有一些规则。

But there are some rules.

1. 数字必须为我指定的大小。目前，数字的大小必须全部为最多 5 位。这几乎不是什么挑战！但每三天，我就会允许数字大一位数。

1. The numbers must be of a size I specify. Currently the numbers must all be at most 5 bits in size. Hardly a challenge! But every three days, I will permit the numbers to be one bit larger.

2. 当您请求将号码进行分解时，您必须提供您本人的合法身份信息。每人每天只能提交一个号码。

2. When you request that a number be factored, you must include legitimate identifying information for yourself. Only one number per person per day, please.

3. 所有要分解因式的数都必须是两个质数的乘积。

3. All of the numbers to be factored must be the product of two primes.

我希望随着时间的推移，知名的公众人物会要求考虑越来越多的数字，让人们明白我确实可以做到我所说的一切。

My hope here is that as time passes, recognizable public figures will ask for ever larger numbers to be factored, allowing folks to understand that I can indeed do what I say I can do.

我将于 2017 年 11 月 11 日对 64 位数字进行分解。

I will be factoring 64-bit numbers on November 11, 2017.

我将于 2018 年 5 月 22 日对 128 位数字进行分解。

I will be factoring 128-bit numbers on May 22, 2018.

我将于 2019 年 6 月 10 日对 255 位数字进行分解。

I will be factoring 255-bit numbers on June 10, 2019.

到 2019 年，我预计任何依赖公钥加密的人都会找到另一种保护数据的方法。我鼓励依赖公钥加密的人尽快切换到至少 256 位编码方案。我不会在公共场合分解 256 位数字。

By 2019, I expect that anyone relying on public key encryption will have found another way to protect their data. I encourage people relying on public key encryption to switch to at least a 256-bit encoding scheme as rapidly as possible. I will not factor 256-bit numbers in public.

演示阶段完成后，我将继续进行分发。其工作方式如下：

After the demonstration phase is complete, I will move forward with distribution. This will work as follows:

2019 年 6 月 10 日，我将开始接受使用该技术的许可的竞标。该许可将是永久性的，并且独占一年。目标与美国政府或公民的目标相冲突的实体的竞标将不被接受。

On June 10, 2019, I will begin accepting bids for a license to use the technology. The license will be perpetual and will be exclusive for one year. Bids will not be accepted from entities whose goals conflict with the goals of the government or citizens of the United States of America.

2019年7月10日，我将向最高出价者提供该技术，并公布该出价者的身份。

On July 10, 2019, I will provide the technology to the highest bidder and announce that bidder’s identity.

2020年7月10日，我将这项技术提供给美国政府。

On July 10, 2020, I will provide the technology to the government of the United States.

2021 年 7 月 10 日，我将公开这项技术，并透露我的身份。

On July 10, 2021, I will make the technology publicly available and will reveal my identity as well.

我打算对任何试图干扰这一总体计划的行为采取相对严厉的措施，例如，试图关闭此博客或我的电子邮件地址，或试图在我选择透露身份之前发现我的身份。我提醒任何考虑做这些事情的人，互联网上的任何角落都在我的掌控范围之内。

It is my intention to deal relatively harshly with any attempts to interfere with this overall plan by, for example, attempting to bring down this blog or my email address, or attempting to discover my identity before I choose to reveal it. I remind anyone considering doing these things that no corner of the Internet is beyond my reach.

如果您想要分解一个 5 位数，请给我发送一封电子邮件，其中包含所需数字和您的真实身份。

If you would like a 5-bit number factored, please send me an email with both the number in question and your true identity.

直到 2021 年 7 月 10 日，我都会简单地套用不朽的托尼·斯塔克的话：我是因素人 (Factor Man)。

And until July 10, 2021, I will simply paraphrase the immortal Tony Stark: I am Factor Man.

现在著名的计数器位于底部，显示该页面的访问次数。众所周知，该计数器现在显示Factor Man 网页的访问量超过 3500亿次。那天早上我查看它时，它显示“1”。

The now-famous counter was at the bottom, showing the number of visits the page had received. That counter, as is well known, now shows something in excess of 350 billion visits to the Factor Man web page. When I looked at it that morning, it said, “1”.

当然，那时候我并不清楚这些东西到底是什么意思。但我有一个朋友知道。

Back then, of course, I didn’t really know what most of that stuff meant. But I had a friend who did.

* * *

* * *

每年三月，我都会参加美国填字游戏锦标赛（参赛者称之为 ACPT）。

Every year in March, I go to the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament, or the ACPT as the participants call it.

这可能让你觉得这是比死亡更糟糕的命运。但事实并非如此。信不信由你，这很有趣。

This may strike you as a fate worse than death. But it isn’t. Believe it or not, it’s fun.

比赛由《纽约时报》的填字游戏编辑威尔·肖茨 (Will Shortz) 负责组织。比赛在康涅狄格州斯坦福举行，约有 600 名美国最优秀的填字游戏选手参加。2005 年的比赛是一部名为Wordplay的纪录片的主题。

The tournament is run by Will Shortz, the crossword editor for the Times. Held in Stamford, Connecticut, it’s attended by about six hundred of the best crossword solvers in America. The 2005 tournament was the subject of a documentary called Wordplay.

这项活动有几个有趣的方面。首先，它很刺激。在解决了所有 600 名参赛者共同完成的 7 个谜题后，前三名选手将登上舞台，在其他人的注视下解决最后一个残酷的谜题。谁先完成谜题谁就赢了，前提是他们没有犯错。决赛选手（戴着耳机，背对着观众，这样他们就听不到身后喧闹的评论）举手宣布他们已经完成。

The event is fun in a couple of ways. First, it’s exciting. After solving seven puzzles shared by all six hundred contestants, the top three finishers get up on stage and solve one last, brutal puzzle while everyone else watches. Whoever finishes that puzzle first wins, assuming they don’t make a mistake. The finalists (wearing headphones and with their backs to the audience so that they can’t hear the raucous commentary going on behind them) announce that they’re finished by raising their hands.

2015 年，丹·费耶尔（Dan Feyer）赢得了前五场比赛，获得了冠军。但他没有举手，而是决定检查自己的成绩。他右边的下一位选手泰勒·辛曼（Tyler Hinman）在费耶尔开始获胜之前的五年里一直获胜。在费耶尔获胜的五年里，辛曼通常排在第二位。

In 2015 Dan Feyer, who had won the previous five contests, finished first. But rather than raise his hand, he decided to check his work. The next contestant to his right, Tyler Hinman, had won for the five years before Feyer started winning. In the five years Feyer had won, Hinman had generally been second.

欣曼拼命地拼。欣曼知道费耶尔拼得很快，所以他决定在拼图完成后就举手。

Hinman was working frantically to finish. Knowing that Feyer was fast, Hinman had decided to raise his hand the moment his puzzle was done.

费耶尔在检查。欣曼在写字。费耶尔的拼图是完美的，但他自己不知道。欣曼的拼图到目前为止也是完美的。

Feyer was checking. Hinman was writing. Feyer’s puzzle was perfect, but he didn’t know it. Hinman’s was also perfect thus far.

终于，其中一个人举起了手。

Finally, one of them raised his hand.

半秒钟后，辛曼举起了手，观众爆发出热烈的欢呼声。费耶尔的连胜纪录仍在继续，不过第二年被霍华德·巴金打破。

Hinman’s hand went up half a second later, and the audience exploded. Feyer’s streak continued, although it would be broken by Howard Barkin the next year.

不过，我期待 ACPT 的真正原因是观众。我为《纽约时报》报道的部分内容是高水平智力运动赛事。世界上最好的象棋选手、桥牌选手或其他选手，通常都不是很有趣。他们的自我形象太专注于他们擅长的游戏了。

The real reason I look forward to the ACPT, though, is the people. Part of what I cover for the Times is high-level mental sporting events. The world’s best chess players, or bridge players, or what have you, are generally not a lot of fun to be around. Their self-images are too wrapped up in the games at which they excel.

但填字游戏解谜者却有所不同。他们都有日常工作。（ACPT 大奖只有 5000 美元，所以他们不得不工作。）费耶尔是一名音乐家；欣曼是一名计算机程序员。参赛者包括律师、作家、像我这样的记者，以及好莱坞导演，比如执导Wordplay的帕特里克·克里登。这是一个令人惊叹的兼收并蓄的群体。

But crossword solvers are somehow different. They all have day jobs. (The ACPT grand prize is only $5000, so they have to.) Feyer is a musician; Hinman is a computer programmer. The contestants include lawyers, authors, reporters like me, and Hollywood directors like Patrick Creadon, who directed Wordplay. It’s an amazingly eclectic group.

每个人都来这里是为了找乐子。由于自我形象基本不复存在，每个人都希望其他人也能取得好成绩。每个人都希望其他人的成绩比去年有所提高。唯一一个常年出现的反派是“菲尔博士”，一个填字游戏计算机程序。菲尔博士在比赛举办地舞厅后面解答谜题。每解完一个谜题，肖茨就会宣布菲尔博士的成绩；程序做得越差，掌声就越响亮。

And everyone is there to have fun. With the self-images mostly out of it, everyone wants everyone else to do well. Everyone wants everyone else to improve on their scores from the previous year. The only perennial villain is “Dr.Fill”, a crossword-solving computer program. Dr.Fill solves the puzzles in the back of the ballroom where the contest is held. When each puzzle is done, Shortz announces how Dr.Fill did on it; the worse the program did, the louder the applause.

我在 2017 年的比赛中遇到了 Emma Hardaway。我当时是一名记者，而她是纽约市一家文学机构的手稿审查员。我们只是同一场活动中的一对文字书呆子。在比赛开始前一晚的葡萄酒和奶酪派对上，我们在闲聊Trivial Pursuit游戏时互相介绍了自己。

I met Emma Hardaway at the 2017 tournament. I was a reporter, and she was a manuscript screener for a literary agency in New York City. Just a couple of word nerds at the same event. We introduced ourselves to each other while kibitzing a Trivial Pursuit game during the wine and cheese party that takes place the night before the tournament begins.

艾玛活泼迷人。身材高挑、魅力十足、谈吐优雅、聪明伶俐，但她眼中却闪烁着邪恶的光芒，警告人们不要将她视为理所当然。这种互动会让你事后希望交换联系方式。好吧，明年的锦标赛总是有的。

Emma was effervescent and charming. Tall, attractive, well-spoken and smart, but with a wicked glint in her eye that warned against taking her for granted. One of those interactions where you wish afterward you’d exchanged contact information. Well, there was always the next year’s tournament.

但实际上，我不需要等那么久。我在 SoHo 的一家小咖啡馆里遇到了艾玛，这是纽约那些不可能发生的巧合之一，让这座城市的生活变得值得。这一次，我收到了一个电子邮件地址，我以为是一份几周后见面共进晚餐的临时协议。但我的电子邮件说这是不可能的。

In reality, though, I didn’t need to wait that long. I bumped into Emma in a little coffee shop in SoHo, one of those impossible New York coincidences that make life in the city worth living. This time, I got an email address and – I thought – a tentative agreement to meet for dinner a few weeks later. But my email had said it was not to be.

* * *

* * *

在 2017 年 ACPT 上遇见 Emma 的几年前，我在 2015 年的比赛中遇见了 Montgomery Grimes。他编写了处理锦标赛计分的软件，尽管谜题本身是由人类评委评分的。（这些评委在周末期间总共检查了大约一百万个填满的方格。）更有趣的是，Grimes 是恶棍 Dr.Fill 的作者，他始终称其为“它”而不是“他”。Dr.Fill 在 2015 年的比赛中名列第 55 名。Grimes 就该程序的工作原理发表了一场有趣的演讲，我将其收录在了为《纽约时报》撰写的有关该赛事本身的文章中。

A couple of years before I met Emma at the 2017 ACPT, I met Montgomery Grimes at the 2015 event. He wrote the software that handles the scoring for the tournament, although the puzzles themselves are graded by human judges. (Those judges collectively examine about a million filled-in squares over the course of the weekend.) More interestingly, Grimes is the author of the villainous Dr.Fill, which he steadfastly refers to as “it” instead of “he”. Dr.Fill finished 55th in 2015. Grimes gave an entertaining talk about how the program worked, and I included it in the article I wrote for the Times about the event itself.

不从事 Dr.Fill 工作时，格莱姆斯坚决否认自己已经 60 岁出头。除了经营三家初创公司（马克·库班是其中两家的投资者）之外，多年来，他和我通过电子邮件交流过他的各种疯狂计划——找不到更好的词来形容。他认为他可以使用几台高清摄像机和计算机来确定篮球比赛中篮板球的去向——即使投篮还在空中。格莱姆斯认为他可以解释鸟类的群集现象，认为这是一种使进化更有效的机制。他给孩子们讲了一个关于约翰·吉兹莫的故事，这个家伙用一些小玩意儿帮他们摆脱各种麻烦，比如猫咪运输机，它的大小和形状与手电筒一样，但可以容纳数百万只猫；开始结束，它可以在一小片区域内将时间倒流，将最顽固的罪犯变成哭泣的婴儿；还有 gezuntifier ，它可以使任何打喷嚏的人失去行动能力。我认为蒙蒂是一个聪明人，可以告诉我发生了什么事。

When not working on Dr.Fill, Grimes is in steadfast denial of the fact that he’s in his early sixties. In addition to running three startups (Mark Cuban is an investor in two of them), he and I have exchanged email over the years about a variety of his – for lack of a better phrase – mad schemes. He thinks he can use a couple of high-definition cameras and computers to figure out which way a rebound is going in basketball – while the shot is still in the air. Grimes believes he can explain birds’ flocking as a mechanism to make evolution more efficient. He raised his kids on a diet of stories about a guy named John Gizmo, who bails them out of all manner of trouble with gadgets like the cat transporter, which is the size and shape of a flashlight but can hold millions of cats, the beginning end, which turns back time in a small area, converting the most hardened criminal into a crying infant, and the gezuntifier, which disables anyone who sneezes. I figured Monty was a smart guy and could tell me what was up.

发件人：William Burkett (wburkett@nytimes.com)

From: William Burkett (wburkett@nytimes.com)

收件人：Montgomery Grimes (montgomerygrimes@gmail.com)

To: Montgomery Grimes (montgomerygrimes@gmail.com)

主題: 看一下嗎？

Subject: take a look?

嘿蒙蒂：

Hey Monty:

你能看看 factorman0.blogspot.com 并告诉我你的想法吗？

Can you take a look at factorman0.blogspot.com and tell me what you think?

谢谢

Thx

威廉

William

格莱姆斯是个怪人。当你给他发电子邮件时，他通常会在五分钟内回复。无论什么时候。我不明白他是怎么做到的。我不知道他的妻子是否明白。

Grimes is a weird duck. When you send him an email, he generally responds within five minutes. Doesn’t matter what time it is. I don’t understand how he does it. I wonder if his wife does.

发件人：蒙哥马利·格莱姆斯（montgomerygrimes@gmail.com）

From: Montgomery Grimes (montgomerygrimes@gmail.com)

收件人：William Burkett （wburkett@nytimes.com）

To: William Burkett (wburkett@nytimes.com)

回复：看一下？

Re: take a look?

哇哦。这家伙真聪明。

Whoa. This guy is really smart.

我们的电子邮件对话仍在继续。

Our email dialog continued.

伯克特：您想更具体一点吗？

Burkett: You feel like being a bit more specific?

格莱姆斯：这是真的吗？

Grimes: Is this real?

伯克特：我希望你能告诉我。这是什么意思？

Burkett: I was hoping you could tell me. What does it mean?

格莱姆斯：电子邮件太麻烦了。电话呢？

Grimes: Too much for email. Telephone?

伯克特：当然可以。给我一些，我会给你打电话。

Burkett: Sure. Give me a few; I’ll call you.

当 Grimes 说电话时，他指的是电话。不是 Skype，也不是 FaceTime。我不知道这是因为他太老派了，还是因为他住在乡下，网络连接很差。可能两者都有。

When Grimes says telephone, he means telephone. Not Skype, not FaceTime. I don’t know if this is because he’s ridiculously old school, or because he lives out in the sticks and his Internet connection is terrible. Could be either one.

电话铃响第二声时他接了起来。“嘿。”

He picked up on the second ring. “Hey.”

“那么我在这里看到的是什么？”我问道。他向我解释了，或者至少尝试解释。

“So what am I looking at here?” I asked. He explained it to me, or at least attempted to.

“好的，”他开始说道。“很多问题都涉及计算机科学家所说的‘搜索’。那不是像谷歌那样的搜索；而是像大海捞针一样的搜索。”

“Okay,” he began. “Lots of problems involve what computer scientists call ‘search’. That’s not search like Google; it’s search like looking for a needle in a haystack.”

我嘟囔了几句鼓励的话，他便继续说道。

I mumbled something generally encouraging, and he continued.

“想象一下，你想在周五晚上去看电影。现在是 8:17，电影 8:35 开始，而你又非常讨厌迟到。你能在 18 分钟内到达电影院吗？”

“Imagine you’re trying to go to a movie on a Friday night. It’s 8:17, the movie starts at 8:35, and you’re the kind of person who really hates being late for a movie. Can you get to the theater in eighteen minutes?”

“当然可以，”我告诉他。“电影院离我家只有五分钟的路程。”

“Sure,” I told him. “The movie is only five minutes away from my apartment.”

蒙蒂不理我。“解决问题的一个方法是考虑你可能走的每一条路。你从车道出发，可以向右或向左走。假设你向右走。三十秒后，你来到街区的尽头；现在你可以直行、向右或向左走。你也可以转身，但这显然很蠢。假设你再次向右转。再过三十秒，你就会到达另一个十字路口。更多的选择。”不管有没有打电话，我都能看到他一边走来走去，一边挥舞着双手，开始讨论这个话题。

Monty ignored me. “One way to figure it out is to consider every possible path you might take. You head out of your driveway, and can go either right or left. Let’s say you go right. Thirty seconds later, you come to the end of your block; now you can go straight, right, or left. You can also turn around, but that’s clearly dumb. Let’s say you turn right again. After thirty more seconds, you get to another intersection. More choices.” Telephone or not, I could see him, walking around and waving his hands as he got into the topic.

“事实上，有很多选择。假设你在十八分钟内可以到达大约三十个路口，每个路口有三种可能性。所以第一个路口有三个选择，每个选择在下一个路口有三个后继。一共有九种可能性。这九种选择又有三个后继；你就有二十七种了。当你处理完所有三十种选择时，你将考虑大约……”他停顿了五秒钟，想了想。“200万亿种可能性。当你考虑完所有可能性时，电影不仅开始了，而且也结束了。电影结束了，续集也结束了——如果你每秒考虑一百万种可能性，那么大约需要七年的时间才能全部检查完。”

“In fact, there are a lot of choices. Say you can get to about thirty intersections in the eighteen minutes available, and there are three possibilities at each intersection. So there are three choices at the first intersection, and each of those has three successors at the next intersection. That’s nine possibilities. And each of those nine has three successors; you’re up to twenty-seven. By the time you deal with all thirty choices, you’ll have considered about…” He paused for maybe five seconds while he figured it out. “200 trillion possibilities. By the time you think about them all, the movie will not only have started, it’ll be over. It’ll be over and so will the sequel – if you consider a million possibilities a second, it would take about seven years to check them all.”

我告诉他，如果我这么着急，我只需打开谷歌地图，让我的手机找出位置即可。毕竟，人们往往都会准时去看电影。

I told him that if I was in such a hurry, I would just pull up Google maps and let my phone figure it out. People did, after all, tend to make it to movies on time.

“但即使是谷歌地图也无法替你考虑 200 万亿种可能性。那么他们是如何做到的呢？他们有没有办法绝对肯定地告诉你，他们给你的是一条最有效的路线？”

“But even Google maps can’t look at 200 trillion possibilities on your behalf. So how do they do it? Is there any way for them to tell, with absolute certainty, that they’re giving you the most efficient route?”

“大概吧。这就是他们开发这个应用程序的原因。”

“Presumably. That’s why they have the app.”

“但是这个应用程序是如何工作的呢？”他又停顿了一下，无疑是在等我做出进一步的解释。

“But how does the app work?” He paused again, doubtless waiting for me to add an explanation.

我让他失望了。

I disappointed him.

“诀窍就在这里，”他告诉我，“你不用按所需时间来标记每条可能的路径，而是用到达那里所需的时间来标记每个路口。从你家旁边的路口开始；这很容易。而且由于你总是能知道从一个路口到另一个路口需要多长时间，你可以逐渐标记越来越远的路口，直到你知道到达电影院需要多长时间。

瞧！以这种方式组织计算，它需要大约 900 步，而不是数万亿。”

“Here’s the trick,” he told me. “Instead of labeling each possible path by the amount of time it takes, you label each intersection by the amount of time it takes to get there. You start with the intersections next to your house; they’re easy. And since you can always tell how long it takes to get from one intersection to another, you can gradually label intersections further and further out until you know how long it takes to get to the movie theater.

Voilà! Organizing the calculation this way, it takes about 900 steps instead of trillions.”

“好的。我想我跟上了。这样我的手机就能告诉我什么时候到达。”

“Okay. I think I’m following. That’s how my phone can tell me when I’ll arrive.”

“没错，”蒙蒂回答道。“但现在我们来考虑一个不同的问题。有一年夏天，”他说，“你决定和家人一起来一次长途旅行。计划是游览美国大陆的每个州首府，从你家开始，再到你家结束。但你必须在三个月内完成，因为那时你的孩子们需要回学校了。”

“Exactly,” Monty answered. “But now let’s think about a different problem. One summer,” he said, “you decide to go on a giant road trip with your family. The plan is to visit every state capital in the continental United States, starting and finishing at your house. But you have to do it in three months, because that’s when your kids need to be back in school.”

我告诉蒙蒂我没有孩子。

I told Monty I didn’t have any kids.

“假装，”他回答。

“Pretend,” he answered.

我佯装。

I pretended.

“不行，”我最后说道。“这是一次愚蠢的旅行，没有一个有理智的人会花三个月的时间带着孩子待在车里。”

“Can’t do it,” I finally said. “It’s a stupid trip and no one in their right mind would spend three months with their kids in the car.”

“暂时不要怀疑。”

“Suspend your disbelief.”

我犹豫了。我告诉他我不知道这是否有可能。

I suspended. I told him I had no idea if it was possible or not.

格莱姆斯停顿了一下，毫无疑问是在等我说些比“我不知道”更有见地的话。我再次让他失望了。

Grimes paused, no doubt waiting for me to say something more insightful than, “I have no idea.” I disappointed him again.

“好吧，”他最终继续说道。“我们一起考虑一下。假设我们决定从奥尔巴尼开始。我们知道我们可以很容易地算出从你家开车到奥尔巴尼需要多长时间。”

“Fine,” he eventually continued. “Let’s think about this together. Suppose we decide to start with Albany. We know we can figure out pretty easily how long it will take you to drive to Albany from your house.”

“公寓，”我纠正他。

“Apartment,” I corrected him.

“随便。公寓。然后如果下一个目的地是特伦顿，我们可以算出从奥尔巴尼开车到特伦顿需要多长时间。所以一旦你决定了参观城市的顺序，就不难算出按照这个顺序的旅行是否可以在三个月内完成。和我一起吗？”

“Whatever. Apartment. And then if Trenton is next, we can figure out how long it will take to drive from Albany to Trenton. So once you decide in what order you’re going to visit the cities, it’s not too hard to figure out if a trip that uses that order can be completed in three months. With me?”

考虑到我们之前讨论过开车去看电影要花多长时间，这很有道理。是的，我说。我和他一起去。他继续说。

Given our earlier discussion about how long it would take to drive to the movie, this made sense. Yes, I said. I was with him. He continued.

“问题是，可能出现的顺序太多了。事实上，有超过 12 个 novemdecillion 种方式可以做到这一点，其中 novemdecillion 是一个你不常听到并且可能不想听到的词。它的意思是 1 后面跟着 60 个零。”

“The problem is that there are a lot of possible orders. In fact, there are over 12 novemdecillion ways to do it, where novemdecillion is a word you don’t hear terribly often and probably don’t want to. It means 1 followed by sixty zeroes.”

“所以，不管怎样，可能性都很多，”我告诉他。

“So twelve novemwhatever possibilities are a lot,” I told him.

“11亿亿。太多了。在任何合理的时间内都无法考虑这么多，”他总结道。

“Novemdecillion. More than a lot. It’s too many to consider in any reasonable amount of time,” he concluded.

“我明白，”我回答道。“但是我们不能想出一些新的巧妙方法让我们更快地解决这个问题吗？家庭度假问题似乎与准时看电影的问题没什么不同。”

“I can see that,” I answered. “But couldn’t we just figure out some new clever trick that lets us solve this faster? The family-vacation problem doesn’t seem that different from the get-me-to-the-movie-on-time problem.”

“它们是不同的，”蒙蒂告诉我。“我们以前用过的技巧，即标记交叉路口而不是道路，在这里不起作用。城市秩序似乎是我们正在考虑的基本事项。”

“They are different,” Monty told me. “The trick we used before, labeling intersections instead of paths, doesn’t work here. The city orderings seem like the basic things that we’re considering.”

“好的，”我说道，鼓励他继续。

“Okay,” I said, encouraging him to continue.

“事实证明，没有人知道家庭度假问题能否在合理的时间内得到解决，”格莱姆斯告诉我。“它实际上被计算机科学家称为‘旅行推销员’问题，因为它始于试图弄清楚旅行推销员需要多长时间才能拜访所有客户。电影准时放映问题被称为‘最短路径’问题。”

“It turns out that no one knows if the family vacation problem can be solved in a reasonable amount of time or not,” Grimes told me. “It’s actually called the ‘traveling salesman’ problem by computer scientists, since it started by trying to figure out how long a traveling salesman would need to visit all his customers. The movie-on-time problem is called the ‘shortest path’ problem.”

他继续说道：“好好想想。”

He kept going. “And think about it.”

“停下来，”我说。

“Stop,” I said.

他停了下来。

He stopped.

我的意思是，他停了下来。电话线那头一片寂静。最后，他问：“什么？”

I mean, he just stopped. Silence on the other end of the phone line. Finally, he asked, “What?”

我告诉蒙蒂我的脑子已经满了。

I told Monty my brain was full.

“我只是总结一下，”他回答道。“如果你想知道去看电影需要多长时间，你的手机可以告诉你。但是如果你要出去办事，回家之前有 15 个地方要去，你该按什么顺序去办？没有应用程序可以解决这个问题。这就是旅行商问题。最短路径问题在某种程度上很容易，而旅行商问题在某种程度上很难。这就是谷歌地图存在而事件排序应用程序不存在的真正原因。”

“I’m just summing up,” he answered. “If you want to know how long it will take to get to the movie, your phone can tell you. But what if you have to run errands, and you have fifteen places to visit before coming home. What order should you run them in? There’s no app for that. That’s the traveling salesman problem. The shortest path problem is somehow easy, and the traveling salesman problem is somehow hard. That’s the real reason that Google maps exists but the event sequencing app doesn’t.”

我很惊讶。“原来这些事情在现实生活中真的很重要啊。”

I was surprised. “So this stuff actually matters in real life.”

“确实如此。而这里的‘简单’其实指的是‘多项式时间内可解’。 ”

“It does. And ‘easy’ here turns out to mean something specific called, ‘solvable in polynomial time’.”

我再次打断道：“你把这叫做总结？用我听过的单音节单词。”

I interrupted again. “You call this summing up? Use words of one syllable that I’ve heard before.”

蒙蒂停顿了一下，然后继续说。“好吧。这个。家伙。说。他。能。快速解决所有问题。就像旅行的事情一样。就像上帝解决问题一样快。”

Monty paused before continuing. “Fine. This. Guy. Says. He. Can. Solve all things fast. Like the trip thing. As fast as God can solve things.”

我简直不敢相信他居然真的这么做了。我告诉他别再胡闹了。

I couldn’t believe he was actually doing it. I told him not to be an asshole.

“这个‘因子人’可以让任何问题都变得简单，”蒙蒂告诉我。“任何问题。就好像他可以猜出任何问题的答案，所以他所要做的就是检查他的答案是否正确。你想猜出参观首都的正确顺序吗？他可以做到。”

“This ‘Factor Man’ can make any problem easy,” Monty told me. “Any problem at all. It’s as if he can just guess the answer to anything, so that all he has to do is check that his answer is right. You want to guess the right order to visit the capitals? He can do that.”

格莱姆斯停顿了一下，我沉默不语，试图弄清楚这一切与因式分解和素数有什么关系。“他能解决任何问题吗？”我问道。

Grimes paused, and I said nothing while trying to figure out what all this had to do with factoring and prime numbers. “He can solve any problem?” I asked.

“是的。任何问题。后果都是深远的，而且不只是对旅行推销员而言。你想破解密码吗？因子人可以猜出钥匙。”

“Yes. Any problem. The consequences would be profound, and not just for traveling salesmen. You want to break a secret code? Factor Man can guess the key.”

“所以可能有一个应用程序可以解决这个问题。”我回答道。

“So there could be an app for that,” I answered.

“没错。可能会有一款应用程序让你入侵任何系统，解密任何秘密信息。但这只是一个开始。例如药物设计。这通常涉及找到具有特定形状的蛋白质。计算特定蛋白质的形状很容易，但猜测要使用哪种蛋白质却很难。因子人可以猜测，药物设计就变得容易了。

“Exactly. There could be an app that would let you hack into any system, decrypt any secret message. But that’s only the beginning. Drug design, for example. That typically involves finding a protein that takes a particular shape. Computing the shape of a specific protein is easy, but guessing what protein to use is hard. Factor Man can guess, and drug design just got easy.

“通过不断猜测下一步的最佳走法，你可以下一场完美的棋。

“You can play a perfect game of chess by always guessing the best next move to make.

“即使数学也很简单。识别费马大定理等某些难解结果的有效证明很容易；找到证明却很难。因子人声称能够猜测证明，而且每次都是正确的。”

“Even mathematics is easy. Recognizing a valid proof of some hard result like Fermat’s Last Theorem is easy; finding the proof is hard. Factor Man is claiming to be able to just guess the proof and be right every time.”

“他能解决任何问题。”我总结道。

“He could solve anything,” I summarized.

“他能解决任何问题。”蒙蒂继续告诉我，曼声称拥有的算法，即一种让他能够做出解决任何问题的全知猜测的算法，被计算机科学家称为“上帝算法”。当然，大多数人认为上帝算法是上帝独有的，凡人永远不会受到如此的启发。格莱姆斯引用了麻省理工学院的斯科特·阿伦森的话，他说，如果上帝算法存在，那么“世界将与我们通常认为的完全不同。‘创造性飞跃’将不再具有特殊价值，解决问题和找到解决方案后识别解决方案之间没有根本差距。”

“He could solve anything.” Monty went on to tell me that the algorithm Factor Man claimed to have, one that would allow him to make omniscient guesses that solved any problem, was called “God’s algorithm” by computer scientists. Of course, most people believe that God’s algorithm is reserved for God, and that mere mortals can never be so inspired. Grimes quoted MIT’s Scott Aaronson, who had said that if God’s algorithm existed, then “the world would be a profoundly different place than we usually assume it to be. There would be no special value in ‘creative leaps,’ no fundamental gap between solving a problem and recognizing the solution once it’s found.”

但疯狂科学家格莱姆斯不同意。他说，他的观点是，上帝的算法终究是存在的。

But Grimes, the mad scientist, disagreed. His view, he said, was that God’s algorithm existed after all.

“为什么？”我问他。

“Why?” I asked him.

“因为我不认为上帝会把最好的算法留给自己。”

“Because I don’t think God would keep the best algorithms to himself.”

哎呀。只有格莱姆斯会把密码破译变成一个关于上帝对我们其他人的个人态度的问题。

Geez. Only Grimes would turn code breaking into a question about God’s personal attitude toward the rest of us.

“那这个 Factor Man 呢？”我继续说道。“你说你认为他非常聪明。你认为他已经解决了这个问题吗？”

“What about this Factor Man guy?” I continued. “You said you thought he was really smart. Do you think he’s solved this?”

“我认为他找到了上帝的算法吗？我不知道，”他回答道。格莱姆斯停顿了一下，我几乎可以听到他停下脚步，决定接下来要说什么。“我一直认为，如果有人真的找到了上帝的算法，那将是一场竞赛。要么政府会杀了他，要么他会统治世界。因子人的计划实际上可能是一种穿针引线的方法。它要么是本世纪的突破，要么是十年的骗局。”

“Do I think he’s found God’s algorithm? I have no idea,” he responded. Grimes paused, and I could almost hear him stop pacing as he decided what to say next. “I’ve always thought that if someone did find God’s algorithm, it would be a race. Either the government would kill him, or he would take over the world. Factor Man’s plan might actually be a way to thread that needle. It’s either the breakthrough of the century, or the fraud of the decade.”

他又停顿了一下。“因子人的帖子之所以如此聪明，是因为他没有一下子把所有信息都告诉我们。他说他有上帝的算法，他可以分解非常大的数字。他可以破解加密。”

He paused again. “What makes Factor Man’s post so smart is that he’s not springing it on us all at once. He says that he has God’s algorithm, and he can factor really big numbers. He can break encryption.”

“等一下，等一下。”我再次打断他，“大数字和加密有什么关系？”

“Wait, wait.” I stopped him again. “What do big numbers have to do with encryption?”

“有一道题叫‘数字分解’，有人给你一个数字x，你的任务是想出另外两个数字y和z，这两个数字相乘后得到x。数字分解用于加密互联网上的信息。

“There’s a problem called ‘number factoring’, where someone gives you a number x and your job is to come up with two other numbers y and z that can be multiplied together to produce x again. Number factoring is used to encrypt information on the Internet.

“例如，当你将信用卡信息发送给亚马逊时，亚马逊会给你一个x，你可以用它来加密信息。但只有找到分解x的y和z才能解密信息。因此，如果你能随着x越来越大而解决数字分解问题，你就能破解用于在互联网上保密信息的密码。

“When you send your credit card information to Amazon, for example, Amazon gives you an x that you use to encrypt that information. But you can only decrypt the information if you can find the y and z that factor x. So if you can solve number factoring problems as x gets bigger and bigger, you can break the codes that are used to keep information private on the Internet.

“检查x是否是y和z的乘积很容易。但如果x非常大，比如 1000万亿...

“Checking that x is the product of y and z is easy. But if x is really big, like a googol or a novemdecillion, then there are too many possible y and z values to consider. Unless you use God’s algorithm to guess the factors, in which case you can decrypt the message and steal the credit card information. But right now, all this Factor Man guy is offering to do is to factor numbers that are so small you could factor them in your head. A bit is a single 0 or 1 in computer memory somewhere, so a 5-bit number has to be less than 32. Factoring something like 22=2×11 isn’t that tough.”

“那么我为什么要感到印象深刻呢？”我问道。

“So why should I be impressed?” I asked.

“因为他提出要继续分解更大的数字。分解数字的常规方法，只是除以质数直到找到一个因数，在 64 位时就会失效。有一些专门的技术可以做得更好，可能高达 90 位。但当你达到 128 位时，很明显他已经发现了一些东西。”

“Because he offers to keep factoring bigger numbers. Normal methods for factoring numbers, just dividing by primes until you find a factor, will run out of steam at maybe 64 bits. There are some specialized techniques that can do better, maybe up to 90 bits. But by the time you get to 128 bits, it’ll be obvious he’s onto something.”

我在一张纸上潦草地写下“128 位”，并把它圈起来。“他是不是用了一台更快的电脑？”我问道。

I scribbled “128 bits” on a scrap of paper and circled it. “Can he just be using a faster computer?” I asked.

“只有在电影里才会出现，”蒙蒂回答道。他听起来好像觉得我看了太多电影。“要对一个数字进行多一位的因式分解，你要么需要一台速度快一倍的计算机，要么需要两倍的计算机。世界上没有足够的计算机来用现有技术对 128 位数字进行因式分解。”

“Only in the movies,” Monty answered. He sounded like he thought I watched too many movies. “To factor a number with one more bit, you need either a computer that’s twice as fast, or twice as many computers. There aren’t enough computers in the world to factor a 128-bit number with existing techniques.”

“那么我们什么时候才能知道他是否诚实呢？”

“So when will we know if he’s on the level?”

“这没什么意义。随着数字越来越大，他说的是真的的可能性就会逐渐增加。”

“There’s no real point. As the numbers get bigger, it will become gradually more likely that he’s for real.”

“那么我们什么时候才能知道？”

“So when will we know?”

“如果他一年后还继续参加比赛，我们就会知道。”从他的语气中，我无法判断格莱姆斯的期望是什么，他是否真的期望什么。“但在此之前，不确定。”

“If he’s still going a year from now, we’ll know.” I couldn’t tell from his tone what Grimes expected, if he expected anything at all. “But before then, not for sure.”

“我要把它写下来吗？”

“Do I write it up?”

“不知道。如果你选择写下来，但你错了，你会看起来像个白痴。如果你选择不写下来，但你错了，你会错过普利策奖。”

“No idea. If you choose to write it up and you’re wrong, you’ll look like an idiot. If you choose not to write it up and you’re wrong, you’ll miss out on your Pulitzer.”

“你会怎么办？”

“What would you do?”

格莱姆斯告诉我他不会当记者，然后我们就挂断了电话。

Grimes told me he wouldn’t be a reporter, and we hung up.

* * *

* * *

等我和格莱姆斯通话结束，已经是周六的晚餐时间了。我仍然不知道是否要写《Factor Man》。所以，我违背自己的判断，决定去问问我的编辑。

By the time my call with Grimes finished, it was dinner time on Saturday. I still had no idea whether to write about “Factor Man” or not. So, against my better judgment, I decided to ask my editor.

现在，您需要了解一些有关编辑器的事情。

Now, there are some things you need to understand about editors.

首先，他们不是你的朋友。电影里那些慈祥的编辑们悉心照料记者的场景？都是童话。

First, they are not your friends. All those movie portrayals of avuncular editors nurturing their reporters along? Fairy tales.

其次，他们的主要目标不是快速传播故事，而是正确报道故事。

Second, their primary goal is not to get the story out quickly. It’s to get the story right.

如果你抢占了整个星球，他们不会获得普利策奖；作家会。对编辑来说，最令人兴奋的事情就是发表一个错误的故事，而且它很重要，他的工作变成了人间地狱，直到其他编辑犯下类似的错误。

They don’t get the Pulitzer Prize if you scoop the entire planet; the writer does. The most exciting thing that arguably ever happens to an editor is that a story comes out that’s wrong, and it matters, and his job becomes a living hell until some other editor makes a comparable mistake.

所以编辑们都很保守。他们不喜欢被已经过了一半的 48 小时截止期限所催促，尤其是当截止期限本身可能是由一个匿名疯子提供的。编辑们通常也不喜欢在周六晚上被打扰，但我想他宁愿现在被打扰，也不愿在午夜被打扰。

So editors are conservative. They don’t like being rushed by a 48-hour deadline that’s half gone, especially when the deadline itself was arguably provided by an anonymous nut case. Editors are generally not thrilled about being disturbed on Saturday evening, either, but I figured he’d rather be bothered now than at midnight.

别误会我的意思。我喜欢我的编辑。他是一个五十岁的慢跑狂热者，名叫托马斯·道尔顿，和他结婚近一个世纪的女人住在丹佛。他们似乎仍然疯狂地相爱。空巢老人，两个孩子都在加利福尼亚某所大学上学。汤姆戴着领结参加 Skype 会议，所以至少有些刻板印象是真的。他很聪明，很细心，不止一次救了我。

Don’t get me wrong. I like my editor. He’s a fifty-year-old jogging fanatic named Thomas Dalton who lives in Denver with the woman he’s been married to for approximately a century. They still seem to be madly in love. Empty nesters, with two kids both in college in California somewhere. Tom shows up for Skype conferences wearing a bow tie, so at least some of the stereotypes are true. He’s smart, he’s careful, and he’s saved my butt on more than one occasion.

不过，在联系他之前，我试图为我们争取一些时间。

Before I contacted him, though, I tried to buy us some time.

发件人：William Burkett (wburkett@nytimes.com)

From: William Burkett (wburkett@nytimes.com)

收件人：Factor Man (factorman0@gmail.com)

To: Factor Man (factorman0@gmail.com)

回复：回报恩惠

Re: returned favor

嘿FM：

Hey FM:

我的部门周末不上班。我有可能工作 72 小时而不是 48 小时吗？谢谢。

My department doesn't work on the weekends. Any chance of my getting seventy-two hours instead of forty-eight? Thanks.

威廉

William

没有回复。我在当地一家披萨店吃了几片披萨后仍然没有回复，所以我放弃了，发了短信。

No response. And still no response after I grabbed a couple slices at a local pizza shop, so I gave up and sent the text.

致 Tom Dalton [晚上 8:27]：可能需要谈谈。支持信息已通过电子邮件发送。

to Tom Dalton [8:27PM]: Might need to talk. Supporting info sent by email.

Tom Dalton [晚上 8:42]：目前为止，没有读到所有细节。最好打电话。十分钟？

from Tom Dalton [8:42PM]: At a thing, didn’t read all details. Phone best. Ten mins?

致 Tom Dalton [晚上 8:44]：周六晚上实现梦想。方便时请打电话。

to Tom Dalton [8:44PM]: Living the dream on a Saturday night. Call when convenient.

* * *

* * *

道尔顿终于在 9:30 左右打来了电话，我们聊了大约一个小时。

Dalton finally called around 9:30, and we spoke for maybe an hour.

首先，我告诉他我想写这个故事。毕竟，如果 Factor Man 够诚实，那么这确实是一生难忘的故事，而且很有可能让我获奖（甚至可能是大奖）。如果 Factor Man 是个骗子，人们会像指责其他任何人一样指责 Tom。你懂的。

For starters, I told him I wanted to write the story. After all, if Factor Man was on the level, it was indeed the story of a lifetime and likely to get me awards (perhaps even the Big Award). If Factor Man was a fraud, people would point at Tom as much as anything else. You get it.

汤姆也明白了。

Tom got it, too.

但汤姆的工作能力几乎和我一样强。他想出了一个计划，让我可以写关于 Factor Man 的文章，而不必冒着看起来像个白痴的风险。他承诺会在周日晚上 8 点抽出时间阅读我写的内容，并表示如果文章足够好，他会在 10 点之前完成。我们比 Factor Man 的截止时间提前了四分钟。

But Tom is almost as good at his job as I am at mine. He came up with a plan that would let me write about Factor Man without running the risk of looking like an idiot. He promised to make time on Sunday night at 8 to read whatever I had written and said that if it was good enough, he’d get it out by 10. We’d beat Factor Man’s deadline by four minutes.

于是我回到博客，重读了一遍，发现我仍然没有理解大部分内容。我有些不情愿地给格莱姆斯回了电话。

So I went back to the blog, reread it, and realized I still didn’t understand most of it. Somewhat reluctantly, I called Grimes back.

“是啊？”他回答道。

“Yeah?” he answered.

“如果我要写这个，”我告诉他，“我需要理解这个博客。解释一下其余部分。”

“If I’m going to write this,” I told him, “I need to understand the blog. Explain the rest of it.”

“我以为你的脑子已经满了。”

“I thought your brain was full.”

“好吧，我喝了点咖啡，这样就腾出空间了。”

“Well, I drank some coffee and that made room.”

“出色的。”

“Excellent.”

我等待着。

I waited.

“你还在吗，威尔伯？那是一个三个音节的词。我想确保你没有昏倒或发生什么。”

“You still there, Wilbur? That was a three syllable word. I want to make sure you didn’t pass out or something.”

“很可爱，蒙蒂。”

“Cute, Monty.”

“实际上，”他安慰我说，“你已经理解了大部分内容。剩下的就是P和NP 了。”

“Actually,” he reassured me, “you already understand most of it. All that’s left are P and NP.”

“打我吧，”我说。

“Hit me,” I said.

“P 代表‘多项式’。计算机科学家经常会说，一个简单的问题‘属于P’。一个更困难的问题，比如旅行商问题——还记得吗？——并不属于 P。

“P stands for ‘polynomial’. A computer scientist will often say that an easy problem is ‘in P.’ A harder problem, like the traveling salesman problem – remember that? – is not known to be in P.

“但是如果你有上帝的算法，你只需猜测各州首府的最佳排序，就能解决旅行商问题。我们讨论过这个问题。你可以采用最佳排序，并检查是否可以在三个月内完成。问题又会是多项式问题，回到 P 问题中。像这样的问题被称为“ NP问题”，其中P仍然代表多项式，N 代表“如果我足够聪明，可以做出绝妙的猜测”。所以NP 的实际含义是“如果我足够聪明，可以做出绝妙的猜测，那么问题就会在P问题中”。N 实际上代表非确定性，但对于计算机科学家来说，这是一回事。”

“But if you had God’s algorithm, you could solve the traveling salesman problem by just guessing the best ordering of the state capitals. We talked about that. You could take that best ordering and check if you could do it in three months. The problem would be polynomial again, back in P. Problems like this are said to be ‘in NP,’ where the P still stands for polynomial and the N stands for, ‘if only I were smart enough to make a fantastic guess.’ So NP actually means, ‘If I were smart enough to make a fantastic guess, the problem would be in P.’ The N actually stands for nondeterministic, but to a computer scientist it’s the same thing.”

“不是什么？”我问。“音节太多了。”

“Non-what?” I asked. “Too many syllables.”

“你快完成了，”蒙蒂告诉我。“在实践中，P表示‘不需要聪明才智’。NP 表示‘如果你能做出全知猜测，就不需要聪明才智’。正是这种全知性让它被称为上帝算法。如果P和NP相同，则意味着对于任何需要神灵启发猜测的问题，比如旅行商问题，都存在一种聪明的算法可以快速做出正确的猜测。破解密码。药物设计。下棋。数学。你懂的。”

“You’re almost done,” Monty told me. “In practice, P means ‘no cleverness required.’ NP means ‘no cleverness required, if you can make an omniscient guess.’ That bit of omniscience is why it’s called God’s algorithm. If P and NP are the same, it means that for any problem requiring a divinely inspired guess, like the traveling salesman problem, there is a clever algorithm that can make a correct guess quickly. Breaking codes. Drug design. Playing chess. Mathematics. You get it.”

令人惊奇的是，我感觉我确实如此。

Amazingly enough, I felt like I did.

格莱姆斯解释说，因子人声称他发现了上帝的算法。他声称P=NP，并且他有一个计算机程序可以实际演示这一点。他实际上可以做我们一直在谈论的所有事情。

Grimes explained that Factor Man was claiming that he had found God’s algorithm. He was claiming that P=NP and that he had a computer program that actually demonstrated it. He could actually do all of the things we’d been talking about.

“最后一件事，”他告诉我，“ NP中有很多问题。我们已经讨论过其中一些问题，比如药物设计等等。但有些问题很特殊。它们非常难，如果你能解决它们，你实际上就能解决任何问题。”

“One last thing,” he told me. “There are lots of problems in NP. We’ve talked about some of them – drug design, and so on. But there are some problems that are special. They’re so hard that if you can solve them, you can actually solve anything.

“其中一个超难问题叫做‘布尔可满足性’，而这正是 Factor Man 声称已经解决的问题。布尔可满足性简称为 SAT。因此，当他在博客文章中说他有一个‘多项式时间 SAT 求解器’时，他是在说他已经证明 SAT 属于 P。因为 SAT 是一个超难问题，所以这意味着P和NP是相同的，并且所有其他问题也属于P。 ”

“One of those superhard problems is called ‘Boolean satisfiability,’ and that’s the problem Factor Man is claiming to have solved. Boolean satisfiability is called SAT for short. So when he says in his blog post that he has a ‘polytime SAT solver,’ he’s saying that he has proven that SAT is in P. Because SAT is a superhard problem, it means that P and NP are the same and all of those other problems are in P as well.”

我看了看手机，它似乎比我更聪明。当我意识到我实际上什么都不懂时，我问蒙蒂是否愿意再解释一遍，他说当然可以。

I looked at my phone, which somehow seemed like it was smarter than I was. I asked Monty if he would explain it all again when I realized I didn’t actually understand any of it, and he said sure.

* * *

* * *

如何发现疯子

How to Find a Crackpot

威廉·伯克特，《纽约时报》

William Burkett, The New York Times

1818 年，维克多·弗兰肯斯坦据说躲进了实验室，创造了一个改变世界的怪物。两个世纪后的今天，这样的事情真的会发生吗？

In 1818, Victor Frankenstein supposedly withdrew to his laboratory and created a monster that changed the world. Can something like this actually happen now, two centuries later?

时代至少在两个重要方面发生了变化。首先，如今科学更像是一项团队运动； 2015 年《自然》杂志上一篇论文的平均作者人数接近 20 人。孤立的天才以前所未有的方式推动科学发展的浪漫时代可能已经一去不复返了。

Times have changed in at least two important ways. First, science is much more a team sport these days; the average number of authors of a Nature paper in 2015 was nearly 20. Gone – perhaps – are the romantic days of isolated geniuses moving the scientific needle in unprecedented fashion.

但还有另一个不同之处。如果算上业余爱好者，今天的科学家数量比以往任何时候都多。互联网本身就以前所未有的方式提供了科学文献。当斯坦福大学的吴恩达开设机器学习在线课程时，有超过两万五千名学生注册。也许这些人中最终会有一个成为孤独的天才。

But there is another difference as well. If you include the amateurs, there are many more scientists today than ever before. The Internet alone makes the scientific literature available in an unprecedented manner. When Stanford’s Andrew Ng offered an online course in machine learning, over twenty-five thousand students registered. Perhaps one of these folks will be the lone genius after all.

当然，有很多人声称自己是下一个维克多·弗兰肯斯坦。例如，2015 年，一位名叫望月新一的日本数学家悄悄宣布已经解决了“ ABC猜想”。这被广泛认为是数学中最重要的未解问题之一，而望月只是在他的网站上发布了该猜想的（所谓）证明。他拒绝接受采访，但有人就他的工作召开会议。据说这些会议增加了彻底研究这项工作的数学家的数量，使他们不再屈指可数。没有人知道望月是对的，还是个疯子。

There are certainly plenty of folks claiming to be the next Victor Frankenstein. In 2015, for example, a Japanese mathematician named Shinichi Mochizuki quietly claimed to have solved the “abc conjecture.” This is widely recognized as one of the most important open problems in mathematics, and Mochizuki simply posted a (purported) proof of the conjecture on his web site. He has refused interviews, but there are conferences about his work. The conferences are described as increasing the number of mathematicians who have thoroughly studied the work so that they can no longer be counted on one’s fingers. No one knows if Mochizuki is right, or a crackpot.

一个类似的领域似乎是深奥的问题，即P=NP是否成立。这也被描述为数学中最重要的未决问题之一，普遍的共识是P≠NP。粗略地说，P=NP意味着可以完美下棋，创作一首优美的交响乐并不比欣赏一首交响乐更难。这也意味着电子商务背后的加密技术基本上没有提供任何保护。

A similar area appears to be the esoteric question of whether P=NP. This, too, is described as one of the most important open questions in mathematics, with the general consensus being that P≠NP. Roughly speaking, P=NP would mean that it’s possible to play a perfect game of chess, and that composing a beautiful symphony would be no more difficult than appreciating one. It would also mean that the encryption techniques underlying e-commerce provide essentially no protection at all.

2010 年 8 月，惠普公司的 Vinay Deolalikar 声称已经证明P≠NP，因此互联网商务是安全的。两位资深研究人员认为该证明有其价值，尽管后来发现它存在致命缺陷。但围绕这个所谓证明的骚动是如此之大，以至于这篇论文发表了一篇社论：“步骤 1：后难以捉摸的证明。步骤 2：观看烟花。”最终，Deolalikar 只是犯了一个错误，而他只是与此类问题有关的计算复杂性领域的外行。

In August of 2010, Hewlett-Packard’s Vinay Deolalikar claimed to have proven that P≠NP, so that Internet commerce was safe. Two senior researchers suggested that the proof had merit, although it subsequently turned out to be fatally flawed. But the commotion surrounding the supposed proof was such that this paper published an editorial about it: “Step 1: Post Elusive Proof. Step 2: Watch Fireworks.” In the end, Deolalikar, an outsider to the field of computational complexity that is concerned with such matters, had simply made a mistake.

鉴于如今业余科学家的数量庞大，他们中的一些人似乎不可避免地会做出看似科学突破的事情。我们如何判断他们是否取得了突破？更直白地说，我们如何判断所谓的科学家是否是个疯子？

Given the enormous number of amateur scientists floating around these days, it seems almost inevitable that some of them will make what appear to be scientific breakthroughs. How do we tell when they have, and when they haven’t? Somewhat more bluntly, how can we tell if a purported scientist is a crackpot?

科学家们对此也感到担忧，这并不令人意外。2009 年，人类学家 Pascal Boyer 提出，科学怪人可以这样识别：

Not surprisingly, scientists worry about this as well. In 2009, anthropologist Pascal Boyer suggested that scientific crackpots could be identified as follows:

  1. 疯狂的陶艺是基础。
  2. Crackpottery is foundational.
  3. 所有疯子都是男性。
  4. All crackpots are male.
  5. 物理学狂人往往是工程师。
  6. Physics crackpots tend to be engineers.
  7. 疯子们对其他疯子们视而不见。
  8. Crackpots ignore other crackpots.
  9. 荒诞理论都是直观的。
  10. Crackpot theories are intuitive.
  11. 荒诞理论从数学上来说很简单。
  12. Crackpot theories are mathematically simple.
  13. 荒诞理论是基于教科书，而不是期刊论文。
  14. Crackpot theories are based on textbooks, not journal papers.

其他作者也列出了类似的清单。

Other authors have formed similar lists.

在此背景下，我想评估两种理论。一如既往，您的观点可能有所不同。

There are two theories that I would like to evaluate in this context. As always, your mileage may vary.

其中一个观点是蒙哥马利·格莱姆斯 (Montgomery Grimes) 认为鸟类群居是因为这样可以提高进化效率。他的观点是，通过聚集在一起，一个物种可以确保最弱的成员通常被捕食者杀死。格莱姆斯将其与两个人逃离熊的老笑话进行了类比。“我们为什么要跑？”有人问道。“我们跑不过熊。”

One is Montgomery Grimes’ suggestion that birds flock because it makes evolution more efficient. His argument is that by clustering together, a species can ensure that the weakest members are the ones typically killed by predators. Grimes draws an analogy with the old joke about two people running away from a bear. “Why are we running?” asks one. “We can’t outrun a bear.”

“我不需要跑得比熊快，”他回答道，“我只需要跑得比你快。”

“I don’t have to outrun the bear,” is the reply. “I just have to outrun you.”

那么，格莱姆斯是不是个疯子？主流期刊似乎确实这么认为；《自然》和《科学》都拒绝了他描述该理论的论文，且未进行审查。根据博耶的表格：

So is Grimes a crackpot? The major journals certainly seem to think so; both Nature and Science rejected his paper describing the theory without review. According to Boyer’s table:

  1. 荒诞不经是基础。从进化生物学的角度解释群体行为是基础。
  2. Crackpottery is foundational. Explaining flocking would be foundational from the perspective of evolutionary biology.
  3. 所有疯子都是男性。太糟糕了，格莱姆斯。
  4. All crackpots are male. Too bad, Grimes.
  5. 物理学怪人往往都是工程师。格莱姆斯是一名理论天体物理学家，但同时也拥有一系列令人印象深刻的工程成就。我们姑且把这一项称为并列。
  6. Physics crackpots tend to be engineers. Grimes is a theoretical astrophysicist by training, but also has a fairly impressive string of engineering accomplishments. Let’s call this one a tie.
  7. 疯子们会忽视其他疯子。格莱姆斯的文章在引用其他文献方面做得不错。我们或许可以原谅他。
  8. Crackpots ignore other crackpots. Grimes’ article does a reasonable job of quoting other literature. We can probably give him a pass on this one.
  9. 荒诞理论是直觉的。没错。
  10. Crackpot theories are intuitive. Yup.
  11. 荒诞理论在数学上很简单。但在本例中并非如此。格莱姆斯的论文涉及相当多的数学知识，复杂到他必须对所讨论的物种进行计算机模拟，才能弄清楚到底发生了什么。
  12. Crackpot theories are mathematically simple. Not in this case. Grimes’ paper involves a reasonable amount of mathematics, intricate enough that he had to build a computer simulation of the species in question to figure out what actually happened.
  13. 荒诞理论是基于教科书，而不是期刊论文。格莱姆斯的理论基于阿尔弗雷德·洛特卡和维托·沃尔特拉在 20 世纪初开发的一个相当著名的进化模型。不是教科书材料，也不是前沿期刊材料。
  14. Crackpot theories are based on textbooks, not journal papers. Grimes’ theory is based on a fairly well-known evolutionary model developed by Alfred Lotka and Vito Volterra early in the 20th century. Not textbook material, but not cutting edge journal stuff, either.

因此，格莱姆斯在 7 分制中的得分为 4.5 分。这足以让他不被真正的生物学家认真考虑吗？目前还不清楚。

So Grimes scores 4½ on the crackpot scale of 7. Is that enough to deny him serious consideration by real biologists? It’s not clear.

我的第二个例子完全超出了常规。还记得我们的老朋友P=NP吗？现在看看 factorman0.blogspot.com。你会发现有人声称已经证明了P=NP，甚至声称正在向全世界证明这一点。

My second example is outside the box completely. Remember our old friend P=NP? Now take a look at factorman0.blogspot.com. You’ll find someone who claims to have shown that P=NP and even claims to be on track to prove it to the world.

基础理论，当然。这位博主看起来也是男性；他称自己为“因子人”。这篇文章读起来就像是科学家写的。不可能判断因子人是否忽略了其他人，他的理论是否直观、数学上简单，或者它基于什么。我们假设根据我们实际可以评估的标准，3 个中有 2 个。

Foundational, for sure. The blogger also appears to be male; he calls himself “Factor Man.” The post reads like a scientist wrote it. It’s impossible to tell if Factor Man ignores everyone else, if his theory is intuitive, mathematically simple, or what it’s based on. Let’s say 2 out of 3 on the criteria that we can actually evaluate.

毕竟，这家伙实际上是在威胁要摧毁互联网。我们应该关注吗？

The guy is, after all, basically threatening to bring down the Internet. Should we pay attention?

对于 21 小时的工作来说还不错。

Not bad for 21 hours’ work.

* * *

* * *

几天后，博客开始了。

The blog began a few days later.

2017 年 5 月 16 日

May 16, 2017

Factor Man 博客

The Factor Man blog

22=2×11（大卫·帕克要求）

22=2×11 (requested by David Parker)

21=3×7（马修·利文斯顿要求）

21=3×7 (requested by Matthew Livingston)

25=5×5（Dan Davidson 要求）

25=5×5 (requested by Dan Davidson)

26=2×13（Emily Pandu 要求）

26=2×13 (requested by Emily Pandu)

15=3×5（山姆·怀斯曼请求）

15=3×5 (requested by Sam Wiseman)

六位数字将在三天内被分解。

Six bit numbers will be factored in three days.

该网站已被访问过 2,037 次。

This web site has been visited 2,037 times.

截止日期已然过去，我决定再多打探一下。格莱姆斯告诉我，麻省理工学院的斯科特·阿伦森对P=NP表示怀疑，我在德克萨斯大学奥斯汀分校读研究生时曾见过斯科特一次。我当时的女朋友是一名计算机科学研究生，她告诉我阿伦森非常聪明，我们需要参加他关于量子计算的客座讲座。

The deadline comfortably behind me, I decided to do a little more poking around. Grimes had told me that MIT’s Scott Aaronson was doubtful that P=NP, and I had met Scott once while I was a graduate student at UT Austin. My then girlfriend had been a computer science grad student and told me that Aaronson was beyond brilliant and we needed to attend his visiting lecture on quantum computing.

我不骗你。更糟糕的是，我们被拖着去吃晚饭，甚至不知怎么的还把 Aaronson 送到了他的酒店。我们为爱而做的事情。

I kid you not. To make matters worse, we got dragged along for dinner and somehow even wound up giving Aaronson a lift to his hotel afterwards. The things we do for love.

我试图联系麻省理工学院的 Aaronson，但结果发现他已经跳槽（偏偏去了德克萨斯大学奥斯汀分校）。所以我给他发了一封电子邮件，其中附上了我在《纽约时报》上发表的文章。几天后我们通过电话联系上了。

I tried reaching Aaronson at MIT, but it turned out he had jumped ship (for UT Austin, of all places). So I sent him an email, including a pointer to my Times piece. We connected by phone a couple days later.

斯科特的回答让我印象最深刻的是经过深思熟虑。他说，他不知道 Factor Man 博客，但也完全不为所动。他指出，夸张的说法加上他展示的分解小数的能力，完全是无稽之谈。

More than anything else, Scott’s response struck me as carefully considered. He had been unaware of the Factor Man blog, he said, but was also completely unimpressed by it. Extravagant claims combined with a demonstrated ability to factor small numbers added up to exactly nothing, he pointed out.

研究诸如P=NP是否等问题的人被称为复杂性理论家。在复杂性理论这个陌生而又相对狭小的世界里，阿伦森的知名度相当高。

People who study problems like whether P=NP are called complexity theorists. In the strange and relatively small world of complexity theory, Aaronson has a fairly high profile.

例如，他管理着复杂性“动物园”。事实证明，这些人感兴趣的事物远不止P和NP，斯科特列出了所有这些事物的清单。有数百个。

For example, he curates the complexity “zoo”. It turns out there are many more things of interest to these folks than just P and NP, and Scott has a list of all of them. Hundreds.

他还有个博客，名字叫 Shtetl-Optimized。如果你问他为什么选择这个名字，Aaronson 会给你一个相当长的解释，但归根结底，shtetl 就像《屋顶上的提琴手》中的 Anatevka 社区，Aaronson 觉得自己属于那里，整天研究上帝的话语。他会选择学习数学和理论物理，但 Aaronson 对数学的看法和 Rev Tevya 对上帝的看法可能并没有那么大差别。

He also has a blog called Shtetl-Optimized. Aaronson will give you a fairly long explanation if you ask why he chose that name, but the bottom line appears to be that a shtetl is a community like Anatevka in Fiddler on the Roof, and Aaronson feels like he belongs there, studying the word of God all day. He would choose to study mathematics and theoretical physics, but Aaronson’s view of math and Rev Tevya’s view of God may not be that far apart.

Aaronson在他的博客上讨论了P和NP问题。他的基本观点（再次强调，我在这里进行了大幅压缩）是 P 中存在许多问题， NP中也存在许多问题。在某些情况下，这些问题彼此非常接近，但P中的问题似乎总是比NP中的问题稍微容易一些。Scott 认为，这两个领域之间有一道“看不见的电栅栏”，如果它们以某种方式相同，我们就会在网上的某个点上架起这道栅栏。

Aaronson has discussed the P and NP question on his blog. His basic view (again, I’m compressing substantially here) is that there are many problems in P, and many in NP. In some cases, those problems are incredibly close to one another, but the problems in P always seem to be just a little bit easier than those in NP. Scott believes that there is an “invisible electric fence” separating the two domains, and that if they were somehow the same, we would have bridged the fence at some point along the line.

回到因子人那里，阿伦森似乎完全相信，他分解大数的能力最终会变得有限。在某个时候，他只是无法分解提交的数字。他要么承认失败，要么更有可能停止发帖，回到他出现的匿名互联网黑暗中。阿伦森认为，最有可能的是，因子人会将一些大素数相乘，然后在博客网站上“分解”结果。

Returning to Factor Man, Aaronson appeared completely confident that his ability to factor large numbers would turn out to be limited. At some point, he would simply become unable to factor the numbers that were being submitted. He would either admit failure or, more likely, he would just stop posting, returning to the anonymous Internet murk from which he had emerged. Most likely of all, Aaronson thought, was that Factor Man would multiply some big prime numbers together and then “factor” the results on the blog site.

我指出，这样做不行。假设某个名人，比如马克·库班，决定参与进来，向因子人发送一个巨大的数字，让他在以后分解。因子人无法分解它，并将继续分解（现在发明的）无名小卒提交的数字。库班在广播中宣布他被怠慢了，这场骗局基本结束了。

I pointed out that that wouldn’t cut it. Let’s say someone famous, like Mark Cuban, decided to get involved, sending Factor Man some giant number to factor some time down the road. Factor Man wouldn’t be able to factor it, and would keep factoring numbers submitted by (now invented) nobodies. Cuban takes to the airwaves and announces that he’s been slighted, and the charade is pretty much over.

我不明白的是，为什么 Factor Man（阿伦森也认为他至少还算聪明）会以这种方式让自己陷入失败。为什么要故意公开进行示威游行，而你又知道这注定会失败？

What I didn’t understand was why Factor Man – whom Aaronson agreed was at a minimum reasonably clever – would set himself up for failure in this way. Why embark on a deliberately public demonstration that you have to know is doomed?

斯科特告诉我，对一些人来说，十五分钟的成名就足够了，他们不在乎这十五分钟的结局如何。七十亿人中，你肯定会发现一些疯子。

Scott told me that for some folks, fifteen minutes of fame is enough, and they don’t care how that fifteen minutes ends. Seven billion people, you’re bound to find a few nutters.

2

2

因子人

Factor Man

2017 年 7 月 12 日

July 12, 2017

西当博客数字达到六位（24位）时，我第二次伸出援手。

When the blog hit six digit numbers (24 bits), I reached out for the second time.

来自：factorman0@gmail.com

From: factorman0@gmail.com

收件人：rjhasday@duanemorris.com

To: rjhasday@duanemorris.com

主题：新客户？

Subject: new client?

亲爱的哈斯戴先生：

Dear Mr. Hasday:

我发现自己需要法律代理，一位共同的同事向我推荐了你。这项工作将是国际性的，可能由两个完全可分离的部分组成。其中一部分是起草一份必须绝对严密的合同，另一部分将涉及通常由私人快递员处理的文件传送。我想你可以接触到这样的人。你被推荐给我是因为你在合同法方面的专业知识。

I find myself in need of legal representation, and you have been recommended to me by a mutual colleague. The work will be international in nature and is likely to consist of two quite separable parts. One of these will be the drafting of a contract that will need to be absolutely ironclad, and the other part will involve document transfers of the type often handled by private couriers. I assume you have access to such individuals. You have been recommended to me because of your expertise in contract law.

由于我预计最终会清楚的原因，我希望保持匿名。我理解律师-客户特权应该保护我的身份，但在这种情况下，我想格外谨慎。请放心，我不会要求您做任何不道德或非法的事情，如果我要求您做非法或不道德的事情，我完全希望您拒绝。

For reasons that I expect will eventually become clear, I would like to remain anonymous. I understand that attorney-client privilege should protect my identity, but would like to exercise an additional degree of caution in this case. Please rest assured that I will not ask you to do anything immoral or illegal and, should I ask you to do something illegal or immoral, I would fully expect you to decline.

如果可以接受，请通过电子邮件向我发送留任协议。我会签署该协议并通过常规邮寄方式将其寄回给您。

If this is acceptable, please send me a retention agreement by email. I will sign it and return it to you by conventional post.

提前感谢您的关注，并期待共同合作。

Thank you in advance for your attention, and I look forward to working together.

调频

FM

Hasday 迅速作出了回应。

Hasday responded promptly.

发件人：Robert Hasday (rjhasday@duanemorris.com)

From: Robert Hasday (rjhasday@duanemorris.com)

收件人：Factor Man (factorman0@gmail.com)

To: Factor Man (factorman0@gmail.com)

回复：新客户？

Re: new client?

尊敬的先生/女士：

Dear Sir/Madam:

虽然你的请求很不寻常，但我认为满足它并没有什么坏处。不过，在我为你提供代理之前，我需要进行冲突检查，看看你的利益是否与我们目前的任何客户相抵触。我不知道如何在不知道你是谁的情况下做到这一点。

While your request is unusual, I don't see any harm in potentially honoring it. Before I can offer you representation, however, I need to run a conflict check to see if your interests are adverse to any of our current clients. I cannot see how to do that without knowing who you are.

鲍勃·哈斯戴

Bob Hasday

发件人：Factor Man (factorman0@gmail.com)

From: Factor Man (factorman0@gmail.com)

收件人：Robert Hasday (rjhasday@duanemorris.com)

To: Robert Hasday (rjhasday@duanemorris.com)

回复：新客户？

Re: new client?

亲爱的哈斯戴先生：

Dear Mr. Hasday:

我不认为冲突应该成为问题。目前肯定不存在冲突，因为我没有涉及任何法律事务。我理解未来可能会出现冲突，但我不会指望你在没有任何冲突方明确豁免的情况下代表我。

I do not believe that conflicts should be an issue. There are certainly no conflicts at the moment, because there are no legal matters in which I am involved. I understand that conflicts may arise in the future but I will not expect you to represent me without an explicit waiver from any conflicting party.

这样就够了吗？

Is that sufficient?

发件人：Robert Hasday (rjhasday@duanemorris.com)

From: Robert Hasday (rjhasday@duanemorris.com)

收件人：Factor Man (factorman0@gmail.com)

To: Factor Man (factorman0@gmail.com)

回复：新客户？

Re: new client?

尊敬的先生/女士：

Dear Sir/Madam:

附有一封留置信。

A retention letter is attached.

由于您要求的关系性质特殊，我们希望您能提前为我们提供一定数额的定金。也许 10,000 美元比较合适？

Because of the unusual nature of the relationship that you have requested, we would like to ask that you provide us with some sort of retainer in advance. Perhaps $10,000 would be appropriate?

我很好奇您给我们安排的工作性质。

I am curious as to the nature of the work that you have for us.

鲍勃·哈斯戴

Bob Hasday

鲍勃·哈斯戴

Bob Hasday

杜安莫里斯律师事务所

Duane Morris LLP

百老汇 1540 号

1540 Broadway

纽约，NY 10036

New York, NY 10036

亲爱的鲍勃：

Dear Bob:

感谢您的电子邮件。附件中附有您签署的留任协议副本以及 10,000 美元现金。

Thank you for your email. A signed copy of your retention agreement is enclosed, along with $10,000 in cash.

我还附上了 Sparta Global Intelligence Group 保险箱的钥匙，地址是 Löwengasse 39, 1030 Vienna。保险箱号码是 1739，密码是 I@mF@ctorm@n。我会根据需要用这个保险箱向您转入额外资金。

I am also enclosing a key to a safe deposit box at Sparta Global Intelligence Group, Löwengasse 39, 1030 Vienna. The box number is 1739 and the password is I@mF@ctorm@n. I will use the box to transfer additional funds to you as needed.

如果我给你发了一条提到著名物理学家的消息，请检查保险箱。我强烈建议你在维也纳的联系人拥有一部无法追踪的手机，仅用于此目的。请把钥匙放在安全的地方，不要告诉任何人它的位置。

If I send you a message mentioning a famous physicist, please check the safe deposit box. I recommend strongly that your contact in Vienna have an untraceable cell phone used only for this purpose. Please put the key somewhere safe, and tell no one of its location.

目前就是这样，明年左右可能也是如此。不过你会收到我的消息。

That’s it for now, and probably for the next year or so. But you’ll hear from me.

调频

FM

我最好的猜测是，我需要两次将现金送到 Hasday。在我计划的所有交易中，这两笔交易被发现的风险最大。我的指纹留在了 10,000 美元现金上，但这些现金很可能在有人关心之前就被存入了账户，无法追踪。我小心翼翼地确保信件或包裹上没有指纹。包裹本身只是通过美国邮政寄出的。

My best guess was that I would need to get cash to Hasday twice. Of everything I had planned, those two transactions held the greatest risk of discovery. My fingerprints were on the $10,000 in cash, but that would presumably be deposited and untraceable long before anyone cared. I had been careful to ensure that there were no fingerprints on the letter or the package that contained it. The package itself had simply been sent through the US mail.

现在一笔交易大概已经完成了。我知道，第二笔交易一旦完成，就会困难得多。

One transaction was presumably now complete. I knew that the second, when it came, would be much more difficult.

伯克特

Burkett

2017 年 9 月 6 日

September 6, 2017

神秘网站浏览量达 200 万次；科学家仍持怀疑态度

Mystery Web Site Gets 2 Million Views; Scientists Still Skeptical

威廉·伯克特，《纽约时报》

William Burkett, The New York Times

昨晚，一位自称解决了计算机科学领域一个重大悬而未决问题的人发表了一篇匿名博客，该博客的阅读量达到了两百万次，但科学家们仍然怀疑这位博主是否真的实现了他所声称的目标。

An anonymous blog posted by someone who claims to have solved one of the major open questions in computer science recorded its two millionth view last night, but scientists remain skeptical that the blogger has actually achieved what is claimed.

这位博主只知道他的名字是“因子人”，他声称自己能够解决任意难度的问题。他通过分解读者提供的数字来证明这一点，这意味着读者向因子人提供大量数字，他用两个素数来回答，这两个素数相乘后会重现原始问题。随着时间的推移，所涉及的数字会越来越大。

The blogger, known only as “Factor Man,” purports to be able to solve problems of arbitrary difficulty. He is demonstrating this by factoring numbers provided by his readers, which means that they present Factor Man with large numbers and he responds with two prime numbers that, when multiplied together, reproduce the original queries. As time passes, the numbers involved get ever larger.

该博客目前正在对 42 位（约一万亿）的数字进行因式分解。科学家表示，虽然使用现代计算机对这种规模的数字进行因式分解相对简单，但随着数字变大，问题会变得更加困难。对 60 位（约 10 18，即 1 后面跟着 18 个零）的数字进行因式分解代表了现有技术可以轻松完成的极限。Factor Man 博客每三天将规模增加一位，因此这个特定的阈值仍需要几个月的时间。

The blog is currently factoring numbers that are 42 bits in size, or around one trillion. Scientists say that while factoring numbers of this size is relatively straightforward using modern computers, the problem becomes much harder as the numbers get larger. Factoring numbers that are 60 bits in size (about 1018, or 1 followed by 18 zeroes) represents the limit of what can easily be done with existing technology. The Factor Man blog increases the size by one bit every three days, so this particular threshold is still a couple of months out.

因式分解问题之所以重要，是因为它们用于加密通过互联网发送的信息。计算机科学家已经开发出编码方案，您可以使用大整数对消息进行编码，但要解码相关消息，您需要对编码中使用的整数进行因式分解。如果可以快速对大整数进行因式分解，则通过互联网发送的信息将不再安全。

Factoring problems are important because they are used to encrypt information being sent over the Internet. Computer scientists have developed encoding schemes where you can encode a message using a large integer, but to decode the associated message, you need to factor the integer used in the encoding. If it is possible to factor large integers quickly, information sent over the Internet will no longer be secure.

更具体地说，当客户向亚马逊等在线供应商发送信用卡信息时，信用卡号会使用亚马逊提供的大数字进行加密。亚马逊（希望只有亚马逊）可以解码该消息以检索原始信用卡信息，因为亚马逊（希望只有亚马逊）知道如何将大数字写为两个其他数字的乘积。如果任意个人可以分解亚马逊的数字，他们也可以获取信用卡和其他仅供亚马逊使用的信息。

Somewhat more specifically, when a customer sends credit card information to an online vendor like Amazon, the credit card number is encrypted using a large number that Amazon supplies. Amazon (and hopefully only Amazon) can then decode the message to retrieve the original credit card information, since Amazon (and hopefully only Amazon) knows how to write the large number as a product of two other numbers. If arbitrary individuals could factor Amazon’s number, they could also obtain the credit card and other information that was intended only for Amazon.

互联网上用于加密信息的数字通常为 128 位或更大（10 36左右），因此 Factor Man 所做的事情目前没有风险。不过，他声称能够分解 128 位或更大的数字，据说将在大约八个月内实现。如果属实，这有可能对互联网商务造成严重破坏，更不用说其他安全信息了。

The numbers used for encrypting information on the Internet are generally 128 bits or bigger (1036 or so), so there is no current risk to what Factor Man is doing. He claims to be able to factor numbers of 128 bits and larger size, however, and will supposedly be doing so in about eight months. If true, this has the potential to wreak havoc with Internet commerce generally, not to mention other secure information.

科学家们并不十分担心，因为他们认为 Factor Man 声称解决的问题是无法解决的。粗略地说，Factor Man 声称能够将极其困难的问题转化为简单得多的问题，而大多数科学家认为这是不可能的。例如，2002 年对领先的复杂性理论家进行的一项民意调查发现，几乎 90% 的人认为这种转换通常是不可能的。

Scientists are not terribly concerned because they believe that the problem Factor Man has claimed to solve is insoluble. Roughly speaking, Factor Man claims to be able to convert extremely difficult problems into much simpler ones, and most scientists believe this is not possible.
