A 2002 poll of leading complexity theorists, for example, found that almost 90% of them believed conversions of this sort are impossible in general.

如果科学家们是对的，那么 Factor Man 博客最终将被揭露为一个骗局。尽管该博客的网络流量正在增加，但其中没有广告或其他机制可以让 Factor Man 本人受益。如果他没有做他声称的事情，他肯定知道这一点，而他创建该博客的目的仍不清楚。

If the scientists are right, the Factor Man blog will eventually be revealed as a sham. Although the blog is seeing an increasing amount of web traffic, there are no ads or other mechanisms from which Factor Man himself might benefit. If he has not done what he claims, he surely knows that, and his purpose in starting the blog remains unclear.

从现在起两到八个月左右的时间我们就会知道结果。

Some time between two and eight months from now, we’ll know.

* * *

* * *

随着时间流逝，Factor Man 博客继续向前发展。慢慢地，世界开始注意到它。

Time passed, and the Factor Man blog kept clunking along. Very slowly, the world began to notice.

2017 年 11 月 8 日

November 8, 2017

Factor Man 博客

The Factor Man blog

7679242802718243149=4128135071×1860220819

7679242802718243149=4128135071 × 1860220819

（应威尔·惠顿要求）

(requested by Wil Wheaton)

4642207329833315777=3608657033×1286408569

4642207329833315777=3608657033 × 1286408569

（应唐纳德·哈珀要求）

(requested by Donald Harper)

5829354591263741267=3615644117×1612258951

5829354591263741267=3615644117 × 1612258951

（应唐纳德·比绍夫要求）

(requested by Donald Bischoff)

6369235188560869753=3095117269×2057833237

6369235188560869753=3095117269 × 2057833237

（由 Megan Farnsby 请求）

(requested by Megan Farnsby)

5198239902527246893=3693259111×1407493963

5198239902527246893=3693259111 × 1407493963

（应迈克尔·肯尼迪要求）

(requested by Michael Kennedy)

64 位数字将在三天内被分解。

64-bit numbers will be factored in three days.

我偶尔读到，这篇博客必然会让我出丑，因为我的基本主张 P=NP 是不正确的。对此似乎有三个基本论据。

I occasionally read that this blog will inevitably make a fool of me because my basic claim that P=NP is untrue. There appear to be three basic arguments for this.

1. 如果P等于NP，那早就有人弄清楚了。

1. If P were equal to NP, someone would have figured it out a long time ago.

2. P 不能等于 NP，因为（例如）创作一首出色的交响乐显然比欣赏一首交响乐困难得多。

2. P can’t be equal to NP because (for example) it’s obviously much harder to write a brilliant symphony than it is to appreciate one.

3. P可能不等于NP，因为它们之间似乎存在着一条不可逾越的天然界限。

3. P is probably not equal to NP because there seems to be a natural boundary between them that cannot be crossed.

让我依次处理每一个问题。

Let me deal with each of these in turn.

1. 有人早就知道了这一点。这几乎不值得回应。这有点像查尔斯·杜尔 1899 年的名言：“一切可以发明的东西都已经被发明了。”杜尔当时是美国专利局局长；唯一的问题是，这句话完全是杜撰的，他从来没有说过这句话。

1. Someone would already have figured this out. This almost doesn’t merit a response. It’s sort of like Charles Duell’s famous 1899 quote, “Everything that can be invented has been invented.” Duell was the US Commissioner of Patents at the time; the only problem is that the quote is completely apocryphal and he never said it.

2. 制作酷炫的东西比欣赏酷炫的东西更难。这里的基本论点是，只有莫扎特才能创作出一首伟大的交响乐，但普通人却可以欣赏一首交响乐。

2. Making cool stuff is harder than appreciating cool stuff. The basic argument here is that it takes a Mozart to compose a great symphony, but your average schmo can appreciate one.

我认为，这实际上是相信 P=NP 而不是 P=NP 的最有说服力的理由之一。毕竟，莫扎特和乔·施莫之间的真正区别是什么？

I would argue that this is in fact one of the most compelling reasons to believe that P=NP, as opposed to the reverse. What, after all, is the real difference between Mozart and Joe Schmo?

这肯定不是硬件。脑细胞数量大致相同。基本架构相同，等等。

It’s surely not hardware. Same number of brain cells, give or take. Same basic architecture, etc.

不，莫扎特和我们其他人之间的区别完全在于软件。天才确实存在（无论是莫扎特还是霍金），而且他们实际上与我们其他人如此相似，这让我想到 P=NP。

No, the difference between Mozart and the rest of us is entirely software. The fact that geniuses exist (be they Mozart or Hawking) and that they are in reality so extraordinarily similar to the rest of us suggests to me that P=NP after all.

3. 阿伦森的“神奇边界”论证。这也许是三个论证中最有趣的一个。斯科特·阿伦森观察到，即使在最好的情况下，P 问题似乎也总是比 NP 问题稍微容易一些。他认为这意味着这两个类别可能不同。阿伦森将其比作两组青蛙——黄色的小青蛙和绿色的大青蛙。尽管你可以将它们混合在一起，但它们实际上永远不会繁殖。这表明它们不能繁殖。

3. Aaronson’s “magical boundary” argument. This is perhaps the most interesting argument of the three. Scott Aaronson has observed that problems in P always seem to be ever so slightly easier than problems in NP, even at the best of times. He suggests that this means that the two classes are likely different. Aaronson draws an analogy to two groups of frogs – small yellow ones and big green ones. Intermix them as you may, they never actually breed. That suggests that they can’t breed.

但人们当然可以想象出其他情况。也许很久以前，青蛙出现了某种身体畸形，只有同时有（或同时没有）这种畸形的青蛙才能自然杂交。随着时间的推移，青蛙种群分裂成两种类型，它们看起来只是两个物种。如果我们继续假设，如果青蛙的饮食中摄入了足够的钾，畸形就会消失，我们只需给它们一些补充剂，它们就会疯狂地杂交。

But one can certainly imagine otherwise. Perhaps, long ago, a certain physical deformity appeared so that only frogs that both had (or both lacked) the deformity could naturally interbreed. Over time, the frog population split into two types, which only looked like two species. If we go on to postulate that the deformity disappears if the frogs get enough potassium in their diet, all we need do is give them some supplements and they’ll be interbreeding like crazy.

换言之，如果它看起来像鸭子，走路像鸭子，叫声也像鸭子，那么它很可能就是鸭子。但即使某样东西看起来不同，走路方式不同，而且不叫，它也可能仍然是鸭子——只是伪装了一下，有点难以辨认。

Put somewhat differently, if it looks like a duck, and walks like a duck, and quacks like a duck, it’s probably a duck. But even if something looks different, walks differently, and doesn’t quack, it might still be a duck – just in disguise and a little hard to recognize.

该网站已被访问 58,836,211 次。

This web site has been visited 58,836,211 times.

看看吧。《星际迷航：下一代》的童星、 《生活大爆炸》的常客威尔·惠顿 (Wil Wheaton ) 曾要求 Factor Man 考虑一些事情。推文很快发布：

Check it out. Wil Wheaton, child star of Star Trek: The Next Generation and regular on The Big Bang Theory, had asked Factor Man to factor something. The tweet followed quickly:

@wilw (Wil Wheaton)：是的，我可以在 factorman0.blogspot.com 上确认这个数字。宇宙大爆炸的人们提供了这个数字。这到底是怎么回事？

@wilw (Wil Wheaton): yup, can confirm number on factorman0.blogspot.com actually from me. Big Bang folks provided number. something to this after all?

因子人

Factor Man

2017 年 11 月 8 日

November 8, 2017

威尔·惠顿。这有多酷？但威尔要求我考虑一些因素这一事实意味着我将得到更多的关注。是时候再次伸出援手了。这是我预计的第三次，总共是四次。

Wil Wheaton. How cool is that? But the fact that Wil had asked me to factor something meant that I was about to get a lot more attention. Time to reach out again. This was the third time of what I expected would be a total of four.

发件人：factor.man@yandex.com

From: factor.man@yandex.com

收件人：finnbrian@gmail.com

To: finnbrian@gmail.com

主题：你好

Subject: hello

亲爱的布莱恩：

Dear Brian:

我怀疑那些装模作样的人即将大批涌现，因此想在那之前尝试与你建立联系。

I suspect that the posers are about to come out in force, and wanted to try to connect with you before that happens.

我有一个商业建议给你。你愿意听吗？

I have a business proposition for you. Are you willing to listen?

调频

FM

发件人：Brian D Finn (finnbrian@gmail.com)

From: Brian D Finn (finnbrian@gmail.com)

收件人：Factor Man (factor.man@yandex.com)

To: Factor Man (factor.man@yandex.com)

回复：你好

Re: hello

始终愿意倾听。

Always willing to listen.

双向引流管

BDF

因素人：谢谢。

Factor Man: Thanks.

首先，我要声明的是，我使用的是不同的电子邮件地址，而不是我常用的 factorman0@gmail.com。这样做是为了确保额外的保护，以防 Gmail 帐户被黑客入侵。

First, let me acknowledge that I’m using a different email address for this, not my usual factorman0@gmail.com. I am doing this to ensure an additional level of protection, in case the Gmail account gets hacked.

但我是因子人。我将在明天的博客文章中计算的一个数字是 7973748292415255209。

But I am Factor Man. One of the numbers I will be factoring in tomorrow’s blog post is 7973748292415255209.

我想借一些钱，金额由您选择，在 500 万美元到 5000 万美元之间。对于您借给我的每 500 万美元，我都会在明年用我代码许可所得资金的 1% 偿还您，并在两年后的 Factor Man 揭幕晚会上付款给您。

I would like to borrow some money, an amount of your choosing between $5M and $50M. For each $5M you lend me, I will repay you with 1% of the funds received from the license to my code next year, with payment to you at the Factor Man coming out party two years after that.

如果许可费低于 5 亿美元（我认为这极不可能），我将偿还您原始贷款金额的两倍，但在任何情况下，我都不会偿还超过许可费总额的金额。

In the event that the license fee is less than $500M (which strikes me as incredibly unlikely), I will repay you double the original amount of the loan, but in no case will I repay you more than the total amount of the license fee.

在你仔细考虑这个问题的同时，我要补充一点，我是你认识和信任的人。如果你愿意，我会向你透露我的身份，但我强烈建议你不要听信我的话——这是为了你的幸福，而不是我的。我还指出，如果我想骗你，我只需入侵你的一个账户，然后骗你。但我迄今为止所做的一切（以及我计划在未来做的一切）都是合法和公平的。我无意改变这一点。

While you mull this over, let me add that I am someone whom you know and trust. I will reveal my identity to you if you want, but recommend fairly strongly that you not take me up on that – for your well-being, not mine. I also point out that if I wanted to rip you off, I would simply hack into one of your accounts and rip you off. But everything I have done so far (and everything I plan on doing in the future) is both legal and fair. I have no intention of changing that.

Finn：有趣。一些初步问题。您预计许可费最终会是多少？可能出现什么问题？

Finn: Interesting. Some initial questions. What do you expect the license fee to eventually be? What can go wrong?

Factor Man：很难根据许可费做出判断。如果让我猜的话，我会说在 100 亿美元到 1000 亿美元之间。所以我给你的回报是 20 倍，也许是 200 倍。

Factor Man: It’s hard to judge on the license fee. If I had to guess, I would say something between $10B and $100B. So I’m offering you a return of 20×, perhaps 200×.

很多事情都可能出错。最有可能的是我的身份被发现，然后事情就会以某种方式被揭穿。我不相信它会被发现（老实说，这封电子邮件是最薄弱的环节之一）。如果我的身份在许可协议完成后被发现，一切都应该没问题。如果在许可协议完成之前被发现，那就太糟糕了。

A lot can go wrong. Most likely is probably that my identity is discovered and things somehow unravel. I don’t believe that it will be discovered (in all honesty, this email is one of the weakest links). If my identity is discovered after the licensing deal is done, everything should still be ok. If it’s discovered before the licensing deal is done, it will be a mess.

芬恩：我怎样才能给你弄到钱呢？

Finn: How would I get you the money?

代理人：我会请你建立一个瑞士账户并转账。你会通过电话向我提供该账户的凭证。

Factor Man: I would ask you to establish a numbered Swiss account and transfer the funds. You would get me credentials for the account over the phone.

芬恩：电话？

Finn: The phone?

因素人：为毒贩工作。

Factor Man: Works for the drug dealers.

芬恩：那合同呢？

Finn: What about a contract?

代理人：我很乐意签署你起草的任何合理文件。但我将以代理人的身份签署，因此你的法律保护将受到限制。即使我以自己的身份签署，由于资金在海外，你的保护仍然有限。正如我所说，如果我想偷你的钱，我只会……偷你的钱。目前没有必要转移资金。我会通知你的。

Factor Man: I’m happy to sign whatever reasonable documents you draw up. But I’ll be signing as Factor Man, so your legal protections will be limited. Even if I signed as myself, with the money offshore, your protections would still be limited. As I’ve said, if I wanted to steal your money, I would just … steal your money. And there’s no need to transfer the funds at the moment. I’ll let you know.

芬恩：你什么时候需要答复？

Finn: When do you need an answer?

Factor Man：很快。我需要做一些具体的事情，而且博客即将受到广泛关注。对我（实际上对我们俩）的风险每天都在增加。你需要多长时间？

Factor Man: Soon. There are some specific things I need to do, and the blog is about to get a great deal of attention. The risk to me (to both of us, actually) goes up with each passing day. How long do you need?

芬恩： 一周就好。

Finn: A week would be good.

因素人：完成。

Factor Man: Done.

* * *

* * *

2017 年 11 月 19 日

November 19, 2017

Factor Man 博客

The Factor Man blog

5141777043983270623=3515691407×1462522289

5141777043983270623=3515691407 × 1462522289

（由 Suzanne Bonamici 请求）

(requested by Suzanne Bonamici)

(requested by Donald Knuth)

7354934760809584847=3529199239 × 2084023673

5361298675999551319=4043265371 × 1325982389

（由 Josephine McCall 请求）

(requested by Josephine McCall)

4912824077198864347=2508420991×1958532517

4912824077198864347=2508420991 × 1958532517

（道格拉斯·海勒要求）

(requested by Douglas Heller)

64 位数字将在两天内被分解。

64-bit numbers will be factored in two days.

该网站已被访问 63,917,708 次。

This web site has been visited 63,917,708 times.

事情确实在好转。博纳米奇是众议院科学、空间和技术委员会的成员。事实上，她是研究和技术小组委员会的成员。克努斯是斯坦福大学的退休教授，他公开表示相信 P=NP，但也认为“快速”算法不够快，无法发挥作用。鲁迪奇是卡内基梅隆大学的复杂性理论家，他已经证明了各种看似可以证明 P≠NP 的技术根本行不通。另外两个名字是未知数。

Things were definitely picking up. Bonamici was a member of the House Committee on Science, Space and Technology. In fact, she was a member of the subcommittee on Research and Technology. Knuth was a retired Stanford professor who was on record as believing that P=NP but also believing that the “fast” algorithms wouldn’t be fast enough to be useful. Rudich was a complexity theorist at Carnegie Mellon, and had shown that a wide range of techniques that looked like they might prove that P≠NP were simply never going to work. The other two names were unknowns.

* * *

* * *

发件人：Brian D Finn (finnbrian@gmail.com)

From: Brian D Finn (finnbrian@gmail.com)

收件人：Factor Man (factor.man@yandex.com)

To: Factor Man (factor.man@yandex.com)

回复：你好

Re: hello

好的。我同意以下条件。

OK. I will agree under the following conditions.

我的贷款金额为 2500 万美元。当你分解 128 位数字时，我将借给你 500 万美元，然后当你分解 148 位、168 位、188 位和 208 位时，我将再借给你 500 万美元。

The amount of my loan will be $25M. I will lend you $5M at the point that you factor 128-bit numbers, and then $5M more at 148 bits, 168 bits, 188 bits and 208 bits.

我们俩都可以访问这个编号的账户。如果您在任何时候未能计算出相关数字，我将提取剩余的所有资金，并且不再提供任何资金。您同意，如果您有理由相信我即将提取资金，您将不会亲自提取资金。

Both of us will have access to the numbered account. If you at any point fail to factor the numbers in question, I will withdraw whatever funds remain and contribute no more. You agree that if you have reason to believe that such a withdrawal by me is imminent, you will not withdraw the funds yourself.

您同意在技术竞标开始后不从账户中提取资金，并且只有在剩余资金加上最终许可费超过 5000 万美元时才可以随后提取资金。如果许可费加上剩余资金少于 5000 万美元，我将获得全部剩余资金和许可费。

You agree not to withdraw funds from the account after bidding starts for the technology, and to only withdraw funds subsequently if the remaining funds, together with the eventual licensing fee, exceed $50M. If the licensing fee plus the remaining funds is less than $50M, I get both the remaining money and the licensing fee in its entirety.

您还同意仅在需要时从编号账户中提取资金。

You also agree that you will withdraw money from the numbered account only as needed.

正如您所指出的，我们双方对此都抱有信任的态度。

As you point out, there is an element of trust in this for both of us.

让我感到些许安慰的是，只有当你已经证明有能力秘密地取走这些资金时，我才会投入资金。

I am taking some solace from the fact that I am only committing funds at the point that you have demonstrated an ability to remove them by stealth anyway.

双向引流管

BDF

来自：Factor Man

From: Factor Man

收件人：Brian D Finn

To: Brian D Finn

回复：你好

Re: hello

同意所有条款，但有一小点修改。请立即开立编号账户。我想在全世界都看到之前从您那里获取账户信息。请随意存入银行最低金额，在您存入第一个 500 万美元的余额之前，我不会提取任何款项。

Agreed on all counts, with one small modification. Please open the numbered account now. I would like to get the account information from you before the whole world is watching. Feel free to deposit the bank minimum, and I will not withdraw anything until you have contributed the balance of the first $5M.

完毕？

Done?

芬恩：完成了。

Finn: Done.

从某种意义上说，这里有两笔交易。布莱恩同意借给我 2500 万美元。我预计，最终我会偿还他 5 亿至 50 亿美元。

There were, in some sense, two transactions here. Brian had agreed to lend me $25 million. And I would, I expected, eventually repay him somewhere between $500 million and $5 billion as a result.

我需要 Finn 的钱吗？可能需要。因为 Hasday 的账单要付。Factor Man 出柜派对可能会有相关费用；如果有的话，这些费用无疑会相当可观。我当然希望在 Brian 交付这笔钱到我的身份在出柜派对上被揭晓后能够获得所有预期资金的这段时间里享受这 2500 万美元。

Would I need Finn’s money? I might. There would be Hasday’s bill to pay. There might be expenses associated with the Factor Man Coming Out Party; if there were, they would doubtless be substantial. And I was certainly hoping to enjoy the $25 million between the time Brian delivered it and the time when I could access all of my expected funds after my identity was revealed at the coming out party later on.

但这真的值五亿多美元吗？老实说，我没想到。我给布莱恩提供以牺牲我为代价获利的机会的真正原因是，作为 Factor Man 实在是太孤独了。

But was this really worth somewhere in excess of half a billion? In all honesty, I expected not. The real reason I offered Brian the opportunity to profit so at my expense was that being Factor Man was pretty damn lonely.

从根本上来说，除了丹尼斯，我不会和任何人分享它。

Fundamentally, I could share it with no one except Denise.

当然。我可以在博客上发布一些内容，让数百万人阅读。（我当时并不知道，但我的读者数量最终将超过除《圣经》之外的所有其他印刷文字。）但我无法真正与这些看不见的数百万人交谈，因为这不是真正的对话。Factor Man 之旅是一次极其私密的旅程。

Sure. I could post something on the blog and have it read by millions of people. (I didn’t know it at the time, but my readership would eventually pass that of every other printed word except the Bible.) But I couldn’t really talk to any of those unseen millions because it wasn’t an actual dialog. The Factor Man journey was an absurdly private one.

但现在布莱恩和我一起参与了。他会分担利润或损失，他会分担旅程。你可以说，5 亿美元对于一个同伴来说太贵了，我会回答说，虽然从这个角度看，这听起来很多，但从 Factor Man 企业的 5% 的税来看，这似乎很划算。

But now Brian was in on it with me. He would share in the profit or loss, and he would share in the journey. You can argue that $500 million is an awful lot to pay for a companion, and I will answer that while looking at it that way makes it sound like a lot, looking at it as a 5% tax on the Factor Man enterprise makes it seem a bargain.

两天后，布莱恩履行了自己的承诺。

Brian fulfilled his commitment two days later.

Finn：账户已开通。最低存款额 1000 美元。您希望我如何向您提供信息？

Finn: The account is open. $1K minimum. How would you like me to get you the information?

因素人：我需要一个电话号码。

Factor Man: I need a phone number.

芬兰人：516-662-2457

Finn: 516-662-2457

联系人：您将接到 218-367-9210 打来的电话。我不会说任何话。请直接向我提供相关信息。请仔细阅读两遍，以确保万无一失。现在方便吗？

Factor Man: You will receive a call from 218-367-9210. I will not say anything. Please simply provide me with the relevant information. Read it twice, just to make sure. Is now convenient?

芬恩：当然了。

Finn: Sure.

三天后，布莱恩收到了一个包裹。里面有一部手机（218-367-9210）、1000 美元现金和一张手写便条：“不想让你不必要地担心。”

Three days later, Brian got a package in the mail. It was a cell phone (218-367-9210), $1000 in cash, and a handwritten note: “Didn’t want you to worry unnecessarily.”

邮戳是丹佛。但除此之外，芬恩从未试图追踪过它。

The postmark was Denver. But beyond that, Finn never tried to trace it.

伯克特

Burkett

2017 年 12 月 2 日

December 2, 2017

随着博客越来越受欢迎，美国各地的人都试图利用它来获得他们一直想要的东西：名利。

As the blog gained in popularity, Americans far and wide tried to use it to get what they always wanted: fame and money.

名气一如既往地难以捉摸，因为博客上越来越多的是知名（有时是不太知名）的名人。这些人知道，博客一出现，他们的 Google 点击量就会达到数十万，他们的网站、Twitter 信息流或其他内容的浏览量也相当可观。在互联网时代，这些浏览量是这个领域的货币。

Fame was as elusive as usual, as the spots on the blog were increasingly taken by reasonably well-known (and sometimes less well-known) celebrities. These folks knew that as soon as the blog appeared, they would receive hundreds of thousands of Google hits, with comparable numbers of views on their web sites, Twitter feeds, or what have you. In the Internet age, those views are very much the coin of the realm.

当然，并不是每个名人都有数字。一位网络名人（她已经受到太多的负面报道，我不必在这里提及她的名字）抱怨她没有数字，最后有人问她如何选择要提交的数字。“这很容易，”她回答说，“我只需要在电子邮件中输入一个很长的数字。”

Of course, not every famous person had a number factored. An Internet celebrity (who has already gotten so much bad press that I needn’t name her here) complained bitterly about her absence, and was eventually asked how she selected a number to submit. “It was easy,” she answered, “I just stuck a really long number into an email.”

当然，并不是很多“非常长的数字”都具有所需的位数。其中，只有相对少数是两个质数的乘积。其中许多都不合适，因为因式分解问题太简单了。例如，一个由 2 和另一个质数相乘的数字显然是偶数（只要看看最后一位数字），而因式分解大师很难通过注意到（比如说）33330761460464216926 = 16665380730232108463 × 2 来提高他的声誉。

Of course, not many “really long numbers” have exactly the requisite number of bits. Of those, only a relative handful are the product of two primes. And of those, many are unsuitable because the factoring problem is too easy. A number that is the product of 2 and another prime, for example, is obviously even (just look at the last digit), and Factor Man would hardly enhance his reputation by noticing (say) that 33330761460464216926 = 16665380730232108463 × 2.

因此，提交一个符合 Factor Man 要求的数字的问题相当困难，而且随着所需数字的增加，难度会越来越大。几位富有创造力的数学家创建了一个小型家庭手工业，他们创建了 submittofactorman.com，只需 150 美元，您就可以获得一个保证符合 Factor Man 要求的数字。他们的客户几乎都是富人和名人，他们不太在乎 150 美元，但非常在乎自己的名字能出现在聚光灯下，无论时间有多短。

And so it turned out that the problem of submitting a number that met Factor Man’s requirements was reasonably difficult, and would get more so as the required numbers grew larger. A couple of inventive mathematicians created a small cottage industry by creating submittofactorman.com where, for the modest sum of $150, you could get a number that was guaranteed to conform to Factor Man’s requirements. Their clientele was pretty much exclusively the rich and famous, who cared little about the $150 but cared greatly about having their names in lights, however briefly.

毫不奇怪，这两位数学家原来是高中生。

The two mathematicians turned out, not surprisingly, to be high school students.

与此同时，英国人的赚钱方式却简单得多。

The British, meanwhile, had a much simpler way to make money.

人与政治市场

Factor Man and the Political Markets

威廉·伯克特，《纽约时报》

William Burkett, The New York Times

英国人会打赌任何事情，无论是美国政治竞选的结果还是女王在生日宴会上戴的帽子的颜色。在互联网上，你可以下注，比如 betfair.com。

The British will bet on anything, whether it’s the outcome of US political races or the color of the hat the queen will wear at her birthday party. There are Internet sites such as betfair.com where you can place such bets.

几周前，你可以对 Factor Man 下注。最初，博彩市场只是押注 Factor Man 能否成功实现他提出的 255 位目标。但这个市场变得非常不平衡（反对者占了上风），因此投注转向 Factor Man（当时正在分解 69 位数字）会失败的点。你可以押注 70 位或更少（没有那么多人接受这个数字）、71-100 位、101-130 位等。

As of a couple of weeks ago, you could bet on Factor Man. Initially, the betting markets were simply about whether Factor Man would succeed or fail to reach his stated 255-bit goal. But that market became incredibly lopsided (the nays had it), so the betting shifted to the point at which Factor Man (who was then factoring 69-bit numbers) would go down in flames. You could bet on 70 bits or less (not so many takers on that one), 71-100 bits, 101-130 bits, etc.

一些数学家（不是运营 submittofactorman.com 的孩子们，而是一些真正的数学家）表示，在研究了所有最新技术并做了大量工作之后，他们得出结论，一台大型个人计算机可以在 24 小时内分解一个 78 位数字。更大的数字不太可能分解。

Some mathematicians came along (not the kids running submittofactorman.com; some real mathematicians) and said that after a reasonable amount of work looking at all the latest techniques, they had concluded that a good-sized personal computer could factor a 78-bit number in 24 hours. Larger numbers were unlikely.

因此，他们预测，除非因子分解人发明了某种新数学，否则他在 78 位左右就会失去动力。这是假设他每天发布五种因式分解，每种分解都使用一台计算机。

So unless Factor Man had invented some new mathematics, they predicted, he’d run out of steam around 78 bits. That was assuming that he was devoting one computer to each of the five factorizations he published daily.

他们接着指出，因式分解是“可并行化的”，这意味着如果你有两台计算机，你几乎可以在每台计算机上完成一半的工作。因此，大致来说，将因式分解者拥有的计算机数量增加一倍，可以让他再成功一点。亚马逊可以在云端为他提供大量计算机，尽管这会很快变得昂贵。

They went on to point out that factorization was “parallelizable,” meaning that if you have two computers, you can (almost) do half the work on each one. So doubling the number of computers Factor Man had would, roughly speaking, let him succeed for one more bit. Amazon could provide him with lots of computers in the cloud, although it would get expensive fairly quickly.

数学家们得到了大量的宣传，而显而易见的结论是 100 比特超出了 Factor Man 的能力范围，因为根据上述分析，这需要大约 2000 万台计算机。71-100 比特的赌注大幅增加，其他赌注则全部减少。博彩市场做出了反应，将 71-100 比特的范围一分为二，其他一些范围则崩溃了。截至撰写本文时，以下是各个范围的赔率：

The mathematicians got a tremendous amount of publicity, and the obvious conclusion was that 100 bits was out of Factor Man’s reach, since it would require about twenty million computers according to the above analysis. There was a huge spike in the 71-100 bit bets, and all of the others trailed off. The betting markets responded, splitting the 71-100 range and collapsing some of the others. As of the time of this writing, here are the odds for the various ranges:

表格中显示，如果您押 1 美元赌因子人会在达到 81 位之前失败，那么 3.6:1 的赔率意味着如果您猜对了，您将获得 4.60 美元的回报（您最初的 1 美元赌注，加上 3.6 倍赌注的回报）。如果您押 1 美元赌因子人会在 81 到 90 之间失败，您将获得 1.70 美元的回报，依此类推。

To read the table, if you bet $1 that Factor Man will fail before reaching 81 bits, the odds of 3.6:1 mean that you’ll get paid $4.60 if you’re right (your original $1 bet, plus the payoff of 3.6 times that bet). If you bet the dollar that he’ll fail between 81 and 90, you’ll be paid $1.70, and so on.

因此普遍的看法是，因子人将在 81 到 90 位之间失败，而该特定赌注的回报将略低于一注金额。

So the prevailing wisdom is that Factor Man will fail somewhere between 81 and 90 bits, with that particular bet paying off slightly less than even money.

或者，我们可以使用几率来计算因子人能够分解任意特定大小数字的隐含概率。69 位数的概率为 1，因为他已经在分解了。但 128 位（互联网加密中使用的数字的常见大小）被认为只有 6% 的机会，而 256 位（因子人建议使用的数字大小）的可能性则更小。

Alternatively, we can use the odds to compute the implied probability that Factor Man can factor numbers of any particular size. The probability for 69-bit numbers is 1, since he’s already doing it. But 128 bits (a common size for numbers used for Internet encryption) are viewed as having only a 6% chance, and 256 bits (the size of the numbers Factor Man is suggesting be used instead) are a bit less likely still.

当然，民意调查可能不是找到答案的最佳方式。我们只能拭目以待。

Of course, public polling may not be the best way to find this out. All we’ve got to do is wait and see.

* * *

* * *

随着越来越多的人开始关注，问题也开始出现。

As ever more people started paying attention, questions started arising.

Factor Man 博客现在每天的点击量达到数百万次。假设（假设）有 5% 的访问者要求 Factor Man 为他们分解某个数字，Factor Man 每天仍需要筛选数十万条消息。他如何筛选出符合两个质数乘积标准的提交内容？很明显，他每天可以分解五个数字，但他能分解（或尝试分解）数十万个数字吗？

The Factor Man blog was now getting millions of hits every day. Assuming that (say) 5% of the visitors asked Factor Man to factor a number for them, Factor Man would still need to sift through hundreds of thousands of messages daily. How was he filtering for submissions that met the criteria of being products of two primes? It was clear he could factor five numbers daily, but could he factor (or attempt to factor) hundreds of thousands?

一旦他进行了过滤，他如何找到现在每天占据 Factor Man 博客主导地位的名人投稿呢？

Once he filtered, how was he finding the submissions from famous people, who were now dominating the Factor Man blog each day?

一位名叫 Alex Gunderson 的 Facebook 程序员对此有自己的想法。他猜测这个过程的一部分就是从电子邮件中取出姓名，然后在维基百科上查找。

A Facebook programmer named Alex Gunderson had an idea about this. What he suspected was that one part of the process was simply to get the names out of the emails, and look for them on Wikipedia.

于是，冈德森创建了一位名叫鲍勃·斯维克的演员，并给他创建了一个维基百科页面。斯维克是典型的二线角色演员，在大片中出演过很多小角色。他有照片（冈德森从随机选择的 Facebook 账户中抽取的），有背景故事，一应俱全。他还提交了一个数字，将其计入网页中。

So Gunderson created an actor named Bob Thwick and gave him a Wikipedia page. Thwick was your classic B-list character actor, lots of small parts in big films. He had pictures (that Gunderson pulled from a randomly selected Facebook account), a backstory, the whole deal. And he submitted a number to be factored on the web page.

2017 年 12 月 7 日

December 7, 2017

Factor Man 博客

The Factor Man blog

3108547364451513006637=66042197591×47069108507

3108547364451513006637=66042197591 × 47069108507

（应马克·鲁弗洛要求）

(requested by Mark Ruffalo)

2543180303080618090831=47952916709×53034945059

2543180303080618090831=47952916709 × 53034945059

（由丹妮卡·麦凯拉要求）

(requested by Danica McKellar)

3786123199377133637119=55426745599×68308596481

3786123199377133637119=55426745599 × 68308596481

（应约翰·马尔科维奇要求）

(requested by John Malkovich)

2867803314766004593513=51147568463×56069201351

2867803314766004593513=51147568463 × 56069201351

（应杰瑞·莫兰要求）

(requested by Jerry Moran)

3166843927185980711161=47315996341×66929668021

3166843927185980711161=47315996341 × 66929668021

（应 Michael Genesereth 要求）

(requested by Michael Genesereth)

明天将对 73 位数字进行分解。

73-bit numbers will be factored tomorrow.

罗伯特·思威克（Robert Thwick）不是真实存在的人。

Robert Thwick is not a real person.

该网站已被访问 163,337,480 次。

This web site has been visited 163,337,480 times.

Thwick 可能不是真人，但他的维基百科页面确实引起了很多关注。这些照片原来是住在堪萨斯州的某个名叫 Austin Simons 的人所发，而且几乎没费什么力气，这些照片就被追踪到了 Simons 的 Facebook 上。Thwick 维基百科页面本身是在几天前从属于 Facebook 的一个 IP 地址创建的。

Thwick might not have been a real person, but his Wikipedia page certainly got a lot of action. The pictures turned out to be some guy named Austin Simons who lived in Kansas, and it took almost no time at all for them to be tracked to Simons’ Facebook. The Thwick Wikipedia page itself had been created a few days prior from an IP address that belonged to Facebook.

此时，Facebook 介入并了解到这些图片都是用 Gunderson 的机器抓取的，并且创建维基百科页面的连接也是来自 Gunderson 的机器。

At this point, Facebook got involved, and learned that the pictures had all been scraped using Gunderson’s machine, and that the connection used to create the Wikipedia page was from Gunderson’s machine as well.

冈德森被解雇了，这是有记录以来第一次因为 Factor Man 博客而导致人们丢掉工作。

Gunderson was fired, the first recorded time that the Factor Man blog caused someone to lose his or her job.

与此同时，这五个人的名字也受到了一贯的关注。鲁法洛和马尔科维奇是众所周知的。麦凯勒曾主演过《奇迹年代》，后来获得了加州大学洛杉矶分校的数学博士学位。莫兰是参议院商务、科学和交通委员会委员。吉内塞雷斯是斯坦福大学的计算机科学系教师。

Meanwhile, the five names got the usual scrutiny as well. Ruffalo and Malkovich were well known. McKellar had starred in The Wonder Years and then gotten a Ph.D. in mathematics from UCLA. Moran was on the Senate committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation. Genesereth was computer science faculty at Stanford.

因子人

Factor Man

2018 年 3 月 16 日

March 16, 2018

Factor Man 博客地址为 factorman0.blogspot.com，因此该博客由 blogspot.com 托管。Blogspot 归 Google 所有。

The Factor Man blog address was factorman0.blogspot.com, so the blog was hosted by blogspot.com. Blogspot was owned by Google.

2018 年 3 月，谷歌更改了其主页，将我当前的 Factor Man 博客文章的副本以及常见的谷歌内容（包括广告）包含在内。两天后，Bing 和雅虎也做了同样的事情。谷歌首席执行官 Sundar Pichai 向媒体表示，由于 Factor Man 托管在谷歌网站上，雅虎和必应无权转播该页面。谷歌要求雅虎和必应将主页改回原来的样子。

In March of 2018, Google changed its home page so that it included a copy of my current Factor Man blog posting along with the usual Google stuff, including ads. Two days later, Bing and Yahoo did the same thing. Sundar Pichai, the Google CEO, commented to the press that since Factor Man was hosted on a Google site, Yahoo and Bing had no rights to rebroadcast the page. Google demanded that both Yahoo and Bing change their home pages back to what they had been.

这种事让我很恼火。

This sort of stuff ticks me off.

来自：factorman0@gmail.com

From: factorman0@gmail.com

收件人：sundar@google.com

To: sundar@google.com

主题：Factor Man 帖子

Subject: Factor Man postings

皮查伊先生：

Mr. Pichai:

我不反对您将我的内容放在您的主页上，但您必须向我提供每日点击次数，以便我可以更新 Factor Man 博客上的计数器。请将每日点击次数发送到此地址。

I have no objection to your putting my content on your homepage, provided that you provide me with daily hit counts so that I can update the counter on the Factor Man blog. Please send daily hit counts to this address.

与此同时，我也向 Bing 和 Yahoo 提出了类似的要求，希望他们能够满足我的要求。请撤回你向媒体提出的有关 Factor Man 内容转播权的评论。

Meanwhile, I am making similar requests of Bing and Yahoo, and expect that they will comply. Please retract your comments to the press regarding rebroadcast rights of Factor Man content.

调频

FM

发件人：Kris Stafford (kstafford@google.com)

From: Kris Stafford (kstafford@google.com)

收件人：Factor Man (factorman0@gmail.com)

To: Factor Man (factorman0@gmail.com)

回复：Factor Man 帖子

Re: Factor Man postings

我是谷歌的总法律顾问，您发给 Pichai 先生的电子邮件已转发给我。

I am the General Counsel for Google, and your email to Mr. Pichai was forwarded to me.

如果您查看 blogspot 的服务条款，您会发现其中包括以下内容：

If you look at the blogspot terms of service, you will see that they include the following:

当您上传或以其他方式向我们的服务提交内容时，即授予 Google（以及我们的合作伙伴）一项全球许可，允许其使用、托管、存储、复制、修改、创建衍生作品（例如，我们为使您的内容更好地与我们的服务配合使用而进行的翻译、改编或其他更改所产生的作品）、传播、发布、公开表演、公开展示和分发此类内容。您在此许可中授予的权利仅限于运营、推广和改进我们的服务以及开发新的服务。

When you upload or otherwise submit content to our Services, you give Google (and those we work with) a worldwide license to use, host, store, reproduce, modify, create derivative works (such as those resulting from translations, adaptations or other changes we make so that your content works better with our Services), communicate, publish, publicly perform, publicly display and distribute such content. The rights you grant in this license are for the limited purpose of operating, promoting, and improving our Services, and to develop new ones.

Google 点击数统计是专有的，恐怕我们无法与您分享。

Google hit counts are proprietary and I am afraid we will not be able to share them with you.

发件人：Factor Man (factorman0@gmail.com)

From: Factor Man (factorman0@gmail.com)

收件人：Kris Stafford (kstafford@google.com)

To: Kris Stafford (kstafford@google.com)

回复：Factor Man 帖子

Re: Factor Man postings

你把事情搞混了。我敦促你重新考虑你的回复，但只给你三天时间。到时候我会发布附件。

You are confusing the tail and the dog here. I urge you to reconsider your response, but will only give you three days to do so. At that time I will post the attached.

调频

FM

由于 Google（blogspot 的母公司）的顽固行为，我决定将 Factor Man 博客移至一个单独托管的域。Bing 和 Yahoo 将继续被允许在其主页上复制 Factor Man 博客，但 Google 则不行。

Because of intransigent behavior on Google's part (the parent of blogspot), I have decided to move the Factor Man blog to a separately hosted domain. Bing and Yahoo will continue to be permitted to reproduce the Factor Man blog on their home pages, but Google will not.

我知道，我知道。为什么要向谷歌脸上踢沙子呢？

I know, I know. Why kick sand in Google’s face?

这是性格缺陷。我生长在一个犹太家庭，犹太人有领地意识。有人拿走你的东西，你就拿回去。有人打你，你就还手。（“要加倍狠”，我父亲经常这样对我说。）

It’s a character flaw. I was brought up in a Jewish household, and Jews are territorial. Someone takes your stuff, you take it back. Someone hits you, you hit them back. (“Twice as hard,” my father often told me.)

这一政策在中东地区几个世纪以来一直行之有效。

It’s a policy that’s worked great for centuries in the Middle East.

但是，没错，向海滩上最强壮的人脸上踢沙子通常是一个错误。我花了很长时间才发现这是一个多大的错误。

But yes, kicking sand in the face of the biggest guy on the beach is generally a mistake. I wouldn’t find out for a while just how big a mistake it had been.

发件人：约翰·托马斯（jthomas@google.com）

From: John Thomas (jthomas@google.com)

收件人：Factor Man (factorman0@gmail.com)

To: Factor Man (factorman0@gmail.com)

抄送：Kris Stafford (kstafford@google.com)

CC: Kris Stafford (kstafford@google.com)

回复：Factor Man 帖子

Re: Factor Man postings

自我们开始收录您的博客以来，Google 主页的点击次数如下：

The number of hits to the Google home page since we started including your blog were as follows:

第 1 天：34,342,817（这是部分日期）

day 1: 34,342,817 (this was a partial day)

第二天：298,322,184

day 2: 298,322,184

第 3 天：287,219,350

day 3: 287,219,350

第四天：302,128,322

day 4: 302,128,322

第 5 天尚未结束。将来，您将自动从 dataservices@google.com 收到这些数据。Bing 和 Yahoo 也有权转发您的博客。

Day 5 is not yet complete. In the future, you will be receiving this data automatically from dataservices@google.com. Permission is granted for both Bing and Yahoo to repost your blog as well.

3

3

伯克特

Burkett

2018 年 4 月 3 日

April 3, 2018

碳阴谋论开始出现。最流行的两种说法是，Factor Man 实际上是 NSA 制造的骗局，以及他是亚马逊制造的骗局。这两种说法都不太合理，但阴谋论者从未因此而气馁。

Conspiracy theories began to spring up. The two most popular ones were that Factor Man was in fact a hoax perpetrated by the NSA, and that he was a hoax perpetrated by Amazon. Neither of these really made much sense, but conspiracy theorists have never been daunted by that.

NSA 理论是阴谋论中最容易被接受的理论，阴谋论者通常将几乎所有事情都视为 NSA 阴谋。其观点是，美国政府负责密码学和类似事务的部门 NSA 的科学家很久以前就破解了公钥加密。他们多年来甚至几十年来一直在利用这一成果监视美国人民。出于某种原因，NSA 决定现在是时候让全世界知道公钥加密不再安全了，而 Factor Man 是他们首选的（而且极富想象力的）方式。

The NSA theory was the lowest hanging fruit of the conspiracy world, which generally views pretty much everything as an NSA conspiracy. The notion was that scientists at the NSA, the branch of the US government that deals with cryptography and similar things, had actually cracked public key encryption long ago. They had been using the results to spy on the American people for years, if not decades. For one reason or another, the NSA had decided now was the time to let the world know that public key encryption was no longer secure, and Factor Man was their preferred (and incredibly imaginative) way of doing so.

美国国家安全局让全世界知道这件事的动机很模糊，尽管一个典型的暗示是，某个外国（可能是朝鲜）也即将破解公钥加密，而美国国家安全局希望每个人都尽快转向更安全的系统。如果朝鲜有人对复杂性理论有所了解，这将会更有意义，但他们不知道。事实上，世界上绝大多数复杂性理论家都是美国人。

The NSA’s motivation for letting the world know was vague, although a typical suggestion was that a foreign country (probably North Korea) was also about to crack public key encryption and the NSA wanted everyone to move to a more secure system as briskly as possible. This would have made more sense if anyone in North Korea had known a damn thing about complexity theory, but they did not. In fact, the vast majority of the world’s complexity theorists were Americans.

亚马逊理论的根源在于，Factor Man 实际上是 submittofactorman.com 背后的人。毕竟，他在引起商业兴趣之前一直在计算的数字并没有显示出任何技术突破。一旦他引起了名人的兴趣，他就可以通过 submittofactorman.com 向他们提出问题，而没有人会更聪明。

The Amazon theory had its roots in the idea that Factor Man was actually the guy behind submittofactorman.com. After all, the numbers he had been factoring before there was all the commercial interest didn’t show any technological breakthroughs. Once he got celebrities interested, he could just feed them problems through submittofactorman.com and no one would be the wiser.

那些相信这一理论的人在看到运营 submittofactorman.com 的两个高中生出现时并不感到惊慌。他们说，这两个孩子只是 Factor Man 的骗子。

The folks who subscribed to this theory were unfazed when the two high school kids running submittofactorman.com showed up. They were just Factor Man dupes, they said.

更严重的问题是，许多被分解的数字并非来自 submittofactorman.com。众议院和参议院委员会成员没有使用该网站；计算机科学家也没有使用该网站。Factor Man 如何处理他没有生成的查询？

A more serious problem was that many of the numbers being factored didn’t come from submittofactorman.com. Members of House and Senate committees weren’t using the site; nor were computer scientists. How could Factor Man be dealing with queries that he wasn’t generating?

亚马逊就是这样。亚马逊拥有大量可用的计算资源，可以利用这些资源来查找大量因式分解。因此，他们可以整理出一份包含数百万个 65 位数字及其因式的列表，然后当所有 Factor Man 查询出现时，他们可以仔细选择那些已知因式分解的查询。亚马逊的动机仍然有点模糊，但他们至少有足够的资金来完成整个事情。

Enter Amazon. Amazon had a ton of computing resources available, and could be using those resources to find large numbers of factorizations. So they could put together a list of millions of 65-bit numbers and their factors, and then when all of the Factor Man queries appeared, they could carefully select ones for which the factorizations were already known. Amazon’s motives remained a bit obscure, but they at least had the wherewithal to pull the whole thing off.

如果你愿意投入一万台计算机来提前分解数字，那么如果一千名名人提交 64 位查询，你很有可能得到五个答案。但情况很快就变得更糟了；你需要五十万台计算机来处理 70 位数，而大约七百万台计算机来处理 74 位数。当谷歌将博客放在主页上时，亚马逊理论已经开始消亡了。

If you were willing to devote ten thousand computers to the task of factoring numbers in advance, it turned out that you would have a pretty good shot at having five answers available if a thousand famous people submitted 64-bit queries. But it got worse quickly; you would need half a million computers to deal with 70-bit numbers, and about seven million to deal with 74-bit numbers. By the time Google put the blog up on its home page, the Amazon theory was beginning to die out.

当然，联邦政府仍然是嫌疑人。

The federal government, of course, remained a suspect.

* * *

* * *

随着阴谋论者的出现，垃圾邮件发送者和网络钓鱼者也随之而来。

With the conspiracy theorists came the spammers and the phishers.

来自：factorman1809@gmail.com

From: factorman1809@gmail.com

收件人：randybooker34@yahoo.com

To: randybooker34@yahoo.com

主题：因素 人类脆弱性

Subject: Factor Man vulnerability

亲爱的布克先生：

Dear Mr. Booker:

互联网上流传着这样一个事实：我可以侵入任何使用计算机进行银行业务的人的银行账户；我可以侵入任何使用计算机进行电子商务的人的信用卡账户。

The Internet is abuzz with the fact that I can break into the bank account of anyone who uses their computer for banking. I can break into the credit card account of anyone who uses their computer for electronic commerce.

开发这项技术的成本很高，我需要收回成本。我很快就会联系大型银行和电子商务企业，并收取一定费用，让他们的账户持有人不受任何影响。

Developing this technology has been expensive, and I need to recover my costs. I will shortly be approaching the big banks and e-commerce businesses and, for a fee, offering to leave their account holders alone.

他们无疑会支付这笔费用并将其转嫁给你。但对于每月 2.99 美元的低得多的费用，我保证无论你的银行做出什么决定，你的账户都会保持安全。希望你能意识到，在这个不确定的世界中，为了安全而付出的代价是微不足道的。

They will undoubtedly pay this fee and pass it along to you. But for the much smaller fee of $2.99/month, I will guarantee that whatever your bank decides, your accounts will stay safe. Hopefully you will realize that this is a small price to pay for security in this uncertain world.

如需安排付款，请访问 factormanprotectsme.com。

To arrange payment, please visit factormanprotectsme.com.

还有：

There was also:

发件人：keep.you.safe.1287@yahoo.com

From: keep.you.safe.1287@yahoo.com

收件人：jtibalt@hotmail.com

To: jtibalt@hotmail.com

主题：因素 人类脆弱性

Subject: Factor Man vulnerability

亲爱的 JTibalt：

Dear JTibalt:

我想您也知道，有人声称能够破解保护互联网和您的个人信息安全的密码。

As I expect you know, an individual is claiming to be able to break the codes that keep the Internet -- and your personal information -- safe.

这是一个严重的问题。我们公司已经开发出可以保护您的技术，Visa 已聘请我们将这些信息整合到您的帐户中。一旦完成，您就不必担心 Factor Man（或任何其他人）入侵您的帐户并窃取您的个人信息或更糟的情况。

This is a serious concern. Our company has developed technology that can protect you, and Visa has hired us to incorporate this information into your account. Once this is done, you won't have to worry about Factor Man (or anyone else) hacking into your accounts and stealing your personal information or worse.

虽然我们的服务需要收费，但费用由 Visa 支付。要利用此机会，请访问 cybersecurityexperts345.com 并向我们提供必要的信息。您也可以拨打 844-329-2170 并通过电话安全地提供此信息。

Although there is a fee for our service, it is being paid by Visa. To take advantage of this opportunity, please visit cybersecurityexperts345.com and provide us with the necessary information. You can also call 844-329-2170 and provide this information securely by telephone.

大多数关注该博客的人现在每天至少会查看一次，而且通常通过 Google、Yahoo 和 Bing 主页查看的次数更多。对网络钓鱼的响应非常迅速。

Most people following the blog were now viewing it at least once a day, often much more through the Google, Yahoo and Bing home pages. The response to the phishing was brisk.

Factor Man 博客

The Factor Man blog

2018 年 4 月 11 日

April 11, 2018

1422685117127153401593640884254479 = 49079419489494001 × 28987407184628479（小罗伯特·唐尼要求）

1422685117127153401593640884254479 = 49079419489494001 × 28987407184628479 (requested by Robert Downey, Jr.)

2041776769070582681051741728195247 = 63564318042197221 × 32121429631560707 (哈里森·福特要求)

2041776769070582681051741728195247 = 63564318042197221 × 32121429631560707 (requested by Harrison Ford)

1499021642350970659394747462291749 = 58907834462498419 × 25446897785816071 (Douglas Hofstadter 请求)

1499021642350970659394747462291749 = 58907834462498419 × 25446897785816071 (requested by Douglas Hofstadter)

1305158243226719473024165382500769 = 41058336573096571 × 31787898686619539（奥利维亚·穆恩要求）

1305158243226719473024165382500769 = 41058336573096571 × 31787898686619539 (requested by Olivia Munn)

1422388632034281494481472570177801 = 43277705260893391 × 32866544643705511 (由 David McAllester 请求)

1422388632034281494481472570177801 = 43277705260893391 × 32866544643705511 (requested by David McAllester)

112 位数字需要三天才能分解出来。

112-bit numbers will be factored in three days.

我注意到，某些人正试图利用这个博客谋取私利。这些企图通常有两种类型：(1) 有人自称是我，并威胁要破坏人们的安全，除非支付某种赎金；(2) 有人提供针对我的技术的保护，以换取费用或私人信息。

It has come to my attention that certain individuals are attempting to exploit this blog for their own financial gain. These attempts appear to generally be of two types: (1) Individuals claiming to be me and threatening to breach people’s security unless some sort of ransom is paid, and (2) individuals offering protection against my technology in exchange for a fee or private information.

让我尽可能公开地否认这两点。首先，我永远不会向任何人索要钱财或个人信息。我只向别人借过一次钱，那是几个月前的事了。其次，我掌握的技术不是你能保护自己的东西。我鼓励银行和其他企业改变加密方法，因为这是保护你和你的信息的唯一方法。

Let me disavow both of these as publicly as possible. First, I will never ask anyone for either money or personal information. I have asked someone to lend me money exactly once, and that was months ago. Second, the technology that I have in hand is not something against which you can protect yourself. I am encouraging banks and other businesses to change their encryption methods precisely because that is the only way in which you and your information can be safeguarded.

如果有人被这些人骗了，我会知道的。如果你是骗子，我建议你立即停止并归还你获得的任何资金或信息。如果你不这样做，我会说出你的名字，更改你的金融账户密码，并公开新密码。这其中也包括你，匹兹堡 Steelers Blvd 222 号 3B 公寓的 John Farnsworth。

If people are being ripped off by these folks, I will hear about it. If you’re the one doing the ripping off, I suggest you stop immediately and return any funds or information that you have obtained. If you do not, I will name you, change the password on your financial accounts, and make the new password public. That includes you, John Farnsworth of 222 Steelers Blvd in Pittsburgh. Apartment 3B.

该网站已被访问过 67,299,231,222 次。

This web site has been visited 67,299,231,222 times.

网络钓鱼停止了，法恩斯沃思的生活大大恶化，对神秘放贷人的追捕开始了。

The phishing stopped, Farnsworth’s life deteriorated considerably, and the hunt for the mysterious lender began.

* * *

* * *

科学家正在改变对所谓“因子人”的看法

Scientists Changing Views on so-called “Factor Man”

威廉·伯克特，《纽约时报》

William Burkett, The New York Times

这位自称“因数人”的博主正在赢得一些追随者。他声称自己能够分解大数，换句话说，就是产生两个数，当它们相乘时，会得到提供给他的某个原始数。如果这是真的，这将对整个现代社会产生深远的影响，因为这项技术将允许其持有者解密互联网上几乎所有的秘密信息。

The blogger known only as “Factor Man” is winning over some converts. He claims to be able to factor large numbers; in other words, to produce two numbers that, when multiplied together, produce some original number supplied to him. If true, this would have profound implications across modern society, since this technology would allow its holder to decrypt virtually every secret message passing around the Internet.

此外，因数分解人声称使用的技术非常通用。他说，他不仅能够分解大数，而且几乎可以解决任何问题，只要答案一旦产生，就可以被识别为正确答案。如果你能识别出一首伟大的交响乐，他也能创作出一首。描述一种新药的预期效果，他也能创作出它。这种技术的影响甚至比简单地破解所有密码更为深远。

What’s more, the technique Factor Man claims to be using is a stunningly general one. Not only is he able to factor large numbers, he says, but he can solve virtually any problem where the answer, once produced, can be recognized as correct. If you can recognize a great symphony, he can produce one. Describe the desired effect of a new drug, and he can produce that, as well. Such technology would have ramifications even more profound than simply breaking all of the codes.

大约一年前，当因子人首次提出这些主张时，科学家们对此表示怀疑。然而现在，他似乎正在公开展示他所谓的能力，他分解了由相对无懈可击的第三方（如参议院科学委员会成员）提供的数字，而且数字规模如此之大，以至于最优秀的计算机科学家都无法复制他的结果。

When Factor Man first made these claims about a year ago, scientists were skeptical. Now, however, he appears to be providing a public demonstration of his purported abilities, factoring numbers provided by relatively unassailable third parties (such as members of the Senate Science Committee) and of such a size that the best computer scientists have been unable to duplicate his results.

卡内基梅隆大学的计算机科学家史蒂文·鲁迪奇从事类似领域的工作，他对“因子人”的能力没有很好的解释。“这很难解释，”他说。“很难想象一位著名的科学家会采取这种表演方式，但也很难想象他还能用其他什么方式做到这一点。”奇怪的是，鲁迪奇是一位技艺精湛的业余魔术师。

Steven Rudich, a computer scientist at Carnegie Mellon who works in a similar area, has no good explanation for Factor Man’s abilities. “It’s difficult to explain,” he says. “It’s hard to imagine a reputable scientist taking the approach of such a showman, but it’s also hard to imagine how else he might be doing this.” Rudich, curiously enough, is an accomplished amateur magician.

美国国土安全部也在认真对待“人因数”。在最近的新闻发布会上，国土安全部部长威廉·芬戈尔德说：“在当今世界，网络战争与常规战争一样危险。如果一个人有能力侵入国防所必需的计算机系统，那么他显然是一个重大威胁，并将受到同等对待。话虽如此，我们所有的关键防御系统都具有安全措施，不能仅仅通过计算几个大数就被绕过。”

The US Department of Homeland Security is taking Factor Man seriously as well. In a recent press conference, DHS Secretary William Fingold said, “In today’s world, cyber warfare is just as dangerous as conventional warfare. An individual with the demonstrated capability to penetrate the computer systems essential for our national defense is obviously a significant threat and will be treated as such. That said, all of our critical defense systems have safeguards that could not be bypassed simply by factoring a few large numbers.”

Judith Banyon 是亚马逊信息安全项目经理，负责管理一支由 300 多名工程师组成的团队，这些工程师在被考虑录用之前必须获得最高机密的安全许可。“亚马逊对所有网络安全威胁都十分重视，”她告诉我们。“无论这位 Factor Man 掌握着什么技术，我都相信我们客户的私人信息将保持私密。”

Judith Banyon is the program manager for Information Security at Amazon, responsible for a team of over 300 engineers who are required to hold top-secret security clearances before being considered for a job. “Amazon takes all cyber security threats seriously,” she told us. “Whatever technology this Factor Man has at his disposal, I’m confident that the private information of our customers will remain private.”

Factor Man 特别建议亚马逊等公司从 128 位加密转换为 256 位加密。当被问及此事时，Banyon 表示，亚马逊自 2014 年以来一直使用 256 位加密作为其标准，并正在努力确保在转换时不会忽略任何系统。

Factor Man has specifically recommended that companies like Amazon switch from 128-bit to 256-bit encryption. When asked about this, Banyon said that Amazon has used 256-bit encryption as its standard since 2014, and was working to ensure that no systems had been overlooked when the transition occurred.

人因数是否影响电子商务？

Is Factor Man Impacting E-Commerce? A Little

威廉·伯克特，《纽约时报》

William Burkett, The New York Times

因子人再次成为新闻焦点。他的网站访问量已接近 800 亿次。四个月前，我报道过他能够分解任意大小的数的可能性。由于他现在正在分解 114 位数字，所以大部分内容都无关紧要。但几个月前人们的看法是，如果因子人能走到这一步，他很可能能够兑现自己的承诺。这种看法仍然存在。英国博彩市场又回到了“因子人是”和“因子人不是”的简单状态。目前，两者的赔率相当接近，而“不是”略有优势。

Once again, Factor Man is all the news. His web site has been visited almost eighty billion times. Four months ago, I reported on the perceived likelihood that he be able to factor numbers of any particular size. As he is now factoring 114-bit numbers, most of this is irrelevant. But the perception from a couple of months back was that if Factor Man got this far, he would quite possibly be able to deliver on his claims. That perception remains. The British betting markets have gone back to simply “Factor Man yes” and “Factor Man no.” The odds on both are currently quite close to even, with “no” having a slight edge.

人们似乎也更加关注这个问题。例如，美国通过互联网进行的商业活动比例通常会随着时间的推移而稳步增长。自从 Factor Man 的主张获得支持以来，这一比例一直没有变化。这是一个很小的影响，但足以引起人们的注意。

People seem to be paying attention in more profound ways as well. As an example, the fraction of US commerce conducted over the Internet normally increases steadily over time. Since Factor Man’s claims gained traction, that fraction has been unchanged. This is a small effect, but large enough to be noticeable.

同样，随着我们用信用卡做越来越多的生意，信用卡交易总量通常每年都在攀升。每年的增幅几乎都在 7% 左右。2009 年的情况则大不相同，当时经济大衰退导致信用卡使用量下降了 10 % 。

On a similar note, the total volume of credit card transactions typically climbs each year, as we use our cards for more and more business. The increase is almost always around 7% annually. Things were very different in 2009, when the great recession caused a 10% drop in credit card use.

虽然上个季度信用卡使用量没有出现实际下降，但增幅更接近 3%，而非通常的 7%。人们使用信用卡的次数似乎比预期的要少一点。

While the past quarter hasn’t shown an actual drop, the increase has been much closer to 3% than the usual 7%. People appear to be using their credit cards just a little bit less than might have been expected.

这在多大程度上可以归因于“人为因素”？很难说。也许一点都不能。但考虑到目前互联网安全性的不确定性，如果人们决定更频繁地在实体店购物并使用现金，这并不奇怪。

How much of this is attributable to Factor Man? It’s hard to say. Maybe none of it. But given the current uncertainty regarding the security of the Internet, it wouldn’t be a surprise if people decided to shop at brick and mortar stores, and to use cash, just a tad more often.

4

4

刘

Liu

2018 年 5 月 3 日

May 3, 2018

电视通往目的地的道路往往曲折蜿蜒，而非短小精悍。我参与 Factor Man 的故事确实是走了一条迂回曲折的路。

The paths that lead us to our destinations are more often winding than they are short. My involvement in Factor Man’s story was by a circuitous route indeed.

我叫 Janet Liu。我一生致力于报效祖国。

My name is Janet Liu. I spend my life in the service of my country.

我于 1992 年出生在北京郊区的永顺。当时，中国家庭只允许生一个孩子，女孩几乎不受父母宠爱。许多女孩在分娩时神秘死亡。许多女孩被西方外国人悄悄收养。只有极少数女孩被允许在自己的祖国长大。我就是其中之一。

I was born in 1992 in the Beijing suburb of Yongshun. Chinese families were then only allowed to have one child, and female children were hardly prized by their parents. Many mysteriously died in childbirth. Many were quietly adopted by Western foreigners. Relatively few were permitted to grow up in their homeland. I was one of them.

我的父母选择养育我，并不是因为他们爱上怀里的小女儿，而是因为他们觉得这是他们的爱国责任。我从小就被教育爱国比爱家更重要。

My parents chose to raise me not because they fell in love with the baby girl in their arms, but because they felt it was their patriotic duty to do so. I was taught from infancy that love of country is more important than love of family.

我认识到，从道德角度看，一心一意地做事能让人获得极大的自由。对中国有利的就是好的，对中国不利的就是不好的。就这么简单。有人告诉我，我的智力相当高，我只需照照镜子就知道，我的物质财富也相当可观。所有这些天赋都完全由中国支配。

Singlemindedness of purpose, I have learned, is wonderfully freeing from an ethical perspective. What is good for China is good. What is not good for China is not good. It is that simple. I have been told that my intelligence is considerable, and I need only examine a mirror to know that my physical assets are considerable as well. All of these gifts are entirely at China’s disposal.

请不要以为我是某种机器人，盲目地服从政权的命令。这真是大错特错。我只是一个才华横溢的女人，深爱自己的国家，一生致力于为国家提供所需的一切。也许，在好日子里，你也会这样做。

Please do not imagine that I am some sort of automaton, following the orders of the regime with mindless devotion. Nothing could be further from the truth. I am simply a talented woman who loves her country deeply, and who has committed her life to providing what her country needs. Perhaps, on a good day, you would do the same.

从 2004 年到 2009 年，也就是我青少年时期的大部分时间，我家都驻扎在伦敦的中国大使馆，我也住在那里。从 2009 年底开始的四年里，我在哈佛大学读书。我的英语非常流利，而且没有口音。

From 2004 through 2009, most of my teenage years, my family was stationed with the Chinese embassy in London, and I lived there. For four years beginning in late 2009, I attended Harvard University. The result is that my English is excellent and unaccented.

尤其刚开始的时候，我在西方的生活很艰难。如果用一个词来概括这个问题，我会说西方社会很混乱。

Especially at first, I found my time in the West difficult. If I were to summarize the issue in a single word, I would say simply that Western society is disorganized.

也许举个例子会有所帮助。我可以去哈佛广场的银行，让他们把 150 美元兑换成人民币。他们会很乐意这样做，并给我大约 1000 元人民币。交易大约需要五分钟。

Perhaps an example will help. I can go into my bank in Harvard Square and ask them to convert $150 to Chinese yuan. They will happily do so, and will give me approximately 1000 yuan in return. The transaction will take about five minutes.

我可以去北京的银行，让他们把 1000 元兑换成美元。他们也会很乐意这样做，我得到的钱将接近开始时的 150 美元。交易大约需要一个小时，我需要填写各种表格，说明兑换的原因。

I can go into my bank in Beijing and ask them to convert the 1000 yuan back into dollars. They will also happily do so, and I will receive close to the $150 with which I began. The transaction will take approximately an hour, and I will need to complete a variety of forms indicating the reason for the exchange.

这本该如此。如果我要求将本币兑换成外币，政府对我的意图感兴趣是理所当然的。他们担心我计划的行动不符合中国人民的利益，这是合理的。

This is as it should be. If I am requesting a conversion of local into foreign currency, it is appropriate for the government to take an interest in my intentions. It is reasonable for them to be concerned that I plan actions that are not in the interests of the Chinese people.

我曾多次与哈佛的同学讨论这个问题，他们似乎觉得中国的做法削弱了我的个人自由。我反驳说，正是中国社会固有的组织赋予了我们自由。与美国相比，我们没有犯罪。我们没有国际恐怖主义。生活在恐惧中的人民肯定永远不会自由。

I had many occasions to discuss this with my fellow Harvard students, who seemed somehow to feel that the Chinese approach diminished my personal freedom. I would counter that it is the organization implicit in Chinese society that grants us our freedom. Compared to the United States, we are free from crime. We are free from international terrorism. A population living in fear is surely never free.

中国并不是独裁政权。我们的领导人是根据宪法原则和民主做法选举产生的。诚然，共产党是这些选举的唯一参与者，但如果你想参与其中，你只需要加入该党，正如我的 8200 多万同胞所做的那样。

It is not as if China is a dictatorship. Our leaders are elected according to the tenets of our constitution, and following democratic practices. It is true that the Communist Party is the only participant in those elections, but if you wish to be involved, all you need do is join that party, as more than 82 million of my countrymen have done.

我在哈佛大学的大部分时间都希望能遇到对美国和我对中国一样有同感的同学，但我失望了。这些学生似乎要么是理想主义者，想要拯救整个世界，要么就是以自我为中心，希望通过当医生、律师或互联网大亨发财致富。那些希望发财的人在我看来更真诚，但没有一个人对美国本身忠诚。考虑到美国政治的分裂状态，这也许不应该让我感到惊讶。如果真是这样，那这又是另一个支持中国这种制度的理由。

I spent much of my time at Harvard hoping to meet fellow students who felt about the United States the way I feel about China, but I was disappointed. The students seemed to be either idealists, out to save the entire world, or simply self-centered, hoping to get rich as doctors, lawyers, or Internet tycoons. The ones hoping to get rich struck me as more genuine, but no one was devoted to the United States itself. Given the fractured state of American politics, perhaps this should not have surprised me. If so, that is yet another argument in favor of a system such as China’s.

* * *

* * *

虽然我当时并不知道，但我对 Factor Man 故事的了解第一步是由 Factor Man 自己迈出的。他没有尊重谷歌总法律顾问 Kris Stafford。而 Stafford 先生是一位期望得到尊重的人。

Although I did not know it at the time, the first step of my journey into the Factor Man story was taken by Factor Man himself. He failed to respect Kris Stafford, the Google general counsel. And Mr. Stafford was a man who had come to expect respect.

斯塔福德认为，他是全球最大、最有实力的公司之一的总法律顾问。他毕业于哈佛大学，但并不是理想主义者。毕业后，他进入耶鲁大学法学院，后来成为纽约的助理地区检察官。他曾担任多家高科技公司的总法律顾问。他不想被别人看作是“Factor Man”的狗尾巴草。

Stafford’s view was that he was the general counsel for one of the largest and most powerful firms on the planet. He had graduated from Harvard and was not one of the idealists. From there, he had attended Yale Law before becoming an assistant district attorney in New York. He had been general counsel for a host of high-tech companies. He wasn’t about to be thought of as the tail on anyone’s dog, let alone Factor Man’s.

斯塔福德做的第一件事就是派人检查 Factor Man 的所有电子邮件。他这么做的法律依据并不牢固，但只是不牢固，而不是彻底陷入困境。

The first thing Stafford did was to have someone examine all of Factor Man’s email. He was on shaky legal ground in doing this, but only shaky as opposed to outright quicksand.

Google 的服务条款确实赋予了 Google 使用 Factor Man 电子邮件的权利，前提是这样做是为了改进 Google 技术。Stafford 可以辩称，保证 Google 加密技术的安全当然是必要的。

The Google terms of service did indeed give Google the right to use Factor Man’s emails, provided that doing so was for the purpose of improving Google technology. Keeping Google encryption technology safe would certainly count, Stafford could argue.

斯塔福德很清楚，谷歌的服务条款在这方面受到了质疑，多名原告声称这些条款违反了美国的窃听法。美国地方法院法官驳回了谷歌的驳回诉讼动议，但这只意味着谷歌需要数年时间才能在法庭上获胜，而不是几个月。法官还拒绝承认原告为集体诉讼，这意味着他们每个人都必须单独起诉谷歌。没有多少个人原告有足够的能力在法庭上挑战谷歌。

As Stafford well knew, Google had been challenged on its terms of service in this regard, with a variety of plaintiffs claiming that the terms violated US wiretap laws. A US District Court judge had denied Google’s motion to have the lawsuit dismissed, but that meant only that it would take Google years to prevail in court as opposed to months. The judge had also denied recognition of the plaintiffs as a class, which meant that they would each have to sue Google individually. Not many individual plaintiffs had the wherewithal to challenge Google in court.

查阅 Factor Man 的电子邮件并没有让 Stafford 得到太多信息。只有两个名字值得关注：William Burkett，Factor Man 在外界的原始联系人，以及 Bob Hasday，他在 Duane Morris 的律师。Stafford 暗暗记下，有机会时要检查一下 Hasday 的法律背景。

Looking through the Factor Man emails didn’t tell Stafford much. There were only two names of interest: William Burkett, Factor Man’s original contact in the outside world, and Bob Hasday, his attorney from Duane Morris. Stafford made a mental note to check Hasday’s legal background when he had the chance.

但总的来说，他并没有发现什么。

All told, though, he didn’t find much.

斯塔福德正在思考这个问题，他的行政助理打断了他。他被告知外面有一名谷歌技术人员。一名名叫鲍勃·科瓦奇的员工收集了 Factor Man 的电子邮件。科瓦奇声称有几个斯塔福德先生可能会感兴趣的想法。

Stafford was pondering this when his administrative assistant interrupted him. There was a member of Google’s technical staff outside, he was told. An employee named Bob Kovacs who had gathered the Factor Man emails. Kovacs claimed to have a few ideas that Mr. Stafford might find interesting.

斯塔福德把他带进来，向我了解 Factor Man 故事迈出了第二步。“我按照你们的要求提取了电子邮件，”Kovacs 开始说道。他解释说，他（不用说，还有大多数其他员工）一直在关注 Factor Man 的故事。他们一致认为，Factor Man 在某种程度上对 Google 的业务构成了威胁。互联网安全很重要，支持它符合 Google 的利益。Kovacs 解释说，他有一个想法，但不确定它是否合法。

Stafford brought him in, taking the second step on my path into the Factor Man story. “I pulled the emails like you guys requested,” Kovacs began. He explained that he (and, needless to say, most of the other staff) had been following the Factor Man story. Their collective view was that Factor Man was, in some poorly defined way, a threat to what Google did. Internet security mattered, and supporting it was in Google’s interests. Kovacs explained that he had an idea, but wasn’t sure it was legal.

斯塔福德笑了。“我是谷歌的首席法律顾问。我向你保证两件事。第一，谷歌绝不会做任何违法的事情。第二，你不能通过与我分享想法来做违法的事情。让谷歌走上正轨是我的职责，不是你的。”

Stafford smiled. “I’m Google’s chief counsel. Let me assure you of two things. First, Google won’t ever do anything illegal. Second, you can’t do something illegal by sharing a thought with me. Keeping Google on the straight and narrow is my job, not yours.”

科瓦奇想了想。最后他说：“这是中国。”

Kovacs considered. “It’s China,” he finally said.

“中国？”

“China?”

“中国。首先，人为因素肯定让他们抓狂。我的意思是，他们掌握的秘密比任何人都多。大约每个月，他们都会试图入侵谷歌一次，”科瓦奇解释道。“就像每个人都知道是他们。政府知道是他们，公众知道是他们，我们当然知道是他们。每个人都知道。这通常不是什么大事。我们在攻击开始时就看到了，没有任何东西被泄露。”科瓦奇紧张地再次停了下来。

“China. First off, Factor Man has to be just driving them nuts. I mean, they have way more secrets than anyone else. About once a month, they try to hack into Google,” Kovacs explained. “Like, everybody knows it’s them. The government knows it’s them, the public knows it’s them, we certainly know it’s them. Everybody. It’s generally not a big deal. We see the attack as it starts, and nothing is compromised.” Kovacs, nervous, stopped again.

“然后呢？”斯塔福德追问道。

“And?” Stafford prodded.

“那么，如果我们不那么警惕会怎么样？”

“Well, what if we weren’t quite so vigilant?”

“我们不能让外人获取我们的内部信息。”

“We can’t give an outsider access to our inside information.”

“我们不必这么做。如果有人入侵了一个电子邮件帐户，他们对 Google 其余部分的访问权限不会比帐户持有者多。”

“We wouldn’t have to. If someone were to compromise a single email account, they wouldn’t have any more access to the rest of Google than the account holder did.”

“谢谢你，鲍勃。让我考虑一下。”

“Thank you, Bob. Let me think about it.”

科瓦奇离开了，斯塔福德也确实考虑过这件事。

Kovacs left, and Stafford did indeed think about it.

伯克特

Burkett

2018 年 5 月 22 日

May 22, 2018

128 位加密失败，国家恐怖主义警报系统启动

National Terrorism Advisory System Activated as 128-bit Encryption Fails

威廉·伯克特，《纽约时报》

William Burkett, The New York Times

今天，Factor Man 博客提供了 128 位数字的因数分解，NTAS 第三次启动。发布公告称，似乎存在能够破解用于保护美国商业所依赖的大量安全数据的加密方案的技术。

With the Factor Man blog providing factorizations of 128-bit numbers today, the NTAS was activated for the third time. A bulletin was issued to the effect that technology appears to exist that is capable of breaking the encryption schemes used to protect much of the secure data on which American commerce depends.

NTAS 于 2011 年推出，取代了备受诟病的“红黄绿”国土安全警告系统。根据 NTAS，可以发布四种类型的警报：高级警报、中级警报、紧急警报和公告。前三种警报对应于有具体和可信证据表明可能发生恐怖袭击的情况。第四种“公告”类别用于“分发有关趋势和非特定威胁的信息”。

The NTAS was introduced in 2011, replacing the much-maligned “red-yellow-green” Homeland Security Advisory System. Under the NTAS, four types of alerts can be issued: elevated, intermediate, imminent, and bulletins. The first three correspond to situations where specific and credible evidence suggests that a terrorist attack may occur. The fourth “bulletin” class is used to “distribute information about trends and non-specific threats.”

美国国土安全部在发出警告时明确表示，没有理由相信这项技术（如果存在的话）掌握在与美国利益相悖的特工手中。他们在一份声明中表示：“事实上，我们掌握的所有信息都表明，没有人计划将这项技术用于非法目的。我们鼓励所有公民继续照常生活。”

The Department of Homeland Security, in issuing the warning, made it clear that there was no reason to believe that the technology, should it even exist, was in the hands of agents whose interests ran counter to those of the United States. They said in a statement, “In fact, all of the information we have indicates that there are no plans to use this technology for illegal purposes. We encourage all citizens simply to continue business as usual.”

根据 NTAS 公告，对 Factor Man 博主的搜寻似乎将进一步加强。目前，政府仍表示在寻找他（或她，视具体情况而定）方面尚未取得任何进展。

Given the NTAS bulletin, it seems that the search for the Factor Man blogger is likely to intensify even further. At this point, the government continues to say that there has been no progress in finding him – or her, as the case may be.

因子人

Factor Man

2018 年 5 月 23 日

May 23, 2018

发件人：Brian Finn (finnbrian@gmail.com)

From: Brian Finn (finnbrian@gmail.com)

收件人：Factor Man (factor.man@yandex.com)

To: Factor Man (factor.man@yandex.com)

主题：首笔 500 万美元存款

Subject: First $5M deposited

如果可能，请确认已收到

Please acknowledge receipt, if possible

双向引流管

BDF

发件人：Factor Man (factor.man@yandex.com)

From: Factor Man (factor.man@yandex.com)

收件人：Brian Finn (finnbrian@gmail.com)

To: Brian Finn (finnbrian@gmail.com)

回复：首笔 500 万美元存款

Re: First $5M deposited

确认的。

Confirmed.

调频

FM

我喜欢拼图。只是我不确定我有多喜欢这个。

I love puzzles. I just wasn’t sure how much I loved this one.

有两个圈子。一个圈子包括 Brian Finn、我、瑞士银行的账号，以及我用来与 Brian 交流的 Yandex 电子邮件地址，但不包括其他人。另一个圈子包括 Bob Hasday、Gmail 账户、保险箱，以及据我所知的整个文明世界。

There were two circles. One included Brian Finn, me, the numbered Swiss account, and the Yandex email address that I used to communicate with Brian but no one else. The other included Bob Hasday, the Gmail account, the safe deposit box and, for all I knew, the rest of the civilized world.

第二圈的 Factor Man 需要钱。我可能需要钱来为自己辩护，或者为今后的安排做准备。我肯定需要钱来支付 Hasday 的费用，也许还需要组织几年后举行的出柜派对。第一圈的 Factor Man 有钱，这是 Brian Finn 提供的。我只需要把钱从一个圈送到另一个圈。

The Factor Man in the second circle was going to need money. I might need it to defend myself, or to make arrangements going forward. I would definitely need it to pay Hasday, and perhaps to organize the coming out party that was still a few years away. The Factor Man in the first circle had money, courtesy of Brian Finn. I just had to get it from one circle to the other.

我认为一百万美元就足够了。我的计划是假设整个第二圈——Hasday、Gmail 帐户和保险箱——已被盗用。但我还假设第一圈——Finn、Yandex 电子邮件地址和瑞士银行帐户——是安全的。

I figured a million dollars would suffice. My plan was to assume that the entire second circle – Hasday, the Gmail account, and the safe deposit box – had been compromised. But I also was going to assume that the first circle – Finn, the Yandex email address, and the Swiss bank account – was safe.

主要是，如果第一个圆圈中的任何元素与我相关联，它们都会与我相关联。Finn 本人和瑞士银行账户自然会相互关联。Yandex 电子邮件账户会指向 Finn。

Mostly, this was because if any element of the first circle became associated with me, they all would be. Finn himself and the Swiss bank account would naturally lead to one another. The Yandex email account would lead to Finn.

问题是，如果 Finn 和 Factor Man 有关系，我的身份很可能会被发现。我不得不假设人们知道我联系过 William Burkett，我强烈怀疑我是 Burkett 和 Finn 的联系人名单上唯一的人。

And the problem was that if Finn were known to have a relationship with Factor Man, my identity would likely be discovered. I had to assume that people knew I had reached out to William Burkett, and I suspected strongly that I was the only person on both Burkett’s and Finn’s contact lists.

所以我有这两个圈子。理论上，两个圈子都是秘密的。但实际上，只有一个圈子是秘密的。我必须将一百万美元从一个圈子转移到另一个圈子，并且不能泄露任何秘密。

So I had these two circles. In theory, both were secret. But in practice, only one probably was. I had to move a million bucks from one to the other without compromising anything.

转账可能必须以现金进行，很简单。银行转账受到的监控实在太严密了，即使在瑞士这样据称可以保证匿名的地方也是如此。瑞士账户有编号，但瑞士人仍然知道账户所有者的身份，并且在政府压力下表现出完全愿意公布这些信息。所以必须以现金进行。

The transfer would presumably have to be in cash, plain and simple. Banking transfers are simply too well monitored, even in places like Switzerland that supposedly guarantee anonymity. The Swiss account was numbered, but the Swiss still knew the identity of the owner and had shown themselves totally willing to release that information under government pressure. So cash it had to be.

我可以使用快递，但这种方法存在多个问题。首先，我必须找到并联系快递员。这两个电子邮件帐户都无法解决这个问题。

I could use a courier, but there were multiple problems with that approach. First, I would have to find and contact the courier. Neither email account would work for that.

但更重要的是，我并不清楚第一次携带一百万美元的信使是否值得信任。我可以用愤怒的法宝威胁他，但携带一百万美元现金的信使可能会选择直接放弃网络并退休到加勒比海。

More important, though, it wasn’t obvious to me that a first-time courier carrying a million bucks could be trusted. I could threaten him with the wrath of Factor Man, but a courier carrying a million in cash might choose to simply drop off the net and retire to the Caribbean.

所以，我决定当快递员。我用自己的名义买了一张去苏黎世的往返机票，准备待两周。美国的监控摄像头比瑞士少，所以我走进一家高端魔术店，买了一顶好假发。然后我就出发了。

So the courier was going to be me. I bought a plane ticket to Zurich, a round trip in my own name for a two-week stay. There were fewer security cameras in the States than there would be in Switzerland, so I walked into a high-end magic store and bought a good wig. And off I went.

发件人：Factor Man (factor.man@yandex.com)

From: Factor Man (factor.man@yandex.com)

收件人：Brian Finn (finnbrian@gmail.com)

To: Brian Finn (finnbrian@gmail.com)

回复：首笔 500 万美元存款

Re: First $5M deposited

请告诉苏黎世，一名快递员将在五天内从该账户中提取 100 万美元现金（欧元）。

Please tell Zurich that a courier will be withdrawing $1M in cash (Euros) from the account in five days.

回答你显而易见的问题：（1）我是快递员，（2）我可能需要资金来继续运营。如果我确实需要这些资金，我很可能很快就会需要它们，所以我会把它们转移到一个我可以更轻松地访问的账户上。

To answer your obvious questions: (1) I am the courier, and (2) I may need the funds for continued operations. If I do need them, I am likely to need them fairly quickly, so I am moving them to an account I can access a bit more easily.

调频

FM

5

5

刘

Liu

2018 年 5 月 24 日

May 24, 2018

米林胡勇 (博士，斯坦福大学，2003 年) 是中国人民解放军第四部部长。第四部专注于计算机漏洞，通常简称为信息战组 (IWG)。林胡勇本人直接向后勤保障部赵章将军汇报，赵章将军是中央军委委员。中央军委控制着解放军和中国军队的其他部门。

My immediate superior in the Chinese military is Lin Hu Yong (Ph.D., Stanford, 2003), who directs the Fourth Department of the Chinese People’s Liberation Army, or PLA. The Fourth Department focuses on computer vulnerabilities and is generally known simply as the Information Warfare Group, or IWG. Lin himself reports directly to General Zhao Zhang of the Logistic Support Department, who is a member of the Central Military Commission, or CMC. The CMC controls the PLA and the remainder of China’s military.

我们不信任西方。中国自史前时代起就是世界强国，而西方在世界舞台上才刚刚崭露头角。从上个世纪的事件来看，我们看不到任何迹象表明西方对世界存在所伴随的责任抱有适当谦逊的态度。如果这种傲慢导致西方采取不负责任的行动，中国需要做好准备。

We do not trust the West. China has been a world power since prehistory, while the West is a relative newcomer to the world stage. Based on the events of the past century, we see little to reassure us that the West has an appropriately humble attitude toward the responsibilities that accompany a world presence. If this hubris causes the West to act irresponsibly, China needs to be prepared.

林的工作是准备（但希望永远不要实施）针对西方国家尤其是美国的网络攻击。他还负责日常工作，即通过渗透军事和商业企业来测试美国和其他西方国家的防御能力。

Lin’s job is to prepare for – but hopefully never to conduct – a cyberattack on the West in general and on the United States in particular. He is also responsible for the day-to-day business of testing American and other Western defenses by penetrating military and commercial enterprises.

中国这样做似乎是众所周知的事情。2015 年 9 月，美国总统奥巴马明确将中国的网络活动描述为侵略行为，并告诉中国，如果这种行为继续下去，美国“准备采取一些反制措施”。中国对威胁的反应很差，我们的行为没有改变。

It seems to be relatively common knowledge that China is doing this. In September of 2015, your American President Obama explicitly described Chinese cyber activities as an act of aggression and told China that America was “prepared to take some countervailing actions” if the behavior continued. China responds poorly to bluster, and our behavior was unchanged.

2015年9月25日，奥巴马与中国国家主席习近平举行会晤。会晤后，奥巴马宣布两国领导人“一致同意，无论是美国还是中国政府，都不会进行或故意支持通过网络窃取知识产权，包括商业机密或其他机密商业信息，以获取商业优势”。

On September 25, 2015, Obama met with his counterpart, Chinese President Xi Jingping. After the meeting, Obama announced that the two leaders had “agreed that neither the U.S. nor the Chinese government will conduct or knowingly support cyber related theft of intellectual property including trade secrets or other confidential business information for commercial advantage.”

为了商业利益而采取的行动与维护中国主权和独立的必要行动有着天壤之别。在林郑月娥的领导下，网络活动依然没有改变。

There is a great difference between activities taken to achieve a commercial advantage and activities essential to preserve Chinese sovereignty and independence. The cyber activities under Lin’s direction continued without alteration.

部分活动涉及被称为“因素人”的个人。我们认为“因素人”对中国构成威胁，原因有三。

Part of those activities involved the individual known as Factor Man. We view Factor Man as a threat to China for three distinct reasons.

首先，中国本身依赖于信息分类的能力。我们的广大民众不需要知道很多事情。实际上，他们最好不要知道这些事情。所谓的“因子人”技术可能会极大地影响我们向民众提供对他们最重要的信息的能力。

First, China herself depends on the ability to compartmentalize information. There are many things that our population at large need not know. In actuality, they are often better off not knowing these things. The supposed Factor Man technology could significantly impact our ability to provide our populace with only the information that is most important to them.

其次，人性因素似乎只是一个人，对国家或整个世界没有总体责任。我们认为，他声称控制的技术所隐含的权力不应该掌握在一个人的手中。

Second, Factor Man appears to be an individual, with no overarching responsibilities to a state or to the world in general. We do not believe that the power implicit in the technology he claims to control should be in the hands of a single man.

最后，很明显，如果这项技术存在，它应该平等地提供给所有国家。我们不能接受 Factor Man 的明显计划，即首先将信息提供给商业实体，然后提供给美国政府，并在首次发布两年后才提供给世界其他国家。这种偏见简直令人无法容忍。

Finally, it is clear that this technology, should it exist, should be available equally to all nations. We cannot accept Factor Man’s apparent plan of making the information available first to a commercial entity, then to the government of the United States, and to the rest of the world only two years after the initial release. This sort of bias is simply intolerable.

不幸的是，Factor Man 本人的知名度极低，我们很难以任何方式与他互动。他活动的唯一公开足迹是 factorman0 Gmail 帐户。赵将军亲自指示我们获取该帐户的访问权限，但直到最近，我们才成功做到这一点。

Unfortunately, Factor Man himself has an extremely small profile, and it has been challenging for us to interact with him in any way. The only public footprint of his activities is the factorman0 Gmail account. General Zhao himself has instructed us to obtain access to that account, but until recently, we had not succeeded in doing so.

当你登录计算机账户时，你需要输入密码。该密码经过加密并通过互联网发送到你试图访问的计算机。

When you log into a computer account, you enter your password. That password is encrypted and sent out over the Internet to the computer that you are trying to access.

加密算法是公开的，加密密码本身也容易受到攻击。如果我能猜出你的密码，我就可以用同样的算法加密它，然后确认我确实复制了你自己发送的内容。这样做需要我一开始就猜出你的密码，这就是为什么每个人都被告知要让他们的密码比“密码”或他们的狗的名字或类似的东西更复杂。

The encryption algorithm is public, and the encrypted password itself is also vulnerable. If I can guess your password, I can encrypt it using the same algorithm, and then confirm that I have indeed reproduced what you yourself were sending. Doing this requires that I guess your password at the outset, which is why everyone is always told to make their passwords more complicated than “password”, or their dog’s name, or something along those lines.

在林的指导下，IWG 建立了一个庞大的密码猜测数据库，以及密码的加密版本。数据库中包含了所有英文单词，以及所有可能的大写模式。流行的密码修改也包含在数据库中，例如用“p@$$w0rd”代替简单的“password”。如果您的密码在 IWG 数据库中，我们就能在您使用密码时猜出密码。

Under Lin’s direction, the IWG has built a huge database of guesses, along with their encrypted versions. Every English word is in the database, with every possible pattern of capitalization. So are the modifications that have become popular, like “p@$$w0rd” instead of simply “password.” If your password is in the IWG database, we can figure it out as we see you using it.

第二部分也有些挑战性。当你向 Google 发送消息时，它不会直接到达那里。它首先会发送到你的互联网服务提供商 (ISP)。消息本身标记为：“请将此发送给 Google。”当然，它并没有确切地说出这一点；Google 有一个所谓的 IP 地址，对于 Google 来说，它是 172.217.3.174。你的 ISP 有自己的 IP 地址；例如，AT&T 的 IP 地址是 144.160.36.42。

That second part can be somewhat challenging as well. When you send a message to Google, it doesn’t go directly there. It first goes to your Internet Service Provider, or ISP. The message itself is labeled: “Please deliver this to Google.” Of course, it doesn’t say that exactly; Google has what is called an IP address which, in Google’s case, is 172.217.3.174. Your ISP has its own IP address; for example, AT&T’s is 144.160.36.42.

可以这样理解这些地址：它们就像普通地址，只是读法相反。Google 的总部（不是他们处理电子邮件的地方，但适合作为例子）位于美国加利福尼亚州山景城 Amphitheatre Parkway 1600 号。Google IP 地址末尾的 174 对应于 1600 Amphitheatre Parkway 街道地址；IP 地址开头的 172 对应于“美国”。Google IP 地址 172.217.3.174 实际上是“美国，加利福尼亚州，山景城，Amphitheatre Parkway 1600 号”。

The way to think of these addresses is that they are like normal addresses, but read backwards. Google’s headquarters (not where they process email, but appropriate as an example) are located at 1600 Amphitheatre Parkway, Mountain View, California, USA. The 174 at the end of the Google IP address corresponds to the 1600 Amphitheatre Parkway street address; the 172 at the beginning of the IP address corresponds to “USA”. It is as if the Google IP address of 172.217.3.174 actually reads, “USA, California, Mountain View, 1600 Amphitheatre Parkway.”

想象一下，当您的 ISP（地址为 144.160.36.42）收到发往 Google 的电子邮件时会发生什么。它会查看目标地址（在本例中为 172.217.3.174），它首先会问：“这与原始地址相同吗？”（144.160.36.42）如果相同，则可以立即处理该邮件，因为您尝试发送的邮件实际上不需要传输到任何地方。

Consider what happens when your ISP, at 144.160.36.42, gets your email message destined for Google. It looks at the destination address (in this case, 172.217.3.174) and the first thing it asks is, “Is this the same as the originating address?” (144.160.36.42) If it is, the message can be dealt with immediately, since you’re trying to send a message that doesn’t actually need to travel anywhere.

但在这种情况下，这还不够。您的 ISP 接下来将您的消息发送到所谓的路由器。它首先到达的路由器知道所有地址类似于 144.160.36.x 的计算机（其中x是某个值）。如果您的消息只发送到其中一个地址，那么第一个路由器就可以处理它。

In this case, however, that is insufficient. Your ISP next sends your message to what is called a router. The router it goes to first knows about all of the computers whose addresses look like 144.160.36.x for some value of x. If your message had only been going to one of those addresses, the first router could have handled it.

但事实并非如此；它要发往 Google，而 Google 比 Google 更远。因此，路由器会将您的消息发送到第二个路由器。这台路由器就像一个相当大的邮局；它可以处理发往 144.160.xy 中任意位置的邮件，现在x和y是任意的。这也行不通，所以第二个路由器会将您的信件发送到“国家”清算所，它知道 144 域中的所有信息，也就是说任何格式为 144.xyz 的地址

But it wasn’t; it was going to Google, which is further away than that. The router therefore sends your message to a second router. This one is like a fairly large post office; it can handle mail going to anywhere in 144.160.x.y, now for arbitrary x and y. That does not work, either, so the second router sends your letter to the “national” clearinghouse, which knows about everything in the 144 domain, which is to say any address of the form 144.x.y.z.

这仍然不起作用。因此，您的消息最终会发送到全球清算所，在那里，这个过程被逆转。全球清算所将消息发送到负责 172.xyz 的计算机，该计算机查看目标地址以决定将其发送到负责 172.217.xy 的邮局。然后，它转到 172.217.3.x，最后（尽管整个过程通常需要不到一秒钟）它找到了通往原始目的地 172.217.3.174 的路径。Google 收到该消息，并将其发送给预期收件人。

That still does not work. So your message finally goes to a global clearinghouse, where the process is reversed. The global clearinghouse sends the message to the computer responsible for 172.x.y.z, and that computer looks at the destination address to decide to send it to the post office responsible for 172.217.x.y. Then it goes to 172.217.3.x and finally (although this entire process typically takes less than a second) it finds its way to the original intended destination of 172.217.3.174. Google has the message, and delivers it to the intended recipient.

尽管信息是加密的，但第四部门希望在信息从一台机器传输到另一台机器时对其进行监控。为了做到这一点，我们需要在某个地方拦截信息，而拦截方法多种多样。

Even though the messages are encrypted, we at the Fourth Department want to watch them as they are transmitted from one machine to another. In order to do that, we need to intercept them somewhere, and there are a variety of ways to do this.

例如，我们可以进入一家中等规模的邮局，直接告诉邮局复印它处理的每封邮件。然而，这通常风险高得令人无法接受，因为邮局随后会开始向中国大陆发送大量邮件，而这些邮件的流量很难解释。因此，我们很少采用这种方法。但路由机器离中国大陆越近，这个过程就越容易（也更容易解释）。因此，我们拦截从埃及发给谷歌的邮件的可能性要比拦截从旧金山发给谷歌的邮件的可能性大得多。

We could, for example, make our way into one of the moderate-sized post offices and simply tell that post office to make a copy of every message that the post office handled. That is generally unacceptably risky, however, because the post office would then start sending a great number of messages to mainland China, and the traffic would be awkward to explain. This is therefore an approach that we take only rarely. But the closer the routing machine gets to mainland China, the easier (and easier to explain) the process becomes. We are therefore much more likely to intercept a message sent to Google from Egypt than one sent from San Francisco.

在 Factor Man 首次分解 128 位数字的几个小时前，我们很幸运。我们截获了一条发给 Google 的消息，其中包含登录凭据，并出现在我们的可能密码数据库中。我们特别幸运的是，该密码属于一个拥有访问其他 Google 信息所需权限的帐户。

A few hours before Factor Man first factored 128-bit numbers, we were fortunate. We intercepted a message to Google that both included login credentials and appeared in our database of possible passwords. And we were exceptionally fortunate in that the password was to an account that had the privileges needed to access other Google information.
