此类账户的保质期有限。首先，用户总是有可能简单地更改密码。但最重要的是，一旦我们登录账户，用户就会被告知该账户正在其他地方使用，并且登录地点不寻常。我们从随机选择的国家/地区登录，因此活动被追溯到中国的可能性很小，但我们仍倾向于在有限的时间内下载尽可能多的信息。

Accounts such as this have a limited shelf life. First, there is always the chance that the user will simply change his or her password. Primarily, however, once we log into the account, the user is informed both that the account is in use elsewhere and that a login has occurred from an unusual location. We log in from a location in a randomly selected country, so there is little chance of the activity being traced back to China, but we still tend to have a limited window in which to download as much information as possible.

经过与团队的简短讨论，我们决定下载三件东西。首先，我们将获得整个 factorman0 文件。然后，我们将获得 Factor Man 登录其 Google 帐户的所有互联网地址。最后，我们将下载尽可能多的其他 Google 用户的信息。这些信息将被加密（当然），但仍有可能在我们不断增长的密码数据库中找到一两个密码。在连接中断之前，我们获得了 Factor Man 数据和几十万个密码。

After a brief discussion with my team, we decided to download three things. First, we would get the entire factorman0 file. After that, we would get all of the Internet addresses from which Factor Man had logged into his Google account. And finally, we would download information for as many other Google users as possible. That information would be encrypted (of course), but it still might be possible to find a password or two in our ever-growing password database. We got the Factor Man data and a few hundred thousand passwords before the connection was cut.

分析完所有数据后，我发现了三件事：

After all of the data was analyzed, I found myself with three things:

• William Burkett 和 Robert Hasday 的名字，

• The names William Burkett and Robert Hasday,

• Factor Man 访问其帐户的地址，以及

• The addresses from which Factor Man had accessed his account, and

• 电话号码。

• A phone number.

电话号码是最容易追踪的。当你开设 Google 帐户时，你必须提供一个手机号码。然后 Google 会向你发送一条激活帐户所需的消息。虽然互联网上有一些免费的手机“号码”，但它们都曾多次被用来开设 Google 帐户，而 Google 现在拒绝了这些号码。最终结果是，如果不向 Google 提供你实际拥有的手机号码，就很难开设 Gmail 帐户。Factor Man 似乎就是这么做的，现在我有了他用过的电话号码。

The phone number was the easiest to trace. When you open a Google account, you have to provide a cell phone number. Google then texts you a message that you need in order to activate the account. While there are some free cell “numbers” on the Internet, all of them have been used many times to open Google accounts, and Google now rejects them. The net result is that it’s tough to open a Gmail account without giving Google the number of a cell phone that you actually have in your possession. Factor Man appeared to have done just that, and now I had the number of the phone he had used.

不幸的是，这个号码原来是一部在加利福尼亚州圣何塞市沃尔玛用现金购买的一次性手机。它只被使用过一次，用来激活 Factor Man 的 Gmail 帐户。我通过查看手机 ping 到的手机信号塔，得到了一个大概的位置，这有助于缩小到圣何塞机场的半径范围，或多或少。所有这些都不值得我从可以访问 Verizon 和沃尔玛记录的工作人员那里得到好处。

Unfortunately, the number turned out to be a burner phone bought with cash at a Wal-Mart in San Jose, California. It had been used exactly once, to activate Factor Man’s Gmail account. I got an approximate location by seeing which cell towers were pinged by the phone, which served to reduce the radius to San Jose airport, give or take. None of this was worth the favors I had to redeem from operatives with access to Verizon’s and Wal-Mart’s records.

Factor Man 用来访问其 Google 帐户的地址更好一些，因为我可以在地图上找到它们，但同样没用。

The addresses Factor Man had used to access his Google account were better in that I could find them on a map, but equally useless.

当有人发送电子邮件时，他们的计算机必须将其发送到 Google。它会从德克萨斯州的计算机发送到圣路易斯的计算机，然后发送到波特兰的计算机，再发送到俄勒冈州的达尔斯，最后到达那里的 Google 服务器。

When someone sends an email, their computer has to send it to Google. It’ll go from a computer in Texas, say, to one in St. Louis, then one in Portland, then to The Dalles, Oregon, and then to a Google server there.

所有这些地址都已记录在案，因此可以获取收到的电子邮件并将其追溯到德克萨斯州的发件人。根据发件人的计算机连接性质，您可以将其追溯到特定机器或相当小的机器网络。

All of these addresses are recorded, so it is possible to take the incoming email and trace it back to its origin in Texas. Depending on the nature of the sender’s computer connection, you can trace it back to a specific machine, or to a fairly small network of machines.

不幸的是，Factor Man 连接了希腊、德国、俄罗斯和许多其他国家。他使用的机器与一种名为 TOR 的计算机浏览器相关联。TOR 代表“洋葱圈”浏览器。当您使用 TOR 查看网页时，您会从一台 TOR 机器转到另一台 TOR 机器，然后最终“登陆”您真正感兴趣的网站。不可能解开这些机器到机器的跳跃来找出原始用户的物理位置。

Unfortunately, Factor Man had connected from everywhere: Greece, Germany, Russia, and many other countries. He had been using machines associated with a computer browser called TOR. TOR stands for “The Onion Ring” browser. When you look at a web page using TOR, you get directed from one TOR machine to another before finally “landing” at the web site in which you are really interested. It is impossible to unwind these machine-to-machine hops to figure out where the original user had been physically located.

剩下的只有伯克特和哈斯戴。伯克特被证明是无用的，Factor Man 在事情真正开始之前就联系过这位记者。哈斯戴更有价值。

That left Burkett and Hasday. Burkett proved to be useless, a reporter that Factor Man had contacted before any of this really began. Hasday was much more valuable.

发件人：Robert Hasday (rjhasday@duanemorris.com)

From: Robert Hasday (rjhasday@duanemorris.com)

收件人：Factor Man (factorman0@gmail.com)

To: Factor Man (factorman0@gmail.com)

回复：新客户？

Re: new client?

尊敬的先生/女士：

Dear Sir/Madam:

附有一封留置信。

A retention letter is attached.

由于您要求的关系性质特殊，我们希望您能提前为我们提供一定数额的定金。也许 10,000 美元比较合适？

Because of the unusual nature of the relationship that you have requested, we would like to ask that you provide us with some sort of retainer in advance. Perhaps $10,000 would be appropriate?

我非常好奇您为我们安排的工作性质。

I am very curious as to the nature of the work that you have for us.

鲍勃·哈斯戴

Bob Hasday

Factor Man 并未联系过任何其他律师，因此他大概支付了 10,000 美元的费用并聘请了 Hasday。

Factor Man hadn’t reached out to any other lawyers, so he had presumably paid the $10,000 fee and retained Hasday.

鉴于美国社会诉讼猖獗的本质，您的律师绝不会丢弃任何东西。聘金的信函，或许还有支票的副本，可能都存放在 Duane Morris 办公室的某个地方。电子版可能存放在 Duane Morris 服务器上。

Given the absurdly litigious nature of American society, your lawyers never discard anything. The cover letter for the retainer, and perhaps a copy of the check, would be somewhere in the Duane Morris offices. Electronic copies might exist on the Duane Morris servers.

但信函的价值要大得多。如果没有其他可用的东西，信封也可能有用。两者都是物证。它们可能带有指纹或 DNA 痕迹。

But the cover letter would be far more valuable. Even the envelope might help, if nothing else were available. Both were physical evidence. They might carry fingerprints, or traces of DNA.

我与西方的大部分互动都涉及技术获取：专利申请、软件、算法等。获取特定律师持有的特定文件要困难得多。但中国需要知道 Factor Man 是谁，所以我需要找到 Duane Morris 的 Factor Man 文件。

Most of the interactions I have with the West involve the acquisition of technology: patent applications, software, algorithms, and similar. Obtaining a specific file in the possession of a specific attorney would be far more difficult. But China needed to know who Factor Man was, so I needed to find Duane Morris’ Factor Man file.

因子人

Factor Man

2018 年 5 月 27 日

May 27, 2018

当我抵达苏黎世时，我并不知道中国人已经知道了鲍勃·哈斯戴的身份。我随身带着一个小行李箱，里面装着两周的夏装/秋装，还有一个超大但毫无特色的行李袋。行李袋里装着假发和一个引人注目的亮蓝色大背包。

I had no idea that the Chinese had learned Bob Hasday’s identity when I landed in Zurich. I had with me two weeks’ worth of summer/fall clothes in a small suitcase, and an oversized but otherwise nondescript duffel bag. Inside the duffel bag were the wig and a large, bright blue, attention-grabbing backpack.

我住在贝尔沃瑞士品质酒店，房间是用我自己的名义和信用卡预订的。我顺利通过了海关，来到了这家酒店，这是一家宜人的 4.5 星级酒店，可以欣赏到苏黎世湖的美景。我订的是贝尔沃套房，这是一间装修荒谬的房间，铺着硬木地板，有玻璃墙，每晚房费约为 800 美元。

I was staying at the Belvoir Swiss Quality Hotel, in a room I had booked in my own name and with my own credit card. I passed through customs easily and made my way to the hotel, a delightful 4½-star property with a beautiful view of Lake Zurich. I was booked into the Belvoir Suite, an absurdly appointed room with hardwood floors, glass walls, and a price tag of about $800/night.

请理解，我通常不会这样旅行。但我认为我即将从银行提取 100 万美元现金，我可以稍微挥霍一下。老实说，这是我应得的。如果 Factor Man 计划奏效，我不会在意钱。如果它不起作用，我可能也不会在意钱。我已经全押了，所以我不妨这样做。

Please understand that I don’t normally travel like this. But I figured that I was about to withdraw $1 million in cash from the bank, and I could afford to splurge a little. In all honesty, I’d earned it. If the overall Factor Man plan worked, I wouldn’t care about the money. And if it didn’t work, I probably wouldn’t care about the money, either. I was all in, so I might as well act that way.

食物很棒，床也很舒服。第二天早上，我起床、洗澡、刮胡子、穿衣、吃早餐，然后前往 Finn 选择的银行。（瑞士信贷；这并不奇怪。）在那里，我了解到从一个拥有五倍于该金额的账户中提取一百万美元现金（实际上是欧元）是多么容易。我把钱放进行李袋，然后回到贝尔沃酒店。

The food was excellent and the bed comfortable. The next morning, I got up, showered, shaved, dressed, had breakfast, and made my way to the bank that Finn had selected. (Credit Suisse; no surprise there.) While there, I learned how amazingly easy it is to withdraw a million dollars in cash (Euros, actually) from an account that holds five times that amount. I put the money in the duffel bag and returned to the Belvoir.

一切看起来都非常简单。但回想起来，我意识到在那一天里，我肯定透露了自己的身份五十次。我支付了餐费和酒店房费。我需要在银行出示身份证。尽管这不是芬恩给我的凭证的一部分，但银行本身希望将其作为交易的一部分。而且我肯定被拍了很多次，无论是在银行还是在安全意识很强的瑞士街头。

It had all seemed incredibly simple. Looking back on it, though, I realized that I must have revealed my identity fifty times over the course of that single day. I had paid for the meals and the hotel room. I had needed to show ID at the bank. Even though it was not part of the credentials Finn had given me, the bank itself wanted it as a part of the transaction. And I had surely been photographed many times, both in the bank and on the streets of security-conscious Switzerland.

一切都很简单，因为它本来就应该很简单。这是一个简单的圈子，布莱恩·芬恩也在其中。在这个圈子里，我只是另一个游客，另一个银行客户。

It had been simple because it was supposed to be simple. This was the easy circle, the one that included Brian Finn. In this circle, I was just another tourist, just another bank customer.

第二天晚上，贝尔沃套房的床同样舒适，但我睡得不好。第二天早上，我和酒店结清了账，打车去了火车站。在那里，我买了一张略显不寻常的往返维也纳的火车票。

The bed in the Belvoir Suite was just as comfortable the second night, but I slept badly. The next morning, I settled my account with the hotel and took a taxi to the train station. There, I bought a slightly unusual round trip train ticket toward Vienna.

维也纳。保险箱。第二圈，匿名从一种不可能的奢侈变成了绝对必要的。当我用现金支付火车票时，售票员身后的摄像头一眨不眨。当时刚过早上 8 点。

Vienna. The safe deposit box. The second circle, where anonymity would change from being an impossible luxury to an absolute essential. The camera behind the ticket agent never blinked as I paid for my train ticket with cash. It was just after 8 in the morning.

伯克特

Burkett

2018 年 5 月 28 日

May 28, 2018

当然，我对这些一无所知。我既不知道那 500 万美元，也不知道去苏黎世的旅行，也不知道中国人，更不知道 Factor Man 成功在 Google 上搜索到。我只是像我们所有人一样每天查看博客，看着数字越来越大。

I, of course, didn’t know a damn thing about any of this. Not about the five million dollars, or the trip to Zurich, or the Chinese, or the fact that Factor Man had managed to tick off Google. I just checked the blog every day, as we all did, and watched the numbers get bigger.

这就像看着草生长一样。被分解的数字平均每三天就会增加两倍。他们花了大约一个半星期的时间才增加一位数字。相信我，40 位数字和 41 位数字之间的差异并不那么令人印象深刻。

It was a lot like watching grass grow. The numbers being factored got bigger, on average, by a factor of two every three days. It took about a week and a half for them to add another digit. And trust me, the difference between a 40-digit number and a 41-digit number isn’t all that impressive to behold.

草在生长。

Grass growing.

与此同时，猜测仍在继续。博彩市场现在非常倾向于 Factor Man，他真正实现这一目标的几率约为 4:1。阴谋论者仍然是阴谋论者，甚至还有一些更古怪的人加入其中，他们坚持认为 Factor Man 是外星人，或者是来自我们未来的访客。

Meanwhile, the speculation continued unabated. The betting markets were now leaning pretty heavily in Factor Man’s favor, with odds of about 4:1 that he would actually pull this off. The conspiracy theorists remained conspiracy theorists, and were joined by some even wackier folks, who maintained that Factor Man was a space alien, or a visitor from our own future.

当然，大多数人还是像往常一样。他们观看，娱乐，并认为这不会真正影响到他们。

Mostly, of course, people did what they always did. They watched, they were entertained, and they figured it would never really affect them.

当我说“人们”时，我指的是包括我在内的人们。

And when I say people, I mean people including me.

* * *

* * *

那是一个星期五的早上九点左右。艾玛和我刚刚吃完早餐。

It was a Friday morning around nine. Emma and I were just finishing breakfast.

如果你不记得 Emma，她就是在我第一次（实际上是唯一一次）收到 Factor Man 的电子邮件后的那个晚上放了我鸽子的人。我早就原谅了她，为此我得到了丰厚的回报。

In case you don’t remember Emma, she’s the one who stood me up the evening after my first (actually, my only) email from Factor Man. I have long since forgiven her, for which I have been richly rewarded.

你可能想知道我们周五早上九点在家做什么。答案是，做记者（我的工作）和做文学经纪人的手稿审查员（艾玛的工作）都有各自的好处。虽然好处不多，但在略显慵懒的周五早上一边吃麦圈一边盯着别人的眼睛肯定是其中之一。请注意，我们穿着上班服。我们只是还没来得及离开。

You may be wondering what we were doing at home at nine on a Friday morning. The answer is that being a reporter (my job), and being a manuscript screener for a literary agent (Emma’s job) both have their perks. There aren’t many, but staring into someone else’s eyes over Cheerios on a slightly lazy Friday morning is certainly one of them. We were dressed for work, mind you. We just hadn’t gotten around to leaving yet.

在这个特别的星期五，我们的 Cheerios 被一阵敲门声打断了。我开了门，发现是几个穿着西装的男人。

On this particular Friday, our Cheerios were interrupted by a knock on the door. I answered it to find a couple of guys in suits.

“早上好，伯克特先生，”高个子说。“我是联邦调查局特工约翰·哈德森。”他向我出示了一张身份证，然后指了指矮个子。“这是特工罗恩·利文斯通。我们可以进来吗？”

“Good morning, Mr. Burkett,” the taller one said. “I’m Special Agent John Hudson of the FBI.” He showed me some ID and then gestured toward the shorter one. “This is Special Agent Ron Livingstone. May we come in?”

这里有几点需要指出。首先，“矮”只是一个相对术语。利文斯通仍然比我高出三英寸。而另一个家伙哈德森不仅比我高很多，而且体型也更宽。他看起来气势磅礴。我想，这就是联邦政府的长臂所带来的结果。

There are a couple things to point out here. First, “shorter” is only a relative term. Livingstone still had me by a good three inches. And Hudson, the other guy, wasn’t just way taller than I was, he was broader as well. A looming physical presence. That’s what comes from being the long arm of the federal government, I guess.

当像约翰·哈德森这样的人出现在电影中时，刚刚打开门的傻瓜通常会做出一些聪明的事情。当哈德森自称是联邦探员并询问他是否可以进来时，他可能会抽出他值得信赖的瓦尔特 PPK 并射杀所有人。也许他会机智地反驳道：“当然可以，但我要出去了。请检查一下狗有没有水。”也许他只是说“不”，然后关上门。

When someone like John Hudson shows up in the movies, the doofus who just opened the door generally does something clever. In response to Hudson identifying himself as a federal agent and asking if he can come in, maybe he whips out his trusty Walther PPK and shoots everyone. Maybe he’s got a witty retort like, “Sure, but I’m on my way out. Please check that the dog has water.” And maybe he just says, “No,” and shuts the door.

这些事我都没做。前两件事我没做，因为我既没有手枪，也没有狗。第三件事我也没做，因为我当时正忙着站在那里张着嘴。

I did none of these things. I didn’t do the first two because I owned neither a pistol nor a dog. And I didn’t do the third because I was too busy just standing there with my mouth open.

哈德森似乎在等我闭上嘴，但我没有闭上。最后，他又问了一遍。“伯克特先生？”我让开身子，让他们进来。

Hudson appeared to be waiting for me to close my mouth, which didn’t happen. Eventually, he just asked again. “Mr. Burkett?” I stepped aside and let them in.

“早上好，哈达威女士，”他说。“很抱歉打扰了您的早餐。”没有人告诉他们艾玛的名字，无论是姓还是名。我讨厌别人知道我的私事，我不知道他们是怎么知道的。我太讨厌了，所以我闭上了嘴。

“Good morning, Ms. Hardaway,” he said. “We’re sorry to interrupt your breakfast.” Nobody had told them Emma’s name, first or last. I hate it when people know stuff about my personal life and I have no idea how they know it. I hated it so much that I closed my mouth.

这又引发了一场对视比赛，我输了。“我能为您做些什么？”我最终问道。

This led to another staring contest, which I lost. “What can I do for you?” I eventually asked.

哈德森说：“我们正在努力寻找‘因子人’。”

“We’re trying to find Factor Man,” Hudson said.

有趣。我还没搞明白他们为什么问我。“你和其他文明世界的人。也许你应该拿个号码。”我真的需要再想一想再说。

Interesting. It hadn’t dawned on me yet why they were asking me. “You and the rest of the civilized world. Maybe you should take a number.” I really need to think more before talking.

哈德森拉过一把椅子坐下。他做了那种动作：把椅子转过来，向后坐，也许身体前倾，双臂靠在椅背上。利文斯通只是站在那里。我想，做你擅长的事吧。

Hudson pulled up a chair and sat down. He did that thing where you turn the chair around and sit on it backwards, maybe leaning forward and resting your arms on the backrest. Livingstone just stood there. Do what you’re good at, I guess.

“据我们所知，第一次提到 Factor Man 是在你写的一篇文章中。还记得吗？我记得它的名字是《如何找到一个疯子》。

“The first mention of Factor Man – anywhere, as far as we can tell – is in an article you wrote. Remember it? ‘How to Find a Crackpot,’ I think it was called.

“Blogspot 与我们分享了一些记录。您的文章是在 Factor Man 博客向公众开放的前一天发表的。我们很想知道这是怎么发生的。”

“Blogspot has shared some of the records with us. Your article came out the day before the Factor Man blog was visible to the public. We’d love to understand how that happened.”

突然间，事情看起来变得复杂了不少。“我是一名记者。我报道各种事情。我擅长这个。”

Suddenly, this looked a good bit more complicated. “I’m a reporter. I report things. I’m good at it.”

“我们明白，伯克特先生。但是当你报告这件事时，似乎有点，我们可以说，有先见之明。据我们所知，只有两种可能。要么你是 Factor Man，要么你认识 Factor Man。那么告诉我：你是 Factor Man 吗？”

“We understand, Mr. Burkett. But reporting this particular thing, when you did, seems a bit, shall we say, prescient. As far as we can figure, there are only two possibilities. Either you’re Factor Man, or you know Factor Man. So tell me: Are you Factor Man?”

“当然。”先想一想，威廉。先想一想。

“Absolutely.” Think first, William. Think first.

哈德森似乎并不担心。“我明白了。在关于 NP 完全性的第一篇论文中，卡普列出了 21 个最终被证明是 NP 完全性的问题。你能告诉我其中三个吗？”

Hudson seemed unfazed. “I see. In one of the first papers on NP-completeness, Karp listed twenty-one problems that turned out to be NP-complete. Can you tell me, say, three of them?”

我什么也没说。也许我在学习。

I said nothing. Perhaps I was learning.

“啊，”哈德森继续说道。“那么假设你不是 Factor Man。这意味着你可能认识Factor Man。对吧？”

“Ah,” Hudson continued. “So let’s say you aren’t Factor Man. That means you probably know Factor Man. Yes?”

对我来说，什么都不说似乎没用。我坚持这么做。

Saying nothing seemed to be working for me. I kept it up.

“让我直奔主题。我们认为 Factor Man 是你曾经联系过的人。也许他给你发过短信，或者在某个时候发过电子邮件。

“Let me cut to the chase here. We believe that Factor Man is someone you’ve had contact with. Maybe he sent you a text, or maybe an email at some point.

“我们可以从 Verizon 获取您的联系人和手机记录，从您的雇主处获取您的电子邮件记录。但这些事情需要时间。联邦调查局认为，无论 Factor Man 是谁，他都可能是迫在眉睫的恐怖主义威胁。所以我们来这里是希望节省时间。”

“We can get your contacts and cell phone records from Verizon, and your email records from your employer. But those things will take time. The FBI’s view is that Factor Man, whoever he is, is potentially an imminent terrorist threat. So we came over here hoping to save that time.”

我考虑过这个问题。我是一名记者。我不知道他们是否真的可以通过法院命令或类似的东西获得所有这些东西。另一方面，我的联系人列表中没有任何内容可以给他们带来任何好处。另一方面，记者应该相信“永远不要放弃你的消息来源”之类的废话。

I thought about this. I’m a reporter. I had no idea if they actually could get all that stuff through a court order or the like. On the other hand, there was nothing in any of my contact lists that would do them a damn bit of good. On the other hand, there was all the “never give up your sources” crap that journalists are supposed to believe in.

“我不能帮你节省时间。我是个记者。我不会放弃我的消息来源。”

“I can’t save you the time. I’m a reporter. I won’t give up my sources.”

我不敢相信我竟然说出了那句话。那就像一本漫画，那些话就挂在我面前的气球里。

I can’t believe I actually said that. It was like a comic, where the words were hanging in some kind of balloon in front of my face.

哈德森考虑了一下。“最终答案是什么？”他问我。

Hudson considered. “Final answer?” he asked me.

“最终答案。”

“Final answer.”

“对不起。”他伸手从夹克里掏出一张纸。“这是搜查你的电脑和手机的搜查令。请把它们交给我们，我们会让你继续你的早晨。”

“I’m sorry.” He reached into his jacket and pulled out a piece of paper. “Here’s a warrant for your computer and your cell phone. Please provide them to us, and we’ll let you get on with your morning.”

哈德森的名片被钉在逮捕令的顶部。整个事情太糟糕了。

Hudson’s card was stapled to the top of the warrant. The whole thing totally sucked.

刘

Liu

2018 年 5 月 28 日

May 28, 2018

我对罗伯特·哈斯戴（通常被称为鲍勃）进行了研究。从很多方面来说，他都是典型的合同律师。他远离法庭，也许是因为他讨厌法庭，并且作为一名起草人，他享有非凡的声誉，他起草的合同几乎完美无缺，准确反映了客户的意愿。他往往不亲自与客户会面，而是了解他们想要什么，然后实现它。

I did my research on Robert Hasday, generally known as Bob. He was a typical contract attorney in many ways. He stayed out of the courtroom, perhaps because he hated it, and had an extraordinary reputation as a draftsman, producing virtually flawless contracts that accurately reflected his clients’ wishes. He tended not to meet with the clients in person, rather finding out what they wanted and making it happen.

Hasday 的“实现目标”能力是传奇。他能够理解客户复杂的愿望，并准备一份既可靠又准确反映客户最初要求的法律文件。他还能够理解另一位律师提供的材料，并准确地告知客户潜在协议中存在的陷阱和漏洞。

Hasday’s ability to “make it happen” was legendary. He could take a client’s convoluted desires, untangle them, and prepare a legal document that was both rock solid and an accurate reflection of what the client had originally requested. He could also take material produced by another attorney, untangle it, and accurately advise his client of both the pitfalls and loopholes that a potential agreement contained.

为此，哈斯戴每小时收费 1000 美元以上。他热爱自己的工作，杜安·莫里斯也对他的工作表现赞不绝口。他从事这项工作已有三十多年，他的客户都对他赞不绝口。哈斯戴收费如此之高，意味着他们通常只在最复杂的安排中才聘请他，而这似乎正是哈斯戴喜欢的。他的工作很多，工作越复杂，他就越喜欢做。

For doing this, Hasday charged something upwards of $1000 an hour. He loved his work, and Duane Morris loved how well he did it. He’d been doing it for well over thirty years, and his clients all swore by him. The fact that Hasday cost so much meant that they typically used him only for their most complicated arrangements, which appeared to be to Hasday’s liking. He had plenty of work, and the more complicated it was, the more he enjoyed doing it.

我以为当我亲自打电话询问会面时间时，他会感到惊讶。我告诉他的法律助理南希，我是一个敏感问题的潜在客户，希望哈斯戴先生能抽出时间和我见面。他同意了，现在就开始会面。

I assumed he would be surprised when I called to ask for an appointment in person. I informed Nancy, his legal assistant, that I was a prospective client on a sensitive matter and hoped that Mr. Hasday could make the time to meet with me. He had agreed, and the meeting was now.

Hasday 的办公室位于纽约市时代广场东侧，一如既往地令人印象深刻。Hasday 本人比我矮一点，身高 175 厘米（5 英尺 9 英寸），显然很帅气，西装革履，看上去 60 岁左右。

Hasday’s office was predictably impressive, just east of Times Square in New York City. Hasday himself was a bit shorter than my 175cm (5’9"), clearly smart, suit and tie, and looked to be about sixty.

我递给他的名片上写着我是位于北京的泽东企业的负责人。名片散发着淡淡的香味，一面是英文，另一面是普通话。我以正式的中国方式递上名片，用双手，这是源于一项古老的要求的习俗，用来表明自己没有拿着武器。我确保我说话时英语带点口音。

The business card I gave him said that I was a principal with Zedong Enterprises, located in Beijing. The card was lightly perfumed, in English on one side and Mandarin on the other. I presented it in the formal Chinese way, using two hands, a custom stemming from an age-old requirement to demonstrate that one is not holding a weapon. I ensured that my English was slightly accented when I spoke.

哈斯戴邀请我坐下，我们都坐了下来；南希在离开前给我们端来了咖啡，但我们都拒绝了。

Hasday invited me to sit, and we both did; Nancy offered us coffee before leaving, and we both declined.

“刘小姐，请问有什么可以帮到您吗？”

“Tell me, Ms. Liu, what can we do for you?”

“珍妮特，拜托你了。我的公司需要一些帮助来与潜在的美国合作伙伴签订合同。”

“Janet, please. My firm needs some assistance with a contract with a potential American partner.”

我继续解释说，泽东是一家软件开发公司，专门为中国市场开发用户界面。我告诉 Hasday，我们第一次尝试与一家美国公司做生意，开发患者数据库系统的用户界面。这家美国公司起草了一份咨询协议来管理这种关系，泽东觉得很难理解。

I went on to explain that Zedong was a software development firm specializing in the development of user interfaces for the Chinese market. I told Hasday that we were, for the first time, attempting to do business with an American firm, developing the user interface for a patient database system. The American firm had drafted a consulting agreement to manage the relationship, and Zedong was finding it difficult to understand.

“这让人困惑，”我解释道。“他们起草这份协议就好像只考虑自己的利益一样。”

“It is perplexing,” I explained. “It is as if they have drafted the agreement with only their own interests in mind.”

哈斯戴看上去很困惑。

Hasday looked puzzled.

“我肯定我误会了，”我解释道。“他们这么做是愚蠢的，因为这会从一开始就把我们的关系置于对抗地位。”

“I’m sure I have misunderstood,” I explained. “It would be foolish of them to do that, as it would place our relationship on an adversarial footing from the outset.”

哈斯戴笑了笑，然后告诉我，杜安莫里斯如果不进行利益冲突检查，以确保他们不代表美国医疗公司，就无法代表我。“假设没有利益冲突，”他说，“我们会要求你支付一笔定金。然后你可以通过电子邮件将拟议协议的副本发给我，我会看看的。”

Hasday smiled, and then told me that Duane Morris would be unable to represent me without doing a conflict check to ensure that they did not represent the American medical firm as well. “Assuming that there are no conflicts,” he said, “We’ll ask you to pay us a retainer. Then you can email me a copy of the proposed agreement and I’ll take a look at it.”

我假装困惑。“我们在中国有很多竞争对手，”我解释道。“把协议草案通过电子邮件发送给你对他们不公平。”

I feigned confusion. “We have many competitors in China,” I explained. “It would be unfair to them to email the draft agreement to you.”

过了一会儿，我意识到我需要再次澄清。“这可能会鼓励他们试图侵入您的电子邮件服务器。我们不希望这样做。”

A few moments passed, and I realized that I needed to clarify once again. “It might encourage them to try to break into your email servers. We would not wish to do that.”

“我明白了，”哈斯戴回答道。

“I see,” Hasday responded.

“我现在可以给你一份协议的副本吗？但前提是，只有你能代表我们时，你才能审查它。”我问道。

“May I provide you with a copy of the agreement now, with the understanding that you only examine it if you are able to represent us?” I asked.

哈斯戴回答说没问题。他问道：“我可以复印一份这份协议，把原件留给你吗？”

Hasday responded that that would be fine. “Is it okay if I make a copy of this agreement and leave the original with you?” he asked.

我还是显得有些不安。“是的，当然。副本会保存在哪里？”

I continued to look somewhat uneasy. “Yes, of course. Where will the copy be kept?”

“我的文件就放在大厅对面的这间办公室里。案子完成后，我们会将它们存放在异地仓库二十年。”

“My files stay in this office, across the hall. When our case is completed, we keep them in offsite storage for twenty years.”

“我明白了。那就好了。谢谢您的考虑，哈斯戴先生。”

“I see. That will be fine. Thank you for your consideration, Mr. Hasday.”

“鲍勃。拜托。但请你理解，如果冲突检查发现问题，我们将不得不销毁协议副本，并要求你另找律师。”

“Bob. Please. But do understand that if the conflict check reveals an issue, we will have to destroy the copy of the agreement and ask that you find other counsel.”

“是的，当然，”我告诉他。

“Yes, of course,” I told him.

“太好了，”哈斯戴说，“大概需要一两天时间，我很快就会联系你。”他握了握我的手，把我交还给了南希。

“Excellent,” Hasday said. “It should take a day or two, and I’ll be in touch soon.” He shook my hand and returned me to Nancy.

* * *

* * *

三天后，我们闯入了。

We broke in three nights later.

第一天晚上，我的一名特工认出了每天晚上打扫大楼的人。他提出在他们回来时帮他们打扫，他们最初的犹豫很快就被他愿意支付一大笔钱来获得提供这种帮助的权利这一事实所打消。

On the first night, one of my operatives identified the people who cleaned the building each evening. He offered to help them clean when they came back, and their initial reluctance was rapidly overcome by the fact that he was willing to pay a reasonably large sum of money for the privilege of providing such assistance.

进入大楼后，一切就相对容易了。我用藏在衣服纽扣里的摄像头记录了我第一次访问 Hasday 办公室的过程，这让特工找到了 Hasday 办公室和对面的档案室。不出所料，锁根本不是问题。

Once inside the building, it was relatively easy. I had recorded my initial visit to Hasday’s office using a camera hidden in one of the buttons on my dress, and that allowed the operative to locate both Hasday’s office and the file room opposite. The locks were predictably not a concern at all.

标有“Hasday - 活跃”的文件柜中没有 Factor Man 的文件，因此特工快速浏览了所有文件。在标有“待处理”的文件里，他找到了这封信。

The filing cabinet labeled “Hasday – Active,” did not contain a Factor Man file, so the operative quickly scanned through all of the files. In the one labeled “pending,” he found the letter.

感谢您的电子邮件。附件中附有您签署的留任协议副本以及 10,000 美元现金。

Thank you for your email. A signed copy of your retention agreement is enclosed, along with $10,000 in cash.

我还附上了 Sparta Global Intelligence Group 保险箱的钥匙，地址是 Löwengasse 39, 1030 Vienna。保险箱号码是 1739，密码是 I@mF@ctorm@n。我会根据需要用这个保险箱向您转入额外资金。

I am also enclosing a key to a safe deposit box at Sparta Global Intelligence Group, Löwengasse 39, 1030 Vienna. The box number is 1739 and the password is I@mF@ctorm@n. I will use the box to transfer additional funds to you as needed.

如果我给你发了一条提到某位著名物理学家的信息，请检查保险箱……

If I send you a message mentioning a famous physicist, please check the safe deposit box …

特工用随身携带的小型便携式打印机扫描了这封信并复印了一张。他戴着手套，把原信收起来，把复印件放进文件夹。他拿出原来的信封，把它和信件一起放进口袋里一个透明的聚氨酯信封里。

Using a small portable printer that he had brought with him, the operative scanned the letter and made a copy. Wearing gloves, he kept the original letter and replaced it with the copy in the file folder. He took the original envelope, placing both it and the letter in a clear polyurethane envelope in his pocket.

随后，他开始仔细寻找保险箱的钥匙，但最终一无所获。

He then began a careful but ultimately fruitless search for the key to the safe deposit box.

* * *

* * *

尽管这封信无价之宝，但不幸的是，它既没有提供指纹，也没有 DNA 痕迹。没有钥匙也许令人遗憾，但也可能并非如此。我们不可能使用或复制钥匙而不让 Factor Man 知道我们有钥匙。钥匙本身可能在 Hasday 手中或在他家里，而且都不难处理。但这样做的风险几乎不可忽略，好处却微不足道。我们不用钥匙也行，但我们会采取明显的预防措施，侵入 Duane Morris 电子邮件服务器，并确保如果 Factor Man 通过电子邮件联系 Hasday，我们会得到通知。

Invaluable though it was, the letter unfortunately provided neither fingerprints nor traces of DNA. The lack of a key was perhaps regrettable, but also perhaps not. It would have been impossible to either use or duplicate it without Factor Man learning that we had it. The key itself was presumably in Hasday’s possession or in his house, and neither would have been difficult to deal with. But the risks in doing so were hardly negligible, and the advantages modest. We would do without the key, although we would take the obvious precaution of hacking into the Duane Morris email server and ensuring that if Factor Man contacted Hasday by email, we would be informed.

Factor Man 显然预计未来某个时候会给 Hasday 一些钱。我们对钱本身不感兴趣，但对 Factor Man 很感兴趣。

Factor Man apparently anticipated getting some money to Hasday at a point in the future. We had no interest in the money itself, but great interest in Factor Man.

很难知道他是否会把钱交给斯巴达全球情报集团，还是会把钱交给某种代理人。我怀疑他会亲自去做，因为从理论上讲，把钱交给代理人并不比直接交给哈斯戴容易，而且只会给行动带来额外的复杂性。

It was difficult to know if he would bring the money to Sparta Global Intelligence Group, or trust that to a surrogate of some sort. I suspected that he would do it himself, as getting the money to a surrogate would be no easier in principle than giving it to Hasday directly, and would only introduce an additional complexity to the operation.

假设我猜对了，Factor Man 会在某个时候访问维也纳的地址。不过，他大概会在访问结束后才向 Hasday 发送消息。鉴于我们的目标是找到 Factor Man，我们需要提前到达保险箱。

Assuming that I was correct, Factor Man would at some point be paying a visit to the address in Vienna. He would presumably send Hasday the message only after that visit was complete, however. Given that our goal was to find Factor Man, we would need to be at the safe deposit box beforehand.

除了简单地配备人员之外，似乎没有其他方法可以实现这一点。值得庆幸的是，Sparta Global 只在相当正常的营业时间营业，即周一至周五上午 10 点至晚上 8 点。这会让事情变得简单得多。我们会在营业时监视地址，拍摄每个客户的视频。我们还需要找到一种方法将视频与拥有该盒子的人相匹配。我与上级安排了另外五名特工在维也纳与我会面。

There seemed to be no way to accomplish this other than simply by staffing it. Thankfully, Sparta Global was only open during fairly normal business hours, from 10AM until 8PM Monday through Friday. That would make things far simpler. We would watch the address when it was open, capturing video of every customer. We would also need to find a way to match the video to the person owning the box. I arranged with my superiors to have five additional agents meet me in Vienna.

* * *

* * *

“斯巴达全球情报集团”更广为人知的名字是“斯巴达保险箱”，是维也纳市中心的一家商店。街对面有露天座位，可以很容易地监视。最大的问题可能是简单的苦差事，特别是如果我们需要长时间呆在那里的话。

“Sparta Global Intelligence Group” was better known simply as “Sparta Safes,” one of a group of shops in downtown Vienna. There was open air seating across the street, which would make surveillance straightforward. The most significant problem was likely to be simple drudgery, especially if we needed to remain for an extended period.

第二个最重要的问题是，我们无法知道 Factor Man 何时在盒子里给 Hasday 留下了什么东西。我对此有所了解，并以客户的身份进入了 Sparta Safes。

The second most significant problem was that we had no way of knowing when Factor Man had left something in the box for Hasday. I had an idea about that, and entered Sparta Safes as a customer.

我租了一个小盒子，偷偷拍下了设施布局和帮助我的那位工作人员的照片。他们告诉我，有四个私人区域可供客户开展业务，尽管他们警告我，斯巴达是一个小型设施，房间没有电子安全措施。

I rented a small box, taking surreptitious images of both the facility layout and of the single staffer who helped me. I was told about the four private areas in which customers could conduct business, although I was warned that Sparta was a small facility and the rooms were not electronically secure.

出了门后，我喝了杯咖啡，等到下午 4 点后不久，那名工作人员离开了。他很可能被另一名工作人员替换了，第二名特工进入设施，租用了第二个箱子并与那名工作人员打交道。

Once outside, I enjoyed a coffee and waited until the staffer himself left shortly after 4PM. He was presumably replaced by another staffer, and a second agent entered the facility to rent a second box and deal with that staffer.

在一周的时间里，一共有四名员工，我们从他们每人那里租了一个箱子。每位员工都被跟踪到一个相对私密的地方，在那里，他们被要求支付 25,000 欧元，以换取如果有人试图进入 1739 号箱子，他们会立即打电话，但要小心谨慎。工作人员被告知（这是正确的，但这并不重要），因为没有人试图识别箱子的主人，所以他们没有提出任何非法建议。四名工作人员没有商量就接受了，然后就开始等待了。

Over the course of a week, there were a total of four employees, and we rented a box from each. Each staffer was followed to a relatively private location, where he or she was offered the sum of 25,000 Euros in exchange for a discreet but immediate phone call if anyone attempted to access box 1739. The staffers were told (correctly, not that it mattered) that since no attempt was being made to identify the owner of the box, nothing illegal was being suggested. All four of the staffers accepted without negotiation, and the wait began.

6

6

因子人

Factor Man

2018 年 5 月 28 日

May 28, 2018

我订了去维也纳的RailJet 165号火车票。RJ 165号火车于上午10:40从苏黎世出发；我利用出发前的时间去了一家九点开门的电子产品商店。我用现金买了一副高端夜视镜，并把它和钱一起塞进了行李袋。回到火车站后，我有足够的时间登上RJ 165号火车，尽管我还没有打算去维也纳。

I was booked on the RailJet 165 train to Vienna. RJ 165 left Zurich at 10:40AM; I used the time before departure to visit an electronics shop that opened at nine. I bought a pair of high-end night vision goggles with cash, and slipped them into the duffel along with the money. Back to the railway station in plenty of time, I boarded the RJ 165, even though I had no intention – yet – of going to Vienna.

让我在这里澄清一下。我不是间谍。我是一名计算机科学家。在互联网安全领域，如果你想要保护公司的内部网络，就必须将其置于防火墙后面。在防火墙和外部世界之间，通常有一个称为 DMZ 或非军事区的区域。如果外部人员想要访问公司的网络，他们必须通过 DMZ。从那里，他们可以使用有限的工具穿过防火墙并访问网络本身。

Let me be clear here. I’m not a spy. I’m a computer scientist. In the world of Internet security, if you want to keep a company’s internal network private, you put it behind a firewall. Between the firewall and the outside world, there is generally something called the DMZ, or demilitarized zone. If someone from the outside wants to access the company’s network, they have to go through the DMZ. From there, they can use a limited number of tools to get through the firewall and access the network itself.

DMZ 确实是一个恰当的缩写。你可以进入它，但你必须先卸下武器才能继续前进。DMZ 可以让网络本身保持相当安全。

DMZ really is an appropriate acronym. You can get into it, but then you have to remove your weapons before going further. The DMZ keeps the network itself reasonably safe.

我对这两个圈子的看法是相似的。布莱恩·芬恩所在的圈子需要保持安全；鲍勃·哈斯戴所在的圈子在外面，本质上是不安全的。我必须在两个圈子之间穿梭——如果我的整体计划成功的话，只需要一次——为此，我引入了一个现实世界的网络 DMZ 等价物。当我最终从维也纳的保险箱回来时，我会使用 DMZ 作为路径点，以确保我的匿名性，然后再重新进入第一个圈子的世界。

My view of the two circles was similar. The circle with Brian Finn needed to be kept safe; the circle with Bob Hasday was in the outside world and inherently unsafe. I had to go between the two circles – exactly once, if my overall plan held up – and to do that, I introduced a real-world equivalent of the network DMZ. When I eventually returned from the safe deposit box in Vienna, I would use the DMZ as a waypoint to ensure my anonymity before reentering the world of the first circle.

至少，这是计划。

At least, that was the plan.

在这种情况下，DMZ 是 RJ 165 路线上的一个名为 Ötztal 的小镇。

In this case, the DMZ was a small town on the RJ 165 route called Ötztal.

奥兹山谷是蒂罗尔阿尔卑斯山脉中一座风景优美的小镇。奥兹山谷冰川路是阿尔卑斯山脉最高的铺装道路，海拔超过 9200 英尺。1991 年，人们发现了一具约公元前 3300 年的天然木乃伊，这座山谷也因此而声名鹊起。这具木乃伊被昵称为“冰人”（也简称为“奥兹”），保存完好，为人们提供了大量有关欧洲铜石并用时代的信息。奥兹木乃伊目前陈列在意大利博尔扎诺的南蒂罗尔考古博物馆。

Ötztal is a spectacularly beautiful town in the Tyrolean Alps. The Ötztal Glacier Road is the highest paved road in the Alps, over 9200 feet high. The valley itself was briefly famous in 1991 when a natural mummy from about 3300 BC was discovered there. Nicknamed The Iceman (also simply Ötzi), the amazingly preserved body provided a wealth of information about Europeans of the Chalcolithic age. Ötzi is currently on display in the South Tyrol Museum of Archaeology in Bolzano, Italy.

我的计划很平淡。我买的往返火车票实际上包括两次旅行，一次从苏黎世到奥兹山谷，另一次稍后从奥兹山谷到维也纳。我在奥兹山谷下车，步行到 Ferienschlössl，这是一家豪华酒店，我已经确认它有三个关键设施。他们接受现金，房间里有高质量的 Wi-Fi，还有带顶棚的停车场。

My plans were quite mundane. The round trip train ticket I had bought actually involved two trips, one from Zurich to Ötztal and one from Ötztal to Vienna some time later. I detrained in Ötztal, and walked to the Ferienschlössl, a luxury hotel that I had already confirmed had three crucial properties. They took cash, they had good quality Wi-Fi in the rooms, and they had covered parking.

我没有预订 Ferienschlössl，但他们有房间，而且非常乐意接受现金支付十二晚住宿费用，以及一大笔押金。只靠现金生活——但钱很多——绝对值得推荐。我感觉就像在家一样。

I did not have a reservation at the Ferienschlössl, but they had space, and were more than happy to accept cash for a twelve-night stay, along with a significant security deposit. Living only on cash – but with plenty of it – definitely has things to recommend it. I made myself at home.

接下来的十一个晚上过得非常愉快。当然，我每天都要负责数字分解，但这个过程现在几乎完全自动化了，我所做的大部分工作都是向某位知名人士发送电子邮件（当然是通过 TOR），以确认他们所谓的数字确实来自他们。我会在博客上发帖，关上笔记本电脑，然后去远足。

The next eleven nights were wonderful. I did, of course, have my daily number factoring responsibilities, but that process was nearly entirely automated by now, and most of what I did involved sending emails (through TOR, of course) to one notable or another in order to confirm that the numbers that supposedly came from them in fact did. I would post to the blog, close my laptop, and go hiking.

阿尔卑斯山美得令人难以置信。四周景色令人惊叹。当时正值初夏，海拔高，天气凉爽，几乎像秋天一样。天气晴朗，山间空气清新，你可以感受到。由于海拔高，加上我缺乏锻炼，徒步旅行一开始很艰难，但每天都变得容易起来。第一天，我买了一根手杖作为拐杖。我几乎不再需要它了，但还是带着它。

The Alps were extraordinary. Stunning scenery on all sides. It was early summer, and the altitude meant that the weather was brisk, almost fall-like. The days were clear and the mountain air so fresh you could taste it. Between the altitude and my general lack of exercise, hiking began as a struggle, but got easier every day. The first day, I had bought a cane to use as a walking stick. I rarely needed it any more, but brought it with me anyway.

尽管我很欣赏徒步旅行和风景，但我同样欣赏我没有做的事情。

As much as I appreciated the hiking and the scenery, though, I appreciated what I didn’t do just as much.

我没有和同事说话。我没有和家人说话（说实话，我非常想念他们）。我没有工作。（想不到！）我没有看电影。我没有看任何广告。令人惊讶的是，我甚至没有担心。

I didn’t talk to colleagues. I didn’t talk with my family (whom, truth be told, I missed terribly). I didn’t work. (Fancy that!) I didn’t watch movies. I didn’t see any ads. Amazingly enough, I didn’t even worry.

还有一件事我没有做。

And there was one other thing I didn’t do.

我沒有刮毛。

I didn’t shave.

三十年前，我曾在加勒比海的一艘小游艇上度过了一个星期没有刮胡子的日子。那一周过得非常愉快，但当我看到旅行结束时的照片时，我感到十分震惊。大部分时候，我看起来太像犹太人了，根本认不出来；照片上我更像是一名犹太教教士，而不是一名科学家。我还曾在加勒比海度过过其他几周，但我总是随身带着剃须刀。

I had gone without shaving for a week once thirty years previously, spent on a small yacht in the Caribbean. The week was great, but when I saw pictures from the end of the trip, I was mortified. Mostly, I looked so Jewish as to be unrecognizable; the photos showed a rabbi as opposed to a scientist. There had been other weeks in the Caribbean, but I had always brought a razor.

退房前一天，我起得很早。我把夜视镜、假发、公文包和背包，以及大约 95 万美元的现金放进了行李袋。令人惊讶的是，我的口袋里竟然有大约 4 万美元。我吃过早餐，步行到火车站，按照计划于上午 9:51 登上 RJ 161 航班。

The day before I checked out of the Ferienschlössl, I rose early. I put the night vision goggles, the wig, the briefcase and backpack, and about $950,000 in cash in the duffel bag. About $40,000 was, amazingly enough, in my pockets. I had breakfast, walked to the train station, and boarded the RJ 161 at 9:51AM, as planned.

在我这样做的同时，我戴上了假发。我实际上已经练习过了，我想我已经相当熟练了。一上火车，我就进了卫生间，修剪了胡子。我还把行李袋里的所有东西都转移到了背包里，然后把行李袋扔掉了。

As I did so, I slipped on the wig. I had actually practiced this, and I think I had gotten pretty good at it. Once on the train, I entered a bathroom and trimmed my beard. I also transferred everything from the duffel bag to the backpack, and discarded the duffel bag itself.

有了胡子和假发，Ferienschlössl 的人们既不会认出我是拉比，也不会认出我是衣着整洁的美国游客。直到现在，欧洲还没有人见过这个背包。我戴上在火车站买的一副便宜的太阳镜，发了一封电子邮件。

Between the beard and the wig, I would not be recognized as either the rabbi or the clean cut American tourist by the folks at the Ferienschlössl. No one in Europe had even seen the backpack, until now. I put on a cheap pair of sunglasses that I had bought in the train station, and sent an email.

发件人：Factor Man (factorman0@gmail.com)

From: Factor Man (factorman0@gmail.com)

收件人：Bob Hasday (rjhasday@duanemorris.com)

To: Bob Hasday (rjhasday@duanemorris.com)

主题：物理学家

Subject: physicists

也许是阿尔伯特·爱因斯坦？

Albert Einstein, perhaps?

我认为，在哈斯戴安排取货之前，钱就会放进箱子里，所以，钱在箱子里停留的时间越短越好。

I figured the money would be in the box before Hasday could possibly arrange a pickup, and the less time it spent there, the better.

然后我就等着，希望火车能把我哄睡着。我两点半就能到维也纳，下午会很忙。

And then I waited, hoping to allow the train to rock me to sleep. I would be in Vienna at 2:30, and would have a busy afternoon.

刘

Liu

2018 年 6 月 8 日

June 8, 2018

我们几乎肯定比哈斯戴先看到了这条消息。至少可以说，这令人沮丧。经过一周的持续监视，我们似乎不太可能错过这次投递。

We almost surely saw the message before Hasday did. It was distressing, to say the least. It seemed unlikely that after a week of constant surveillance, we had somehow missed the drop-off.

鉴于我们的目标只是找出人因而不是干涉他，我们别无选择。更广泛的目标是确保中国能够获得人因显然已经开发的技术；就目前情况而言，这项技术可能会在多个领域给西方带来不可接受的优势。中国不再称你们为西方帝国主义者，这更多地反映了语言的变化，而不是态度的变化。

Given that our goal was simply to identify Factor Man as opposed to interfering with him, we had only poor options. The broader goal was to ensure that China had access to the technology that Factor Man had apparently developed; as things stood, the technology might give the West unacceptable advantages in a variety of areas. The fact that China no longer refers to you as Western imperialists reflects more a change in language than one in attitude.

任何更戏剧性的选择都无法实现这一目标。我们可以闯入保险箱，但这只会给 Factor Man 带来不便，而不是识别他。这大概也会让他意识到我们的存在。我们可以将 Sparta Safes 全部摧毁，让其看起来像是恐怖袭击。这会产生同样的效果。我们需要的是一张照片、一个地址或一个指纹。一个真正有意义的电子邮件地址也同样有价值。

None of the more dramatic options would further this goal. We could break into the box, but that would serve to inconvenience Factor Man as opposed to identifying him. It would presumably alert him to our presence as well. We could destroy Sparta Safes in its entirety, making it appear to have been a terrorist attack. That would have the same effect. What we needed was a photograph, an address, or a fingerprint. An email address that actually meant something would be similarly valuable.

我们决定等待救援车。也许，只是也许，Factor Man 也会留意救援车，然后我们就可以去接他了。与此同时，我还要承担一项不愉快的责任，那就是联系赵将军，告诉他我们可能失败了。

We decided to wait for the pickup. Maybe, just maybe, Factor Man would watch for the pickup as well and we could pick him up then. In the meantime, I had the unpleasant responsibility of contacting General Zhao and informing him that we had probably failed.

* * *

* * *

我后来才意识到，Factor Man 可能也在等着。他大概已经到了维也纳，去了 Sparta Safes（从火车站步行去是最方便的选择），然后等着。那天下午，这家小店的客流很低；几乎没有一个顾客。Factor Man 可能更愿意把钱放在尽可能拥挤的地方。我可以想象他从当地的一家咖啡馆买一杯浓咖啡，静静地等待 Sparta 看到一些生意。也许他在看书。也许他只是假装在读一本从当地一家外语商店买的书。但无从得知。保险箱对面的公园里人来人往，一如既往。

I would realize later that Factor Man was probably waiting as well. He had presumably arrived in Vienna, traveled to Sparta Safes (on foot from the train depot was as easy as any other option), and waited. Traffic at the small business was slow that afternoon; there was rarely even a single customer. Factor Man’s preference was likely to have been to drop off the money in as crowded a facility as possible. I could imagine him, getting an espresso from a local café and waiting quietly for Sparta to see some business. Perhaps he was reading. Perhaps he was only pretending to be reading a book that he had purchased from a local shop in a foreign language. But there was no way to know. The park across from the safe deposit box had the same traffic as ever.

快到四点的时候，三位顾客接连进入了 Sparta。几分钟后我接到电话，通知我 1739 号信箱已被访问。

Shortly before four, three customers entered Sparta in relatively rapid succession. I got a call a few minutes later to inform me that box 1739 had been accessed.

我迅速进入 Sparta Safes，取出我的保险箱，发现确实有三个保险箱不见了。保险箱管理员带我到了一个私人区域，告诉我他们今天很忙，我很幸运地得到了最后一个剩余的空间，这证实了这一点。

I entered Sparta Safes briskly, removing my safe deposit box and noticing that three others did indeed appear to be missing. This was confirmed when the safe agent showed me to a private area, telling me that they were busy today and that I had been lucky to get the last remaining space.

服务员告诉我，这个亭子没有电子安全措施，这是对的。我打电话给和我一起值班的特工。我告诉他有三种可能。很难预测杜安·莫里斯的快递员会是什么样子；也许是商人或女人，但很难说。我叫来了团队剩下的四名成员；我们需要跟踪每个人，还要留下足够的人手来跟踪任何看起来在监视的人。我的五名员工少得可怜。

The attendant had been correct when he told me that the booth was not electronically secure, and I placed a call to the agent who had been on watch with me. I told him that there were three possibilities. It was difficult to predict what a Duane Morris courier would look like; perhaps a businessman or woman of some sort, but it was hard to tell. I called in the four remaining members of the team; we would need to follow everyone, and still leave enough people in place to follow anyone else who appeared to be watching. My staff of five was distressingly thin.

我们观察了斯巴达保险箱进出的交通情况。有一名新人到达，有四人离开。不算到达的人，离开的人是一男一女，身着职业装，还有一名留着胡子、背着蓝色背包、拄着拐杖、走路有点跛的男子。不知怎的，那个职业装男子给我留下了最有希望的印象，我决定亲自跟踪他；另外两个离开的人被指派了单独的特工。我离开时，告诉剩下的三名特工跟随接下来的三人离开广场，前提是他们在接到有关 1739 号信箱的电话时在那里。

We watched the traffic in and out of Sparta Safes. There was one new arrival, and four departures. Not counting the arrival, the departures were a man and woman dressed professionally, and a bearded man with a blue backpack, a cane and a slight limp. The professionally dressed man somehow struck me as the best prospect, and I decided to follow him myself; individual agents were assigned to the other two departures. As I left, I told the three remaining agents to follow the next three people to leave the square, provided that they had been there when the call about box 1739 had come in.

单独跟踪某人需要几乎不可能的技巧。如果你能看到目标，目标也能看到你。最终，他或她会想知道为什么同一个人不断出现，无论是在餐馆、地铁还是电影院。

Following someone solo involves a nearly impossible level of tradecraft. If you can see the subject, the subject can see you. And eventually, he or she will wonder why it is that the same person keeps appearing, be it in restaurants, on the subway, or in a movie theater.

六个目标中，有三个最终会丢失，因为一个特工很难追踪到他们。这位职业女性似乎注意到了发生了什么，登上了一辆拥挤的地铁，并在最后一刻下车。离开广场的三个人中有一个身材矮小，很快就消失在人群中。另一个人似乎注意到了追捕，并向一名警察走去。

Of the six targets, three would eventually be lost because it was simply too difficult for one agent to track them. The professional woman seemed to notice what was up, boarded a crowded U-Bahn train and got off at the last moment. One of the three people leaving the square was short, and simply disappeared into a crowd. Another of them appeared to have noticed the pursuit and approached a police officer.

涉事的三名特工撤退并向我汇报。他们被重新分配，因此剩下的每个目标现在都有两名追随者。当时我不知道我们是否仍在跟踪感兴趣的目标，但跟踪本身已经变得容易得多。

The three agents involved backed off and reported back to me. They were reassigned, so that each of the remaining targets now had two followers. I did not know at the time if we were still following the target of interest, but the following itself had gotten substantially easier.

因子人

Factor Man

2018 年 6 月 8 日

June 8, 2018

两个圈子。一个是公开的，一个是匿名的。毫不奇怪，把钱存入公开圈子的保险箱很容易。要让我自己回到私人圈子可能要困难得多。

Two circles. One public, one anonymous. Getting the money into the safe deposit in the public circle had, not surprisingly, been easy. Getting myself back into the private circle was potentially significantly harder.

我不知道自己是否被跟踪。但我很久以前制定的计划假设我被跟踪了，我不知怎么在 Sparta Safes 被抓了，现在需要穿过奥兹山谷的非军事区，回到苏黎世私人圈子的安全地带。

I had no idea if I was being followed or not. But the plan I had produced so long ago assumed that I was, that I had somehow been picked up at Sparta Safes and now needed to make my way through the DMZ in Ötztal and back into the safety of the private circle in Zurich.

第一站是奥兹山谷。但如果非军事区要发挥它的作用，我到达那里时必须干净整洁。如果我有尾巴，我需要在维也纳和蒂罗尔阿尔卑斯山之间把它甩掉。

The first stop was Ötztal. But if the DMZ were to serve its purpose, I had to be clean when I got there. If I had a tail, I needed to lose it between Vienna and the Tyrolean Alps.

正如我所说，我不是间谍。如果有人跟踪我，可以肯定的是，他们跟踪我的能力肯定比我观察我的能力强。可能强得多。所以我需要某种方法才能在维也纳和奥兹山谷之间有效地隐身。经过一番深思熟虑——毫无疑问，我看了太多间谍电影——我想出了一个计划。第一步是用现金买一部一次性手机。

As I’ve said, I’m not a spy. If people were following me, it was a safe bet that they would be better at following than I was at looking. Probably much better. So I needed some way to become effectively invisible between Vienna and Ötztal. After a reasonable amount of deliberation – undoubtedly informed by too many spy movies – I had come up with a plan. The first step was to buy a disposable cell phone with cash.

在一家网吧，我用手机验证身份创建了一个新的电子邮件账户，然后打开了 Craigslist。Google 很好心地翻译了页面，我发现了一些私下出售的新款汽车。我给每个卖家都发了信息，然后等着回复。我早早就吃了晚饭，因为我不知道什么时候才能再吃东西。可能短期内不会了。

At an Internet café, I used the cell phone as authentication to create a new email account and then pulled up craigslist. Google was kind enough to translate the page, and I found a handful of late model vehicles for sale privately. I sent messages to each of the sellers, and waited to hear back. I had an early dinner, since I didn’t know when I would be able to eat again. Probably not any time soon.

第一次回复是在十分钟内，而且是在我吃完饭之前。是的，那辆深蓝色丰田车还可以用。地址是维也纳郊区的埃德布鲁斯特街。

The first response was within ten minutes and came before I had finished my meal. Yes, the car, a dark blue Toyota, was still available. The address was on the Erdbrustgasse, in the outskirts of Vienna.

我打车去了目的地，没有讨价还价就买下了这辆小丰田车，卖家再次出乎意料地用现金支付。这笔交易花掉了我从 Finn 的一百万美元中保留下来的大部分资金，但这没什么问题。

I took a taxi to the location, and bought the little Toyota without negotiating, surprising the seller by – again – paying cash. The purchase consumed most of what I had held back from Finn’s million dollars, but that was fine.

刘

Liu

2018 年 6 月 8 日

June 8, 2018

两名特工跟踪留着大胡子、拄着拐杖的男子，看到了这一切，并打电话给我。“就是那个背着背包的男子，”他们告诉我。“他知道了，所以就跑了。”

The two agents following the man with the beard and cane saw all of this and called me. “It’s the one with the backpack,” they told me. “He knows, and he’s running.”

这是个好消息，原因有很多。首先，我们可以集中所有资源跟踪一个人。六名受过训练的特工可以跟踪任何人，而且基本不会被发现。我将包括我在内的其余特工调往 Erdbrustgasse。

This was excellent news for multiple reasons. First, we would be able to focus all of our assets on following a single man. Six trained agents can follow anyone with essentially no risk of detection. I redirected the remaining agents – myself included – toward the Erdbrustgasse.

不过，更好的是，我们可以合理地假设我们跟踪的是 Factor Man 本人。信使不会逃跑。我们一定是搞错了时间。也许我最终还是可以省去给赵将军打电话的麻烦。

Better still, though, it was not unreasonable to assume that we were following Factor Man himself. The courier wouldn’t run. We must have gotten the timing wrong somehow. Perhaps I would be spared my call to General Zhao after all.

因子人

Factor Man

2018 年 6 月 8 日

June 8, 2018

我开着丰田车来到 Ringstrassen-Galerien，这是位于我买车的地方和维也纳市中心之间的一个购物中心。我把车停在购物中心停车场外的阴凉处，但没有下车。

I drove the Toyota to the Ringstrassen-Galerien, a shopping mall between where I had bought the car and central Vienna. I parked at the shaded outer edge of the mall parking lot but did not get out.

我能想到的只有三种方法，一种是开车跟在我后面，一种是想办法在车上装上 GPS，还有一种是使用卫星。我都有应对这些情况的计划。

I could only come up with three ways for people to tail me. They could drive along behind me, put a GPS on the car somehow, or use a satellite. I had plans for dealing with all of those.

伯克特

Burkett

2018 年 6 月 8 日

June 8, 2018

我当然对这一切一无所知。我没有手机，也没有电脑，所以我几乎什么都不知道。

I, of course, knew nothing about any of this. I had no cell phone and no computer, so I pretty much knew nothing about anything.

FBI 的头目们离开了，Emma 让我用她的手机。我打电话给我的编辑，他又打电话给《纽约时报》的法律人员。他们让我去买一部新手机和一台新电脑，并报销这两部手机的费用。他们还找了一群其他律师，他们都问我同样的问题，比如 FBI 的人是否虐待了我，然后就去做律师的事情了。

The FBI heavies left, and Emma let me use her cell phone. I called my editor, who called the legal folks at the Times. They told me to go buy a new phone and a new computer, and expense them both. They also got a bunch of other lawyers involved, all of whom asked me the same questions about whether the FBI guys had mistreated me, and then went off to do lawyerly things.

我去了 Verizon 售货亭，换了一部新手机。我告诉他们我的旧手机丢了，这似乎是真的。他们问我是否想让他们远程清除我旧手机上的数据。

I went to a Verizon kiosk and got a new phone. I told them that my old phone was lost, which seemed true enough. They asked me if I wanted them to remotely wipe my old phone.

好问题。我打电话给一位律师并询问了他。十分钟后他给我回电话，说有法律先例，在警方拘留期间远程擦除手机数据算作销毁证据。所以我不应该这么做。

Good question. I called one of the lawyers and asked him. He called me back ten minutes later and said that there was legal precedent that remotely wiping a phone in police custody counted as destruction of evidence. So I shouldn’t do it.

当然，手机是锁着的；我并不是一个十足的傻瓜。我想知道联邦调查局是否会像破解加州恐怖分子的手机一样破解我的手机。

The phone was locked, of course; I’m not a complete moron. I wondered if the FBI would manage to hack into my phone like they had the phone of those terrorists in California.

我去了当地的一家苹果商店，买了一台新电脑。我从旧电脑的备份中恢复了它，据说备份大约有两个月了。从某种意义上说，这很尴尬，但从另一种意义上说，这完全无关紧要，因为真正重要的是我的电子邮件，反正它也在云端。我一直在写一篇关于如果 Factor Man 真的能做到他说能做的事，而这件事却消失了，可能会对经济产生什么影响的文章，但无论如何，我最好还是重新开始。

I went to a local Apple store and got a new computer. I restored it from a backup of my old computer, said backup being about two months old. Embarrassing in one sense, but totally irrelevant in another, since all that really mattered was my email, which was in the cloud anyway. I had been writing a story about the likely economic impact if Factor Man turned out to be able to do what he said he could do, and that was gone, but it would probably be better if I started over in any case.

到目前为止，一切都很好。但事情即将变得更糟。我即将了解到，写新闻比真正成为新闻要愉快得多。

So far, so good. But things were about to get a whole lot worse. I was about to learn that writing about the news is a lot more pleasant than actually being the news.

《纽约时报》的律师（他们人数多得我都无法想象）在周一早上提起了大约 30 起诉讼。他们要求拿回我的电脑和手机。他们要求确保 FBI 不会侵入我的电脑和手机，理由是这侵犯了隐私，而我并没有被指控犯罪。他们要求确保 FBI 不会侵入我的电脑和手机，理由是我是一名记者，我的联系人受到《第一修正案》的保护。他们说，逮捕令本身执行不当。他们还提出了一大堆动议，这些动议甚至比这些更难以理解。

The Times lawyers (there were more of them than I could have imagined) filed about thirty court actions on Monday morning. They filed to get my computer and cell phone back. They filed to ensure that the FBI didn’t hack their way into either one, on the grounds that it was an invasion of privacy and I hadn’t been accused of committing a crime. They filed to ensure that the FBI didn’t hack their way into either one on the grounds that since I was a reporter, my contacts were protected by the First Amendment. They said that the warrant itself had been improperly executed. And they filed a whole bunch of motions that were even less comprehensible than that.

所有这些法律纠纷的真正结果就是让我的生活变得更糟。

The only real result of all of the legal wrangling was to make my life worse.

是的，周一法院发出了紧急命令，要求联邦调查局不要动我的手机。但实际上，他们在周末花了大约五分钟就侵入了我的手机。他们得到了一些朋友和商业联系人的电话号码，仅此而已。他们确实从我的手机进入了我的电子邮件帐户，他们发现 Factor Man 最初使用 factorman0@gmail.com 与我联系。我的笔记本电脑也受到了同样的对待。

Yes, an emergency court order was issued on Monday telling the FBI to leave my phone alone. In actuality, though, it had taken them about five minutes to hack into it over the weekend. They got the phone numbers of a bunch of friends and business contacts, and that was about it. They did get into my email account from my phone, and they found out that Factor Man had used factorman0@gmail.com to contact me originally. My laptop got treated about the same.

《纽约时报》许多案件的法律论点都有些奇怪。事实证明，美国法律提供的所有保护都植根于美国宪法，而法院裁定这些保护不适用于美国地理边界以外的非公民。没有人知道 Factor Man 是否是公民。没有人知道他在哪里（从地理上讲）。因此，不清楚他是否有权享受我们其他人享有的相同法律保护。

The legal arguments in many of the Times cases were somewhat bizarre. It turns out that all the protections offered by US law are rooted in the US Constitution, and the courts have ruled that those protections don’t apply to non-citizens outside the geographic borders of the United States. No one had a clue if Factor Man was a citizen or not. No one had a clue where he was, geographically speaking. So it wasn’t clear if he was entitled to the same legal protections guaranteed the rest of us.

但《纽约时报》提起所有这些案件的事实已为公众所知。不幸的是，这让我成为了一个轰动一时的人。人们似乎已经忘记了很久以前，我在《如何找到一个疯子》一文中向世界介绍了 Factor Man。现在，随着政府提交的一些简报，包括提到我与“被称为 Factor Man 的可能的恐怖分子”的电子邮件通信，我成了全世界都认为认识他的人。突然间，全世界都想亲自认识我。

But the fact that the Times had filed all these cases became public knowledge. And that, unfortunately, made me something of a cause célèbre. People had sort of forgotten that I had introduced Factor Man to the world way back when, in my old “How to Find a Crackpot” article. Now, with some of the briefs filed by the government including mentions of my email communication with the “likely terrorist known as Factor Man,” I became the one guy that the whole world figured knew him personally. And suddenly the whole world wanted to know me personally.

由于 Factor Man 在他的初始消息中提到我（显然）在某个时候帮过他一个忙，事情变得更加糟糕。也许我确实认识他。至少，我们曾经见过一段时间也是合理的。无论是我在电视上（这种情况经常发生），在街上被搭讪（这种情况也经常发生），还是在想管好自己的事时被打断（这也是……你明白我的意思），似乎每个人都想知道我的想法。

Since Factor Man had mentioned in his initial message that I had (apparently) done him a favor at some point, things became even worse. Maybe I did know him personally. At a minimum, it was reasonable that we had met some time. Whether I was on TV (which happened a lot), accosted in the street (which also happened a lot), or simply interrupted somewhere while trying to mind my own business (which also … you get the point), everyone, it seemed, wanted to know what I thought.

因素人接下来会做什么？他是骗子吗？我过去认识的人中是否有人是可能的候选人？想想我认识的所有人，他们看起来通情达理吗？有没有人很奇怪或令人毛骨悚然？有罪犯吗？

What would Factor Man do next? Was he a fraud? Was there anyone from my past who stuck out as a likely candidate? Just thinking about all the people I had ever known, did they seem reasonable? Was there anyone odd or creepy? Any criminals?

当然，这些都是同样的问题。每当我告诉人们我完全不知道答案时，他们还是会继续问。

It was all the same question, of course. And as often as I told people I had absolutely no idea about the answer, they just kept asking anyway.

7

7

哈德森

Hudson

2018 年 6 月 8 日

June 8, 2018

我我当了27 年的 FBI 探员。这占了我一生的大部分时间，几乎占了我整个职业生涯。在这段时间里，我得到了两名记者的合理合作。

I’ve been an FBI agent for twenty-seven years. That’s most of my life, and virtually all of my professional life. In all that time, I’ve gotten reasonable cooperation from exactly two journalists.

威廉·伯克特 (William Burkett) 不是其中之一。

William Burkett wasn’t one of them.

总的来说，他还只是个孩子。他没有意识到在恐怖分子开始行动之前就阻止他们符合所有人的利益，也没有意识到给 FBI 帮忙通常能得到丰厚的回报。你对我们好，我们会记住。你对我们不好，我们也会记住。

Mostly, he was just a kid. He hadn’t learned that it’s in everyone’s interests to stop terrorists before they start, and he hadn’t learned that favors to the FBI generally come back in spades. You treat us well, and we remember. Treat us badly, and we remember that, too.

伯克特大概会在某个时候学到这两件事。但现在，他还只是个孩子。一个有态度的孩子，没错，但他们都有态度。

Burkett would presumably learn both of these things at some point. But right now, he was just a kid. A kid with attitude, true, but they all have attitude.

我们惊讶地发现，Factor Man 个人在公众形象和业务上都使用同一个 Gmail 帐户。如果他犯过一次这样的错误，他可能还会犯不止一次。所以我联系了 Google，要求查看 Factor Man 的所有电子邮件。

We were surprised to learn that the Factor Man individual was using the same Gmail account both for his public persona and to conduct business. If he’d made that mistake once, he’d probably made it more than once. So I reached out to Google and asked to see all of Factor Man’s email.

谷歌说不。

Google said no.

我一直觉得这很神奇。谷歌根本不关心你的隐私，我指的是一点也不。他们会记录你曾经进行过的每一次互联网搜索。给你妻子买些珠宝作为生日礼物？谷歌知道。在拉斯维加斯寻找妓女？谷歌也知道。它的基本观点是，你的私人信息属于你和谷歌。只是不属于其他任何人。

I always find this amazing. Google has zero concern for your privacy, and I mean zero. They keep track of every Internet search you’ve ever done. Getting your wife some jewelry for her birthday? Google knows. Checking out the hookers in Vegas? Google knows that as well. Its basic view is that your private information belongs to you and to Google. Just not to anyone else.

接下来，我要求查看 Factor Man 的联系人列表，并辩称这些联系人本身不一定是私人的，而且由于 Factor Man 尚未确立自己是美国公民或居民的身份，所以所有联系人都是 Factor Man 实际正在做的事情的潜在同谋，等等。

I next asked to see a list of Factor Man’s contacts, arguing that the contacts themselves were not necessarily private, and that since Factor Man had not established himself as either a US citizen or resident, all of the contacts were potential co-conspirators in whatever it was that Factor Man was actually up to, and so on.

谷歌总是乐于助人，它给我发送了一份超过一亿个用于向 Factor Man 发送电子邮件的电子邮件地址列表。

Google, ever obliging, sent me a list of the over one hundred million email addresses that had been used to send email to Factor Man.

相信可以用数据埋葬美国政府永远是一个错误。

It is always a mistake to believe that you can bury the United States government with data.

* * *

* * *

美国国家安全局（NSA）曾经是美国政府中一个相对不为人知的部门。他们的职责大致就是收集和分析政府可能感兴趣的所有数据或其他信息。

The National Security Agency, or NSA, used to be a relatively obscure branch of the United States government. Their job, roughly speaking, was to gather and analyze all data or other information that might be of interest to the government.

随着数据收集在社会上越来越普遍，美国国家安全局被迫走出阴影，进入公众视野。当爱德华·斯诺登 (Edward Snowden) 表明（再次粗略地说）我们所有的手机通话都被视为“政府可能感兴趣的数据或其他信息”时，美国国家安全局 (NSA) 就成了家喻户晓的词。

As data gathering became more common in society generally, the NSA was forced out of the shadows and into the public eye. When Edward Snowden showed that (again, roughly speaking) all of our cell phone conversations were considered “data or other information that might be of interest to the government,” the NSA became a household word.

美国国家安全局不喜欢 Gmail。原因是 Gmail 是加密的：当您使用 Gmail 发送邮件时，邮件在离开您的计算机并通过互联网发送之前就已经加密。收件人（假设他也在使用 Gmail）只有在邮件到达他的计算机后才会解密。用于加密的大量数字（因此据说无法分解）是您 Google 帐户的一部分。

The NSA didn’t like Gmail. The reason was that Gmail is encrypted: When you send a message using Gmail, it’s encrypted before it even leaves your computer and heads out over the Internet. The recipient (assuming that he’s also using Gmail) decrypts it only after it arrives on his machine. The large (and supposedly therefore unfactorable) numbers used for the encryption are part of your Google account.

美国国家安全局无法阅读电子邮件这一事实让他们非常恼火。但即使他们无法阅读电子邮件，他们也毫不畏惧。通过 Gmail 发送消息，美国国家安全局会悄悄记录消息的来源。通过 Gmail 阅读消息，他们会记录您收到消息时所在的位置。

The fact that the NSA can’t read the emails annoys them greatly. But even though they can’t read the emails, they are undaunted. Send a message over Gmail, and the NSA will quietly record where it’s coming from. Read a message over Gmail, and they’ll record where you are when you get it.

顺便说一句，这些对 Factor Man 都不起作用，因为他使用 TOR。NSA 不喜欢 Gmail，但他们更不喜欢 TOR。

None of this worked with Factor Man, incidentally, since he used TOR. Much as the NSA disliked Gmail, they disliked TOR more.

但谷歌向政府提供的电子邮件地址列表却是一笔宝贵的财富。每个电子邮件地址都包含一个姓名（据说是 Factor Man 数据库中联系人的姓名）和一个 IP 地址，IP 地址是联系人在其 Google 帐户处于活动状态时倾向于使用的互联网位置。它还包括一个时间戳，表明联系人最后一次与 Factor Man 联系的日期。

But the list of email addresses provided to the government by Google was a treasure trove. Each email address included both a name (supposedly, the name of a contact in Factor Man’s database) and an IP address, which was the Internet location that the contact tended to use when his Google account was active. It also included a timestamp, giving the date at which the contact last was in touch with Factor Man.

就像 NSA 不喜欢 Google 和 TOR 一样，他们更不喜欢 Factor Man。他们与 Factor Man 的关系从根本上来说是不对称的：Factor Man 可能会了解 NSA 的秘密，但反过来却不行。

Much as the NSA didn’t like Google and TOR, they liked Factor Man even less. Their relationship with Factor Man was fundamentally asymmetric: Factor Man could potentially learn the NSA’s secrets, but not the other way around.

美国国家安全局通常支持不对称关系。但当不对称关系朝这个方向发展时，他们却不赞成。因此，他们迫切希望从 Google 提供的联系人列表中获取尽可能多的信息。

The NSA was generally in favor of asymmetric relationships. Just not when the asymmetry went in this particular direction. So they were eager to learn whatever they could from the contact list that Google had supplied.

对于每个联系人，他们首先会查找相关 IP 地址用于发送或接收 Google 电子邮件的所有时间。这很简单，因为他们知道任何人发送或接收此类电子邮件的所有时间。

For each contact, they began by finding all of the times that the IP address in question had been used to send or receive email from Google. That was straightforward, since they knew all the times that anyone had sent or received such email.

然后，他们找到了时间戳与 Factor Man 最近的联系相匹配的消息，并查看该消息是收到的还是发出的。他们毫不意外地发现，虽然有一亿人给 Factor Man 发过电子邮件，但 Factor Man 回应的人数却少得多。而且，最后一封电子邮件从 Factor Man 发给联系人的情况确实很少见，而反过来的情况则很少见。

Then they found the message whose timestamp matched the most recent contact with Factor Man, and looked to see if the message was incoming or outgoing. They found, not surprisingly, that while a hundred million people had sent email to Factor Man, Factor Man had responded to far fewer. And it was rare indeed that the last email went from Factor Man to the contact, as opposed to the other way around.

如果 Factor Man 对分解您的号码不感兴趣，则电子邮件将仅发送至 Factor Man。如果他核实了您的身份，则会发送一条外发消息要求确认，然后发送一条内发消息提供确认。

If Factor Man was uninterested in factoring your number, the email would be inbound (to Factor Man) only. If he checked your identity, there would be an outbound message asking for confirmation, and then an inbound message providing it.

Burkett 与 Factor Man 的通信没有显示出来，这意味着最后一条消息是 Burkett 发给 Factor Man 的。（该消息是请求更多时间发布原始文章的消息，但 NSA 不知道这一点。）事实上，Factor Man 发送的消息中只有一次没有得到回复。

Burkett’s exchange with Factor Man didn’t show up, which meant that the last message was from Burkett to Factor Man. (The message was the one requesting more time to publish the original article, but the NSA didn’t know that.) In fact, there was exactly one instance of Factor Man sending a message to which there had been no response.

联邦调查局的人看得出这是一条短信。我们看不懂，但后来我才知道，短信上写的是：“也许是阿尔伯特·爱因斯坦？”

The Feds could tell that it was a short message. We couldn’t read it, but I learned much later that it said, “Albert Einstein, perhaps?”

获奖者是杜安莫里斯公司的罗伯特·哈斯戴 (Robert Hasday)。

The recipient was Robert Hasday of Duane Morris.

我们已经找到了 Factor Man 的律师，并且已经全力以赴。

We had found Factor Man’s lawyer, and we were all over it.

因子人

Factor Man

2018 年 6 月 8 日

June 8, 2018

我坐在停车场里，在心里翻看自己要做的事情。克服 GPS 的干扰。克服汽车跟踪的干扰。克服卫星的干扰。

I sat in the parking lot, going through the mental list I had made of what I needed to do. Defeat GPS. Defeat following me by car. And defeat satellite.

第一，我必须确保没有人靠近我的车。

One. I had to make sure that no one approached the car.

二。我必须访问此丰田品牌和型号的在线文档。

Two. I had to access the online documentation for this make and model of Toyota.

三。我必须等待商场关门。

Three. I had to wait for the mall to close.

使用 GPS 跟踪我需要一个实际的设备，要么连接到汽车上，要么连接到我身上。从我离开 Sparta Safes 到我买车，我一直小心翼翼地确保没有人与我有任何重大的身体接触，而且在我开始驾驶之前，汽车不可能被标记。所以现在的风险是，当我坐在车里时，有人在车上安装了跟踪器。

Following me using GPS would involve an actual device, attached either to the car or to me. I had been careful to ensure that no one had any significant physical contact with me from the time I left Sparta Safes until I bought the car, and there was no way the car could have been tagged before I started driving it. So the risk was that someone put a tracker on the car now, while I was sitting in it.

停车时，商场的一名保安只接近过我一次。我启动了汽车，驶向停车场中另一个偏僻的地方。

I was approached only once while I was parked, by a security guard for the mall. I just started the car and drove to another remote location in the parking lot.

顺便说一下，确实有 GPS 干扰器。但它们的工作原理是发出与 GPS 系统所用频率相同的随机信号，我认为任何试图跟踪我的人都可以同样轻松地跟踪该信号。

There are GPS jammers, incidentally. But they work by putting out a random signal on the same frequency that GPS systems use, and I figured that anybody trying to track me could track that signal just as easily.

访问丰田汽车的在线文档很容易。我用一次性手机创建热点，登录 TOR，基本安全。找到文档后，我找到了方向盘左侧的保险丝盒，找到了刹车灯、车内灯和方向灯的保险丝。理论上，我可以不使用转向灯，但我担心自己可能会出于习惯而这样做。我不是间谍。我暂时把保险丝留在了里面。

Accessing the online documentation for the Toyota was easy. I used the burner phone to create a hotspot, logged onto TOR, and was pretty much safe. Once I found the documentation, I located the fuse box to the left of the steering wheel, and found the fuses for the brake lights, interior lights, and directionals. In theory, I could simply not use my turn signals, but I was afraid that I might do so out of simple habit. Not a spy. I left the fuses in for now.

然后我就开始等待。如果我不那么紧张的话，那会很无聊。当然，我确实花了一些时间计算当天的五个数字并发布结果。

And then I waited. It would have been boring, if I hadn’t been so nervous. I did take time to factor the day’s five numbers and post the results, of course.

刘

Liu

2018 年 6 月 8 日

June 8, 2018

当事人开车来到商场，然后停车。商场的停车场是多层结构，他将车停在最顶层，那里的车最少，他就待在车里。

The subject drove to the mall, and parked. Parking for the mall was a multilevel structure; he parked on the top level, which was the least occupied, and simply remained in the car.

监视相对简单。我和另一名特工驾驶车辆跟着他到了顶楼，并停在离他有一段距离的地方，确保他一直处于视线范围内。其余特工在较低楼层，靠近出口。由于只有一个出口，因此跟踪工作最终会变得容易。

Surveillance was relatively straightforward. One other agent and I, in our vehicles, followed him to the top floor and parked some distance away, keeping him in sight. The remaining agents were on lower floors, near the exit. The fact that there was only a single exit would eventually make it easy to resume the tail.

商场保安也注意到了这辆孤立的车辆，并走近了它。嫌疑人当时启动了汽车，停在了更近的地方。商场警察离开了，嫌疑人的车辆回到了停车场边缘的一个点（尽管是另一个点）。嫌疑人留在车里。我们必须保持合理的距离，这让我们很难确定他在做什么，尽管他似乎在用笔记本电脑。这在一定程度上证实了嫌疑人确实是 Factor Man。

Mall security also noticed the isolated vehicle, and approached it. The subject started his car at that point and parked closer in. The mall cop left, and the subject vehicle returned to a point (albeit a different one) on the edge of the lot. The subject remained in the vehicle. We had to maintain a reasonable distance, which made it difficult to determine what he was doing, although he seemed to be using a laptop computer. This provided some measure of confirmation that the subject was indeed Factor Man.

该对象似乎在车辆左侧仪表板下操作某物，但无法确定他在做什么。

The subject appeared to manipulate something under the dashboard on the left side of the vehicle, but it was impossible to determine what he was doing.

大家都在等待。

Everyone waited.

商场九点关门。涉事车辆离开，前往 A1 高速公路上的休息区，就在维也纳西边。他把车停在休息区一个相对偏僻的地方，然后等待。两名最近的特工开车经过休息区，停在 A1 高速公路的一侧；第三名特工驶入休息区，停在相当中心的位置。其他三辆车稍稍落后。从 A1 高速公路的这个位置开始，直到抵达大约七个小时车程外的苏黎世，几乎没有任何车辆。

The mall closed at nine. The subject vehicle left and proceeded to a rest area on the A1, just west of Vienna. He parked in a relatively remote location in the rest area and waited. The two closest agents drove by the rest area and pulled to the side of the A1; the third agent pulled into the rest area and parked in a fairly central location. The other three vehicles remained somewhat behind. From this point on the A1, there was virtually nothing until you arrived in Zurich, about seven hours’ drive away.

十一点刚过，他又开始开车了。

He began driving again shortly after eleven.

* * *

* * *

我们经常轮流值班。晚上在几乎空无一人的高速公路上跟踪一辆孤零零的汽车是一项挑战，但我们都受过训练。我们练习过这一点。

We all traded off fairly regularly. Following a lone car at night on a nearly deserted highway is a challenge, but it is a challenge for which we had all been trained. We had practiced this.

深夜环境对追捕者和追捕者来说都是有利的。它让目标更容易发现任何尾随他的车辆。但也让尾随者更容易，因为我们可以在近一英里外追踪目标车辆，而无需使用特殊设备。如果需要，我们甚至可以从前面跟车，特别是在出口相隔很远的路段。

A late night environment confers advantages to both the hunted and the hunter. It made it easier for the subject to spot any single car that was tailing him. But it also made it easier for the tails, since we could track the target vehicle from nearly a mile away without the use of special equipment. We could even follow from in front if need be, especially on sections of the road where exits were separated by significant distances.

一切进展顺利。我们追上了目标。我们超越了目标。我们后退，然后加速。我们尽可能地模仿其他几辆深夜从维也纳驶往瑞士的汽车。

It went just as it should. We followed the target. We leapfrogged it. We fell back, and sped up. As much as possible, we resembled a handful of other cars also traveling from Vienna toward Switzerland late at night.

在距离到达奥兹山谷约六十英里处，嫌疑人将车停在路边，似乎是想方便一下。他关掉了车头灯，我开着他下车时从他身边经过的那辆车。我在离路边约一英里的地方停了下来，前面还有另一名特工。其余四名特工在后面。我们都没有离得太近，但我们也不需要太近。我们留在车里，继续等待。

About sixty miles before reaching Ötztal, the subject pulled to the side of the road, apparently to relieve himself. He switched his headlights off and I was driving the vehicle that passed him as he got out of the car. I pulled to a stop about a mile down the road, along with another agent that was also in front. The four remaining agents were behind. None of us were terribly close, but we didn’t need to be. We remained in our cars and resumed waiting.

大约十分钟后，我隐约感觉到有车经过，但什么也没看见。我们的车窗都关上了，有没有车经过的声音？

After about ten minutes, I had a vague sense of a vehicle passing, but saw nothing. Our windows were rolled up; had there been the sound of a car going by?

我指示一位在离案发地点一英里处停车的探员继续前行，当他到达案发车辆停放的位置时，车辆已经不见了，只剩下一部被丢弃的手机。

I instructed one of the agents who had stopped a mile or so back to proceed forward; when he got to the location where the subject vehicle had been parked, it was gone. All that was there was a discarded cell phone.

大约落后了二十分钟，我们疯狂地向苏黎世驶去。尽管车速很快，却没有超过任何人。也许他已经把车停在路边过夜了。我们在苏黎世郊外停下，等待那辆蓝色丰田车。

About twenty minutes behind now, we drove frantically toward Zurich. In spite of our speed, we passed no one. Perhaps he had pulled off the road to spend the night. We stopped just outside Zurich and waited for the blue Toyota.

因子人

Factor Man

2018 年 6 月 8 日

June 8, 2018

离开维也纳的高速公路上车流量太大。更糟糕的是，我后面的车似乎总是比前面的多，离开维也纳的车也比到达维也纳的车多。我觉得午夜前的情况应该正好相反。

There was too much traffic on the highway out of Vienna. And to make matters worse, there always seemed to be more cars behind me than in front of me, and more traffic leaving Vienna than arriving. It seemed to me that just before midnight, it should have been the other way around.

可悲的是，我似乎被跟踪了。

Sadly, it appeared that I was being followed.

是的，我有一个计划。是的，我认为这是一个相当不错的计划。但我不是间谍，希望永远不会是。这些人受过训练，而我只是个业余爱好者。我曾（非常）希望我的计划不是必要的；希望我能以某种方式完成整个计划，同时保持安静和绝对匿名。好吧，你知道人们是怎么说最周密的计划的。

Yes, I had a plan. Yes, I thought it was a pretty good plan. But I’m not a spy and, hopefully, never will be. These folks were trained, and I was an amateur. I had hoped (a lot) that my plan wouldn’t be necessary; that I would somehow pull the whole thing off while remaining quietly and absolutely anonymous. Well, you know what they say about the best-laid plans.

我回到 A1 路肩上的车里，找到了我之前发现的三根保险丝。我把它们从小塑料支架里拿出来。刹车灯、方向灯或车内灯都不见了。我擦了一下一次性手机，然后扔了出去。它不会引导我，但它自己可以被追踪。然后我从背包里拿出夜视镜。它们的效果和我预期的差不多。希望自己能隐形，我回到 A1 并继续向苏黎世行驶。我在下一个出口下了车，然后走上匝道回到高速公路，停在足够远的地方，这样我就能看到 A1 的交通，而不会被人发现。

I got back into the car on the shoulder of the A1 and found the three fuses I had identified earlier. I popped them out of the little plastic holders where they lived. No more brake lights, directionals, or interior lights. I wiped down the burner phone and tossed it. It wouldn’t lead to me, but it could be tracked itself. Then I took the night vision goggles out of the backpack. They worked pretty much like I expected. Hopefully invisible, I returned to the A1 and proceeded toward Zurich. I got off at the next exit, but then took the onramp back toward the freeway, stopping far enough back that I could see the A1 traffic without being seen myself.

果然，有一辆车从我刚才驶出的出口驶入了镇内。其余的车继续沿着 A1 向苏黎世方向行驶，速度比之前快得多。我等他们全部通过后才重新上路。

Sure enough, one car took the exit that I had used and proceeded into the town. The remainder stayed on the A1 toward Zurich, going much faster than they had before. I waited for them all to pass and then got back on the road myself.

我继续前行，前面什么也没有。我也不停地查看后视镜，但那里什么也没有。

There was nothing in front of me as I proceeded. I kept checking my rearview mirror as well; nothing there, either.

我尽可能地开快车，但速度仍然远低于限速。我最终在五点前到达了奥兹山谷出口。天色仍然很暗，而且我好几英里都没看到另一辆车。GPS 和实体跟踪都派不上用场了。但跟踪我的人都知道这辆车，而且卫星图像上也有可能找到这辆车。

I drove as quickly as I dared, which was still significantly below the speed limit. I eventually reached the Ötztal exit shortly before five. It was still dark, and I hadn’t seen another car in miles. So much for GPS, and for a physical tail. But anyone following me knew the car, and the car could potentially be found on satellite images.

当我回到酒店时，奥兹山谷一片漆黑，空无一人。我把车停在有顶棚的停车场，仔细擦拭了开车时碰过的所有表面。为了保险起见，我取下了车牌。我真希望自己能想出办法把车开进奥兹山谷的阿切河。电影里把这看起来很容易，但我不知道实际怎么做。从桥上开车下来似乎不太现实，这里的水太清澈了，我无论如何也看不出我能用这种方式把车藏起来。

Ötztal was dark and empty as I navigated my way back to the hotel. I parked in the covered parking and carefully wiped down all of the surfaces I had touched while driving. For good measure, I removed the license plates. I wished I could figure out a way to just drive the car into the Ötztal Ache river. They make that look easy in the movies, but I had no idea how to do it in actuality. Driving off a bridge just didn’t seem practical, and the water here was so clear that it wasn’t obvious to me that I could hide the car that way in any case.

但我看不出这有什么关系。我把假发和护目镜放进现在空了的背包里，然后把它扔进了酒店后面的一个小垃圾箱。垃圾箱盖可以确保背包不会出现在任何卫星图像上，而且它会在一天内消失。我相当坚定地相信我已经毫发无损地回到了 DMZ，于是我回到房间睡着了。我离开还不到二十四小时。

But I couldn’t see how it mattered. I put the wig and goggles in the now empty backpack, and tossed it into a small dumpster behind the hotel. The dumpster cover would ensure that the backpack didn’t show up on any satellite imagery, and it would be gone in a day. Believing fairly solidly that I had returned to the DMZ unscathed, I went back to my room and crashed. I had been gone less than twenty-four hours.

第二天早上，一切都很顺利。由于睡眠不足，我比平时起得晚一些，然后刮了胡子。

The next morning was delightfully uneventful. I arose somewhat later than usual after not nearly enough sleep and shaved.

酒店服务员一边给我送早餐，一边微笑着说：“今天没留胡子吗？”

The hotel waiter smiled as he brought my breakfast. “No beard today?”

我也笑了笑。“是时候回归外面的世界了，”我解释道。服务员笑了，我们一致认为，一切美好的事物都必须有个结束。

I smiled back. “Time to rejoin the outside world,” I explained. The waiter laughed and we agreed that all good things must come to an end.

我的脸再次与护照相符，我搭乘 RailJet 前往苏黎世。安全回到私人圈子后，我以自己的名义返回家乡，成为又一个在夏天旅行的美国游客。幸运的是，这两个圈子永远不会再接触。

My face once again matching my passport, I caught the RailJet to Zurich. Safely back in the private circle, I returned home under my own name, just one more American tourist traveling during the summer. With any luck, the two circles would never touch again.

刘

Liu

2018 年 6 月 9 日

June 9, 2018

那辆丰田车再也没有出现。第二天早上，我们才知道他已经不见了。

The Toyota never appeared. By the next morning, it was clear that we had lost him.

我只有糟糕的选择。我们可以沿着原路返回维也纳，希望能偶然发现那辆车，但这似乎不太可能。

I had only poor choices. We could retrace our steps toward Vienna and hope to somehow stumble across the car, but that seemed unlikely.

我可以进行卫星搜索。这似乎也不太可能。我们最后一次看到这辆车是在距苏黎世约 350 公里的地方，而且我们不确定我们的目标最终是否会抵达苏黎世。苏黎世只是他最后被人发现前往的方向上的第一个大型国际机场。

I could do a satellite search. That also seemed unlikely. We had last seen the car about 350km from Zurich, and had no certainty that our subject would eventually arrive in Zurich in any event. Zurich was simply the first large international airport in the direction he was last known to be heading.

最后，我终于可以寻求一些帮助了。虽然这不太可能成功，但也许是我所有选择中成功率最高的一个。不幸的是，这也是最危险的一个。中国特工不需要帮助。即使他们需要帮助，他们也不会主动提出要求。

Finally, I could enlist some assistance. This was also unlikely to be successful, but had perhaps the best chance of my various possibilities. It was also, unfortunately, the most fraught with political peril. Chinese operatives are not expected to need help. And when they do, they are not encouraged to actually request it.

我在心里盘算了一下。我会离开酒店，买一部无法追踪的手机，这在任何大都市地区都很容易。苏黎世公共交通 VBZ 会带我去一个随机地点，然后我会打电话给苏黎世警方。

I played it out in my mind. I would leave the hotel and purchase an untraceable cell phone, trivial in any large metropolitan area. Zurich public transport, the VBZ, would take me to a random location, and I would call the Zurich police.

我会用阿拉伯语告诉他们，我是一个虚构的伊斯兰极端组织的成员，我把一辆深蓝色丰田车停在了瑞士一个未公开的公共场所。车牌号是 K-799 RY。车里装满了炸药，五小时后就会爆炸。

I would tell them, in Arabic, that I was a member of a fictional Islamic extremist group, and that I had left a dark blue Toyota at an undisclosed public location in Switzerland. The license plate was K-799 RY. The vehicle was filled with explosives and was set to detonate in five hours.

接下来会发生什么就不太确定了。他们肯定会追踪到打电话的地点，并搜索附近的所有监控录像。他们可能会发现是我打的电话。

What would happen next was less certain. They would surely trace the cell call to the location from which it had been made, and search all of the nearby security footage. It was possible that they would discover that I had been the one making the call.

他们会在维也纳找到这辆车的卖家。卖家会报告说，司机确实看起来很着急，用现金支付了这辆车。买家似乎是闪族人。但不幸的是，买家还会报告说，买家说着一口流利的英语，带有美国口音。

They would find the seller of the car in Vienna. He would report that the driver had indeed seemed to be in a hurry and had paid for the car with cash. He would report that the buyer appeared to be Semitic. But he would also report, unfortunately, that the buyer spoke flawless English with an American accent.

即使这两件事都没有发生，警方决定找到这辆车，我也觉得他们不太可能找到。这辆车肯定是藏起来了，甚至可能被毁了。它可能在奥地利或瑞士的任何地方。而且它还挂着原车牌的可能性几乎为零。
