顶尖调查记者威廉·伯克特 (William Burkett) 回来了。

William Burkett, crack investigative reporter, was back.

哈德森

Hudson

2019 年 8 月 1 日

August 1, 2019

我一直都很喜欢西雅图。也许是因为小时候和家人一起去太空针塔度假。也许是因为那里的雨。有些人就是性格阴郁。

I’ve always liked Seattle. Maybe it was going up in the Space Needle as a kid on a family vacation. Maybe it’s the rain. Some people just have an overcast personality.

我不想住在这里，不想用纽约的喧嚣换取太平洋西北部的悠闲。但我可以忍受少量的悠闲。我喜欢这里的天气，也喜欢蛤蜊浓汤。

I wouldn’t want to live here, to trade the hustle and bustle of New York for the laid back of the Pacific Northwest. But I could deal with laid back in small quantities. I liked the weather, and I liked the clam chowder.

我特别喜欢 Ivar's 的蛤蜊浓汤。它现在是一家连锁店，甚至在西塔科还有一家分店。但三十年前我第一次去那里时，它只是一家家庭餐馆，从那时起我就一直去那里。如果不去 Ivar's，去西雅图地区探望家人就不算完整。如果幸运的话，我还会再去三十年。

I especially like the clam chowder at Ivar’s. It’s a chain now, even with a branch in SeaTac. But it was just a family restaurant when I first went there thirty years ago, and I’ve been going ever since. A visit to family members in the Seattle area just wouldn’t be complete without a stop at Ivar’s. With any luck, I’ll be going for thirty years more.

我向西雅图特别行动委员会报了名，然后前往约翰·金德曾经居住过的贝尔维尤。我在那里会见了警察局长。

I checked in with the Seattle SAC and then headed out to Bellevue, where John Kind had lived. I met with the chief of police there.

这些会议总是充满挑战。总的来说，警察只想做个好警察。可悲的是，想做好警察的警察往往不会成为局长。警察局长往往把这个职位看作是垫脚石，而不是责任。

These meetings are always a challenge. By and large, cops just want to be good cops. The sad thing is that the cops who want to be good cops tend not to become chiefs. Police chiefs all too often view the position as a stepping stone instead of a responsibility.

在我偶尔出差处理当地案件时，或者更常见的情况是，当我在纽约为其他地方的特工帮忙时，我总是先与局长联系。尤其是如果是在像贝尔维尤这样相对较小的地区。然后会发生以下两种情况之一：要么我被交给负责我感兴趣的案件的侦探或其他调查员，要么我就不会被交给他们。

On those rare occasions when I travel to get involved in a local case, or the more common ones when I’m doing a New York favor for an agent elsewhere, I always start with the chief. Especially if it’s a moderately small place like Bellevue. Then one of two things happens. Either I get handed off to the detective or other investigator handling the case that interests me, or I don’t.

交接案件是件好事。这意味着所有涉案人员都意见一致，目标是破案，或者至少了解犯罪事实。不交接案件总是争夺地盘的第一步。那些主要关心地盘的人只是不明白，包括我在内的大多数人真的不在乎它。

Getting handed off is good. It means that everyone involved is on the same page and that the goal is to solve the crime or, at a minimum, to understand it. Not getting handed off is always the first step in jockeying for turf. The people who care primarily about turf just don’t understand that most people, including me, really couldn’t give a rip about it.

贝尔维尤警察局长甚至没有让我坐下。相反，他把我带到了负责此案的侦探黛比·哈勒的办公桌前。我确实坐在那里，哈勒把谋杀案记录本给了我。告诉我我可以慢慢来，抄写任何我想抄写的内容，当场或在审讯室里检查。只是不要把它带走。

The Bellevue chief of police didn’t even ask me to sit down. Instead, he brought me to the desk of Detective Debbie Haller, who was handling the case. There I did sit, and Haller gave me the murder book. Told me I could take my time with it, copy anything I wanted, examine it right there or in an interrogation room. Just don’t take it away with me.

这本书很薄，哈勒对此感到很沮丧。贝尔维尤平均每年发生两起谋杀案，而她在这一案中没有胜诉。她采访了家人和同事，但没有找到作案动机。金德的财务状况很好。他和妻子拥有一栋简朴的房子，抵押贷款数额与你想象的差不多。他们俩都在工作，这就是他们偿还贷款的方式。

The book was thin, which Haller found frustrating. Bellevue has an average of two murders a year, and she wasn’t winning on this one. She had interviewed family and coworkers, and there was no motive. Kind’s finances were clean. He and his wife owned their modest house and had a mortgage about the size you’d expect. They both worked, which is how they made the payments.

案发当天早上，金德独自一人在家，随后被杀。据大家所知，他开门后就被枪杀了。凶手记录中有一份弹道报告，表明他是被一把格洛克手枪击中，并采访了许多邻居，但邻居们什么也没看到。这并不奇怪；金德居住的小社区在任何时候，包括周六早上，都有相当多的车辆通行。凶手不太可能以任何有用的方式脱颖而出。

On the morning in question, Kind had been alone in the house when he was killed. As far as anyone could tell, he had answered the door and been shot right there. The murder book had a ballistics report indicating that he was shot with a Glock and a bunch of interviews with neighbors who had seen nothing. It wasn’t surprising; the little community in which Kind had lived saw a reasonable amount of vehicular traffic at any time, including Saturday mornings. The killer was unlikely to have stood out in any useful way.

我照例去了犯罪现场，那里不再用通常的黄色胶带封锁。我在一条绿树成荫的街道上发现了一栋中产阶级的小房子，街道两旁都是其他中产阶级的小房子。其中一栋房子前面挂着待售标志；我不知道这是对谋杀案的回应，还是郊区生活的正常变动。

I took a predictable trip to the crime scene, which was no longer cordoned off with the usual yellow tape. I found a small middle-class house on a tree-lined street full of other small, middle-class houses. There was a for-sale sign in front of one of the houses; I couldn’t tell if it was a response to the murder or just the usual turnover that accompanies suburban living.

验尸官的报告显示，金德是被一颗子弹打死的，子弹穿过他的右眼窝，进入枕叶，并向后脑勺方向扩散。子弹在他的脑袋里回荡，金德当场毙命。凶手自凶杀案发生后一直无人居住，大部分证据都完好无损。前门内的血迹与枪击描述相符。也许凶手是左撇子；如果你面对面射击某人，你往往会用持枪手的同一侧射击。根据子弹首先击中金德后脑勺的位置，也许凶手比金德的 5 英尺 11 英寸矮几英寸。或者也许我什么都不知道。

The coroner’s report indicated that Kind had been killed by a single bullet, which had passed through his right eye socket, entered the occipital lobe and expanded on its way toward the back of Kind’s skull. It had then rattled around the inside of his head, and he had been killed instantly. The house had been unoccupied since the murder, and most of the evidence remained intact. The blood spatter inside the front door was consistent with the description of the shooting. Maybe the killer was left-handed; if you’re shooting someone while standing face-to-face, you tend to shoot them on the same side as your gun hand. Maybe the killer was a few inches shorter than Kind’s 5’11”, based on the point at which the bullet first impacted the back of Kind’s skull. Or maybe I didn’t know a damn thing.

我走进房子，发现里面有三间卧室，一间主卧和两间儿童房。一切看起来都很正常，甚至有些乏味。一些衣服和洗漱用品都被拿走了，但一切都做得干净利落。哈勒告诉我，她亲自收集了全家人需要的东西，这样他们就不必再回家了；他们住在金德的婆婆家，她住在西雅图市区。这些照片反映了一个幸福的家庭，各种家庭成员的合影很不错，只有几张个人照。

I made my way into the house and found three bedrooms, a master and two kids’. Everything appeared absolutely normal, almost boring. Some of the clothing had been removed, along with toiletries, but it was all done neatly and carefully. Haller had told me that she herself had gathered what the family needed so that they would not have to return to the house; they were staying with Kind’s mother-in-law, who lived in Seattle proper. The pictures reflected a happy family, with a decent mix of groupings of the various family members and only a couple of individual shots.

我走进房子后面的办公室，哈勒告诉我电脑就在那里。她还告诉我硬盘已被清除。贝尔维尤警方已将其取出进行分析，发现不仅所有文件都被删除，而且文件还被垃圾覆盖，以至于无法恢复曾经存在的信息。除了电脑不见了以外，办公室和其他一切都一样平淡无奇。

I went into the office at the back of the house, where Haller had told me the computer had been located. She had also told me that the hard drive had been wiped. The Bellevue police had pulled it for analysis and determined that not only had all the files been deleted, but they had been overwritten with garbage in a way that made it impossible to recover the information that had once been there. Other than the fact that the computer was now missing, the office was as unremarkable as everything else.

所有这些都与我的观点一致，即有人断定 Kind 就是 Factor Man，或者可能是。鉴于这两起谋杀案都发生在 Factor Man 拍卖结束之前，而且 Factor Man 本人可能已经将代码分发给了中标者，因此凶手对 Kind 身份的判断似乎是错误的。

All of this was consistent with my view that someone had concluded that Kind either was, or might be, Factor Man. Given that the murders had both occurred before the Factor Man auction concluded, and that Factor Man himself had presumably distributed the code to the winning bidder, it appeared that the killer had been wrong about Kind’s identity.

但那并没有多大帮助。基本上没有物证，而且我认为重复哈勒对家人的采访并干扰可能需要数年甚至永久的治疗过程不会有什么收获。

Not that it helped much. There was essentially no physical evidence, and I decided that little would be gained by repeating Haller’s interviews with the family and interfering with a healing process that would take something between years and forever.

我订了第二天早上飞往迈阿密的航班。回酒店的路上，我去了 Ivar's 餐厅，但那里的杂烩汤不如往常好吃。

I booked myself on a flight to Miami the next morning. On the way back to my hotel, I stopped at Ivar’s, but the chowder wasn’t as good as usual.

* * *

* * *

迈阿密拥有西雅图所没有的一切。

Miami was everything Seattle wasn’t.

天气很热，阳光明媚。

It was hot. It was sunny.

这里的节奏和纽约一样，甚至可能更糟。退休人员（有很多）表现得非常匆忙，生怕自己在完成手头的工作之前心脏病发作而倒下。尚未退休的人也同样匆忙，生怕他们的顾客倒下。

And the pace was like New York’s, or maybe even worse. The retirees – and there were many – acted like they were in a tremendous rush, lest they keel over of a heart attack before they finished whatever it was they were doing. People who had not yet retired were in similar rushes, lest their customers keel over.

鲍勃·斯特里克兰是警察局长。他没有和我握手，但他请我坐下。“首先，我们要做的事情是，”他告诉我。“我们正在进行一项积极的调查。你认为你可以参与其中，那很好。我很乐意帮忙。但如果你什么也做不了，那就帮大家一个忙，让我们做我们受过训练要做的事情。”

Bob Strickland was the chief of police. He didn’t shake my hand, but he did ask me to sit down. “First things first,” he told me. “We have an active investigation going on here. You think you can add to it, that’s great. I’d love the help. But if you’ve got nothing to contribute, do everyone a favor and let us do what we’ve been trained to do.”

迈阿密平均每年发生 81 起谋杀案。斯特里克兰又花了一个小时才告诉我，他们在破案方面有多出色，尤其是在他值班的时候。负责戴尔·米勒谋杀案的侦探同时还在处理另外两起谋杀案。斯特里克兰打电话给他，问他是否想抽出时间见我。告诉他这“完全是自愿的”。他停顿了片刻，我只听到了他那边的说法。“没问题，”他说。“我会支持你的。绝对的。”

Miami averages 81 murders a year. It took Strickland another hour to tell me how good they were at solving them, especially on his watch. The detective handling the Dale Miller murder was handling two others at the same time. Strickland called him up and asked if he wanted to make time to see me. Told him it was “totally optional.” He paused for a few moments and I only heard his side of it. “Not a problem,” he said. “I’ve got your back. Absolutely.”

他转身对我说：“抱歉，”他说，“负责此案的侦探还有另外两起谋杀案要处理。当然，他可以抽出时间给你，但得等上几天。”

He turned back to me. “Sorry,” he said. “The detective working that case has two other active murders on his plate as well. He can make time for you, of course, but it’ll be a few days.”

我感谢他抽出时间，然后离开了。纸板。

I thanked him for his time, and left. Cardboard.

斯特里克兰已经明确地告诉他的侦探，他更愿意放过我；侦探决定这样做是最安全的避免引起波澜的方式，这并不奇怪。但侦探和巡警是一样的。目标是破案，避免政治。

Strickland had been pretty clear with his detective that his preference was to blow me off; it was hardly surprising that the detective had decided the safest way to avoid making waves was to do just that. But a detective was the same as a beat cop. The goal was to solve the crime and avoid the politics.

米勒是一位相当知名的互联网人士，而这起案件在迈阿密媒体上也得到了可想而知的报道。我用谷歌搜索了大约两分钟才发现，负责此案的侦探是迈阿密海滩分局的乔希·威尔逊。

Miller had been a reasonably well-known Internet guy, and the case had gotten a predictable amount of play in the Miami press. It took about two minutes on Google for me to find out that the detective who pulled the case was Josh Wilson, who worked out of the Miami Beach precinct.

我开车去了那里，和负责接待的警官交谈。向他出示了我的证件，并说我希望和威尔逊侦探谈谈。

I drove down there and spoke to the sergeant who was manning reception. Showed him my credentials and said I was hoping to talk with Detective Wilson.

“我确信你会来，”他回答道。“目前还不清楚这位侦探是否希望与你交谈。”

“I’m sure you are,” he responded. “It’s not so clear that the detective is hoping to talk with you.”

“我认识的每一位侦探都希望局长所希望的差不多，”我告诉他。“我并不想在这里引起波澜。只是我在西雅图有一个案子，看起来可能与这个案子有关。上次我检查时，我们都应该站在同一边。”

“Every detective I’ve ever known hopes pretty much what the chief hopes,” I told him. “I’m not looking to make waves here. It’s just that I’ve got a case in Seattle that looks like it might be related to this one. Last I checked, we were all supposed to be on the same side.”

警官最终决定我们可能确实是同一阵营的，并告诉我，威尔逊下班后经常去 Lionesse Wetlab。那是 Rickenbacker Causeway 上的一家廉价酒吧。

The sergeant eventually decided that we probably were indeed on the same side, and told me that Wilson could often be found at the Lionesse Wetlab after his shift. It was a dive bar on the Rickenbacker Causeway.

* * *

* * *

在廉价酒吧停车总是个难题。最后我才发现，我需要把车停在附近的迈阿密大学海洋学院校园里，而且酒吧下班后开门，停车很方便。

Parking is always a challenge at a dive bar. I eventually figured out that I needed to park on the neighboring University of Miami Marine School campus, which turned out to be easy after business hours when the bar opened up anyway.

六点刚过，威尔逊走进来，我从报纸剪报上认出了他。四十多岁，一张脸看起来像是一个值得信任的人，但同时也是一个不会接受任何人废话的人。他超重了，因为他的街头生涯早已过去。但体重没有超重多少，因为他还记得街头的生活，照镜子时仍然觉得自己是个巡警。

I recognized Wilson from a newspaper clipping when he walked in a little after six. Mid-forties, face that looked like someone you could trust but also someone who wouldn’t take any crap from anyone. Overweight, because his street days were long behind him. But not much overweight, because he remembered what they were like and still saw a beat cop when he looked in the mirror.

我走上前去。“威尔逊侦探？约翰·赫德森。”

I stepped up. “Detective Wilson? John Hudson.”

他看上去不太高兴见到我。“是的，中士告诉我你可能会来这里。我不知道我对此有何感受。”

He looked less than excited to see me. “Yeah, Sarge told me you might show up here. Not sure how I feel about that.”

他的回答简单直接。我决定也试一试，希望能有好运。“侦探先生，请告诉我，杀害戴尔·米勒的凶手是左撇子吗？”

His response was simple and direct. I decided to try the same back and hope for some luck. “So tell me, Detective, was Dale Miller’s killer left-handed?”

威尔逊考虑了一下。“好的，特工约翰·哈德森。我请你喝一杯，你可以告诉我你为什么问这个问题。”他给我买了一杯啤酒，我们在后面找了一张桌子坐下。

Wilson considered this. “Okay, Special Agent John Hudson. I’ll buy you a drink, and you can tell me why you asked that particular question.” He bought me a beer and we found a table in the back.

“好吧，”他问我。“为什么问这个问题？”

“Okay,” he asked me. “Why that question?”

“我认为答案是‘是的’。 ”

“I assume that the answer is, ‘Yes.’ ”

“答案是‘可能’。勒痕暗示了这一点，但还不确定。轮到你了。”

“The answer is, ‘Probably.’ The strangulation marks suggest it, but it’s not certain. Your turn.”

“其实，情况是一样的，”我告诉他。“西雅图郊外发生了一起谋杀案，我认为可能与此有关。类似的模糊证据表明凶手是左撇子。”

“Same deal, actually,” I told him. “There’s a murder outside Seattle that I think might be related. Similar vague evidence of a left-handed killer.”

我们俩都等着。“那家伙在门口被杀，脸部右侧中枪。”

We both waited. “Guy killed in his doorway, gunshot to the right side of the face.”

“我明白了。你认为这些谋杀案有关联……为什么？”

“I see. And you think the killings are related … why?”

这个问题问得好，但我不太愿意回答。我告诉威尔逊，他们的鼻子很像。

It was a good question, and not one I was really willing to answer. I told Wilson that they had similar noses.

“鼻子？你开玩笑吧。”

“Noses? You gotta be kidding me.”

“天晓得。你给我留点面子，好吗？西雅图凶杀案基本上没有物证。什么都没有。凶手用的是格洛克手枪。就是这样。”

“God’s own truth. Cut me a little slack here, okay? There was basically zero physical evidence in the Seattle killing. Nothing. Killer used a Glock. That’s it.”

威尔逊只是盯着我看。我看得出他对迈阿密谋杀案还有更多了解，但我不知道是什么。轮到我等着他决定分享什么和不分享什么。

Wilson just stared at me. I could tell that he had more in the Miami killing, but I had no idea what it was. My turn to wait while he decided what to share and what not to.

“我们掌握的信息不止这些。”他停顿了一下。“但如果我们要交易，就必须交易。FBI 不会只告诉你我们认为你需要知道的那些废话。”

“We’ve got more than that.” He paused. “But if we’re gonna trade, we gotta trade. No FBI-telling-you-only-what-we-think-you-need-to-know crap.”

“这很公平。但我在这里是孤注一掷，侦探。我的 ASAC 知道我在旅行，但我甚至还没有告诉她我为什么认为这些谋杀案有关联。这太牵强了。但如果证据确凿，你会是第二个知道的人。够了吗？”

“That’s fair. But I’m out on a limb of my own here, Detective. My ASAC knows that I’m traveling, but I haven’t even told her why I think the murders are connected. It’s too thin. But if it firms up, you’ll be the second to know. Good enough?”

“太好了。他是乔什。”他终于隔着桌子伸出了手，我握了握。

“Good enough. And it’s Josh.” He finally offered a hand across the table, and I shook it.

“我相信你，西雅图案没什么有趣的，但我还是想看看这本书。你同意吗？”

“I’ll trust you that there’s nothing of interest in the Seattle case, but I’d still like a look at the book. You swing that?”

我告诉他我可以。“我甚至可以开始，”我说。“西雅图案的硬盘被抹掉了。”

I told him I could. “And I’ll even start,” I said. “The hard drive in the Seattle case was erased.”

“我们也一样，”乔什说。他停下来笑了笑。“鼻子？ ”

“Same with us,” Josh said. He stopped and grinned. “A nose?”

我回之以微笑。“鼻子。”

I smiled back. “A nose.”

“好的。”他停顿了一下，我等着他告诉我他正在考虑的事情。“我们有头发了。”

“Okay.” He paused for a moment, and I waited for whatever it was he was considering telling me. “We’ve got a hair.”

一根头发都很重要。除此之外，如果我们能找到凶手，一根头发就意味着定罪。“在系统中？”我问。

A hair was huge. Among other things, a hair meant a conviction if we could find the killer. “In the system?” I asked.

“仍在等待测序。目前，我们只知道它很长、很直、而且是黑色的。很粗。可能是亚洲人。”

“Still waiting on sequencing. At this point, all we know is that it’s long, it’s straight, and it’s black. Thick. Maybe Asian.”

测序就是 DNA 测序。我猜迈阿密警察局的 DNA 数量超出了他们的处理能力，而且严格按照先进先出的原则处理。他们可能要等上几周才能得到结果。

Sequencing meant DNA sequencing. My guess was that the Miami PD had more DNA than they could deal with, and it was handled strictly first-in, first-out. It might be a couple of weeks before they had results.

我告诉威尔逊，我可以加快速度。但我也告诉他，我预计他会拒绝。他必须和一屋子等待自己 DNA 检测结果的人一起工作，如果让联邦调查局的人帮他插队，他不会交到任何朋友。

I told Wilson I could make it go faster. But I also told him I expected him to decline. He had to work with a roomful of guys waiting on their own DNA results, and he wouldn’t make any friends by having the Feds help him jump the queue.

“我很好，”他告诉我。“谢谢你的理解。”

“I’m good,” he told me. “And thanks for understanding.”

我们一边喝啤酒一边聊了一会儿。乔希告诉我，就像在西雅图一样，这起谋杀案发生在一个安静的街区，除了头发，基本上没有其他物证。邻居们什么也没看到。我们交换了对案件的模糊感受，这些感受往往比谋杀书中的细节更重要。我们同意交换书籍并互相通报情况。

We talked a little more as we worked on our beers. Josh told me that just like in Seattle, the murder had taken place in a quiet neighborhood and that other than the hair, there was basically nothing in the way of additional physical evidence. The neighbors hadn’t seen a thing. We swapped vague feelings about the cases, which are often more important than the details in the murder books. We agreed to exchange books and keep each other informed.

回酒店的路上我喝了一杯古巴雪茄。比我记忆中的味道还要好。

I had a cubano on the way back to my hotel. It was better than I remembered.

17

17

伯克特

Burkett

2019 年 8 月 2 日

August 2, 2019

发件人：jess@jmac.com（Jess MacMurray）

From: jess@jmac.com (Jess MacMurray)

收件人：wburkett@nytimes.com（威廉·伯克特）

To: wburkett@nytimes.com (William Burkett)

主题：转发：帮忙举办聚会吗？

Subject: Fwd: help with a party?

伯克特先生：

Mr. Burkett:

你知道我应该怎么想吗？说实话，我不知道该问谁。

Any idea what I should make of this? In all honesty, I haven’t a clue who to ask.

杰斯

Jess

<Factor Man 发给 Jess MacMurray 的信息>

<message from Factor Man to Jess MacMurray>

发件人：William Burkett (wburkett@nytimes.com)

From: William Burkett (wburkett@nytimes.com)

收件人：Jess MacMurray (jess@jmac.com)

To: Jess MacMurray (jess@jmac.com)

主题：回复：转发：帮忙举办聚会吗？

Subject: Re: Fwd: help with a party?

只是想确认这确实是为我准备的。

Just confirming that this was actually intended for me.

威廉

William

麦克默里：是的。我想，你似乎比其他任何人都更了解 Factor Man。

MacMurray: Yes. You seem to know more about Factor Man than anyone else, I think.

伯克特：谢谢。我知道的不多。

Burkett: Thanks. I don’t know much.

麦克默里：在盲人的国度里……

MacMurray: In the land of the blind …

伯克特：太令人高兴了。

Burkett: Flattering.

麦克默里：魅力是我的中间名。

MacMurray: Charm is my middle name.

伯克特：真是巧合，我们的中间名竟然是一样的。

Burkett: Curious coincidence that we have the same middle name.

我们就这样继续了一段时间。我很惊讶杰西竟然想让我参与进来；这个故事本身就值很多钱。她解释说她从来没有做过这样的事情；她在设计大型活动时的标准程序始终是确保在执行过程中绝对没有利益冲突。从门票销售（50,000 张门票，每张 1000 美元？）和与超级碗相媲美的赛事的转播权来看，无论如何她都会赚得盆满钵满。

We went on like that for a while. I was surprised that Jess wanted my involvement; the story itself had to be worth a fortune. She explained that she never did anything like that; her standard procedure in designing a big event was always to ensure that she had absolutely no conflicts of interest in its execution. Between the ticket sales (50,000 tickets at $1000 each?) and the broadcast rights to something that rated to rival the Super Bowl, she was going to make a mint in any event.

我们最终同意，她会将她与 Factor Man 的交流内容抄送给我。作为交换，我写的任何内容都必须先交由她处理。她没有编辑权，但可以要求我将出版时间推迟一周。而我会尽我所能，帮助她处理出现的问题。

We eventually agreed that she would cc me on her exchanges with Factor Man. In exchange, anything I wrote I’d have to run by her first. She had no editorial authority but could ask me to delay publication by up to a week. And I would be available to help her deal with whatever arose, to the extent that I could.

直到差不多两年后我才意识到这些电子邮件有多么宝贵。

It would be almost two years before I realized how valuable those emails really were.

刘

Liu

2019 年 8 月 7 日

August 7, 2019

我阻止 Factor Man 的任务显然没有成功，失败的责任在我。虽然最初至少有一点可能是 John Kind 或 Dale Miller 是问题对象，但 Apple 似乎不太可能在没有他直接参与的情况下获得 Factor Man 代码。我带回中国的两块硬盘上也没有任何有趣的东西。

My mission to stop Factor Man had apparently not succeeded, and the responsibility for the failure lay with me. While there had initially been at least some chance that either John Kind or Dale Miller was the subject in question, it appeared unlikely that Apple had gotten the Factor Man code without his direct involvement. There was also nothing of interest on either of the hard drives I had brought back with me to China.

赵将军的不满显而易见。他们承认，我可以声称成功识别了“人形因子”并在维也纳获得了视频片段，但我此后的任务几乎完全失败了。

General Zhao’s displeasure was apparent. It was recognized that I could claim success in identifying Factor Man and obtaining the video footage in Vienna, but my mission since had been an almost complete failure.

我们仍然无法知道，除掉 Factor Man 是否会导致他的代码在苹果之外传播开来。但只要存在这种可能性，随着时间的推移，我们识别他的需求就会变得更加迫切。如果 Factor Man 还活着进行交换，那么美国政府肯定会在不到一年的时间内获得该技术。

We still had no way of knowing if eliminating Factor Man would result in his code spreading no further than Apple. But as long as it was a possibility, our need to identify him would grow only more pressing as time passed. If Factor Man were alive to effect the exchange, it was a certainty that the United States government would gain access to the technology in less than a year.

对于中国来说不幸的是——但对于我来说幸运的是——我仍然是中国最有资格找到他的人。

Unfortunately for China – but fortunately for me – I remained the individual in China most qualified to find him.

我们在搜索中调查了 12,762 人。仍然活着的 12,760 人都需要重新检查，而且要更加小心。如果我们每天考虑四十人，我们的分析将在下一个截止日期之前完成。

We had investigated 12,762 individuals in our search. The 12,760 that were still alive would all need to be examined anew and with greater care. If we considered forty a day, our analysis would be complete well before the next deadline.

因子人

Factor Man

2019 年 8 月 8 日

August 8, 2019

发件人：Jess MacMurray (jess@jmac.com)

From: Jess MacMurray (jess@jmac.com)

收件人：Factor Man (factorman0@gmail.com)

To: Factor Man (factorman0@gmail.com)

主题：回复：帮忙举办聚会吗？

Subject: Re: help with a party?

好的，你来了。有两个条件。首先，William Burkett 将帮助我。主要是检查一下事情的进展，但你应该知道他有权查看你发给我的任何电子邮件。

OK, you’re on. Two conditions. First, William Burkett will be helping me. Mostly as a sanity check on what’s going on, but you should expect him to have access to any email that you send me.

其次，你会付给我一大笔钱来为你做这件事。我在这方面非常擅长。你的首要任务是让我自由地完成我的工作。

Second, you will be paying me an absurd amount of money to do this for you. I’m incredibly good at it. Your primary job is to give me the freedom to do my job.

杰斯

Jess

因素人：两点都同意。告诉威廉要负责任。我们从地点开始好吗？

Factor Man: Agreed on both counts. Tell William to behave responsibly. Shall we start with venue?

麦克默里：是的。

MacMurray: Yes.

Factor Man：日期您知道。地点实际上由您决定，只要它在美国大陆即可。我想要 750 个相当好的座位，随机分为两排、三排和四排。

Factor Man: You know the date. Venue actually up to you, provided it is in the continental United States. I’d like 750 reasonably good seats for myself, randomly grouped in blocks of two, three and four.

MacMurray：我建议去洛杉矶体育场（93,607 个座位）或玫瑰碗体育场（92,542 个座位）。那里有更大的空间，但没有那两个体育场那么有声望。

MacMurray: I would suggest either the LA Coliseum (93,607 seats) or the Rose Bowl (92,542). There are larger spaces, but they don’t have the cachet of those two.

因素人：他们有空吗？

Factor Man: Are they available?

麦克默里：根据这份小通知，没有合适的人选。

MacMurray: Nothing suitable will be available with this little notice.

因素人：？

Factor Man: ?

麦克默里：一切都会预订，但金钱至上。我猜买下这两个场馆目前的承诺价将是 500 万到 1000 万美元。应该不会更多了；我会打电话告诉他们，在我醒悟过来并向其他人提供更低的价格之前，他们最好接受。我们当然有那么多的余地。我猜座位的平均价格可能为 1500 美元。所以在我们讨论转播权之前，我有 1.5 亿美元的门票销售额可以玩，转播权应该是这个数字的三倍。我会给他们一个他们无法拒绝的报价。

MacMurray: Everything will be booked, but money talks. My guess is that buying out either venue’s current commitment will be $5-10M. Shouldn’t be more; I’ll call and tell them they’d better take it before I come to my senses and offer less to someone else. We certainly have that much to work with. My guess is that the seats will go for an average of maybe $1500. So I’ve got $150M in ticket sales to play with before we even talk about broadcast rights, which should be triple that. I’ll make them an offer they can’t refuse.

因素人：那么我们可以选择任意一个位置吗？

Factor Man: So we can go either way on the location?

麦克默里：我想是的。有什么我不知道的特别事情吗？

MacMurray: I’d expect so. Is there likely to be anything special that I don’t know about?

因素：安全。非常非常的安全。

Factor Man: Security. Lots and lots of security.

麦克默里：如果是那样的话，我会选择玫瑰碗。他们的知名度更高一些，而且可能更有能力在那里做得更好。

MacMurray: I would go with the Rose Bowl in that case. They are a bit higher profile and probably in a position to do a better job there.

因素人：听起来很合理。就这么做吧。

Factor Man: Sounds reasonable. Make it so.

MacMurray：如你所愿。两个人可以玩这个游戏:)

MacMurray: As you wish. Two can play this game :)

哈德森

Hudson

2019 年 8 月 10 日

August 10, 2019

一个亚洲人试图消灭 Factor Man 这件事情感觉是对的。一个中国人试图消灭他这件事情感觉更对。而有一个中国人试图消灭他这件事情感觉尤其对。

That an Asian had tried to eliminate Factor Man somehow felt right. That a Chinese had tried to eliminate him felt even more right. And one in particular seemed especially right.

珍妮特·刘从一开始就与此事有关。她参与了闯入哈斯戴办公室的事件。我向欧盟的同行们询问后发现，在据称是 Factor Man 的视频曝光之前，她曾到过欧洲。美国海关和边境保护局告诉我，约翰·金德被枪杀的第二天，她就从俄勒冈州的波特兰飞往北京。

Janet Liu had been mixed up with this from the beginning. She had been involved in the break-in at Hasday’s office. An inquiry to my counterparts in the EU showed that she had been in Europe some time before the video, supposedly of Factor Man, had surfaced. And US Customs and Border Protection told me that she had flown from Portland, Oregon, to Beijing the day after John Kind had been shot.

波特兰是一个奇怪但也许明智的选择。从技术层面来说，它比西雅图要好，但又足够方便。

Portland was an odd but perhaps sensible choice. Better than Seattle simply as a matter of tradecraft, but close enough to be convenient.

奇怪的是，刘先生没有乘坐任何一班抵达波特兰的航班。

What was odd was that Liu wasn’t on any of the flights arriving into Portland.

于是我开始查看安检视频。很容易就找到了她，她正前往北京航班；我知道当时的时间和登机口。刘就在那里，安检站的闭路电视录像清晰可见。波特兰只有一个安检站。

So I started looking at the security cam video. Finding her working her way to the Beijing flight was easy; I knew the time of day and the gate. There Liu was, plain as day in the CCTV recording of the security checkpoint. Portland has only one.

对于她的到来，我没有什么可说的。我确实有一整天的时间，正如我所料，因为两起谋杀案之间正好相隔一天。

For her arrival, I had much less to go on. I did have the day, I expected, since the two murders had exactly one full day between them.

我不知道这家航空公司，但波特兰只有一个检查站，这可能意味着我不需要知道。我不认为她会乘坐夜间航班，从东海岸飞往波特兰国际机场的航班通常在上午 11 点到下午 7 点之间到达。

I didn’t know the airline, but Portland’s single checkpoint might mean that I didn’t need to know it. I didn’t think she’d take a redeye, and flights from the East Coast into PDX generally arrive between 11AM and 7PM.

不幸的是，CCTV 对抵达地面并乘飞机离开机场的乘客的覆盖范围比对乘飞机抵达然后从地面离开的乘客的覆盖范围要好得多。通过安检的人通常只能从后面看到，虽然机场周围散布着其他摄像头，但我不能保证刘先生从他们身边走过。

The CCTV coverage of the passengers arriving on the ground to take a flight out of the airport is unfortunately much better than the coverage of the people arriving by air and then leaving by ground. The people going out past security were generally visible only from behind and, while there were other cameras scattered around the facility, I had no guarantee that Liu had walked by any of them.

我开始寻找身高 5 英尺 9 英寸、长而直的黑发女性。这样的人太多了。

I started looking for any woman about 5’9” with long, straight, black hair. There were too many of them.

我还想再试一件事。假设刘女士真的以波特兰作为她抵达太平洋西北地区的中转站，我怀疑她来来往往时穿的衣服可能不一样。不过，虽然她可能换了其他衣服，但她穿的鞋子很有可能是同一双。

There was one other thing I could try. Assuming that Liu even had used Portland as her point of arrival in the Pacific Northwest, I suspected that she had worn different clothes coming and going. But while she might have changed everything else, there was a pretty good chance she had worn the same shoes.

当她飞往北京时，她穿着黑色的靴子，颜色暗淡，像是绒面革，高度刚好到脚踝处。

When she flew to Beijing, she was wearing black boots, dusky enough to be suede, just above ankle height.

通过查看到达 PDX 和离开机场的人员的视频，有四种可能。分别是 12:45、1:13、3:44 和 6:32。现在我只需要查看机场所有摄像头拍摄的大约前十分钟的视频。

Looking through the video of the people arriving into PDX and leaving the airport, there were four possibilities. They were at 12:45, 1:13, 3:44 and 6:32. Now I just had to look at the video for all the airport cameras for maybe the preceding ten minutes.

答对了。她乘坐的美联航航班大约在六点一刻抵达。她很可能在芝加哥转机了。

Bingo. She had come in on a United flight arriving at about quarter past six. Most likely, she had changed planes in Chicago.

现在事情变得简单了。在从芝加哥飞往波特兰的联合航空航班上，所有乘客中只有一人来自佛罗里达。伊丽莎白·朱于 12:01 离开坦帕。

Now it got easy. Of all of the passengers on the United arrival from Chicago into Portland, exactly one had come from Florida. Elizabeth Chu, leaving Tampa at 12:01.

她在坦帕的摄像机前清晰可见。

And there she was on the Tampa cameras, plain as day.

伊丽莎白·朱在抵达波特兰时租了一辆车，两天后还车。她开了 375 英里，刚刚好。她在坦帕开了 425 英里，也刚刚好。

Elizabeth Chu had rented a car on her arrival in Portland, returning it two days later. She had put 375 miles on it, just about right. She had put 425 miles on a car in Tampa, also just about right.

非常简单，非常简单。

Easy, peasy.

* * *

* * *

我要告诉两个人。威利斯 (Willis)，我的助理特派员 (ASAC)，会比较容易。乔希·威尔逊 (Josh Wilson) 会比较难。

I had two people to tell. Willis, my ASAC, would be easy. Josh Wilson was going to be hard.

我告诉詹妮弗我需要尽快见到她，结果发现她得在几个小时内。我给她做了总结：一名名叫 Janet Liu 的中国特工显然杀害了两名美国公民，一名在迈阿密，另一名在贝尔维尤。我还没有拿到 DNA 证据，但我完全相信她会在迈阿密犯罪现场。我可以确定刘女士在谋杀案发生的两个城市内或附近。她杀害的美国人似乎没有犯下任何罪行，除了鼻子长得像 Factor Man 和从事计算机行业。

I told Jennifer I needed to see her as soon as possible, which turned out to mean in a couple of hours. I summarized it for her: A Chinese operative named Janet Liu had apparently killed two American citizens, one in Miami and one in Bellevue. I didn’t have it yet, but I fully expected to have DNA evidence placing her at the scene of the Miami crime. I could place Liu in or near both cities where the murders were committed. The Americans she had killed appeared to have committed no crime other than having a nose that looked like Factor Man’s and being in the computer business.

我能看出威利斯的脑子在转。这件事情超出了她的职权范围。可能远远超出了她的职权范围。一名中国特工在美国领土上毫无理由地杀害了两名美国公民。然后她又回到了中国。

I could see the wheels turning in Willis’ head. This was about to be above her pay grade. Probably way above her pay grade. A Chinese agent had murdered two American citizens, on American soil, for basically no reason. And then she had returned to China.

我很高兴自己能摆脱这一切。

I was glad that I would be out of it.

我向詹妮弗解释说，我需要告诉乔什·威尔逊，我已经结案了。她认识我很久了，知道劝阻我是没有意义的。

I explained to Jennifer that I needed to tell Josh Wilson that I had closed his case. She had known me for long enough to know that there wasn’t any point in trying to talk me out of it.

“我讨厌政治，约翰，”威利斯告诉我。“这件事将引发令人难以置信的混乱。”

“I hate the political ones, John,” Willis told me. “The shitstorm coming on this is going to be unbelievable.

“去吧，”她告诉我，“用政府的钱飞往迈阿密。我猜整个事情在你落地之前就会被保密。我不知道你要说什么，但你最好亲自说出来。”

“Go ahead,” she told me. “Fly to Miami on the government’s dime. My guess is that the whole thing will be classified before you even touch down. I have no idea what you’re going to say, but it’ll be better if you say it in person.”

那里没有纸板。但我也不知道该对威尔逊说什么。我们已经解决了他的案子，而他永远也解决不了。我不可能和他分享任何事。

No cardboard there. But I didn’t have a clue what I was going to say to Wilson, either. We had solved his case, and he never would. And I wasn’t going to be able to share a damn thing with him.

* * *

* * *

我们在 Lionesse Wetlab 见面，比上次晚了一点。大学生人群涌了出来，我希望自己年轻二十岁。见鬼，我宁愿年轻十年。

We met back at the Lionesse Wetlab, a little later into the evening than the last time. The college crowd was out in force, and I wished that I was twenty years younger. Hell, I’d settle for a decade.

乔什没有浪费时间。“你回来这里只有一个理由，”他告诉我。“你已经取得了进步，而我将被坑。”

Josh wasted no time. “Only one reason for you to come back here,” he told me. “You’ve made progress, and I’m gonna get screwed.”

“我先点几杯啤酒你介意吗？”我问他。

“You mind if I order a couple of beers first?” I asked him.

“继续吧。不过你要告诉我我错了。”

“Go ahead. But tell me I’m wrong.”

我告诉他我不能告诉他这些，结果他却对我破口大骂，并提出了一个相当不卫生的建议，问我该怎么处理这瓶啤酒。

I told him I couldn’t tell him that, and was rewarded with a stream of expletives and a rather unsanitary suggestion as to what I could do with the beer.

“听着，威尔逊，”我告诉他。“我在这儿，好吗？我本可以留在纽约，然后骗你钱的。”

“Listen, Wilson,” I told him. “I’m here, okay? I could have stayed in New York and stiffed you.”

“我很惊讶你没有这么做。”

“I’m surprised you didn’t do just that.”

“别再说了。我说过我不会这么做的，我也没有这么做。”

“Cut it out. I told you I wouldn’t, and I didn’t.”

“当面搞我并不比通过电话搞我好多少，哈德森。你不是我的类型。”

“Screwing me in person isn’t any better than screwing me by phone, Hudson. You’re not my type.”

我告诉他他也不是我的类型。

I told him he wasn’t my type, either.

这一切结束后，我们仍然站在拥挤的酒吧里。乔什拿起啤酒，大步走回一张桌子旁。我跟着他，我们俩都坐了下来。

After all this, we were still standing at the crowded bar. Josh picked up his beer and stalked back to a table. I followed him and we both sat down.

“你是个混蛋，”他对我说。“你知道吗？”

“You’re a prick,” he told me. “You know that?”

“是的。”

“Yup.”

“你到底要告诉我什么，还是就让我继续在这里追寻我的尾巴？”

“You gonna tell me anything at all, or just let me keep chasing my tail down here?”

我告诉他，他的案子已经破了，他可以不用再纠结了。不出所料，我又被他精心挑选的语言所吸引。当他稍微冷静下来后，他问是不是同一个人杀死了他的受害者和西雅图的那个人。

I told him he could stop chasing his tail because his case was solved. Not surprisingly, this got me another stream of carefully chosen language. When he calmed down – a little – he asked if the same person had killed both his vic and the guy in Seattle.

“是的。”

“Yup.”

“你不打算告诉我他是谁吗？”

“And you’re not going to tell me who it is?”

“没有。我会告诉你他们已经不在迈阿密了，而且可能永远不会再来迈阿密了。但我只能告诉你这些了。”

“Nope. I’ll tell you that they’re no longer in Miami, and probably will never be in Miami again. But that’s all I can tell you.”

“去你妈的，哈德森。还有你骑的那匹马。”

“Fuck you, Hudson. And the horse you rode in on.”

然后他又去喝啤酒，隔着桌子盯着我。

And he went back to his beer, staring at me across the table.

威利斯是 ASAC 而我不是，这是有原因的。我是个好探员。我会深入挖掘事情，如果有什么事情可以解开，我至少和其他人一样有可能解开它。

There is a reason Willis is the ASAC and I’m not. I’m a good agent. I dig through things, and if something can be unraveled, I’m at least as likely to unravel it as the next guy.

但我有一个致命的缺点，我认为好人就应该受到尊重。

But I have a fatal flaw. I believe that good people should be treated with respect.

就其本身而言，这并非完全致命。这很糟糕，但还不算致命。

In itself, that’s not completely fatal. It’s bad, but it’s not fatal.

但我相信尊重他们比遵守规则更重要。

But I believe that treating them with respect is more important than following the rules.

这是致命的。

And that’s fatal.

我不会在这里违反规则，但我即将改变它们。

I wasn’t going to break the rules here, but I was about to bend them.

“听着，”我告诉乔什，“我昨天就弄清楚了。昨天。你明白吗？”

“Listen,” I told Josh. “I figured this out yesterday. Yesterday. You understand?”

“据我所知，你已经搭乘下一班飞机来告诉我这个好消息了。”

“What I understand is that you got on the next plane down to tell me the good news.”

“我想说的是，在我下飞机之前，整个事情就已被保密了。”

“What I’m trying to tell is that before I even got off the plane, the whole thing had been classified.”

“机密？机密什么？”

“Classified? Classified what?”

“机密，”我告诉他。“就像绝密一样。”

“Classified,” I told him. “Like top-secret classified.”

你不应该这么做。信息被保密这一事实本身通常也是保密的。

You’re not supposed to do that. The very fact that information was classified was in general also classified.

乔希还是没明白。“绝密？”

Josh still didn’t get it. “Top secret?”

“是的，”我告诉他。“但这不是重点。重点是这件事立即就被列为机密。从来没有任何事情能这么快被列为机密。而且它被列为机密的程度如此之高，即使有人认为你应该知道，也需要大约八个月的时间对你进行背景调查，以确认可以告诉你。”

“Yes,” I told him. “But that isn’t the point. The point is that this got classified instantly. Nothing ever gets classified that fast. And it got classified at a level where even if someone decided you should know, it would take about eight months to run the background checks on you to confirm that it was okay to tell you.”

“操我。”这是深思熟虑后的回答。

“Fuck me,” was the considered response.

“好吧，我们所有人，”我告诉他。“你、我，还有我骑的那匹马。”

“Well, that’s all of us,” I told him. “You, me, and the horse I rode in on.”

他稍微友善地看着我。“你允许告诉我这些吗？”

He looked at me with a bit more kindness. “You allowed to tell me any of this?”

“告诉你什么了？”我反问道。“喝你的啤酒。”

“Tell you any of what?” I asked back. “Drink your beer.”

我们喝酒了。

We drank.

* * *

* * *

当你对联邦政府这个庞大的官僚机构感到惊讶时，有两件事几乎肯定会发生。

When you surprise the vast bureaucracy known as the federal government, two things are pretty much guaranteed to happen.

首先，他们会尽一切努力确保没有人知道他们受到了惊吓。这通常包括对惊吓进行保密，这样如果其他人知道了，他们就会被关进监狱。

First, they will do whatever is necessary to make sure that no one else knows they’ve been surprised. This generally involves classifying the surprise, so that if someone else learns about it, people can be put in jail.

其次……

And second …

不会有第二件事情发生。发生的第二件事绝对不会发生。

There is no second. The second thing that will happen is absolutely nothing.

现在，可能真的没什么大不了的。会议正在召开。选项正在权衡。决定正在作出。

Now, it’s probably not really nothing. Meetings are taking place. Options are being weighed. Decisions are being decided.

但在外界看来，这看上去没什么。

But to the outside world, it looks like nothing.

我从来没真正理解过这一点。我本质上是个警察。线索都有有效期。你在两天内破获谋杀案的可能性比在两个月内破获谋杀案的可能性大得多，大多数其他犯罪也是如此。如果你在十二个人就此事开了十一次会时袖手旁观，那么等你准备行动时，这件事就一文不值了。

I have never really understood this. I’m fundamentally a cop. Clues come with expiry dates. You’re way more likely to solve a murder in two days than in two months, and the same goes for most other crimes. If you sit on something while twelve people have eleven meetings about it, it’ll be worthless by the time you’re ready to act.

我的第一位合伙人很久以前就向我解释过这一点。她告诉我，这个世界分为两种人：企业家和托管人。

My first partner explained this to me a long time ago. She told me that the world divided into two types of people: entrepreneurs and custodians.

企业家总是想尽快做事。他们破案、创业。对于一个企业家来说，四次失败一次成功是件很棒的事。

The entrepreneurs always want to do things as quickly as possible. They solve crimes and form businesses. For an entrepreneur, four failures and one success is fantastic.

还有看管人，他们想尽可能慢地做事。这并不是因为他们懒惰或胆小（尽管有些人确实如此）；而是因为他们很小心。对于看管人来说，四次失败和一次成功是一场灾难。事实上，四次成功和一次失败是一场灾难。

Then there are the custodians, who want to do things as slowly as possible. It’s not because they’re lazy or cowards (although some certainly are); it’s because they’re careful. For a custodian, four failures and one success is a disaster. In fact, four successes and one failure is a disaster.

我的合伙人告诉我，这个世界需要这两种人。只有看管人，什么事也做不成。只有创业者，什么事也做不成。

What my partner told me was that the world needs both of these groups. Only custodians, and nothing ever gets done. Only entrepreneurs, and nothing ever works.

你在政府中的职位越高，你就越有可能成为一名托管人。

The higher up in government you get, the more likely you are to be a custodian.

这就是为什么在我告诉威利斯在西雅图和迈阿密发生的事情后，两个月内我没有听到任何消息。

Which is why after I told Willis what had happened in Seattle and Miami, I heard absolutely nothing about it for two months.

就在那时，我收到了一张飞往华盛顿特区的机票，并被告知要去联邦调查局局长理查德·斯塔基的办公室报到。

At which point, I was handed an airplane ticket to DC and told to report to the office of FBI director Richard Starkey.

斯塔基在进入法学院之前，主修化学和宗教。从那以后，他走上了一条相当直接的政治道路，先是担任美国检察官，然后担任司法部副部长，最后被任命为联邦调查局局长。

Starkey had completed a double major in chemistry and religion before going to law school. From there, he had followed a fairly direct political trajectory, serving as a US Attorney and then as Deputy Attorney General before being appointed to head the FBI.

不过，他最应该做的是打篮球。这名男子身高超过六英尺半。他本人在许多方面都令人生畏。

Mostly, though, he should have been a basketball player. The man is well over six and a half feet tall. Intimidating in person on many levels.

从纽约到华盛顿的班车一般都在里根机场停靠，我从那里乘坐 Uber 前往位于宾夕法尼亚大道 935 号的联邦调查局总部。然后我上楼，走进了可能是我去过的最大的办公室。斯塔基的报告路径就写在墙上：他向司法部长肯尼斯·辛格报告，辛格向总统报告。从斯塔基开始，就只有两步路可以到达总统。

The shuttles from New York to Washington generally arrive at Reagan, and I took an Uber from there to the FBI headquarters at 935 Pennsylvania Avenue. Then I made my way upstairs and into what was probably the biggest office I had ever been in. Starkey’s reporting path was there on the wall: he reports to Attorney General Kenneth Singer, and Singer reports to the president. Starting with Starkey, it’s two steps to POTUS.

办公室宽敞又大。没有杂乱，只有空间和许多非常大的家具。斯塔基的管理员带我进去，主管从办公桌前走过来和我握手。他坐在办公室右侧的会议桌旁，邀请我和他一起。

The office was spacious as well as big. There was no clutter, just space and a lot of really big furniture. Starkey’s admin showed me in and the director stepped around from the desk to shake my hand. He sat at a conference table on the right side of the office and invited me to join him.

那里没有其他人。威利斯不在。政府权力等级中，威利斯和斯塔基之间的十几个人也不在。

No one else was there. Willis wasn’t there. Neither were any of the dozen or so people who were probably between Willis and Starkey in the governmental pecking order.

通常情况下，整个指挥链都会出现。如果你下面的人正在与你上面的人交谈，你需要在场才能知道他们在说什么。但在这种情况下，大部分报告路径都在纽约市，这意味着斯塔基可以把他们排除在外，他​​们没有有效的机制让他们重新加入。只有斯塔基和我，两个好老伙计，正在享受一个愉快的下午聊天。

Normally, the whole chain of command would have shown up. If someone below you is having a conversation with someone above you in the hierarchy, you need to be there to know what’s being said. But in this case, most of the reporting path was back in New York City, which meant that Starkey could leave them out and they had no effective mechanism for pushing their way back in. Just Starkey and me, two good ol’ boys having a nice afternoon chat.

“所以，”他开始说道，“你认为中国政府特工因为两名美国公民的身高和鼻子长相而残忍地杀害了他们。也可能是随机的，没有任何真正原因。对吗？”

“So,” he began. “You think an agent of the Chinese government killed two American citizens in cold blood because of how tall they were and what their noses looked like. Might just as well have been random, for no real reason at all. Right?”

“是的，先生。”

“Yes, sir.”

“跟我说说看。”

“Tell me about it.”

我拿出了平时用来记录调查进展的笔记本。“我可以参考一下我的笔记吗？”

I took out the pad I generally used to keep track of ongoing investigations. “Okay if I refer to my notes?”

“当然。但我还想要钞票上没有的东西。”

“Absolutely. But I also want what’s not in the notes.”

“一切都记录在笔记里，先生。”

“Everything’s in the notes, sir.”

斯塔基笑了。“特工哈德森，你可能不相信我，但我们是站在同一边的。如果外国政府的特工进入美国领土并杀死了我们的两名公民，请相信我。这超越了政治。我们只需要确保我们做对了。”

Starkey smiled. “Special Agent Hudson, you may not believe me, but we’re on the same side here. If an agent of a foreign government came onto American soil and killed two of our citizens, believe me. It transcends politics. We just need to make sure we have it right.”

于是我把整个事情都告诉了他，从哈斯戴办公室被盗事件开始，到坦帕和波特兰机场发生的事件。在我讲述的过程中，他问了几个问题来澄清，但基本上只是听着。

So I told him the whole thing, starting with the break-in at Hasday’s office and ending with my connecting the dots at the Tampa and Portland airports. He asked a few clarifying questions as I went along but pretty much just listened.

“我相信你。那么告诉我吧，哈德森探员。我们该怎么办？”

“I believe you. So tell me, Agent Hudson. What should we do about it?”

“先生？”

“Sir?”

“你听见我说的话了。假设你坐在我的椅子上。你会给总检察长什么建议？”

“You heard me. Let’s say you were sitting in my chair. What would be your recommendation to the AG?”

“我不知道。先生。”

“I have no idea. Sir.”

斯塔基笑了。“是啊，那我们两个都一样。包括所有看到这个的人。

Starkey smiled. “Yeah, well that makes two of us. Includes everyone else who’s seen this as well.

“仔细考虑一下，Hudson 探员。看看你能想出什么。你是唯一一个能够充分了解每个人动机并能将谜团拼凑起来的人。我不能保证我会听从你的任何建议，但我可以保证我至少想听听你的建议。”

“Give it some thought, Agent Hudson. See what you can come up with. You’re the only person who understood everyone’s motivations well enough to piece the puzzle together. I can’t promise you I’ll follow whatever recommendation you make, but I can promise you I’d like to at least hear it.”

“是的，先生。”

“Yes, sir.”

“几周后再来。格拉迪斯会帮你找一个合适的时间。”

“Come back in a couple of weeks. Gladys will find you a time that works.”

他站了起来。

He stood.

我站了起来。

I stood.

我離開了辦公室。

I left the office.

他留下来了。

He stayed.

18

18

因子人

Factor Man

2019 年 10 月 17 日

October 17, 2019

发件人：Jess MacMurray (jess@jmac.com)

From: Jess MacMurray (jess@jmac.com)

收件人：Factor Man (factorman0@gmail.com)

To: Factor Man (factorman0@gmail.com)

主题：FCOP

Subject: FCOP

玫瑰碗已安全。我需要联系帕萨迪纳和洛杉矶，让他们知道情况。如果您遇到问题，请告诉我。

Rose Bowl secured. I need to contact both Pasadena and Los Angeles and let them know what’s up. Please let me know if you have a problem with that.

接下来应该是广播。您有偏好吗？

Broadcast should probably be next. You have a preference?

杰斯

Jess

因素人： 对于帕萨迪纳和洛杉矶来说，这很好。

Factor Man: On Pasadena and LA, that’s fine.

在广播方面，随心所欲。一个网络还是多个网络，对我来说都无所谓。国际报道都可以。请确保至少有一个主要的电视、广播和互联网网络对活动进行现场直播。一个条件：我基本上把这看作是一场两小时的新闻发布会。在结束前不能有商业广告。我们应该什么时候开始？

On broadcast, do whatever you want. One network or many, doesn’t matter to me. International coverage is fine. Please do ensure that the event is covered live by at least one major network on television, radio, and the Internet. One condition: I am viewing this basically as a two-hour press conference. No commercial interruptions until it’s over. What time should we start?

麦克默里：今天是星期六，但我认为太平洋时间下午 6 点开始没问题。你同意吗？

MacMurray: It’s a Saturday, but I think we’re ok starting at 6PM Pacific time anyway. You good with that?

因素人：当然了。

Factor Man: Sure.

麦克默里：关于帕萨迪纳和洛杉矶，我只想处理这类事情，不让你参与。这是我的职责。可以吗？

MacMurray: On Pasadena and LA, I’d like to just handle things like this without involving you. My job. OK?

Factor Man：好的。反正我收到了很多电子邮件。相信我。

Factor Man: OK. I get plenty of email anyway. Trust me.

麦克默里：还有别的吗？

MacMurray: Anything else?

Factor Man：是的。在您宣布场地之前，请为我预订 300 间客房，供我在活动前后入住，这些客房位于一系列高档但便利的地点。我还需要私人飞机接送各种客人；这就算一百次了。您能搞定吗？

Factor Man: Yes. Before you announce the venue, please reserve 300 rooms for me for the nights before and after the event at a fairly wide range of upscale but convenient locations. I’ll also need private jet transportation for a variety of guests; call it a hundred trips. Can you handle that?

麦克默里：当然了。航空旅行的起源是什么？

MacMurray: Absolutely. Origins for the air travel?

因素人：还不知道。

Factor Man: Don’t know yet.

麦克默里：没问题。您有空时告诉我一声。

MacMurray: Not a problem. Let me know when you can.

因素人：当然了。

Factor Man: You bet.

伯克特

Burkett

2019 年 10 月 22 日

October 22, 2019

玫瑰碗将举办世纪派对

Rose Bowl to Host Party of the Century

威廉·伯克特 (William Burkett)，纽约时报独家报道

William Burkett, exclusive to The New York Times

现在众所周知的“因素人出柜派对”（The Factor Man Coming Out Party，简称 FCOP）将于 2021 年 7 月 10 日太平洋时间下午 6 点在玫瑰碗举行。

The Factor Man Coming Out Party, or FCOP, as it is now universally known, will take place at 6PM Pacific Time at the Rose Bowl on July 10, 2021.

这是自 Factor Man 同意以 1470 亿美元的价格将同样神秘的技术授权给苹果公司以来，我们第一次听到这位神秘人物的消息。长期以来以内部保密著称的苹果公司也对此保持沉默。

This is the first we’ve heard from the mysterious character since Factor Man agreed to license his equally mysterious technology to Apple for $147 billion just under three months ago. Apple, long known for its internal secrecy, has also said nothing.

谣言四起。

Rumors abound.

其中一个谣言是这项技术毫无价值，完全是某种骗局。但这似乎与 Factor Man 之前的演示以及他对 FCOP 的坚定进展相矛盾。

One of those rumors is that the technology is worthless, all a scam of some kind. But that seems at odds both with Factor Man’s previous demonstrations and with his resolute progress toward FCOP.

FCOP 本身由 JMac, Inc. 组织，这是一家由 Jess MacMurray 领导的华盛顿特区精品活动组织公司。她也对整个事件守口如瓶。“2021 年的两个小时内，”她告诉我，“地球上的每个人都会观看同一个舞台。”

FCOP itself is being organized by JMac, Inc., a boutique DC event-organizing firm led up by Jess MacMurray. She, too, has been quite tight-lipped about the whole affair. “For two hours in 2021,” she told me, “everyone on the planet will be watching a single stage.”

另一个传言是，MacMurray 女士与 Factor Man 保持私人联系，以安排细节。MacMurray 女士在被问及时表示，Factor Man 只是通过电子邮件联系，仅此而已，他使用 factorman0@gmail.com 与她联系，就像其他人一样。

Another rumor is that Ms. MacMurray is in personal contact with Factor Man to arrange the details. Ms. MacMurray, when asked, has said that Factor Man is an email contact, nothing more, and that he uses factorman0@gmail.com to contact her, just like everyone else.

麦克默里女士说每个人都会观看，这也许是对的。据报道，她正在与多家电视网商谈《FCOP》的播出权。

Ms. MacMurray may well be right that everyone will be watching. She is reportedly in discussions with multiple networks regarding the broadcast rights to FCOP.

这篇文章发表于周二早上。到当天下午，洛杉矶盆地的所有酒店都已预订一空。FCOP 一周内的所有航班也都已预订一空。

The article appeared on a Tuesday morning. By that afternoon, every hotel in the L.A. basin was booked. Every airline flight within a week of FCOP was booked as well.

华尔街似乎对这一切的喧嚣并不以为然。苹果股价悄然但稳步下跌，投资者想知道苹果投入数十亿美元究竟得到了什么。

Wall Street seemed unimpressed by all the hoopla. Apple stock drifted quietly but steadily lower as investors wondered what Apple had actually gotten for its billions.

因子人

Factor Man

2019 年 11 月 4 日

November 4, 2019

发件人：Factor Man (factorman0@gmail.com)

From: Factor Man (factorman0@gmail.com)

收件人：Jess MacMurray (jess@jmac.com)

To: Jess MacMurray (jess@jmac.com)

主题：FCOP

Subject: FCOP

很高兴听到机票、酒店和航班都已解决。

Glad to hear that the tickets, hotels and air travel worked out.

关于门票的一般情况：门票不可转让，就像机票一样。我希望活动的安全措施非常严格。至少要像机场 TSA 提供的一样严格，但希望要严格得多。所有门票必须在活动开始前至少 30 天签发，否则无效。除此之外，您可以以任何您想要的方式出售它们。

About the tickets in general: They are to be nontransferable, just like airline tickets. I would like security at the event to be incredibly strict. At least as strict as what TSA provides at airports, but hopefully much stricter. All tickets must be issued at least thirty days before the event, or they are void. Other than that, you are welcome to sell them in any way you want.

至于我的 750 张门票，我希望按以下方式分配。首先，世界上每个国家都可获得两张，中国除外。台湾可获得两张。包括台湾在内的 195 个国家/地区（不包括中国）共有 390 张门票，并且必须在活动开始前至少六个月确定接收者。

With regard to my 750 tickets, I would like them distributed as follows. First, every country in the world gets two, except China. Taiwan gets two. There are 195 countries including Taiwan but not China, so that is 390 tickets, and the recipients must be identified no less than six months before the event.

凯特·杰克逊和小罗伯特·唐尼每人获得两张票。一共是四张。

Kate Jackson and Robert Downey, Jr. each get two tickets. That's four.

我想请你列出美国所有计算机科学家的名单。请广义地解释“计算机科学家”：任何拥有计算机科学学位、是计算机科学教师或学生、从事计算机科学工作或曾经从事过这些工作的人。然后我想请你从名单中随机选择十个名字，并给他们每人三十张票，包括他们及其客人的机票（私人飞机）和酒店。一共有 300 张票，所以我还剩下五十六张。这十位计算机科学家和他们的客人必须对他们的邀请保密；任何在活动前被媒体确认的持票人都将被拒绝入场。他们所需要做的就是告诉我们他们和他们的客人住在哪里；我们会从那里安排机票。这样，希望媒体无法发现。

I would like you to make a list of all of the computer scientists in the United States. Please interpret "computer scientists" broadly: anyone who has a CS degree, is CS faculty or a CS student, works as a computer scientist, or has been any of those things. Then I want you to select ten names from that list at random, and give each of them thirty tickets, including air travel (private jet) and hotel for them and their guests. That is 300 tickets, so I've got fifty-six left. The ten computer scientists and their guests are to keep their invitations secret; any of those ticketholders identified by the press in advance of the event is to be denied entry. All they need to do is to tell us where they and their guests live; we’ll arrange air travel from there. That way, hopefully the press can’t figure it out.

这 300 名持票人的姓名以及其他相应的安全信息将提供给我。我将在 FCOP 前一天将其以及我和乘客的类似信息提供给 TSA（或负责安全事务的人员）。

The names of those 300 ticketholders, along with any other corresponding security information, is to be provided to me. I will provide it, along with similar information for me and my guests, to the TSA (or whomever is handling security) the day prior to FCOP.

门票应该包含餐饮。玫瑰碗应该能为这么大的团体提供最好的餐饮。

Food should be included with entry. It should be as good as the Rose Bowl is capable of providing to a group that large.

体育场周围应该有麦克风。正如我所说，这基本上是一场新闻发布会。应该有一个可以看到整个观众的舞台，上面还有另一个麦克风和十三把椅子。

There should be microphones scattered around the stadium. This is, as I've said, basically a press conference. There should be a stage in view of the entire audience, with another mic and thirteen chairs on it.

应该有一个特殊的证件让持有者登上舞台。那是给我的，一旦你弄清楚它应该是什么样子，请把它通过电子邮件发送给我，我会把它打印出来。当我上台的时候，我会假设我可以出示我的特别票并完成这件事。

There should be one special credential that gets the holder onto the stage. That's for me and, once you figure out what it should look like, please just email it to me and I'll print it out. When it’s time for me to go on stage, I’ll assume I can present my special ticket and get that done.

如果有任何不清楚的地方，请告诉我。

Please let me know if any of this is unclear.

麦克默里：一切正常。我期待在 2021 年 7 月 10 日与您会面。我可以与公众分享您告诉我的信息吗？

MacMurray: All clear. I will look forward to meeting you on July 10, 2021. Am I allowed to share what you have told me with the public?

因素人：当然了。

Factor Man: Sure.

19

19

哈德森

Hudson

2019 年 11 月 6 日

November 6, 2019

我我花了两周的时间试图弄清楚美国应该如何应对这一据我所知是外国敌对行为，我于 11 月的一个雨天早晨返回华盛顿。

I returned to DC on a rainy morning in November, having spent the requisite two weeks trying to figure out what the United States should do about what was, as far as I could tell, a hostile act by a foreign power.

我认为有三个选择。我们可以公开指责中国。我们可以私下指责他们。或者我们可以什么也不做。

The way I figured it, there were three options. We could call China out in public. We could call them out privately. Or we could do nothing.

没有好的选择，因为我们没有 Janet Liu 的 DNA。

There were no good options, because we didn’t have Janet Liu’s DNA.

每一个看过证据的人都确信她对约翰·金德和戴尔·米勒的死亡负有直接责任，但中国政府显然会否认这一点。他们会非常生气，珍妮特·刘会悄悄消失。除了美国政府会感到尴尬之外，什么也不会发生，毫无疑问，国会会以某种我甚至不想考虑的方式加入进来。

Everyone who had seen the evidence was convinced that she was directly responsible for the deaths of John Kind and Dale Miller, but the Chinese government would obviously deny it. They would be incredibly offended, and Janet Liu would quietly disappear. Nothing would happen except the American government would be embarrassed, doubtless with Congress piling on in some way that I didn’t even want to consider.

私下与中国接触无疑会产生同样的效果，因为他们可以选择将整个事情公之于众，声称完全无知，要求道歉等等。国会也会同样加入进来。

Approaching China privately would undoubtedly have the same effect, since they would have the option of making the whole thing public, professing complete ignorance, demanding an apology and so on. Congress would pile on, just the same.

因此，什么也不做就是最后一个糟糕的选择。

So that left doing nothing, the final lousy choice.

乔什·威尔逊大概还在为我知道谁是凶手而他不知道而感到难过。所以他是迈阿密一颗潜在的定时炸弹。

Josh Wilson was presumably still upset that I knew who his killer was and he didn’t. So he was a potential ticking time bomb in Miami.

刘女士可能永远不会回到美国了。

Janet Liu might well never return to the United States.

而且，最重要的是，我不知道总统忽视这一点是否合法。

And, most important, I had no idea if it was even legal for the president to ignore it.

我走出电梯，斯塔基主任就迎上来。他说：“我们出去走走。”

Director Starkey met me as I entered his suite after getting out of the elevator. “We’re going for a walk,” he said.

我疑惑地看着他。“950，”他说。“就在隔壁。”

I looked at him questioningly. “950,” he said. “Right next door.”

太棒了。宾夕法尼亚大道 950 号是司法部，辛格总检察长就在这里工作。华盛顿的等级制度非常严格：没有人会在下属的办公室里会见下属。如果我们走到司法部，辛格就会参加会议。

Fantastic. 950 Pennsylvania Avenue was Justice, where Attorney General Singer worked. The Washington pecking order was incredibly strict: No one ever met a subordinate in the subordinate’s office. If we were walking over to Justice, Singer was going to be part of the meeting.

我实在想不出这能让我的生活变得更好。

I could think of absolutely no way in which this was likely to make my life better.

司法部大楼看起来和华盛顿的其他建筑没什么两样。它用米色石头建成，非常巨大。大楼里到处都是旗帜，还有各种标签，比如“司法部”、“美利坚合众国”和“司法部长办公室”。标签都是大写字母。大楼前有警察，小巷里有反卡车反恐路障。

The Department of Justice building looked like every other building in DC. It was built of beige stone and huge. There were flags all over the place, and various labels, like “Justice,” “United States of America,” and “Office of the Attorney General.” The labels were all in capital letters. There were police out front, and anti-truck anti-terrorist blockades on the side streets.

没人笑。我们进去时，负责金属探测器的警卫肯定没有笑。斯塔基没有笑，只是以一个身高六英尺八英寸的人匆忙时的速度行走。

No one was smiling. The guards manning the metal detectors when we went in certainly weren’t smiling. Starkey wasn’t smiling, just walking at the speed a six-foot-eight guy walks when he’s in a hurry.

我沒有笑。

I wasn’t smiling.

我们被带进一间会议室，里面还有另一个人，我认出他是白宫法律顾问彼得·弗利尔。弗利尔身材瘦削，秃顶，六十多岁。见过他的人都说他非常聪明。斯塔基正式介绍了我们，我们正要坐下时，辛格走了进来，身边还跟着一个我不认识的女人。她被介绍为美国国家安全局局长、海军上将博比·斯佩尔曼。

We were brought into a conference room containing one other person, whom I recognized as Peter Flier, White House counsel. Flier is thin, bald and in his mid-sixties. He’s smart as a whip, according to anyone who’s ever met him. Starkey introduced us formally, and we were about to sit down when Singer came in, accompanied by a woman I didn’t recognize. She was introduced as Admiral Bobbie Spellman, director of the NSA.

我的日子一天天好起来了。

My day just kept getting better.

我们坐下后，辛格开口道：“感谢您前来，哈德森探员。”

We sat, and Singer started. “Thank you for coming down, Agent Hudson.

“正如你所见，我们决定将这次会议的规模尽可能缩小。目前，我们认为你提供给斯塔基主任的信息只有少数人知道，我们希望保持这种状态。”

“As you can see, we’ve decided to keep this meeting as small as possible. Right now, we believe the information you provided to Director Starkey is only known to a handful of folks, and we’d like to keep it that way.”

我看了看桌子旁的人。人数绝对少，包括那个告诉总统什么能做什么不能做的人。如果我不得不打赌，我敢打赌他们决定选择第三个选项。什么也不做。

I looked at the people at the table. An absolutely minimum number of people, including the guy who told the president what he could and couldn’t do. If I had to bet, I would bet that they had decided to go with option three. Do nothing.

我不想成为一个唯唯诺诺的人，但我认为他们是对的。

I didn’t want to be a yes man, but I thought they were right.

“所以，”斯塔基继续说道。“我请你想想我们应该怎么做。你做到了吗？”

“So,” Starkey continued. “I asked you to think about what we should do about this. Have you?”

“是的，先生。”我咽了口唾沫，知道鹿在车灯下是什么感觉。“我认为我们什么也没做，先生。我们知道我们所知道的，但我们无法证明我们所知道的。如果刘珍妮特回到祖国，一切都会改变。”

“Yes, sir.” I swallowed, knowing what a deer feels like in the headlights. “I think we do nothing, sir. We know what we know, but we can’t prove what we know. If Janet Liu ever returns to the homeland, that all changes.”

辛格看着弗莱尔。“彼得？”

Singer looked at Flier. “Peter?”

“据我所知，”他说，“这是一个选择。但合法并不意味着可行。如果消息传出去，总统将被弹劾，并被定罪。他们会称之为叛国罪，或不履行保卫国家的职责，或其他什么罪名。不管他们怎么称呼它都无所谓。”

“As far as I can tell,” he said, “that’s an option. But just because it’s legal doesn’t mean it’s actually viable. If word of this gets out, the president will be impeached, and he’ll be convicted. They’ll call it treason, or a dereliction of his duty to defend the country, or some other damn thing. It won’t matter what they call it.”

“他有偏好吗？”辛格又问。

“Does he have a preference?” Singer again.

“不管你信不信，他想做对国家最有利的事情。他同意你的观点。如果没有证据，我们所做的一切就只是冒着暴露自己的风险而一无所获。”

“Believe it or not, he wants to do what’s in the country’s best interests. He agrees with you. Without proof, all we do is risk tipping our hand with nothing to show for it.”

“那怎么办？”辛格问我。“这里有可能找到证据吗？”

“What about it?” Singer asked me. “Any chance of getting some proof here?”

“我不这么认为，”我告诉他。“我们找到了刘在坦帕和波特兰租车的照片。汽车行驶里程与她直接驾车前往两起案件的谋杀地点、处理受害者并返回的里程一致。她保留了每辆车一段时间，但我们能找到的唯一有关她的视频是在坦帕和波特兰。她前往西雅图和迈阿密的道路是高速公路而不是收费公路，所以没有她开车前往受害人地点的视频。

“I don’t think so,” I told him. “We’ve got pictures of Liu renting cars in Tampa and Portland. The mileage on the cars is consistent with her driving directly to the murder locations in both cases, dispatching the victims, and returning. She kept each car for a while, but the only video we can find of her anywhere is in Tampa and Portland. The roads she would have used to get to Seattle and Miami are freeways instead of tollways, so there’s no video of her driving to the vics’ locations.

“我们把所有东西都整理好后就把车拿走了，但几乎一周过去了，我们还是没有找到法医证据。没有指纹。没有 DNA。我们无法将任何证据与 Janet Liu 或两起谋杀案联系起来。”我花了六天时间才弄清楚事情，这很快，这些人都知道这一点。但在租车的生活中，这就像永远一样。

“We grabbed the cars as soon as we put it all together, but almost a week had passed and there was no forensic evidence to be had. No fingerprints. No DNA. Nothing we could tie to either Janet Liu or the two murders.” The six days it had taken me to figure things out was fast, and these guys all knew it. But in the life of a rental car, it was forever.

“受害者的具体位置呢？”

“The victims’ locations themselves?”

“答案一样：没有。我们已经检查过了。它们都是住宅区。我们和所有邻居都谈过了，希望其中一个人有一段幸运的视频，可以用智能手机或其他东西拍下来。我们只需要一个。我们不必把她放在两个谋杀现场，只要一个就行。但我们做不到。

“Same answer: Nothing. We’ve checked. They’re both residential areas. We’ve spoken to all the neighbors, hoping that one had a lucky piece of video on a smartphone or something. All we need is one. We don’t have to place her at both murder sites, just one. But we can’t do it.

“我们在迈阿密谋杀案现场找到了一根头发，但法医在西雅图没有找到任何证据。如果我们有刘珍妮特，我们可以用这根头发确定她与那起犯罪有关。但如果没有刘珍妮特或她的 DNA，一切都只是间接证据。”

“We have a hair from the murder site in Miami, but forensics turned up nothing in Seattle. If we had Janet Liu, we could use the hair to link her to that crime with certainty. But without Janet Liu or her DNA, it’s all circumstantial.”

弗莱尔站起来，开始踱步。“问题就在这里，”他说。“总统担心这种事情再次发生。金德和米勒已经死了。他不愿意再拿任何美国人的生命冒险。如果有机会，他现在就会和中国人正面交锋。”

Flier got up and started pacing. “Here’s the problem,” he said. “The president is concerned that this happens again. Kind and Miller are already dead. He’s not willing to risk the lives of any additional Americans. If there’s a chance of that, he’ll go toe to toe with the Chinese now.”

他们都看着我，就好像我可以直接与刘珍妮特·刘或中国政府沟通一样。

They all looked at me, like I had a direct channel into the mind of either Janet Liu or the Chinese government.

“我不确定，”我回答道。“他们必须知道他们错过了什么。他们可能认为这次他们侥幸逃脱了，但风险太大了。我猜他们不会再尝试，除非他们确定了。不能再凭猜测杀人了。”

“I’m not sure,” I answered. “They have to know they missed. They may think they got away with it this time, but the risk is crazy. My guess is that they don’t try again until they’re sure. No more killing people based on guesswork.”

辛格看着斯塔基。“迪克？”

Singer looked at Starkey. “Dick?”

“我想那可能没错，”他回答道。“我肯定会这么做。”

“I think that’s probably right,” he answered. “It’s certainly how I’d do it.”

“中情局怎么说？”斯塔基问道。中情局就是美国中央情报局。

“What’s the Agency say?” Starkey asked. The Agency was the CIA.

“中情局什么都没说，”辛格回答道，“因为他们什么都不知道。告诉他们就等于告诉全世界。”他环顾四周。

“The Agency doesn’t say anything,” Singer answered, “because they don’t know anything. Telling them is the same as telling the world.” He looked around.

“好吧，”他继续说。“就说我们决定这么玩吧。谁知道呢？”

“Okay,” he continued. “Let’s say we decide to play it that way. Who knows?”

斯塔基第一个回答。“当然是哈德森特工。他的助理特工詹妮弗·威利斯。纽约特工特工，我的助理局长，还有我。一共五个人。你和彼得加起来就是七个。”

Starkey answered first. “Agent Hudson, of course. His ASAC, Jennifer Willis. The New York SAC, my assistant director, and me. That’s five. You and Peter make seven.”

“还有总统，”弗莱尔补充道。“八人。”

“And the president,” Flier added. “Eight.”

“太多了。”歌手。“还有其他人吗？”

“That’s six too many.” Singer. “Anyone else?”

“我们这边不行。”斯塔基。

“Not on our side.” Starkey.

我想到了乔希·威尔逊和 Lionesse Wetlab。“迈阿密警察，”我说。

I thought about Josh Wilson and the Lionesse Wetlab. “The Miami cop,” I said.

斯塔基惊呆了。“你在开玩笑吧。”

Starkey was dumbfounded. “You’re kidding me.”

“他知道的不多。他知道这两起谋杀案有关联，因为我在调查开始时就告诉了他西雅图的情况。他知道我破案了，也知道一切都匆忙被保密了。”

“He doesn’t know much. He knows that the two murders are connected, because I told him about Seattle at the beginning of the investigation. He knows I solved it, and he knows everything got classified in a hurry.”

“而他知道这些是因为你认为告诉他这些事情是个好主意？”斯塔基又问。

“And he knows because you decided it was a good idea to tell him these things?” Starkey again.

“我不得不这么做，”我回答道。“我不得不告诉他西雅图的事，因为除非我告诉他，至少是一点点，否则他不会告诉我任何事情。我告诉他一切都是机密，因为我想让他停止调查，而不是开始调查。”

“I had to,” I answered. “I had to tell him about Seattle because he wasn’t going to tell me anything unless I filled him in, at least a little. And I told him everything was classified because I was trying to get him to stop investigating, not start.”

“好吧，”辛格说。“就说八个半吧。还是太多了。”

“All right,” Singer said. “Call it eight and a half. Still way too many.”

“这个房间里的每个人都很好，”斯塔基回答道。“我并不总是相信我的指挥系统，但从哈德森开始，一切都很稳定。我认为我们在这方面没有问题。”

“Everyone in this room is good,” Starkey answered. “I don’t always trust my chain of command, but from Hudson up is solid. I don’t think we have a problem there.”

然后他们都看着我。

And then they all looked at me.

“迈阿密的那名警察名叫乔希·威尔逊，”我告诉他们。“我不认为他会有什么问题。我可以过去跟他谈谈，但我认为最好还是别管他了。”

“The Miami cop is named Josh Wilson,” I told them. “I don’t think he’s an issue. I can go down and talk with him, but I think he’s best simply left alone.”

“好的。”歌手又说。“还有什么？”

“Okay.” Singer again. “What else?”

斯塔基回答道：“因子人本人。所有这些都有效，直到中国人弄清楚他是谁。如果他们比我们先找到他，我们必须假设他们会对他采取行动。”

Starkey answered. “Factor Man himself. All of this works until the Chinese figure out who he is. If they find him before we do, we have to assume they’ll act against him.”

“我同意。那我们怎么找到他？”辛格问道。

“I agree with that. So how do we find him?” Singer asked.

斯塔基看着我。我承认道：“我不知道。”

Starkey looked at me. “I have no idea,” I conceded.

“中国人领先我们吗？”

“Are the Chinese ahead of us?”

“我不这么认为，”我回答道。“我认为他们比我们更努力。但我认为他们没有发现任何他们之前上传的视频中没有的东西。拍摄该视频的人亲眼见过 Factor Man。但我想如果有其他方法可以识别他，他们会这么说的。”

“I don’t think so,” I answered. “I think they’re trying harder than we are. But I don’t think they have anything that wasn’t in the video they put up a while back. The people who took that video saw Factor Man in person. But I expect if there was some other way of identifying him, they’d have said so.”

“视频是在哪里拍摄的？” 斯塔基。

“Where was the video shot?” Starkey.

“维也纳。”

“Vienna.”

“所以中国人知道 Factor Man 在哪里。我们不知道。”

“So the Chinese know where Factor Man was. We don’t.”

“我同意，”我反驳道。“但 Factor Man 知道有人在那里发现了他，还拍了视频。我无法想象他会回去。”

“I agree,” I countered. “But Factor Man knows he was spotted there and video was taken. I can’t imagine he’ll go back.”

“好吧，”辛格说。“我们领先中国人了吗？”

“Okay,” Singer said. “Are we ahead of the Chinese?”

“当然。”斯塔基说。“据我​​们所知，他是美国公民。我们推测他在这里生活和工作。最终，他会出现在我们监控的视频或其他媒体上。”

“Absolutely.” Starkey. “He’s an American citizen, as far as we know. We assume that he lives and works here. Eventually, he’ll show up in a video or some other media that we monitor.”

“那么中国人能看到同样的视频吗？”

“And will the Chinese have access to the same video?”

斯佩尔曼终于开口了。“他们可能会的。我们不确定他们如何成功渗透我们的各种监控系统，但我们认为他们可能做得相当不错。但七个月后，这一切都会停止。”

Spellman finally spoke up. “They probably will. We don’t know for sure how successfully they’ve infiltrated our various surveillance systems, but we think they’ve probably done pretty well. But in seven months, that all stops.”

“解释一下。”歌手。

“Explain.” Singer.

斯佩尔曼做到了。“寻找计算机系统中的漏洞就像对大数进行因式分解。这很难做到，但一旦有了答案，就很容易识别答案。我们将使用 Factor Man 代码来确保所有美国网络系统都完全安全。”

Spellman did. “Looking for vulnerabilities in a computer system is like factoring big numbers. It’s hard to do, but easy to recognize an answer when you’ve got one. We’re going to use the Factor Man code to ensure that all of the American cyber systems are completely secure.”

斯塔基询问是否需要花一些时间来弄清楚如何做到这一点。

Starkey asked if it would take a while to figure out how to do that.

“确实如此。但 Factor Man 代码的输入语言应该是 SAT，这是所有人都能理解的。我们花了一年时间将黑客问题翻译成 Factor Man 输入法。明年 7 月 10 日，只要我们拿到代码，我们就可以开始行动了。”

“It would. But the input language to the Factor Man code is supposedly SAT, which is universally understood. We’ve spent the last year translating the hacking problem into Factor Man input. As soon as we get the code on July 10 next year, we’ll be ready to go.”

“那反过来呢？”辛格问道。“中国人能保护自己免受我们的侵害吗？”

“And the other way around?” Singer asked. “Will the Chinese be able to protect themselves against us?”

“没有 Factor Man 技术，我们无法做到，”斯佩尔曼回答道。“事实上，我们将能够利用这项技术比以往更有效地利用他们的系统。”

“Not without access to the Factor Man technology,” Spellman answered. “In fact, we’ll be able to use that technology to exploit their systems more effectively than we ever have.”

没有人说什么，因为事情的后果已经显而易见。

No one said anything, as the consequences of that sank in.

“当然，”斯佩尔曼继续说道，“我们永远不会做那样的事。这取决于中情局。”

“Of course,” Spellman continued, “we wouldn’t ever do anything like that. It would be up to the Agency.”

“很高兴知道，鲍比，”辛格评论道。

“Good to know, Bobbie,” Singer commented.

斯塔基再次说道：“但在接下来的七个月里，我们必须假设中国人知道我们所知道的事情。”

Starkey again. “But for the next seven months, we have to assume that the Chinese know what we know.”

“是的，”辛格回答道。“最重要的是，我们必须让 Factor Man 活下去。”

“We do,” Singer answered. “And more than anything else, we have to keep Factor Man alive.”

“明白，”斯塔基回答。

“Understood,” Starkey answered.

斯佩尔曼：“那就意味着我们必须找到他。”

Spellman. “And that means we have to find him.”

突然间，我有一种不舒服的感觉，好像房间里的每个人都在看着我。

All of a sudden, I had the uncomfortable feeling that everyone in the room was looking at me.

伯克特

Burkett

2020 年 2 月 21 日

February 21, 2020

苹果发布 iPhone 和 Mac 的“最终”补丁

Apple Releases “Final” Patch for iPhone and Mac

威廉·伯克特，《纽约时报》

William Burkett, The New York Times

苹果公司今天发布了据称是 iPhone 和苹果个人电脑所需的最后一个安全补丁。他们之所以能够做到这一点，是因为事实证明，计算机代码中的漏洞就像大数的因数：易于识别，但很难（直到现在）找到。苹果公司曾使用 Factor Man 代码来查找入侵苹果设备的所有方法。所有此类潜在入侵方法都已修复。

Apple today released what it claimed was the final security patch that would ever be needed for the iPhone and for Apple personal computers. They were able to do this because it turns out that vulnerabilities in computer code are like the factors of big numbers: easy to recognize but hard (until now) to find. Apple had used the Factor Man code to find all of the ways someone could hack into an Apple device. Every such potential hack was repaired.

苹果首席执行官蒂姆·库克宣布：“这是我们对 Factor Man 代码的投资的第一个回报。首先，我们用它来查找代码中的漏洞，然后让我们的工程师修复它们。

“This is the first payoff from our investment in the Factor Man code,” Apple CEO Tim Cook announced. “First, we used it to find vulnerabilities in our code, and then we had our engineers fix them.

“两天前，我很高兴地宣布，Factor Man 代码已经确认现在不可能入侵任何 Apple 产品。”

“As of two days ago, I’m pleased to announce that the Factor Man code has confirmed that it is now impossible to hack into any Apple product.”

谷歌的 Android 智能手机操作系统是开源的，可供所有人使用，但它就没那么幸运了。苹果还宣布了两个“严重”漏洞，这些漏洞可让第三方完全访问这两款 Android 手机以及其中可能包含的所有个人数据。

Google’s Android smartphone operating system, which is open source and available to all, was not so fortunate. Apple also announced two “critical” vulnerabilities that would allow a third party to obtain full access to both Android phones and all of the personal data that they might contain.

安全专家已经证实，苹果的说法似乎是正确的，至少就 Android 而言是如此。

Security experts have confirmed that Apple’s claims appear to be valid, at least as far as Android goes.

毫不奇怪，苹果引起了所有人的关注。

Not surprisingly, Apple got everyone’s attention.

华尔街注意到了这一点。随着 Factor Man 技术终于带来红利，苹果股价也因此上涨。

Wall Street noticed. With the Factor Man technology finally paying dividends, Apple stock jumped on the news.

Google 注意到了这一点。在苹果公布漏洞一周后，Google 就发布了补丁。

Google noticed. One week after Apple announced the flaws, Google provided a patch.

苹果注意到了这一点。补丁发布一小时后，苹果又公布了 Android 的两个新漏洞。

And Apple noticed that. An hour after the patch was released, Apple announced two additional flaws in Android.

苹果公布的漏洞非常引人注目，因为调查这些漏洞的安全专家报告称，这些漏洞极难修复或利用。因此，苹果并没有采取任何危害 Android 用户的行为。苹果只是在骚扰谷歌，迫使他们投入大量工程资源修复漏洞，以免其他人利用这些漏洞。

The flaws announced by Apple were remarkable, because security experts who investigated them reported that they were extremely difficult to either fix or to exploit. So Apple wasn’t really doing anything that jeopardized Android users. Apple was just harassing Google, forcing them to spend substantial engineering resources fixing things before other folks could exploit them.

这种局面持续了数月。谷歌会修复问题，而苹果会破坏问题。苹果在智能手机市场的份额开始上升，因为消费者已经证明自己不愿意忍受似乎永无止境的一系列关键更新。

The dance went on for months. Google would fix things, and Apple would break them. Apple’s share of the smartphone market started to increase, as customers proved themselves unwilling to tolerate what appeared to be a virtually endless series of critical updates.

谷歌起诉苹果干涉商业活动。苹果的辩护是，它发现 Android 存在问题，这是在履行公共服务，帮助谷歌解决问题绝对不是苹果的责任。（截至撰写本文时，距离 FCOP 开庭仅剩几天，该诉讼尚未解决，苹果目前占据了智能手机市场约 80% 的份额，而这一切开始时只有 15%。）

Google sued Apple for business interference. Apple’s defense was that it was performing a public service by identifying problems with Android and that it certainly wasn’t Apple’s responsibility to help Google fix things. (As of this writing, with FCOP days away, the suit has not been settled, and Apple currently has about 80% of the smartphone market, up from 15% when all of this began.)

在 Factor Man 准备向美国政府公布其技术的大约一个月前，苹果公司发布了另一份声明。

About a month before Factor Man was due to release his technology to the US government, Apple made another announcement.

苹果宣布国际象棋为平局，但围棋不为平局

Chess is a Draw but Go is Not, Apple Announces

威廉·伯克特，《纽约时报》

William Burkett, The New York Times

苹果宣布，如果双方都发挥完美，国际象棋将打成平局。这丝毫不令人意外。苹果还宣布，如果围棋发挥完美，先手将获胜。这让所有人都感到惊讶。

Apple has announced that with perfect play on both sides, chess is a draw. This surprised no one. Apple also announced that with perfect play in Go, the first player wins. This surprised everyone.

好吧，每个人都有自己的观点。我个人的专长仅限于井字游戏。

Well, everyone who had an opinion. My personal expertise ends with tic-tac-toe.

这些结论是苹果公司使用其授权的 Factor Man 代码获得的最新结果，目前苹果公司正在通过识别 Android 操作系统中的漏洞来骚扰谷歌。

These conclusions are Apple’s latest results obtained using the Factor Man code that Apple has licensed, as Apple continues to harass Google by identifying vulnerabilities in the Android operating system.

尽管“因子人”计划在几周后向美国政府公布其代码，但他本人基本上已经从公众视野中消失了。

Factor Man himself has essentially disappeared from the public eye, although he is scheduled to release his code to the United States government in a few weeks’ time.

与此同时，有关 FCOP 的细节开始浮出水面。门票似乎全部掌握在 Jess MacMurray 手中，她负责处理活动的所有细节。延续 Factor Man 在其原始博客文章中介绍的钢铁侠小传统，各种各样的人开始将 MacMurray 女士称为 Pepper Potts。

Meanwhile, details about FCOP have begun to emerge. The tickets are apparently all in the hands of one Jess MacMurray, who is handling all of the details involved in the event. Continuing the minor Iron Man tradition introduced by Factor Man in his original blog post, a variety of folks have begun to refer to Ms. MacMurray as Pepper Potts.

Potts-MacMurray 女士宣布，在 Factor Man 代码向美国政府公布后不久，门票将开始拍卖。玫瑰碗球场的座位将分成几组，每组座位均以 eBay 方式出售。单个竞标者购买的多个座位将保证连在一起。

Ms. Potts-MacMurray has announced that the tickets will be sold at auction beginning shortly after the Factor Man code is released to the US government. The Rose Bowl accommodations will be broken into groups of comparable seats, with sets in each group sold in an eBay style. Multiple seats bought by single bidders will be guaranteed to be together.

初步估计，门票价格将在 1,000 美元到至少 50,000 美元之间，平均价格约为 2,500 美元。帕萨迪纳有近 100,000 个座位，随着 Factor Man 故事的最新进展，大约有 2.5 亿美元的门票待售。

Initial estimates are that the price of seats will range from $1,000 to at least $50,000, with an average of perhaps $2,500. With almost 100,000 seats available in Pasadena, some $250 million is up for grabs as the Factor Man story takes its latest turn.

一般而言，“体育”赛事的转播权价格约为座位总价值的三倍，有传言称，作为组织该赛事的回报，波茨女士将获得收益。如果真是这样，世界可能会迎来另一位亿万富翁。

In general, broadcast rights for “sporting” events go for approximately triple the aggregate value of the seats themselves, and rumor has it that in exchange for organizing the event, Ms. Potts is to receive the proceeds. If so, the world is likely to welcome another billionaire.

刘

Liu

2020 年 7 月 8 日

July 8, 2020

两年多来，我一直在寻找 Factor Man，除了做其他事情外，没有做其他事情。我的团队规模时而扩大，时而缩小，这取决于我所感知到的进度以及 Factor Man 截止日期的临近程度。

I had been searching for Factor Man, and doing little else, for a bit over two years. The size of my team had grown, and been reduced, depending upon my perceived progress and the proximity of one of the Factor Man deadlines.

下一个截止日期还有两天。

The next such deadline was two days away.

我生命的最后一年实际上是在北京被软禁，我并不指望这种情况在接下来的几天里会有所改变。如果我找到了 Factor Man，我的职责将转移到确保他无法将他的技术转让给美国政府。如果我找不到他，我每天至少要花 18 个小时来尝试找到他。

The last year of my life had been spent in virtual house arrest in Beijing, a situation that I did not expect to change over the next few days. If I found Factor Man, my responsibilities would shift to the task of ensuring that he was unable to transfer his technology to the American government. If I failed to find him, I would be expected to have spent at least eighteen hours daily attempting to do so.

我们已经检查了我原来的名单三次。令人沮丧的是，很明显 Kind 和 Miller 都不是 Factor Man，但名单上其他人都不匹配。他们的鼻子不对。他们要么体重过重，要么太高或太矮。在 12,762 名原始人员中，有两人被强制淘汰，12,760 人为阴性。

We had been through my original list three times. It was distressingly clear that neither Kind nor Miller had been Factor Man, but no one else on the list could be a match. Their noses were wrong. They weighed too much, or were too tall or short. Of the 12,762 original individuals, two had been eliminated by force, and 12,760 were negatives.

我们多次重新审视我们的假设，发现它们似乎都过于保守。但考虑到“人”因素显然不再在我们的样本中，我们需要放宽这些假设。

We had reviewed our assumptions multiple times, and they all appeared to be conservative. But given that Factor Man was clearly no longer in our sample, we needed to relax them.

在 Factor Man 向美国政府提交其代码的两周前，我们将所有范围扩大了 5%，这样 Factor Man 的体重不再限制在 86 公斤（已经超过了我们图片中显示的 82 公斤），而是 90 公斤。我们允许他的最大身高为 189 厘米，而不是 180 厘米。我们郁闷地看着我们收集的可能个体数量猛增至近 100,000 人。

Two weeks before Factor Man was due to provide his code to the American government, we expanded all of our ranges by 5%, so that instead of limiting Factor Man’s weight to 86kg (already more than the apparent weight of 82kg in our images), we allowed it to be 90kg. Instead of 180cm, we allowed his maximum height to be 189cm. And we watched unhappily as our collection of possible individuals jumped to almost 100,000 members.

已知有两人死亡。已知有 12,760 人不是 Factor Man。剩余人数为 86,525 人。

Two were known to be dead. 12,760 were known not to be Factor Man. There were 86,525 remaining.

我们开始逐一检查它们。我们显然无法在两天的时间内完成；事实上，在 Factor Man 向全世界发布他的技术之前，我们不太可能完成。

One at a time, we began to examine them. We would obviously not finish in our two-day time frame; in fact, it was unlikely that we would finish before Factor Man released his technology to the world at large.

我们未能在两天的期限内完成任务。但结果发现这无关紧要，因为根据苹果公司之前未披露的 Factor Man 代码许可条款，是苹果公司，而不是 Factor Man，向美国当局提供了 Factor Man 代码。

We did not meet the two-day deadline. And it turned out not to matter, because in keeping with a previously undisclosed condition of Apple’s license to the Factor Man code, it was Apple, and not Factor Man, that provided the Factor Man code to the American authorities.

三天后，我们可以秘密访问的美国政府机器数量下降了。

And three days after that, there was a drop in the number of US government machines we could access surreptitiously.

归零。

To zero.

* * *

* * *

FCOP 门票拍卖发生在美国政府获得该技术后的两个月内。中国被荒谬地排除在直接接收门票的国家名单之外，被迫购买了两张。

The auction of tickets to FCOP occurred in the two months following the American government’s acquisition of the technology. China, having been absurdly excluded from the list of countries receiving tickets directly, was forced to purchase two.

我们以每张12.5万美元的价格买到了体育场两侧前排中场的两张票。持票人分别是李强武和马永锋。

We obtained two front-row, midfield tickets on opposite sides of the stadium at a price of $125,000 each. The ticket holders were listed as Li Qiang Wu and Ma Yong Feng.

伯克特

Burkett

2020 年 10 月 9 日

October 9, 2020

国会通过因素人法案

Congress Passes Factor Man Act

威廉·伯克特，《纽约时报》

William Burkett, The New York Times

美国政府获得“因子人”代码三个月后，国会通过了所谓的“因子人法案”，要求所有政府运作都必须在“合理可行的”范围内使用“因子人”技术进行优化。

Three months after the United States government obtained access to the Factor Man code, Congress has passed the so-called “Factor Man Act,” which requires that all government operations be optimized using the Factor Man technology to the extent “reasonably practical.”

众议院以 318 票对 117 票通过了该法案，参议院以 72 票对 28 票通过了该法案。在这两场投票中，都有相当多的共和党人和民主党人一起支持该法案。

The vote in the House was 318 to 117; in the Senate, it was 72 to 28. In both cases, a relatively large number of Republicans joined Democrats in supporting the bill.

支持该法案的理由是，根据管理和预算办公室的说法，该法案将削减政府支出约 7%，而不会对服务质量产生任何影响。反对该法案的理由是，该法案只是政府通过额外监管来越权的又一个例子。实际上，反对该法案的真正理由似乎是，许多政府供应商以“成本加成”的方式提供服务，这样他们就可以获得成本补偿，并获得一些利润。

The argument in favor of the bill was that according to the Office of Management and Budget, it will cut government spending by some 7% without any impact on the quality of services. The stated argument against was that the bill was simply another example of government overreach through additional regulation. In practice, the real argument against the bill appears to be that many government suppliers provide services on a “cost plus” basis, so that they get reimbursed for their costs, plus some profit margin.

成本越大，利润越大。

The larger the costs, the larger the profit.

提出了许多修正案，将某些行业排除在要求之外，但所有这些修正案都失败了。争论最激烈的是效率低下的美国造船业；《琼斯法案》要求美国海军舰艇在美国造船厂建造，尽管这种舰艇的每吨成本几乎是任何竞争外国船厂成本的两倍。国会预算办公室 (CBO) 估计，Factor Man 技术每年将使海军 165 亿美元的造船成本减少 10 多亿美元。

Numerous amendments excluding certain industries from the requirements were proposed, but all such amendments failed. The arguments were the most heated for the notoriously inefficient American shipbuilding industry; the Jones Act requires that US Navy vessels be built in American shipyards, even though the cost per ton of such vessels is double what the cost would be in virtually any competing foreign yard. Congressional Budget Office (CBO) estimates are that the Factor Man technology will reduce the Navy’s $16.5 billion annual shipbuilding costs by a bit over $1 billion annually.

该法案包括了优化各个行业的时间表，造船业和飞行计划都计划于明年进行优化。除了节省造船业成本外，优化后的飞行计划还可最大程度降低燃料消耗，预计可使空军每年 80 亿美元的燃料费用减少约 3%。总而言之，到 2022 年该技术全面部署时，使用该技术可节省每年 2000 亿美元。这将弥补目前预计的美国联邦赤字的约 25%，尽管国会预算办公室还估计，该技术更广泛的经济影响有望将赤字降至 1990 年代以来的最高水平。

The bill includes a timetable for the optimization of various industries, with both shipbuilding and flight planning slated for optimization next year. In addition to shipbuilding savings, flight plans optimized to minimize fuel consumption are expected to reduce the Air Force’s $8 billion annual fuel bill by some 3%.
