媒体大举出动，到处都是记者。他们的相机毫无意外地小到可以装进小塑料袋里。

The press was out in force, with reporters everywhere. Their cameras, not surprisingly, were all small enough to fit into the little plastic bags.

我被认出来了。每次媒体看到我，他们都会想采访我。他们总是问我同一个问题：我知不知道 Factor Man 是谁？

I was recognized. Any time someone from the press saw me, he or she wanted to interview me. Always the same question, did I know who Factor Man was.

我告诉他们那不是我，也不是艾玛。但我确信 Factor Man 就在人群中，他们应该四处打听一下。

I told them all that it wasn’t me, and that it wasn’t Emma. But I was confident Factor Man was in the crowd, and they should just ask around.

艾玛最终把我拉到一边，告诉我我是个混蛋，竟然在十万人面前叫别人去打听。之后，我又告诉他们，即使我知道，我又有什么资格去破坏四年来精心准备的惊喜呢？

Emma eventually pulled me aside and told me I was being an asshole, telling people to ask around in a crowd of a hundred thousand. After that, I went back to telling them that even if I did know, who was I to spoil a surprise that had been four years in the making?

艾玛和我慢慢地走向自己的座位。座位不错，但不算特别好——大约在三十码线，大概四十排。我看到了球场上所有的椅子，不知道它们是更好还是更差。离得更近，但可能更难看清。人们逐渐在我们周围坐下，我们一起等待着主赛的开始。

Emma and I gradually made our way to our seats. They were good but not stellar – about the thirty-yard line and maybe forty rows up. I saw all the chairs on the field and wondered if they would be better or worse. Closer in, but maybe harder to see from. People gradually settled in around us, and we collectively waited for the main event.

刘

Liu

上午 11:00

11:00 AM

我睡了大约五个小时，足够了。当天的准备工作非常简单：洗澡、穿衣、吃饭，然后离开酒店。我的塑料枪绑在大腿内侧。根据随枪附带的说明，枪与我的身体两侧平行。多次测试表明，在这种方向上，金属探测器（显然）、全身扫描仪或美国人部署的任何其他商用扫描系统几乎不可能检测到枪。

I got about five hours of sleep, which was sufficient. Preparation for the day was remarkably simple: Shower, dress, eat, and leave the hotel. My plastic gun was strapped to the inside of my thigh. In accordance with the instructions I had received with it, the gun was oriented parallel to my sides. Multiple tests had indicated that in this orientation, there was virtually no chance that the gun would be detected by a metal detector (obviously), full body scanner, or any of the other commercially available scanning systems deployed by the Americans.

如果他们搜查我，肯定会被发现。但我怀疑他们会搜查每个进入玫瑰碗的人。我带了一个小包，足够装下我的护照、一部手机和一块备用电池。我的两颗子弹正好装在电池里，只要打开隐藏在侧面的闩锁就可以取出。

If they searched me, it would be discovered. But I doubted that they would frisk everyone entering the Rose Bowl. I carried a small man bag, big enough for my passport, a phone and a spare battery. My two bullets fit snugly into the battery itself and could be removed by releasing a latch hidden in the side.

我和李搭 Uber 去了玫瑰碗。我们不得不同意一个特殊的“高峰”票价，是正常票价的十五倍。我想，这就是资本主义的精髓。司机把我们放下，然后我们分开，以最大限度地提高我们中至少有一人能通过安检的机会。

Li and I took an Uber to the Rose Bowl. We had to agree to a special “peak” rate of fifteen times the normal fare. Capitalism at its finest, I supposed. The driver dropped us and we separated so as to maximize the chance that at least one of us managed to get through security.

安检包括全身扫描，幸运的是，我们事先就预料到了，因为全身扫描会清楚地表明我是女性，而不是男性。我的小男包里还有一对夹式耳环和一些鲜红色的口红。当我在扫描仪和我的机票与身份证件核对点之间排队等候时，我小心翼翼地戴上耳环，看起来像是在补口红。轮到我接受扫描时，没有人会怀疑我是一个穿着时尚的亚洲女性。

Security included full-body scanners, which we had fortunately anticipated, since a body scan would make it clear that I was a woman instead of a man. My small man bag also contained a pair of clip-on earrings and some bright red lipstick. While I waited in line between the scanners and the point where my ticket had been checked against my ID, I carefully put on the earrings and appeared to fix my lipstick. By the time it was my turn to be scanned, no one would doubt that I was a fashionably dressed Asian woman.

我轻松通过了安检，然后立即去了厕所。我擦掉了口红，扔掉了耳环。我从假电池中取出子弹，装上子弹，然后把枪放进了包里。我的手机放在了大腿上。备用电池盒跟着耳环扔进了垃圾桶。

I cleared security easily and immediately made my way to the loo. I cleaned off the lipstick and discarded the earrings. I withdrew the bullets from the fake battery and loaded the gun, which I placed in my bag. My phone took its place on my thigh. The spare battery case followed the earrings into the trash.

我从厕所出来，走向球场上的座位，看到周围美国人的奢华生活，我感到恶心。随处可见的食物和饮料足够一个中等规模的中国村庄吃一周，而且我相信，活动结束后，其中很大一部分会被扔掉。

As I exited the loo and made my way toward my seat on the field, I was disgusted by the display of American lavishness that surrounded me. The food and drink that was on display everywhere would feed a moderately sized Chinese village for a week, and I was confident that a significant percentage of it would simply be discarded when the event was over.

因子人

Factor Man

中午 12:00

12:00 noon

至少在我们看来，帕萨迪纳朗廷亨廷顿酒店是完全顶级的。

The Langham Huntington Pasadena Hotel was, at least to our eyes, completely over the top.

首先，我们前一天晚上入住时发现有三个房间。一间给我和 Denise，一间给我们的儿子 Navarre，一间给我们的女儿 Rachel。当孩子们还小的时候，我们尽可能多地外出旅行，通常挤在一间有两张大床的单人房里。其中一个孩子会睡在地板上，或者睡在沙发床上，或者他们共用一张床。没问题。

For a start, we found ourselves with three rooms when we had checked in the previous night. One for Denise and me, one for our son Navarre, and one for our daughter Rachel. When the kids were little, we had traveled as often as we could and had generally been crammed into a single room with two queen beds. One of the kids would sleep on the floor, or on a sofabed, or they had shared a bed. No problem.

随着孩子们长大，我们会分到两个房间。丹尼斯和我住一间，纳瓦拉和雷切尔住另一间。

As they got older, we would get two rooms. Denise and I would share one, and Navarre and Rachel would share the other.

但三个房间却是闻所未闻的富丽堂皇。

But three rooms was unheard-of opulence.

房间本身也很不错。床单和羽绒被都很豪华。家具比我们习惯的更像路易十六风格，但也非常出色。设施同样优雅，占地 23 英亩，包括网球场和众多餐厅等各种设施。

And the rooms themselves were just nice. The sheets and duvets were luxurious. The furnishings were a bit more Louis XVI than we were used to, but they, too, were stellar. The facilities were similarly elegant, 23-acre grounds that included everything from tennis courts to a multitude of restaurants.

这是我们一生中第一次使用酒店迷你吧。

For the first time in our lives, we used a hotel minibar.

晚上安顿下来后，我和 Denise 悄悄地聊了聊。她提醒我，如果再来一次，我还会这么做。她提醒我，我的目标一直是在尽可能不引起社会混乱的情况下发布代码，而我似乎正在这样做。她提醒我，即使我想改变什么，也为时已晚。她还提醒我，只剩下不到 24 小时了，我应该好好享受这段旅程。

Denise and I had talked quietly after we settled in for the night. She reminded me that I would do it all again. She reminded me that my goal all along had been to release the code with as little societal disruption as possible, and I appeared to be doing that. She reminded me that even if I wanted to change something, it was too late. And she reminded me that there were less than twenty-four hours left, and I should enjoy the ride.

然后她吻了我道晚安。我睡得比我想象的要好。

And then she kissed me good night. I slept better than I expected.

FCOP 那天我们起床后，在下楼吃早餐之前，我们告诉了孩子们这件事。正如我们所料，他们两个都不惊讶。我们谈论了前一天的袭击，以及我们希望我们不再处于危险之中。我们谈论了科学的道德问题。他们都理解。

After we got up on the day of FCOP, and before we headed down for breakfast, we told the kids. As we had expected, neither was surprised. We talked about the attack the previous day and how we hoped we were no longer in danger. We talked about the morality of science. They both understood.

不过，帕萨迪纳朗廷亨廷顿酒店最棒的地方可能就是它位于帕萨迪纳。距离玫瑰碗球场约五英里。下午 2 点，我们悠闲地离开酒店，加入前往体育场的疯狂人群。在酒店或开车出发时，我们没有看到有人在看守我们，但我怀疑他们在那里。

Arguably the best thing about the Langham Huntington Pasadena, though, was that it was in, well, Pasadena. It was about five miles from the Rose Bowl. We left the hotel at a relaxed 2 PM and joined the mad rush to the stadium. We hadn’t seen anyone watching over us at the hotel or as we started the drive, but I suspected they were there.

安检跟我想象的一样严格。如果说有什么不同的话，那就是更加严格了。你进去时身上只穿一件衣服，也许还带着一个小钱包，仅此而已。其他东西都要在登机口检查。钱包要手动检查，无一例外。人们要通过机场里那种圆形扫描仪，检查图像的人基本上可以看到你赤身裸体的样子。我对此完全没意见。

Security was as tight as I had hoped. Tighter, if anything. You went in with the clothes on your back, maybe a tiny purse, and that was it. Anything else got checked at the gate. The purses were searched by hand and without exception. People went through those circular scanners that you see at the airports, where apparently the people examining the images can basically see you naked. That was all just fine with me.

一进门，我就看到杰西的表现完全超越了自己。食物和饮料都非常棒。我尤其高兴的是，杰西告诉我，活动结束后剩下的任何东西都会捐赠给当地的收容所，用于收容无家可归者或受虐妇女。

Once inside, I saw how completely Jess had outdone herself. The food and drink was all phenomenal. I was especially pleased by the fact that Jess had told me that anything left over at the end of the event would be donated to local shelters for either the homeless or battered women.

也许最重要的是，人们似乎都玩得很开心。他们都在聊天，显然经常是在和他们从未见过的人聊天。大部分都是对被击落的中国飞机或 Factor Man 的身份进行无意义的猜测。

Perhaps most important, the people all seemed to actually be having fun. They were all talking, often clearly to other folks they had never met. Mostly idle speculation about the Chinese plane that had been shot down, or about the identity of Factor Man.

我参与了一些猜测，认为 Factor Man 就是比尔·盖茨，而中国飞机实际上是嫉妒的埃隆·马斯克派来的巧妙伪装的无人机，目的是消灭他。

I participated in some of the speculation, suggesting that Factor Man was Bill Gates, and that the Chinese aircraft had in fact been a cleverly disguised drone sent by a jealous Elon Musk to wipe him out.

丹尼斯最终把我拉到一边并告诉我我是个混蛋。

Denise eventually pulled me aside and told me I was being an asshole.

下午时光悄然流逝，我们找到了座位。我要求的舞台被安置在场地中央，但杰斯实际上做得更好。下午，各种当地乐队演奏了三十分钟。他们都很棒，而且都不太出名（直到现在）。我想知道杰斯是付钱给他们，还是他们付钱给他们。

As the afternoon wore on, we found our way to our seats. The stage I had requested had been placed in the center of the field, but Jess had actually gone one better. Over the course of the afternoon, a variety of local bands played thirty-minute sets. They were all great, and they were all relatively unknown (until now). I wondered if Jess were paying them, or the other way around.

哈德森

Hudson

下午 2:17

2:17 PM

据我所知，一切都进展得如预期般顺利。

As far as I could tell, everything was going as smoothly as could be expected.

我漫无目的地在玫瑰碗球场周围徘徊，希望发现任何安保漏洞，但也意识到我的努力可能徒劳无功。安保系统可能有效，也可能无效。如果系统失效，有坏人试图闯入，我们只能希望他们碰到的是运行正常的安保地点，而不是运行不正常的地点。

I was wandering somewhat aimlessly around the perimeter of the Rose Bowl, hoping to notice any lapses in security but also realizing that my effort to do so was probably fruitless. The security system would work or it wouldn’t. If it didn’t and there were bad actors trying to make their way in, we could only hope that they bumped into the security locations that were functioning properly instead of those that weren’t.

这基本上是 TSA 在所有地方都使用的相同原则。尽管有令人恐惧的统计数据表明，携带枪支、刀具或其他东西通过机场安检是多么容易，但底线是，自 2001 年以来，悬挂美国国旗的飞机上从未发生过恐怖事件。

It was basically the same principal that the TSA used everywhere. And although there were frightening statistics about how easy it was to get a gun, or a knife, or what have you through airport security, the bottom line was that there hadn’t been a terrorist incident aboard a United States-flagged aircraft since 2001.

安检时发生了各种各样的事件，一般都是因为富人和/或名人往往不愿意遵守为“其他人”制定的规则，也不愿意以任何理由放弃他们的个人财产。

There were a variety of incidents at security, triggered in general by the fact that the rich and/or famous are all too often unwilling to either play by rules that have been designed for “other folk” or to part with any of their personal possessions for any reason.

外交官——而且有很多——就更加难对付，我见过的最严重的事件就涉及这样一个人。一名中国男子最初要求免于检查，理由是外交豁免权提供了这样的豁免。

The diplomats – and there were many – were more difficult still, and the worst incident I saw involved just such an individual. A Chinese man had initially demanded to be exempted from screening on the grounds that diplomatic immunity provided such an exemption.

安检员按照自己的培训要求，告诉该男子，虽然豁免权意味着他无权对他进行安检，但同样的豁免权并不意味着该男子有权进入该设施，因此将被拒绝进入。该男子随后同意接受安检，安检员除了进行常规的全身扫描外，还决定对该男子进行搜身检查。

The screener, in keeping with his training, told the man in question that while immunity meant that he did not have the right to screen him, that same immunity did not give the man the right to enter the facility, and such entry would be denied. The man then agreed to screening and the screener, in addition to the customary full-body scan, decided to pat the man down as well.

对此，他断然拒绝，拿回了机票，显然是想去别的地方。这时，安检人员叫来了警察，这名男子被拘留了。这符合《维也纳外交关系公约》，该公约是外交豁免权规定的一般来源。公约规定，虽然外交官不得被逮捕或拘留，但“在涉及自卫、公共安全或防止严重犯罪行为的紧急情况下，可以采取合理的限制措施。”这名男子被要求没收机票，然后被释放。

To this, he absolutely refused, taking his ticket back with the apparent intention of simply going elsewhere. At this point, the screener called over police officers and the man was detained. This is in keeping with the Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations, which is the general source for regulations involving diplomatic immunity. The Convention states that while a diplomat may not be arrested or detained, “reasonable constraints, however, may be applied in emergency circumstances involving self-defense, public safety, or the prevention of serious criminal acts.” The man was required to forfeit his ticket and was then released.

他叫李强武。我摸了摸耳塞，要求对其他所有中国入境者进行额外检查。几分钟后，我被告知预计还会有 136 名中国客人。对他们每个人进行检查无疑会加剧中美紧张局势，但我认为额外的安全措施是值得的。我指示对以后所有中国入境者进行人工检查，只希望我及时做出了决定。

His name was Li Qiang Wu. I touched my ear bud and asked that every other Chinese entrant be subjected to additional screening. After a few moments, I was told that there were 136 additional Chinese guests expected. Scrutinizing every one of them would doubtless make Sino-American tensions worse, but I figured the extra safety was worth it. I instructed that any future Chinese entrants be searched by hand, and only hoped that I had made the decision in time.

* * *

* * *

四点刚过，我仍未收到其他安保人员关于可疑中国与会者的回复，这让我很困扰。中国外交官的行为肯定有些不对劲。我不知道是什么原因，但这让我很困扰。

Shortly after four, I still hadn’t heard back from any of the other security folks about suspicious Chinese attendees, and it bothered me. Something about the behavior of the Chinese diplomat had simply been wrong. I couldn’t place it, but it nagged at me.

我最终打电话进去，被告知在客人名单上的 136 名中国公民中，有一人被拒绝入境（外交官李江武），其余人中除了一人之外都已经通过了安检。没有通过安检的那人坐在相对较差的座位上，高高地，靠近终点区。接下来的几个小时里，太阳会照在他们的背上。这是狙击手的绝佳位置，尽管我无法想象有人能带着步枪通过安检。我让几名特工检查一下位置，然后自己也赶了过去。

I eventually called in and was told that of the 136 Chinese nationals on the guest list, one had been denied entry (the diplomat Li Chiang Wu) and all but one of the rest had already passed through security. The one who hadn’t had a relatively poor seat, high up and near one of the end zones. The sun would be at their back for the next couple of hours. Great spot for a sniper, although I couldn’t imagine how anyone could get a rifle through security. I asked a few agents to check out the location while I rushed over myself.

这个座位是空的。我们询问了周围的人，他们是否见过这个座位上的乘客，但没有人见过。

The seat was empty. We asked the surrounding seat holders if any of them had seen the occupant of the seat in question, and no one had.

我的耳机响了，我被告知最后一位中国客人刚刚抵达。他已经接受过人工检查，看起来并不构成威胁。当时是下午五点。

My earpiece chimed, and I was told that the last Chinese guest had just arrived. He had been checked by hand and did not appear to be a threat. It was five o’clock.

李仍然在唠叨我。

Li still nagged at me.

我问了 136 名中国人中有多少人到场，然后才要求对中国参会者进行人工搜查。没有人知道这个要求具体是什么时候提出的。

I asked how many of the 136 Chinese had arrived before I asked that the Chinese attendees be searched by hand. No one knew exactly when that request had been made.

我问他们中有多少人比李先生晚到了十几分钟，他们说信息不是这样存储的。我让他们自己想办法。

I asked how many of them had arrived more than ten minutes after Li had and was told that the information wasn’t stored that way. I told them to figure it out.

过了很久，我才被告知，在开始手检之前，已经有七名中国客人抵达。五男两女。我脑子里想着刘珍妮特，于是问那两个女人坐在哪里。

What seemed like an eternity later, I was told that seven Chinese guests had arrived before the hand searches had begun. Five men and two women. Janet Liu on my mind, I asked where the two women were sitting.

当时还不到六点。

It was a little before six.

二十七

27

因子人

Factor Man

下午 5:50

5:50 PM

电视最后一支乐队在六点十分左右结束演出。他们清理了舞台上的所有东西，重新布置了舞台，放上麦克风和我要求的十三把椅子。正如我要求的那样，椅子被摆放在一个正方形的三边，麦克风放在空边的中央。

The last band finished up at about ten to six. They cleared everything off the stage and reset it with a microphone and the thirteen chairs I had requested. As I had asked, the chairs were arranged on three sides of a square, with the mic at the center of the empty edge.

我们等待着，体育场渐渐安静下来。安静下来后，我握住了丹妮丝的手。

We waited, as the stadium gradually hushed. After it quieted, I took Denise’s hand.

“你准备好了吗？”我问她。

“You ready?” I asked her.

“不，”她说。

“No,” she said.

我放开她的手，站起来，走下楼梯，向舞台走去。

I released her hand, stood, and walked down the stairs toward the stage.

伯克特

Burkett

下午 5:50

5:50 PM

艾玛和我玩得太开心了，直到快六点的时候才坐稳。是的，我知道有现场音乐表演。是的，我知道每个乐队都成了城里最火的乐队。但我能说什么呢？我喜欢说话。

Emma and I were having too much fun to settle into our seats until shortly before six. Yes, I know there was live music. Yes, I know that every band has since become the hottest ticket in town. But what can I say? I like talking.

令人惊奇的是，你可以和任何人交谈。总统身边有一些人群，但沃伦·巴菲特身边没有。小罗伯特·唐尼也没有。

And the amazing thing is, you could talk to anyone. The president had a bit of a crowd around him, but Warren Buffett didn’t. Robert Downey, Jr. didn’t.

我不知道为什么。也许是因为参加活动的名人太多了，以至于没有一个人真正脱颖而出。也许是因为这个活动真的不是为他们而举办的；他们参加活动的原因和其他人一样。

I’m not sure why. Maybe because such a ridiculous number of well-known people were there that no single one of them really stuck out. Maybe because the event truly wasn’t about them; they were there for the same reason as everyone else.

所以，那一个下午，FCOP 的每个人都是这样的：在 FCOP。不多也不少。我们的烦恼都抛到一边。我们吃喝玩乐，开心极了。

So, for that one afternoon, everyone at FCOP was just that: at FCOP. Nothing more or less. Our troubles were all cast aside. We ate, we drank, and we were merry.

这真是太酷了。

It was totally cool.

有些人早早就找到了座位，听乐队表演。有些人没有。但从 5:30 左右开始，每个人都开始陆续进入体育场。那里像往常一样喧闹，成千上万的声音在互相交谈。人们四处走动，但逐渐安顿下来。人群时不时会安静下来。有些人会断定 Factor Man 确实要上台了，他们的谈话就变成了窃窃私语。窃窃私语声传开了。

Some people found their seats early and listened to the bands. Some didn’t. But starting around 5:30, everyone began trickling in to the stadium. There was the usual hubbub, a hundred thousand voices talking amongst each other. People were moving around but gradually settling. Every now and then, the crowd would quiet. Some portion would conclude that Factor Man was actually taking the stage, and their conversation would be reduced to whispers. The whispers would spread.

然后就会有人对去洗手间的最短路线感到困惑，噪音又会再次出现。

And then it would just be some guy confused about the shortest way to the bathroom, and the noise would pick back up.

然后，在 6:07，一个坐在我后面大约十五排的家伙站了起来，开始向球场走去。

And then, at 6:07, a guy about fifteen rows behind me stood up and started making his way down to the field.

我认出了他。

I recognized him.

游戏开始。

Game on.

哈德森

Hudson

下午 5:50

5:50 PM

两名中国女子坐在体育场几乎相反的两侧。我跑向其中一人，原来她是一位陪同家人的老年妇女。其他特工通过耳机呼叫我，告诉我他们已经找到了另一名独自旅行的漂亮女子。我让他们拍下这位客人的照片，然后发短信给我。

The two Chinese women were sitting on nearly opposite sides of the stadium. I raced to one, who turned out to be an elderly woman accompanying her family. Other agents called me over the earbud to tell me that they had reached the other, an attractive woman traveling alone. I had them take a picture of the guest in question and text it to me.

人群突然安静下来。在我右手边的体育场中间，一个人站了起来，朝舞台走去。我从我看过的 Factor Man 真实身份的照片中认出了他。

The crowd suddenly quieted. Halfway around the stadium to my right, someone had stood up and was making his way toward the stage. I recognized him from the pictures I had seen of Factor Man's true identity.

短信发来的图片，我没认出是谁。如果刘女士在观众席中，我们找不到她。

The texted image arrived, and it wasn’t anyone I recognized. If Janet Liu was in the audience, we couldn’t find her.

我权衡了我的选择。

I weighed my options.

我可以取消活动。安全团队在 FCOP 开始前就对此进行了详细讨论，并确定了值得取消的具体条件。但这些条件均未得到满足。我们一致认为，风险和混乱意味着取消活动只是万不得已的手段。

I could cancel the event. The security team had discussed this in considerable detail before FCOP even began, and identified specific conditions that merited cancellation. None of those conditions had been met. We had agreed that both the risk and the sheer turmoil meant that cancellation would only be a response of last resort.

我可以把总统转移到安全的地方。这需要确定具体的威胁，而直觉并不符合要求。

I could have the president removed to a safe location. That required the identification of a specific threat, and a gut feeling didn’t qualify.

我可以让特工包围 Factor Man 并护送他到舞台上，但这似乎没什么用。是的，我们已经知道 Factor Man 的身份超过 24 小时了。是的，我们知道他坐在哪里。

I could have agents surround Factor Man and escort him to the stage, but that seemed unlikely to matter. Yes, we had known Factor Man’s identity for something over 24 hours. Yes, we had known where he was sitting.

但其他人都没有。因此，任何威胁都可能只有在他登台后才会产生效果。

But no one else had. So any threat would likely operate only after he took the stage.

有两件事我似乎可以做，而且似乎很有成效。一是我可以找到最后五位中国嘉宾的座位，二是我可以走到舞台上。最快的方法是绕着体育场内部走一圈，所以我开始这样做，同时询问五位尚未找到的嘉宾的位置。

There were two things I could do that seemed likely to be productive. I could find out where the last five Chinese guests were sitting, and I could make my way to the stage. Fastest would be to go around the inside of the stadium, so I began doing that while asking about the locations of the five not-yet-located guests.

刘

Liu

下午 5:50

5:50 PM

大约三个小时前，李先生给我发短信，说他没能进入体育场。他的票被没收了，但我们的预订是分开进行的，我没有特别的理由相信我们的任务受到了影响。李先生的短信来自一部一次性手机，我们把它留在了租来的车里，以备不时之需。

Li had texted me some three hours previously, indicating that he had failed to gain entry to the stadium. His ticket had been confiscated, but our reservations had been made separately and I had no specific reason to believe that our mission had been compromised. Li’s text had come from a burner phone that we had left in our rental car for just this sort of a contingency.

我自己尽可能早地进入体育场。我不是第一批进入的客人，但在第一支乐队开始演奏后不久就进入了体育场。我在舞台区闲逛了一下，然后坐到了指定的座位上，正如预期的那样，就在舞台前面。我几乎无事可做，只能等待。

I myself entered the stadium as early as appeared to be practical. I was not among the first guests to do so, but entered not long after the first of the bands began playing. I wandered around the stage area before taking my assigned seat, right in front of the stage as expected. I had little to do but wait.

这是美国最奢华的一面。食物。音乐。浪费。

This was America at its opulent worst. The food. The music. The waste.

但我不得不承认，这也是美国最好的一面。无论好坏，这个国家都主宰了 20 世纪，定义了 21 世纪。他们发明了汽车、飞机和电脑。他们粗鲁无礼，但正如从英国到伊斯兰国的所有敌人所发现的那样，他们也是一股不容小觑的力量。

But it was also, I had to concede, America at its best. This was the nation that had, for better or worse, owned the 20th century and defined the 21st. They had invented the car, the airplane, and the computer. They were unmannered and unrefined, but they were also, as every enemy from Britain to ISIS had discovered, a force to be reckoned with.

我曾听说，对美国来说，失败不是一种选择。事实并非如此。对中国来说，失败不是一种选择。

I have heard it said that for America, failure is not an option. That is not true. For China, failure is not an option.

对于美国来说，失败根本不是考虑的事情。

For America, failure is not even a consideration.

我周围有十万个持这种观点的人。我必须承认，这让人感到不安。

I was surrounded by one hundred thousand people who embodied that view. It was, I must confess, unnerving.

我坐在座位上，像个中国人一样，在等待着一场又一场乐队的表演。乐队表演结束后，我继续等待，体育场时而安静下来。

I remained in my seat, looking like a Chinese man simply waiting, through one band performance after another. After the bands were done, I continued waiting as the stadium quieted in fits and starts.

6:07 时，安静变得更加明显。走到半路时，一个人影站了起来。他慢慢地走向场地，最后走向舞台。

At 6:07, the quiet became substantially more pronounced. About halfway up, a single figure had stood. He was gradually making his way down to the field and, eventually, to the stage.

我认出了他。

I recognized him.

是时候了。

It was time.

二十八

28

因子人

Factor Man

下午 6:07

6:07 PM

埃我走向球场时，一切都安静了下来。一开始只是我周围。但很快，寂静笼罩了整个体育场。起初是窃窃私语，然后几乎一片寂静。

Everything got quiet as I headed down to the field. First just around me. But fairly quickly, the silence enveloped the whole stadium. Initially whispers, then almost pure silence.

当我从看台走到球场时，人们看着我。我会微笑，他们也会回以微笑。他们永远不会先微笑。有点奇怪。

People looked at me as I made my way down the stands and to the field. I would smile, and they would smile back. They would never smile first. Kinda weird.

我穿的还是我平时穿的衣服。牛仔裤、运动鞋、白袜子。我通常穿一件纽扣领衬衫，这样我就有口袋可以放手机，但今天，我把手机忘在了酒店房间里。所以我穿了一件 T 恤。

I was wearing what I always wear. Jeans, sneakers, white socks. I normally wear a button-down shirt so that I have a pocket for my phone, but today, I had left my phone in the hotel room. So I got to wear a T-shirt.

我的左手腕上戴着手表，当然还有结婚戒指。右手无名指上戴着我父亲在我大学三年级时去世时继承的钻戒。我希望他会为我感到骄傲。

I had my watch on my left wrist, and, of course, my wedding ring. On my right ring finger was the diamond ring I inherited when my father died during my junior year in college. I hoped he would have been proud of me.

我今年 65 岁了，但由于基因的某些好处，我仍拥有 20-20 的远视力。所以不用戴眼镜。

I’m 65 but, by some generous twist of genetics, still have 20-20 distance vision. So no glasses.

我终于来到了舞台，舞台的四个角落都站着一名面无表情的保安，两边中间也站着一名。舞台本身的布置符合我的要求：十三把椅子排列成正方形的三边，最后一边的中央有一个麦克风架，上面有一个讲台。真的非常简朴。

I finally got to the stage; there was a stone-faced security guard standing at each corner and also one midway along each side. The stage itself had been laid out as I had requested: thirteen chairs arranged in three sides of a square, and a microphone on a stand with a podium at the center of the last side. Pretty Spartan, really.

麦克风前有三层台阶。一名负责安保的警察向我走来；我把打印出来的特别票交给他，他让我走上台阶。

Three steps led up to the mic. One of the police officers providing security came up to me; I gave him the special ticket I had printed out, and he let me head up the steps.

麦克风和讲台的布置使得我发言时，U 形椅子就在我的背后。我从口袋里掏出索引卡，上面写着我的笔记，其实只是一张名字列表。

The mic and podium were arranged so that the U of chairs would be at my back as I spoke. I took the index card out of my pocket on which I had written my notes, which were really just a list of names.

我抬头看着人群。我想知道那里到底是谁。总统，我知道。但我没看到他。我以为大多数好莱坞人都是这样。但这些人在现实生活中看起来从来都不一样。

I looked up at the crowd. I wondered who exactly was out there. The president, I knew that. But I didn’t see him. Most of Hollywood, I expected. But those people never look the same in real life.

与此同时，人群看着我。

The crowd, meanwhile, looked at me.

作为一名商人和科学家，我做过很多演讲。我喜欢在公众面前演讲，尽管这显然是我演讲过的最大的一群人。但我发现在公众面前开始演讲很难。成功演讲的关键是以某种方式与观众建立联系，让他们知道你在和他们说话。但在开始时，这种联系是缺失的。

As a businessman and as a scientist, I’ve given my share of presentations. I like talking in public, although this was obviously far and away the largest group I had ever addressed. But I find it hard to start talking in public. The key to a successful talk is to somehow connect with the audience, to let them know that you’re talking to them. But at the beginning, that connection is missing.

你希望它出现在那里。观众也希望它出现在那里。但直到你开始讲话，它才出现。你首先说的话真的很重要；它会建立联系，否则就不会。

You want it to be there. The audience wants it to be there. But until you start talking, it’s just not there. What you say first really matters; it will establish the connection or it won’t.

我脑子一片空白。

My mind was a blank.

最后，我终于说出了唯一能想到的话。我俯身对着麦克风说：“你好。”

Finally, I said the only thing I could really think of. I leaned over to the mic, and I said, “Hello.”

令人惊讶的是，每个人都笑了。紧张的气氛被打破了。彼此之间有了联系。我笑了。这会很有趣。

Everyone, amazingly enough, laughed. The tension was broken. The connection was there. I smiled. This was going to be fun.

我倾身将麦克风从支架上拿了下来。我说话时必须边走边走。现实生活中有十万人，而电话里只有一个人。如果我要说话，就必须边走边走。

I leaned over and took the mic out of its stand. I can never talk without walking. A crowd of a hundred thousand in real life, or just one other person on the phone. If I’m talking, I have to be walking.

我从讲台后面走出来。

I stepped out from behind the podium.

“晚上好。感谢大家的到来。”

“Good evening. Thank you all for coming.”

哈德森

Hudson

下午 6:12

6:12 PM

当我听 Factor Man 开始演讲时，玫瑰碗的走道和内部空无一人。甚至小卖部也无人看管；每个人都找到了一个可以看到舞台并听着演讲的地方。当我绕着体育场跑的时候，我的耳机响了起来。

The walkway and interior of the Rose Bowl were eerily deserted as I listened to Factor Man begin speaking. Even the concession stands were unattended; everyone had found a place where they could see the stage and listen. As I raced around the stadium, my earbud chimed.

“对不起，”我听到，“客人名单不是这样存储的。我们找到了中国客人，现在我们手动检查了一下，把进来时被搜身的人划掉。我们找到了剩下的五个名字，我可以告诉你具体位置。”

“I’m sorry,” I heard. “The guest list just wasn’t stored that way. We found the Chinese guests, and now we’ve been going through it by hand, crossing out the ones who were frisked when they came in. We’ve got the five names left, and I can give you the locations.”

“去。”

“Go.”

“第15区，第37行。”

“Section 15, row 37.”

“哪里是？”

“Where is that?”

“你在哪里？”

“Where are you?”

我环顾四周。“内部，第 16 区。我正前往中场。”

I looked around. “Interior, section 16. I was heading to midfield.”

“15 号座位在您后面。第 37 排距离跑道约一半。座位号 46。”

“15 is one behind you. Row 37 is about halfway to the field. Seat 46.”

我出发了。大家都还在座位上，所以很快就到了。我耳边告诉他们，46 号座位上坐着一个孩子，他周围围着一个美国家庭。

Off I went. Everyone was still in their seats, so it was quick. I told the people in my ear that seat 46 was occupied by a kid who was surrounded by an American family.

“我知道。交换生。抱歉。”

“I know. Exchange student. Sorry.”

“没什么可道歉的。下一个是谁？”

“Nothing to apologize for. Who’s next?”

“一家三口，在体育场对面。”

“Family of three, across the stadium from you.”

“让别人检查一下。第五个名字？”

“Have someone else check them out. Fifth name?”

“等一下。我正在处理一张纸，它脏了。”

“Hang on. I’m working off a sheet of paper here, and it’s smudged.”

我一边等待，一边回到内部走廊，再次朝中场走去。

I made my way back to the interior corridor as I waited, once again heading toward midfield.

因子人

Factor Man

下午 6:12

6:12 PM

我微笑着说道：“晚上好。感谢大家的光临。”

I smiled. “Good evening,” I began. “Thank you all for coming.”

大家都鼓掌。他们鼓掌，然后起立。

Everyone applauded. They applauded, and they stood.

我甚至还没真正说些什么。但他们明白了。

I hadn’t even really said anything yet. But they got it.

我想，这也是我第一次有这样的感觉。

And for the first time, I think, so did I.

对我来说， P=NP问题一直是纯科学。它一直是个难题，就像我研究过的其他科学问题一样。它已经变成了其他难题，比如如何确保这项技术造福世界，而不会搞乱电子商务和其他一切。比如很久以前在维也纳躲避中国人。比如在事情发展过程中保守我的身份秘密。我在这方面做得并不好。想办法将事物货币化，这样我就可以退休，或者（我真正想要的）回到斯坦福，在年龄超过我真正退休之前再教一段时间。

The P=NP question had been pure science for me. It had been a puzzle, like every other scientific problem I’ve worked on. It had turned into other puzzles, like how to ensure that the technology benefited the world without messing up e-commerce and everything else. Like avoiding the Chinese so long ago in Vienna. Like keeping my identity a secret as things unfolded. I hadn’t done so great at that. Figuring out how to monetize things so that I could retire or (what I really wanted), go back to Stanford and teach a little more before age overtook me and I really did retire.

但这些对玫瑰碗的观众来说都不重要。对他们来说，P=NP意味着几十年来联邦预算首次盈余。这意味着更好的药物和更高效的交通系统。

But none of that mattered to the people in the Rose Bowl. For them, P=NP meant the first federal budget surplus in decades. It meant better drugs, and a more efficient transportation system.

我只见树木不见森林。当然，我知道森林就在那儿。但树木和细节让我不知所措。

I hadn’t seen the forest for the trees. I had known it was there, of course. But the trees, the details, had overwhelmed me.

但这些人，他们眼中只有森林。他们眼中只有技术所能带来的益处。技术已经在做的益处。

But these people, all they saw was the forest. All they saw was the good that the technology could do. That it was already doing.

他们鼓掌了一会儿，这很好，让我有机会弄清楚这一切。可以说，让我赶上自己。

It was good that they applauded for a little while, and gave me a chance to figure all of this out. To catch up with myself, as it were.

我做了一个“冷静”的手势，演讲者在准备讲话时有时会做这个手势。然后大家都坐了下来。

I did the “calm down” gesture that speakers sometimes give when they are ready to talk. Everyone sat back down.

“我知道你们为什么来这里。在我看来，这真的是一场新闻发布会。你们有问题，我想回答。我会一直回答你们的问题，直到他们关灯。但首先，我想说几句话。请你们坐在座位上，直到我有机会说完为止。”

“I know why you’re here. To my mind, this is really a press conference. You have questions, and I want to answer them. I’ll answer them until they turn out the lights. But first, there are some things I’d like to say. Please stay in your seats until I’ve had a chance to say them.”

按照我的要求，人们开始把便携式麦克风拿下来，摆放在过道上。

As I had requested, people began bringing portable microphones down, setting them up in the aisles.

“首先，有许多人帮助我实现了这一切。很抱歉，但在我们继续之前，我真的需要向你们介绍他们。

“First, there are a lot of people who made everything I’ve done possible. And I’m sorry, but before we go on, I really need to introduce them to you.

“第一位是我的妻子丹尼斯。她是我认识的最优秀的人。她拥有超凡的智慧和坚定的信念，令我惊叹不已。她很聪明，而且从不以介词结尾。我们结婚三十多年了，在这三十年里，她每天都是我的榜样。

“Number one is my wife, Denise. She is, quite simply, the finest person I have ever known. She has a transcendent clarity and a profound faith at which I can only marvel. She’s smart, and she doesn’t end sentences with prepositions. We’ve been married for over thirty years, and she’s been a role model to me every day of those thirty years.

“她不仅是我认识的内在最美丽的人，这是最重要的，她也是我认识的外在最美丽的人，作为她的丈夫，这是一种额外的收获。

“And not only is she the most beautiful person I know on the inside, which is the most important, she’s the most beautiful person I know on the outside which, as her husband, is a bonus.

“丹妮丝，我知道你讨厌聚光灯。但就这一次，你能帮我个忙，和我一起上台吗？”

“Denise, I know you hate the spotlight. But just this once, would you do me a favor and join me on stage?”

我等着，看着她从我们的座位上走下来，和我结婚那天一样美丽。观众再次鼓掌并起立。丹妮丝当之无愧。当她上台时，我们拥抱亲吻（掌声更尴尬），然后她坐了下来。

I waited and watched her walk down from our seats, as beautiful as the day I had married her. The crowd applauded and stood again. Denise deserved every bit of it. As she came on stage, we exchanged a hug and a kiss (to more embarrassing applause), and she sat down.

“接下来是我的孩子，纳瓦拉和雷切尔。

“Next, my kids, Navarre and Rachel.

“感谢您容忍了这样一个不完美的父母。我认为没有完美的父母，尽管我们每个人都会努力做到。但我经常认为我的缺点比大多数人都严重，谢谢您，谢谢您容忍这些缺点。

“Thank you for putting up with such an imperfect parent. I expect that there are no perfect parents, try though we all may. But I have often thought that my flaws ran deeper than most, and thank you, thank you for tolerating them.

“我想让你们知道我为你们俩感到多么自豪。你们现在的成就让我惊讶不已。你们俩都很棒。”

“I want you to know how proud I am of both of you. How amazed I am at the man and woman that you have become. You’re both awesome.

“而且，我相信你已经意识到了，今天是有史以来最精彩的 Gizmo 先生的故事。

“And, as I’m sure you realize, today is the best Mr. Gizmo story ever.

“请吧。过来和我一起。”

“Please. Come and join me.”

我等待着，当我的两个可爱的孩子走上舞台时，人群鼓掌。

I waited and the crowd applauded as my two wonderful kids came up to the stage.

“我也想介绍几个你们认识的人。第一个是威廉·伯克特。

“I also want to introduce some people that you know. The first of them is William Burkett.

“我想你们大多数人都知道他是谁。他是《纽约时报》的一名记者，当我意识到我的未来可能会怎样时，他是我第一个联系的人，我试图管理它。

“Most all of you know who he is, I expect. He’s a journalist working for the New York Times and, when I realized what my future was likely to hold, he was the first person I reached out to in an attempt to manage it.

“威尔伯不仅是一名记者，他还是一名优秀的记者。他不仅是一名优秀的记者，他还是一名我信任的优秀记者。

“Not only is Wilbur a journalist, he’s a good journalist. And not only is he a good journalist, he’s a good journalist whom I trust.

“威尔伯，谢谢你的帮助。请上来坐下。”

“Wilbur, thanks for your help. Please come up and take a seat.

掌声渐渐平息后，我继续演讲。几分钟后，威尔伯登上了舞台。

As the applause died down, I continued. Wilbur arrived on stage a few minutes later.

“下一位是杰西·麦克默里。

“Next, Jess MacMurray.

“如果你们今天玩得很开心，那杰西功不可没。我想你们都知道，她安排了今天的活动。她安排了食物和乐队，挑选了场地，基本上把一切都安排好了。她帮我想出了一个匿名参加的方法，把这件事处理好了。每一个细节，从汽车到飞机到酒店到其他一切。她太棒了。

“If you’ve had a good time today, Jess gets the credit. As I expect you all know, she arranged today’s event. She arranged the food, and the bands, and picked the venue, and basically took care of everything. She helped me figure out a way to come anonymously, and took care of that. Every detail, from cars to planes to hotels to everything else. She’s amazing.

“而且你不能再叫她“佩珀·波茨”了。

“And you need to stop calling her Pepper Potts.

“佩珀——对不起，杰西——你能和我们一起吗？”

“Pepper – I’m sorry, Jess – would you be good enough to join us?”

她走过来，拥抱了我一下，然后坐了下来。这是我们俩第一次见面，甚至第一次说话。

She came up, gave me a hug, and sat down. It was the first time that the two of us had ever met, or even spoken.

“最后，我有一名律师。这是美国，所以每个人都有一名律师。我可以毫无保留地告诉你，我的律师很棒。由于鲍勃能够将我的意愿转化为合同，大约价值 2000 亿美元的证券即将转移到我的名下。而且因为鲍勃，我没有欠一分钱的税。直到现在。

“Lastly, I have a lawyer. It’s America, so everyone has a lawyer. I can tell you without qualification that mine is fantastic. Because of Bob’s ability to convert my wishes into a contract, about two hundred billion dollars’ worth of securities are about to transfer into my name. And because of Bob, I haven’t owed a nickel in taxes. Until now.

“我也有朋友。其中两个也是商业伙伴，我真的很幸运这两个人愿意与我分享他们的职业生涯。

“I also have friends. Two are business partners as well, and I am truly blessed that these two guys have been willing to share their professional lives with me.

“大卫·埃瑟林顿和我一起创立了两家公司和一个研究实验室。大卫，希望你和我一样，在过去的二十五年里过得很开心。上来吧。

“David Etherington has founded two companies and a research lab with me. David, I hope you’ve enjoyed the last twenty-five or so years as much as I have. Come on up.

“还有丹尼斯·卡波维拉。你让我的工作每天都充满乐趣和趣味。你每天都关注着工作（和女性）。你让我的工作充满乐趣。请加入我们。

“And Dennis Capovilla. You make my job fun and interesting, every day. You keep your eye on the ball (and on the women), every day. You make coming to work a delight. Please, join us.

“蒂姆·约翰逊，我的牧师，也是我的朋友……”

“Tim Johnson, my pastor and my friend …”

伯克特

Burkett

下午 6:15

6:15 PM

Factor Man 登上舞台开始讲话。我当然认出了他，我和 Emma 先是觉得好笑，然后又觉得很惊讶，听着他的讲话。

Factor Man reached the stage and began talking. I recognized him, of course, and Emma and I listened in amusement first, and amazement second.

“我还想介绍一些你们认识的人，是他们让这一切成为可能。其中第一个是威廉·伯克特。”

“I also want to introduce some people that you know, people who have made all of this possible. The first of them is William Burkett.”

我很好奇家里是否还有另一个威廉·伯克特。艾玛抓住我的肩膀，咧嘴笑着，而 Factor Man 则继续说道。

I wondered if there was another William Burkett in the house. Emma grabbed my shoulder and grinned while Factor Man continued.

“威尔伯，谢谢你的帮助。请上来坐下。”

“Wilbur, thanks for your help. Please come up and take a seat.”

我就这么做了。

And so I did.

我跟着 Factor Man 和他的家人走上舞台，Factor Man 本人和我击掌并快速拥抱。然后我做出了人生中最重要的决定，但绝对是最公开的决定。还剩下十个座位。

I followed the same path Factor Man and his family had taken to the stage, and Factor Man himself and I exchanged a high five and a quick hug. And then I had certainly not the most momentous, but definitely the most public decision of my life. There were ten seats left.

如果我选了一个坐在 Factor Man 家人旁边的座位（他们坐在 Factor Man 身边），我看起来就像一只随波逐流的绵羊。如果我选​​了一个坐在舞台对面的座位，我看起来就像一个愤怒的个人主义记者。

If I picked one next to Factor Man’s family (who had sat as close to Factor Man as possible), I would look like a sheep following the herd. If I picked one across the stage from them, I would look like an angry individualistic reporter.

如果我继续站在那里思考，我会看起来像个呆子。

And if I continued standing there thinking, I would look like a dork.

最终我妥协了，坐在 U 形底座的吧台上，面对 Factor Man 和他身后的观众。

I eventually compromised, sitting on the bar that was the base of the U, facing Factor Man and the audience behind him.

其中一位是亚洲人，坐在剧院里最好的位置，看起来很眼熟。但我记不起他是谁。

One of them, an Asian man with arguably the best seat in the house, looked familiar. But I couldn’t place him.

因子人继续说道。

Factor Man continued.

“还有丹尼斯·卡波维拉。你让我的工作每天都充满乐趣和趣味。你一直关注着事情（和女人）……”

“And Dennis Capovilla. You make my job fun and interesting, every day. You keep your eye on the ball (and on the women) …”

就是这样。舞台对面的中国男人根本不是男人。那是一个女人。事实上，她是奥斯汀咖啡店的那位女士 Janet Liu。无论在哪里我都能认出她的颧骨。

That was it. The Chinese man across the stage from me wasn’t a man at all. It was a woman. In fact, it was Janet Liu, the woman from the coffee shop in Austin. I would recognize those cheekbones anywhere.

我不知道该怎么办。

I had no idea what to do.

我可以大吵大闹。我可以跳起来解释说，舞台对面的那个人实际上是美国联邦调查局通缉的一名中国女性，尽管我不知道他为什么被通缉。

I could make a scene. I could jump up and explain that the guy across the stage from me was in fact a Chinese woman wanted by the FBI, although I had no idea what for.

我不知道结果会怎样，但我怀疑这可能不是我最好的选择。

I didn’t know how that would work out, but I suspected that it was probably not my best option.

或者，我可以打电话给约翰哈德森。

Or, I could call John Hudson.

这样似乎可能更好。

That seemed like it was probably better.

有十万人花了大价钱来观看 Factor Man 的演讲。这十万人也正在观看台上的我们七个人。

A hundred thousand people had paid a ton of money each to watch Factor Man say what he was currently saying. Those hundred thousand people were also watching the seven of us now on stage.

他们每个人都会看到我从口袋里掏出手机打电话。

Every single one of them would see me take my cell phone out of my pocket and make a call.

Emma 已经让我对手机的依赖程度感到很痛苦，她还会让我打电话。不管是否合理，她都会在余生里责骂我。

Emma, who already gave me plenty of grief about the extent to which I was welded to my phone, would also see me make a call. Justified or otherwise, she would ride me about it for the rest of our days.

我拿出电话拨号。

I took out the phone and dialed.

因子人

Factor Man

下午 6:18

6:18 PM

当丹尼斯走上舞台时，我继续说道。

As Dennis made his way to the stage, I continued.

“蒂姆·约翰逊，我的牧师，我的朋友。也是我认识的最乐观的人。他一生的目标是经营一个真正欢迎所有人的教堂。从最正直的公民——我要指出，不是我——到街头流浪汉。一个不歧视任何人、不评判任何人的教堂，真正是上帝的旨意。蒂姆，上来吧。

“Tim Johnson, my pastor and my friend. Also the most flagrantly optimistic man I have ever known. A man whose goal in life is to run a church that truly welcomes everyone. From the most upstanding citizen – not me, I point out – to the street bum. A church that discriminates against no one, judges no one, and truly is what God intended. Tim, come on up.

“布莱恩·芬恩。我一生中创办了四家公司，包括 Factor Man，而你实际上投资了所有这些公司。我认为可以说你是我认识的最善良、最聪明的人之一。多年来，我多次向你寻求建议和意见，你从未让我失望过。

“Brian Finn. I’ve started four businesses in my life, including this Factor Man stuff, and you’ve actually invested in all of them. I think it’s fair to say that you are one of the kindest, wisest people I know. I’ve turned to you many times over the years for counsel and advice, and you have never disappointed.

“还有三个人对我的成长做出了巨大的贡献，尽管我从未见过他们中的任何一个。

“There are three more people who have contributed profoundly to who I am, even though I’ve never met any of them.

“马克·库班。我创办的四家公司中，马克参与了两家。一旦他认为你不是傻瓜，他就会乐于助人，而且他非常聪明。直到他认为你不是傻瓜，他才不那么聪明。我很高兴他对我印象很好，尽管还没有好到接受我提出的我们一起喝一杯的各种建议。马克，我希望你在这里，也许那杯酒现在终于能解决一切问题了。

“Mark Cuban. Of my four ventures, Mark has been involved with two. Once he decides you aren’t an idiot, he’s helpful, and he’s very smart. Until he decides you aren’t an idiot, not quite so much. I’m glad he thinks well of me, although not well enough to accept any of my various suggestions that we get together for a drink. Mark, I hope you’re here, and maybe that drink will work out now after all.

“凯特·杰克逊。1976 年，凯特是《霹雳娇娃》的最初成员之一，而我是加州理工学院的物理学研究生。我当时非常难过，就给她写了一封粉丝信。

“Kate Jackson. In 1976, Kate was one of the original Charlie’s Angels, and I was a graduate student in physics at Cal Tech. I was absolutely miserable, and I wrote her a fan letter.

“她回信说。

“She wrote back.

“凯特，那封信救了我的命。我无法告诉你，对于我来说，你的信有多少次是埃雅仁迪尔之光，当其他所有灯都熄灭时，它照亮了黑暗的地方。它确实做到了。它救了我的命，我仍然保留着它。谢谢你。

“Kate, that letter saved my life. I can’t tell you how many times your note was, for me, the light of Eärendil, a light in dark places when all other lights had gone out. It really did. It saved my life, and I still have it. Thank you.

“再来一个。小罗伯特·唐尼饰演的钢铁侠。你向世界展示了一个疯狂的科学家也可以有灵魂，可以有所作为，而且可以乐在其中。你对钢铁侠的演绎，从很多方面来说，都是《钢铁侠》项目的起源。

“One more. Robert Downey, Jr. Iron Man. You showed the world that a mad scientist could have a soul, make a difference, and have a blast doing it. Your portrayal of Iron Man was, in many ways, the genesis of the project that became Factor Man.

“我不知道你是否在这里，但我希望你在，也希望你能和我们一起上台。”

“I have no idea if you’re here, but I hope you are, and I hope you’ll join the rest of us on stage.”

唐尼确实出席了。我们拥抱了一下，他向人群挥手致意，然后坐到了最后一把椅子上。

Downey was indeed in attendance. We exchanged a hug and he waved to the crowd before taking the last chair.

“这就是我要说的全部内容。我知道你有很多问题，我来回答这些问题。你的两个问题我已经知道了。

“That’s all of my stuff. I know you’ve got a lot of questions, and I’m here to answer them. Two of your questions I already know.

“第一的 …”

“First …”

然后最奇怪的事情发生了。威廉·伯克特袭击了我。

And then the strangest thing happened. William Burkett attacked me.

二十九

29

哈德森

Hudson

下午 6:18

6:18 PM

米我的手机响了，我看了看屏幕。令我大吃一惊的是，我的好朋友威廉·伯克特打来了电话。我一边在体育场里奔波，一边寻找最快的上台路线。“哈德森。”

My cell phone buzzed, and I looked at the display. My pal William Burkett, to my great surprise. I answered it as I hustled around the stadium to find the quickest way to the stage. “Hudson.”

“约翰。我是威廉·伯克特。”

“John. It’s William Burkett.”

过去几分钟我还没看过舞台，但我知道伯克特已经被叫上场了。“威廉？你在跟我开玩笑吗？”

I hadn’t seen the stage in the past few minutes, but I knew Burkett had been called up. “William? Are you kidding me?”

“约翰，听着。不，我不是在跟你开玩笑。刘小姐就坐在观众席第一排。”

“John, listen. No, I’m not kidding you. Janet Liu is in the first row of the audience.”

事情开始变得明朗起来。我问伯克特是否确定，但我已经知道答案了。

Things began to make sense. I asked Burkett if he was sure, but I already knew the answer.

“当然可以吗？不。不过前排有个男生的五官和她一模一样。”

“Sure sure? No. But there’s a guy in the front row who absolutely shares her facial features.”

我告诉他我正在路上，并请他尽量不要做傻事。然后我的耳机响了，我断开连接去听。

I told him I was on my way down and asked that he try not to do anything stupid. Then my earbud chimed, and I disconnected to listen.

“长官，我们找到他了。马永锋。F-19 区，第一排。”

“We found him, sir. Ma Yong Feng. Section F-19, row 1.”

“那到底是哪里？”

“Where is that exactly?”

“我正在看座位图，先生。没有 F-19 区。”

“I’m looking at a seating map, sir. There is no section F-19.”

我想了一会儿。“是田野。F 代表田野。第 19 节在哪儿？”

I thought for a moment. “It’s the field. The F stands for field. Where is section 19?”

“就在你那边。就在中间。”

“It’s on the side you’re on. Right in the middle.”

“冯先生通过安检了吗？”

“Did Feng pass through security?”

“是的，先生。我们不能保留这些图像，但我认为这是一个干净的扫描件。”

“Yes, sir. We aren’t allowed to keep the images, but I’m seeing it as a clean scan.”

我松了一口气。这意味着没有武器。假设冯实际上是 Janet Liu，她不可能通过安检拿到任何东西。考虑到玫瑰碗赛前的严格审查，我无法想象她到达后还能拿到一件藏匿的武器。

I breathed a little easier. That meant no weapon. Assuming that Feng was in fact Janet Liu, there was no way she could have gotten anything through security. And given the pre-event scrutiny the Rose Bowl had seen, I couldn’t imagine that she could have retrieved a cached weapon after arriving.

“好的，”我最后说道，“首先，打电话给特勤局。告诉他们，我相信前排面对舞台的地方有一名中国特工。”我不认为总统会受到任何可能的威胁，但特勤局仍然需要得到通知。

“Okay,” I finally said. “First, call the service. Let them know that I believe we have a Chinese operative in the front row facing the stage.” I didn’t think there was any possible threat to the president, but the Secret Service still needed to be alerted.

台上已经围满了特工，他们接受过专门应对此类突发事件的训练。“假设扫描结果没有问题，”我继续说道，“我想我们没事了。我们尽量不要在国际电视上制造联邦调查局和中国公民之间的闹剧。我现在就去那里。”

The stage was already surrounded by agents who had been trained for exactly this sort of eventuality. “Assuming the scan was clean,” I continued, “I think we’re ok. Let’s try not to create a scene involving the FBI and a Chinese citizen on international television. I’m on my way down there now.”

刘

Liu

下午 6:18

6:18 PM

我亲眼目睹了这位自称“因素人”的恐怖分子登上舞台。

I had watched the terrorist who called himself Factor Man take the stage.

“恐怖分子”是唯一正确的词。中国存在了几千年。它的历史早于基督。在那段时间里，它在艺术、科学和文化方面引领世界。它的人民繁荣昌盛。我们社会的结构性是所有这些成就的根源。

“Terrorist” is the only correct word. China has existed for millennia. It predates Christ. And in that time, it has led the world in arts, in science, in culture. Its people have prospered. The structured nature of our society has been the root of all of those accomplishments.

Factor Man 的技术使这一结构陷入危险。它使我们的生活方式陷入危险。Factor Man 本质上是通过武力做到这一点的，它违背了我们的意愿，也没有征求我们的意见。

Factor Man’s technology puts that structure in jeopardy. It puts our very way of life in jeopardy. And Factor Man does this essentially by force, against our wishes and without consulting us.

他是一名恐怖分子。

He is a terrorist.

我听了他准备好的发言，听到人群因为他的笑话而大笑。

I listened to his prepared remarks. I heard the crowd laugh at his apparent jokes.

然后我等待着。

And I waited.

我认出了他。我在维也纳认出了他，在之前两次试图破坏他的计划之前，通过视频确认了他的身份。

I recognized him. I recognized him from Vienna, and from the video that had confirmed his identity before the two previous attempts to disrupt his plans.

头发花白，看上去比实际年龄年轻。两人一步一步走上舞台，站得笔直。高兴又兴奋。

Grey hair. Looking younger than his reported age. Taking the steps onto the stage two at a time, standing straight. Happy and excited.

恐怖分子通常都是这样的。

Terrorists usually are.

我从包里拿出枪，放在膝盖上，被包盖住。我有两枪。

I withdrew the gun from my bag and placed it on my lap, covered by the bag itself. I had two shots.

活动的安全措施比我想象的要好。八名武装警员包围了 Factor Man 演讲的舞台。我看着这八个人的眼睛，他们的眼睛一动不动。他们都训练有素，注意力集中。

Security at the event had been better than I expected. Eight armed officers surrounded the stage from which Factor Man was speaking. I watched the eyes of the eight, and they never stopped moving. They were all well-trained and attentive.

我坐在舞台一侧的前排座位上，我们原本以为李会坐在我对面，手里拿着他自己的 3D 枪，而我现在拿着这把枪。如果我们其中一人拔出武器，这种分散注意力的方式会帮助另一个人。但李已经被安保人员抓走了。

I was in a front row seat on one side of the stage, and we had anticipated that Li would be seated across from me, armed with his own version of the 3-D gun that I now held. If one of us had drawn a weapon, the distraction would have helped the other. But Li had been caught up in security.

我等着 Factor Man 继续喋喋不休地讲下去。我所要做的就是确保在他宣布他想要说的话之前阻止他。他似乎太忙于谈论自己了，以至于无法马上宣布这件事。

I waited as Factor Man droned on. All I needed to do was to ensure that I stopped him before he made whatever announcement he intended. He seemed far too busy talking about himself for such an announcement to be imminent.

于是我等待。

So I waited.

然后，机会出现了。一名工作人员在舞台周围安装供观众使用的麦克风时绊倒了。他稍微偏向我的右侧，所有能看到我的保安人员都一时分心了。

And then, an opportunity presented itself. One of the workers setting up the microphones to be used by the audience around the stage stumbled. He was slightly to my right, and all of the security guards who could see me were momentarily distracted.

我搬开背包，站起来，举起枪，开了两枪。

I moved the man bag, stood as I raised my gun, and fired my two shots.

三十

30

伯克特

Burkett

下午 6:21

6:21 PM

西当我上高中一年级时，我个子矮小，跑得又慢。高中里跑得快的孩子即使倒着跑也能跑得比我快。

When I was a freshman in high school, I was small and I was slow. The fast kids in high school could outrun me running backwards.

所以我加入了足球队。

So I joined the football team.

我现在知道这毫无意义。但如果你仔细想想，你会发现你在高中时做出的许多决定都没有意义。这个特定的选择既不是我高中时代最好的，也不是最糟糕的。

I know now that this made no sense. But if you think about it, not many of the decisions you make in high school do make sense. This particular choice was neither the best nor the worst of my high school years.

如果你个子小，速度快，你既可以当跑卫，也可以当接球手。这取决于你的手是否好。我的手很差，与我的其他身体素质不相称。但那位一向乐观的新生教练让我尝试了两个位置，结果却是一场灾难。

If you’re small and fast, you can be either a running back or a pass receiver. Sort of depends on whether you’ve got good hands. I had lousy hands, to match the rest of my physical abilities. But the freshman coach, ever the optimist, tried me in both positions, and it was a disaster.

如果你体型高大但速度慢，他们就让你当边锋。克莱默教练也试过这么做。

If you’re slow but large, they make you a lineman. Coach Kramer tried that, too.

结果稍微好一点。我是一名防守前锋，应该跟进比赛并做一些有用的事情。

The results were marginally better. I was the defensive lineman who was supposed to follow the play and do something useful.

大多数时候，“有用”意味着被身材高大的进攻线队员击倒。但偶尔，进攻线队员会采取看似谨慎的做法，无视我，转而选择身材高大的对手，结果让每个人都感到惊讶，我实际上可以打出相当不错的击球。

Most of the time, “useful” turned out to mean getting knocked on my butt by a much larger offensive lineman. But every once in a while, the offensive linemen would take the apparently prudent course of ignoring me in favor of my larger counterparts, and it turned out, to everyone’s surprise, that I could actually make a pretty good hit.

到我大二毕业进入 JV 时，跑卫的体格已经壮大，我甚至连这种可能性都失去了。我放弃了橄榄球，加入了新闻社。你知道这会带来什么结果。

By the time I graduated to JV in my sophomore year, the running backs were bigger and even that possibility deserted me. I gave up football and joined the journalism club. You know where that led.

我马上就回复这一切。

I’ll get back to all of this in a moment.

哈德森告诉我不要做傻事，然后挂了电话。我觉得这是个好建议。

Hudson told me not to do anything stupid, and hung up. I figured that was good advice.

舞台渐渐坐满了人。Factor Man 的特别嘉宾名单上最后一位是小罗伯特·唐尼，我觉得这是个很可爱的举动。

The stage gradually filled up. Last on Factor Man’s list of special guests was Robert Downey, Jr., which I thought was a cute touch.

我越是观察那个我怀疑是 Janet Liu 的人，就越是确信。她——当然，假设她真的是她——一动不动。一只手放在膝盖上，一只手放在一个男士小包上，一只手放在包下。一动不动。我环顾了一下其他前排观众；他们一般都很安静，但肯定坐立不安的程度与你预料的差不多。在椅子上重新调整位置，你有什么可说的。刘一动不动。

The more I watched the person I suspected of being Janet Liu, the more convinced I became. She – assuming, of course, that it actually was a she – was too still. Hands in lap, one on top of a small man bag and one underneath it. Never moving. I glanced around at some of the other front row audience members; they were generally still but certainly fidgeting about the amount you’d expect. Repositioning in their chairs, what have you. Liu never budged.

工作人员在体育场四周设置了麦克风，以便人们提问。有数百个。我没有理会他们，只是看着一动不动的刘翔。

The staff was setting up mics all around the stadium so that people could ask their questions. Hundreds of them. I ignored them, just watching the unmoving Liu.

然后，突然间，她动了起来。时间停止了。

Then, all of a sudden, she was moving. Time stopped.

我向后听了听，你知道怎么做的，然后意识到刘的右边，也就是我的左边，有点骚动。

I listened backward, you know how you can do that, and realized that there had been a little bit of a commotion off to Liu’s right, my left.

刘女士的男式包动了。包下，她的另一只手拿着一个东西，看上去——不可能——像一把枪。

Liu’s man bag moved. Under it, her other hand was holding what looked – no way – like a gun of some sort.

Factor Man 继续说着。“我知道你有很多问题……”他在舞台上走来走去，最后离我只有几英尺远。

Factor Man kept talking. “I know you’ve got a lot of questions …” His wandering around the stage had brought him to just a few feet in front of me.

刘先生站了起来。拿着枪的手开始举起来。

Liu stood. The hand with gun began to come up.

我按照所受的训练去做了。

And I did what I had been trained to do.

我解决了 Factor Man 的问题。

I tackled Factor Man.

哈德森

Hudson

下午 6:21

6:21 PM

我继续向舞台跑去，我唯一的武器是政府配发的格洛克 23 式手枪。我意识到，在拥挤的体育场里，这绝对不是最佳武器。

I continued racing toward the stage, my only weapon a government-issued Glock 23. Absolutely not the weapon of choice in a crowded stadium, I realized.

当我经过一个拿着几个麦克风的人时，我拦住了他。我向他展示了我的警徽。“FBI，”我说。“我需要麦克风。”他感到很困惑，耸耸肩，把麦克风递给了我，然后又走回去拿了几个。

As I was passing one of the guys bringing a couple of mics down, I stopped him. I showed him my badge. “FBI,” I said. “I need the mics.” Puzzled, he shrugged and gave them to me, then headed back up to get a couple more.

我拿着麦克风走向舞台，但距离我还是太远了。随着座位坐满，人们不断被邀请上台。马克·库班。凯特·杰克逊，一位上了年纪但举止庄重的女人，花了一段时间才登上舞台。

I carried the mics toward the stage, still far too distant for my liking. People kept getting invited up as the chairs filled. Mark Cuban. Kate Jackson, an elderly but stately woman who took a while to make it up to the stage.

还剩两个座位。我离舞台很近，可以在台上的人群中认出伯克特。

Two seats left. I was close enough to pick out Burkett among the people seated on stage.

小罗伯特·唐尼。当我走到中间过道时，他正好坐下。

Robert Downey, Jr. He was just sitting down as I came up the center aisle.

是的，前排有一个中国人。一个短发的人，肯定是男装。

Yes, there was a Chinese national in the front row. An individual with short hair, definitely dressed as a man.

想象刘海儿留短发的样子比想象她留短发的样子更容易。没错，她就是这个样子。

It was easier to picture Liu with short hair than the other way around. Yes, that was what she would look like.

那个中国男人也完全不对劲。如果你当经纪人的时间够长，你就会体会到这一点。他太安静了，不知为何，似乎在等待。

The Chinese man was also just wrong. If you’re an agent for long enough, you get a feel for it. He was too still, somehow waiting.

我放下随身携带的两个麦克风中的一个，试图分散他的注意力。他看了我一眼，但没再看下去。

I dropped one of the two mics I was carrying, trying to distract him. He glanced at me, but no more.

这似乎有点不自然。附近的其他观众都转过头来看我。舞台周围的保安也转过头来看我。她以为那位中国“男子”确实是刘，所以只是看了一眼。

It seemed unnatural. All of the other nearby audience members had turned to look at me. The security guards around the stage had turned to look at me. Assuming that the Chinese “man” was indeed Liu, she had done nothing more than glance.

我开始加快速度朝她走去。我随身携带的麦克风和支架效果还不错，但格洛克手枪速度更快，制止力也更强。它还会成倍增加人群的风险，我猜麦克风支架足以抵挡刘设法通过安检的武器——可能是刀子或其他手持武器。

I began moving toward her more quickly. The mic and stand that I was still carrying would be reasonably effective, but the Glock would be faster and obviously had more stopping power. It would also magnify the risk for the crowd exponentially, and my guess was that the mic stand would be plenty against whatever Liu had managed to get through security – presumably a knife or other hand weapon.

于是我把格洛克手枪留在枪套里，把麦克风和支架放在身边，以扩大我的触及范围。 Factor Man 背对着我们两人讲话，面对着 Burkett，刘在他身后。他似乎甚至不知道发生了什么。

So I left my Glock in its holster, and I brought the mic and stand to my side to extend my reach. Factor Man was speaking with his back to both of us, facing Burkett and with Liu behind him. He didn’t even appear to be aware of what was going on.

然后，令我沮丧的是，刘站起来举起了一把看起来像枪的东西。伯克特从椅子上跳起来，把 Factor Man 摔倒在地。我挥舞着麦克风，刘开了两枪。

Then, to my dismay, Liu stood and raised what appeared to be a gun. Burkett leaped from his chair and tackled Factor Man to the ground. I swung the mic as Liu took two shots.

因子人

Factor Man

下午 6:27

6:27 PM

我说：“这就是我要说的全部内容。我知道你有很多问题，我来回答这些问题。你的两个问题我已经知道了。

I said, “That’s all of my stuff. I know you’ve got a lot of questions, and I’m here to answer them. Two of your questions I already know.

“第一的 …”

“First …”

然后，威廉·伯克特 (William Burkett) 把我打倒在地，我听到身后传来两声枪响。

And then William Burkett knocked me to the ground as I heard what appeared to be two gunshots behind me.

我不知道发生了什么。不知道丹尼斯是否中枪了，或者孩子们是否中枪了。

I had no idea what had happened. If Denise had been shot, or the kids.

过了很久，伯克特才从我身上下来，我有些尴尬地在他身后站起来。他举起双手，做了一个“和平”的手势，说：“对不起。”

An eternity passed until Burkett got off me and I scrambled somewhat awkwardly to my feet behind him. He held up his hands in a sort of “peace” gesture, and said, “Sorry.”

我不在乎。我把威尔伯推到一边，跑向我的家人，触摸他们每个人，确认他们都安然无恙。当安保人员跳上舞台，要求所有人留在座位上时，他们相当怀疑地看着我。一名男子似乎挥舞着麦克风支架作为武器，他出示了联邦调查局证件，安保人员向后退去。他对着特勤局戴的耳机说：“不，我想我们没事。我把子弹挡在地上。看来只有一名演员。舞台上没有伤亡。”

I didn’t care. I pushed Wilbur aside and ran to my family, touching each of them and confirming that they were all ok. They looked at me fairly incredulously as security agents jumped onto the stage and asked everyone to stay in their seats. A man who appeared to have been wielding one of the microphone stands as a weapon produced FBI credentials and security backed away from him. He spoke into one of those earpiece headphones like the Secret Service wears, saying, “No, I think we’re good. I deflected the shots into the ground. It appears to have been a sole actor. No casualties on the stage.”

保安给一名中国男子戴上了手铐。我记得他；他当时坐在前排，一动不动。他拿出了一本外交护照，但联邦调查局特工只是接过它，看了看，然后递给了一名同事。“刘女士，这是给一名男士的护照。你希望这有多尴尬？”反对声停止了，那名中国男子（女子？）被带走了，手腕被反绑在身后。

Security handcuffed a Chinese man. I remembered him; he had been in the front row, sitting very still. He produced a diplomatic passport, but the FBI agent simply took it, looked at it and handed it to an associate. “This passport is for a man, Ms. Liu. How embarrassing would you like this to be?” The objections stopped and the Chinese man (woman?) was led away, wrists behind his or her back.

探员走到我面前，和我握手。他自我介绍道：“FBI 特工约翰·哈德森。”

The agent came up to me and shook my hand. He introduced himself. “Special Agent John Hudson, FBI.”

我正要回头介绍，但突然忍不住笑了。“Factor Man，”我回答道。

I started to return the introduction, but caught myself and smiled. “Factor Man,” I responded.

哈德森把手放在我的肩膀上，安慰我，同时看着台上其他人周围的经纪人。他们互相点点头。“帮我个忙，”他说。“我们搞定了。我们做到了。你能做的最大的帮助就是从你上次停下的地方继续。让我们尽可能控制住整个事情。”

Hudson put his hand on my shoulder reassuringly as he looked at the agents surrounding everyone else on stage. They nodded at each other. “Do me a favor,” he said. “We’ve got this. We do. The biggest thing you can do to help is pick up right where you left off. Let’s keep this whole thing as contained as possible.”

我环顾四周。哈德森说得对。伯克特在台上把我抱住时，观众们一下子站了起来，现在他们变得越来越焦躁不安。

I looked around. Hudson was right. The crowd had leaped to their collective feet when Burkett had tackled me onstage, and they were now growing increasingly restless.

我让伯克特回到座位，他照做了。我告诉哈德森，“等一下”，然后和家人确认了一下。瑞秋向我点点头；她没事。纳瓦拉只是耸了耸肩。我的依靠丹妮丝微笑着说，演出还得继续。

I asked Burkett to return to his seat, and he did. I told Hudson, “In a minute,” and checked in with my family. Rachel nodded at me; she was fine. Navarre just shrugged. Denise, my rock, smiled and said that the show had to go on.

我转身面向人群，拿起麦克风，这时他们安静下来，慢慢坐下。“好的，”我说。“也许我知道你们三个问题。别担心；我会有时间回答所有我不知道的问题。

I turned back to the crowd and picked up the microphone as they quieted and slowly sat down. “OK,” I said. “Maybe I know three of your questions. Don’t worry; there’ll be time for all the ones I don’t know, too.

“首先，我不知道那是怎么回事。我们大概会在明天的报纸上一起找出答案。

“First, I have no idea what that was about. We’ll presumably find out together in tomorrow’s paper.

“第二，苹果 CEO 的密码是‘Rainbeau’。大写 R，a，i，n，b，e，a，u。这真的挺贴心的。你可以用它来解密我三月份发布的代码。它的形式和我给苹果和政府的完全一样。能力越大，责任越大，所以好好利用它吧。

“Second. The Apple CEO’s password is ‘Rainbeau.’ Capital-R, a, i, n, b, e, a, u. It’s kind of sweet, really. You can use that to decrypt the code I posted back in March. It’ll be in exactly the same form as what I gave to Apple and to the government. With great power comes great responsibility, so use it well.

“还有最后一件事。

“And one last thing.

“我的名字是蒙哥马利·格莱姆斯 (Montgomery Grimes)，我是 Factor Man。”

“My name is Montgomery Grimes, and I am Factor Man.”

结语

Epilogue

伯克特

Burkett

我最后，有些事情正如大家所预料的那样，有些则不然。

In the end, some things came out like everyone had expected and some didn’t.

电子商务最终还是成功了。信用卡公司安排每笔交易使用不同的卡号，当你把卡号发送给电子零售商时，他们解码卡号的速度比 Factor Man 的代码分解公钥的速度还快。因此交易顺利完成，卡号再也无法使用。

E-commerce turned out to be just fine. The credit card companies arranged for every transaction to use a different card number, and when you sent that number to an e-tailer, they could decode the number faster than Factor Man’s code could factor the public key. So the transaction went through and the card number could never be used again.

然而，秘密确实已经成为过去。不再有匿名博主。不再有匿名评论他人博客。世界似乎因此变得更美好。如果你想保守秘密，你只需将其写在一张纸上并发送出去。

Secrets, however, did become something of a thing of the past. There were no more anonymous bloggers. No anonymous comments on other people’s blogs. The world seemed a better place for it. If you wanted to keep a message a secret, you had to just write it down on a piece of paper and send it.

中国依然是中国，其人民和制度比其领导层意识到的还要稳定。

China remained China, her people and institutions far more stable than even her leadership had realized.

拥有 2000 亿美元可以改变你的生活，但显然比你想象的要少得多。Factor Man 经常接受采访，并评论说他仍然买不到幸福，但有 Denise 在他身边，他真的不需要购买幸福。他更感兴趣的是购买青春，但这也不是可以出售的。大部分钱都捐给了慈善机构。

Having $200 billion changes your life, but apparently much less than you’d imagine. Factor Man was interviewed often, and commented that he still couldn’t buy happiness, but with Denise at his side, that was a purchase he really didn’t need to make. He was more interested in buying youth, but that didn’t turn out to be for sale, either. Most of the money just went to charity.

他在斯坦福大学获得了教职。

He got that faculty job at Stanford.

就技术本身而言，最重要的用途是纳米技术。与药物设计类似，纳米技术涉及有限数量的基本操作，可用于制造各种形状的微观物体。给定目标形状，Factor Man 技术可用于确定生产它所需的步骤。计算机变得更小；没有人需要比手机更大的东西了。纳米粒子将药物输送到肿瘤，很明显，癌症很快就会成为过去。事实证明，Factor Man 在第一篇博客文章中说得对：人们更健康了，我们中最贫穷的人也不再那么贫穷，他的技术带来的效率影响了我们每个人的生活。

As far as the technology itself, the most important use turned out to be nanotech. Not unlike drug design, nanotech involved a limited number of basic operations that could be used to make microscopic objects in a variety of shapes. Given a target shape, the Factor Man technology could be used to identify the steps needed to produce it. Computers became smaller; no one needed anything bigger than a cell phone any more. Nanoparticles delivered drugs to tumors, and it was clear that cancer would soon be a thing of the past. It turned out that Factor Man had been right in that very first blog post: People were healthier, the poorest among us were significantly less poor, and the efficiencies offered by his technology touched the lives of each of us.

我和 Emma 按照计划举行了婚礼，FCOP 结束后很长一段时间，媒体几乎都不再关注我们了。我们将 Factor Man 添加到了宾客名单中，但他拒绝了，说他担心他的出现会让婚礼更多地围绕他而不是围绕我们。

Emma and I got married on schedule, long enough after FCOP that the press pretty much left us alone. We added Factor Man to the guest list but he passed, saying he was afraid his presence would make the wedding more about him than about us.

然后他还是出现了。事实证明，隐私是金钱能买到的少数东西之一。仪式开始时，他和丹妮丝只是出现在会众的后面。他们的结婚礼物是一张镶框的《带我去看球赛》，以及两张 1908 年小熊队比赛的门票，这首歌就是在那场比赛中推出的。

And then he showed up anyway. It turns out privacy is one of the few things money actually can buy. He and Denise simply appeared in the back of the congregation as the ceremony was beginning. Their wedding gift was a framed copy of “Take Me Out to the Ballgame,” along with a pair of tickets to the 1908 Cubs game where the song was introduced.

艾玛和我保住了我们的工作，因为世界仍然需要调查记者。

Emma and I kept our jobs, because the world continued to need investigative reporters.

和文学经纪人。

And literary agents.

虚构与非虚构，永远在一起。

Fiction and non-fiction, together forever.

结束

THE END

致谢

Acknowledgments

威廉·伯克特和艾玛·哈达威是虚构的，但这本书中其他人几乎都是真实的。好吧，好人是真实的。坏人也几乎是虚构的。

William Burkett and Emma Hardaway are made up, but pretty much everyone else in this book is real. Well, the good people are real. The bad guys are pretty much made up, too.

对于那些允许我使用他们的名字和肖像的人们，我深表感谢。我尽力描绘你们每个人的真实面目，所以如果我有错误，请原谅我。

To these folks who have been kind enough to let me use their names and likenesses, my thanks. I’ve tried to paint each of you as you really are, so please forgive me if I’ve gotten something wrong.

有些人没有入选编辑名单；正如我的读者一直告诉我的那样，FCOP 不是奥斯卡颁奖典礼。Stuart Meyer、Larry Gordon、Mike Genesereth、Ethan Coven 和 Dana Delany：我认为你们所有人都很棒。但可以说 Factor Man 舞台上的椅子已经太多了。

Some folks didn’t make the editorial cut; as my readers kept telling me, FCOP was not the Academy Awards. Stuart Meyer, Larry Gordon, Mike Genesereth, Ethan Coven and Dana Delany: I think the world of all of you. But there were already arguably too many chairs on the Factor Man stage.

Scott Aaronson 和 Steven Rudich：我很高兴这本书加强了我和你们每个人的关系。我始终尽最大努力保持科学的准确性。我知道书中有些地方有妥协，但这种情况并不常见，也不会影响读者对复杂性理论、计算机科学以及P与NP问题的整体印象。

Scott Aaronson and Steven Rudich: I am pleased that this book has strengthened my relationship with each of you. I’ve done my best throughout to keep the science accurate. I know that there are compromises here and there, but they are infrequent and should not detract from the overall impression a reader will get of complexity theory, computer science, and the P vs. NP question generally.

大致就像蒙哥马利·格莱姆斯在书的开头所给出的理由一样，我确实相信P=NP。蒙哥马利·格莱姆斯本身是我在卫斯理大学读本科期间在一个神秘广播节目中使用的化名。

For roughly the reasons given by Montgomery Grimes at the beginning of the book, I really do believe that P=NP. Montgomery Grimes itself was an alias I used for a mystery radio show during my undergraduate days at Wesleyan University.

约翰·哈德森是以一位 FBI 探员为原型的，我认识他很多年了，但他要求我不要透露他的真实姓氏。约翰，谢谢你阅读了《Factor Man》的早期版本，并给了我深刻的评论。

John Hudson is modeled after an FBI agent whom I’ve known for many years but who asked that I not use his real last name. John, thanks for reading an early version of Factor Man and for giving me your insightful comments.

艾米·罗杰斯 (Amy Rogers) 的名字只出现在致谢部分，但她参与了每一页。艾米，非常感谢你和 ScienceThrillers Media。朱利安·格林 (Julian Green) 也提供了许多有用的编辑建议。

Amy Rogers’s name appears only here in the acknowledgments, but she has touched every page. Amy, many thanks to both you and to ScienceThrillers Media. Julian Green also provided many useful editorial suggestions.

有些确实出现的人却被冷落了。丹尼斯·卡波维拉一直抱怨自己戏份太少；我猜引发一系列拯救世界的事件还不够好。

Some people who do appear are given somewhat short shrift. Dennis Capovilla has complained incessantly about the fact that he doesn’t have a larger part; I guess that triggering the chain of events that saves the world isn’t good enough.

正如我在玫瑰碗舞台上所解释的那样，我的孩子们很棒。我的女儿斯凯拉要求我不要用她的真名，我答应了。我的儿子也要求我不要用他的真名，说他更喜欢被称为“威震天：世界毁灭者”。我觉得我不能满足这个要求。很抱歉，纳瓦拉。

As I explained from the Rose Bowl stage, my children are awesome. My daughter Skyelar asked that I not use her real name, and I obliged. My son asked that I not use his real name, either, saying that he preferred to be called “Megatron: Destroyer of Worlds.” That was not a request that I felt I could honor. Sorry about that, Navarre.

我对妻子的描述甚至不足以描述她的为人。每页纸上都可以写满她的故事，但远远不够。帕梅拉，谢谢你，谢谢你激励我去做很多事情，也谢谢你在我尝试做这些事情时对我的包容。

The things I say about my wife do not even scratch the surface of who she is. Every page could be filled with her, and it would not be remotely enough. Pamela, thank you for being who you are, for inspiring me to do so many things, and for putting up with me as I try to do them.

最后，我要感谢读者。事实证明写作很有趣，所以谢谢你让我这样做！如果你能享受结果，并且在此过程中学到一点计算机科学知识，那就更好了。

Finally, my thanks to you, the reader. It turns out that writing is fun, so thank you for letting me do it! And if you’ve managed to enjoy the result, and perhaps learned a little bit of computer science along the way, so much the better.

马特·金斯伯格

Matt Ginsberg

2017 年 7 月

July, 2017

关于作者

About the Author

马特·金斯伯格 24 岁时在牛津大学获得天体物理学博士学位。但他很快醒悟过来，转而研究人工智能，并在斯坦福大学任教十年。他登上过《纽约时报》头版，令人惊讶的是，他对此很满意。他曾是政治专栏作家、出版过剧作家，还为《纽约时报》设计填字游戏。他撰写了大约一百篇技术论文。还有一本小说。

Matt Ginsberg got a doctorate in astrophysics from Oxford when he was 24. He quickly came to his senses, however, switching to artificial intelligence and teaching at Stanford for a decade. He’s been on the front page of the New York Times and, surprisingly, was happy about it. He’s been a political columnist and published playwright, and constructs crosswords for the Times. He has written about a hundred technical papers. And one novel.

MattGinsberg.com

MattGinsberg.com

您喜欢Factor Man吗？请在Goodreads或您最喜欢的社交媒体上分享您的想法。

Did you enjoy Factor Man? Please share your thoughts at Goodreads or your favorite social media.
